HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
BAM Spruces Up To Keep Pace With Its Vision

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland 

 BODY:
Institutions keep their identities by always changing. This axiom applies even to places like the Brooklyn Academy of Music, though BAM is one of the few performing-arts organizations around with an identifiable personality worth holding on to. Self-renewal is in the air.
Two hours with Harvey Lichtenstein recently conveyed the restlessness. Mr. Lichtenstein has run BAM for 29 years and -- slowly, painfully -- turned it into a meeting place for the hip and the intellectually curious. He has done so despite BAM's surroundings, a chunk of Fort Greene long on urban degradation and short on Arcadian charm. 
 For a midtown or downtown dweller, BAM is no farther, by subway at least, than Lincoln Center. The ride is simple and direct, but the mind throws up barriers: the bridge or tunnel to get past; the Atlantic Avenue subway station, a vast, hopeless monument to dirt and neglect.
One enticement added in 1987 has been the Majestic Theater, an amphitheaterlike space around the corner, cleverly redone in shabby-chic. If its Spartan seats have provided a test of artistic stimulation over physical discomfort, Mr. Lichtenstein says that relief for the masochistically challenged is on the way: softer benches with more accommodatingly angled backs by the end of the year.
BAM's main building -- with its opera house, Carey Playhouse and smaller Lepercq Space upstairs -- has never been physically enticing. There is a post-office monumentality to its long and gloomy lobby. The grayness of the opera-house interior does nothing to warm the enthusiasm. The Carey features a wall so vulnerable to outside noise that even a passing car or two disrupt the concentration.
Major changes are about to happen, some beginning this summer. Mr. Lichtenstein promises a refurbished lobby; the conversion of the Carey Playhouse into a cineplex, with up to three movie houses (whether for specific series like the Walter Reade Theater's or for high-toned commercial runs like the Angelika Film Center's has not been determined), and the transformation of the Lepercq into a very different kind of space. The opera house will be relighted and given new seats and carpets. Its depressing aspect is not organic, Mr. Lichtenstein said, and is easily reversible with the use of a few flattering lights.
"So many New York halls lack a place where audiences can meet before and after performances," he added. "There's nothing to bring them together. People need somewhere they can sit and talk about what they are going to hear or what they have just been to."
BAM's answer is an upstairs cafe supplanting the Lepercq Space and reachable by escalator, not the current elevators. If BAM is indeed an island, the thinking seems to go, let it be an enticing one, a location where theatergoers will come early and stay late, arguing over Lana Turner, period fiddle-playing and Giorgio Strehler.
BAM, like Carnegie Hall, is owned by the City of New York. Asked who will pay for all this redevelopment, Mr. Lichtenstein says most of the money -- about $7 million -- is in place, with the bulk coming from the city. Elsewhere, BAM's development department is operating valiantly in the face of fierce competition for shrinking arts dollars. There is even optimism about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose administration is busy practicing drastic economies. Mr. Giuliani is an opera fan and perhaps more than a casual one. The mayor went to the Majestic for Monteverdi's "Incoronazione di Poppea" last month, braved the hard seats and long evening, and stayed to the end.
BAM is now New York's established importer of early opera. William Christie and Les Arts Florissants are regular visitors and have just come and gone with Handel's "Orlando." The "Poppea" was Jonathan Miller's production for the Glimmerglass Opera in upstate New York, and Handel's "Tamerlano," also from Glimmerglass, may not be far behind; the operatic Rameau could make a rare appearance from Europe. But staged opera is expensive. Top tickets for "Orlando" reached a hair-raising (for BAM, at least) $120, with a low end of $22.50.
The Brooklyn Philharmonic continues its efforts toward respectability with a promising new music director in Robert Spano and a series of theme weekends designed by Joseph Horowitz. "Orientalism," last weekend, was the latest topic; the concerts introduced Mr. Spano to New York. The Philip Glass-Robert Wilson "Einstein on the Beach" was a major event in New York when it came to BAM in 1984 and again in 1992. Mr. Lichtenstein reports that the two men are working on a sequel. Also being pursued is Mr. Miller's minimal staging of Bach's "St. Matthew Passion," which appeared in Britain several years ago.
One solution to living in a bad neighborhood is to stay there until it gets better. Known for his optimism and salesmanship, Mr. Lichtenstein says betterment is about to happen. Major retail outlets and some new housing under construction a few blocks away creak gradually toward realization. Given a pleasant path between them, Fort Greene is not that far from Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights, both with their leafy and attractive residential streets. There is even hope for the dungeons of the Atlantic Avenue subway station once present construction is over. BAM sits tight, tends to its own and hopes for the best.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rosemary Joshua in "Orlando"--Early opera has become a prime BAM specialty. (Dan Rest/BAM)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK RADIO;
New York Radio Is Alive and Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Neil Strauss displays a complete lack of understanding of the commercial radio medium, how it works and who it serves. For starters, the headline with his article is ludicrous: New York radio has never been healthier. Radio stations in this market attained record revenues in 1995, something Mr. Strauss apparently feels is a sign of weakness. Advertisers are both willing and eager to be on New York radio because of its targeting ability, as well as its ability to travel with its audience (in the car, at work, etc.) and the intense loyalty of its listeners. 
 But economics is only one measure of New York radio's vitality. In any given week, 96 percent of all persons 12 years of age and older listen to the radio in New York. And that high percentage holds true, no matter what demographic segment of the population you were to examine. So, although New York radio may not be delivering what Mr. Strauss would like to hear, he is clearly in the minority.
Mr. Strauss complains of "narrow-niche formats," market research and consultants. He misses the point. The very success of New York radio is its ability to serve specific, targeted audiences. That's why radio listeners are so loyal. That's why listening levels are so high. That's why the average New York area listener spends 25 hours a week with his or her radio.
 
SANFORD JOSEPHSON
New York
 
The writer is executive director of the New York Market Radio Broadcasters Association.

HEADLINE: Variable Rate

 BODY:
To the Editor: I read with interest a letter to the editor Jan. 14 from Victor Lopez of Hyatt Hotels. He said: "Hyatt Hotels Corporation policy is always to quote the same rates in inquiries made to either the hotel or our central reservation office. Room rates are set at the local hotel and then entered into hotel and central reservation computers simultaneously." This strikes me as ludicrous.
On the Sunday of the recent Blizzard of 1996, I was stranded after the New York airports closed and had to find lodging for the night. I was able to get from La Guardia to Manhattan and wound up at Grand Central Terminal, with no luck getting to my home 25 miles north of the city. 
 With the Grand Hyatt right there at the station, I went to the front desk to ask about a room. (I am a member of Hyatt's Gold Passport frequent stay program.) I was told that the rate for the night would be $230. I thought this to be a lot and decided to call the Hyatt 800 central reservation number. Much to my amazement, the rate quoted there was only $159 per night. I made a reservation.
 
KEITH BRONITT
Scarsdale, N.Y.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: In the Region: New Jersey;
Supermarket Expansions Attracting Bank Services

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
SOMETHING different is being marketed these days at the ShopRite supermarket that opened last year on a stretch of the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City. Along with fresh produce and meats, consumers can shop for mortgage loans and savings accounts.
Since June, Statewide Savings Bank, based in Jersey City, has operated a bank branch in the supermarket, one of a spate of such branches to open in New Jersey over the last year or so. Most are in the larger markets like the 67,000-square-foot ShopRite on Luis Munoz Marin Boulevard in Jersey City. 
 Statewide's branch, like other in-store banks, provides full service and occupies an average of 400 square feet. The branches reflect the convergence of two trends in the state: the push by banks to find new and less expensive outlets and by supermarkets to open superstores, considered the fastest growing segment of the industry (and defined by the Food Marketing Institute in Washington as having a median size of 53,533 square feet and offering a variety of nonfood merchandise and services).
Both trends, industry analysts said, are being fueled by each industry's drive to meet consumers' demands for easier and more convenient one-stop shopping and to remain competitive. The activity is good news for the marketplace. With a flattening retail climate and the filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection of national chains like Caldor and Bradlees, supermarkets are among the few users still hungry for space. As a result, rents are inching upward.
Also, because supermarkets are returning to older and more densely populated counties in the northern half of the state, where large sites are scarce, former industrial properties are being used for retail sites. A Manhattan-based developer, Clifpass, for instance, is seeking approval to build a 195,000-square-foot shopping center with a 57,000-square-foot Pathmark on a 15-acre site straddling the border between Clifton and Passaic, where a former wool-manufacturing complex stands.
The supermarket industry recognizes "that bigger is better and that there is a necessity to grow or die," said Charles Bernhaut, a consultant with the Slayton Development Group in Garden City, L.I., which specializes in supermarket development. Fueling that need to grow, he said, is competition -- not only among home-grown chains but also among newcomers such as Stop & Shop of Quincy, Mass., and Edwards Super Food Store of Windsor Locks, Conn. Others angling for a foothold in the state's more than $200-million-a-week food business are warehouse clubs like Sam's Club and BJ's Wholesale Club.
Ted Kraus, who heads a retail consulting firm in Mercerville, predicted that the result would not be "many more supermarkets, just bigger ones." And because the state's economy is not growing, the stores may wind up just "robbing customers," from one another, said Mr. Kraus.
Nonetheless, most of the supermarket chains from ShopRite and Pathmark to A. & P. are either rushing to open superstores or replace or expand existing supermarkets with superstores. A. & P. recently opened a store of more than 60,000 square foot on the Boulevard in Kenilworth and the Acme that was expanded to 64,000 square feet opened in December in the 180,000-square-foot Fair Ground Plaza retail strip on High Street in Mount Holly. Also, ShopRite has opened 12 larger stores and Pathmark 8 in the last three years.
Some of the new or revived stores have bank branches and many more of the new stores planned are expected to include banking facilities. Putting bank branches in these bigger stores is "another facet in the strategy of attracting new shoppers," said Matthew Casey, president of Casey & Associates, a Howell-based research company specializing in supermarkets.
Stanley Sorkin, vice president of public affairs at Pathmark Stores in Woodbridge, agreed. "It is the latest trend," he said, "to try and capitalize on the idea of one-stop shopping." So far, he said, three of Pathmark's 65 stores in New Jersey have full-service bank branches.
Laura McCafferty, a spokeswoman for the Elizabeth-based Wakefern Food Corporation, the cooperative that runs the ShopRite chain said that "in-store bank branches" benefit everyone. She said that of the chain's 114 stores in New Jersey, 8 already had banks.
The concept of in-store bank branches is not new but has gained appeal over the last five years as a way for banks to broaden their customer base and deliver their services more efficiently and less expensively. Nationally, bank branches in supermarkets have increased from 697 in 1989 to 3,142 in 1995, said International Banking Technologies, an Atlanta-based consulting firm that helps banks set up store branches.
Developing a branch in a store costs about $200,000, compared to the cost of building a 4,000-square-foot free-standing bank branch for as much as $2 million, said John W. Garnett, president of International Banking Technologies. But the concept has been slow to catch on in the Northeast, and especially in New Jersey. Now the growth of supermarkets has piqued the interest of banks. Stores must be at least 35,000 square feet to contain a bank branch.
The Bank of Mid-Jersey in Bordentown opened two supermarket branches last year and will open three more in 1996, said Joseph M. Reardon, executive vice president of the bank, which has 18 branches. Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, with a total of 457 branches, has 8 supermarket branches in New Jersey, 55 in Pennsylvania and 5 in Delaware.
MERGERS and acquisitions in the banking industry, which have intensified competition, are also stoking the banks' interest. Since 1990, 70 state-chartered commercial and savings banks and savings and loans were acquired or closed, said the New Jersey Department of Banking and Commerce. In addition, large out-of-state banks are moving into New Jersey, such as First Union of North Carolina, which recently acquired First Fidelity Bank Corporation in Newark; and PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, which purchased Midlantic Bank in Edison. The industry also faces competition from pension funds and on-line banking services.
Supermarkets also offer banks a potential customer base of 20,000 to 30,000 people who shop an average of twice a week and the opportunity to offer banking services mornings and evenings, seven days a week, said Mr. Garnett. "The approach behind in-store branches borrows a page from retailers and gets bankers to go out in the aisles to sell their services," he said.
For example, every day of the week, Statewide Bank employees, dressed in aprons, can be found walking the aisles in the ShopRite in Jersey City, which draws 25,000 shoppers a week. "It raises awareness that the bank is there," said Clifford J. Adams, president of the $575 million institution. Statewide has 15 branches in Passaic, Hudson, Bergen and Union Counties, including a second in-store branch, which opened in December in a ShopRite in Passaic.
Mr. Adams of Statewide said the company decided to enter supermarket banking last year because "you have to be where the customers are and everyone has to go food shopping." The in-store branches give a "competitive edge to the bank," he said, adding that banking "is a consumer-driven business and if this is what people want there will be more in-store branches."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clifford Adams, head of Statewide Savings Bank, and Marina Apolito, branch manager, at Jersey City ShopRite. Gehan Gobrial, in apron, seeks out new customers. (Photographs by Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lawyers Who Mold The Shape of a City

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
IN the city at large, the overheated real estate climate of the 1980's was conjured in a single name: "Donald." But in the corridors and chambers of City Hall where development deals were crafted, another name resonated forcefully: "Sandy."
"Sandy" meant Samuel H. Lindenbaum, a seignorial counsel at the firm of Rosenman & Colin and dean of the land-use bar, a group of several dozen real estate lawyers whose mission was to add value to their clients' property, finding the path to the biggest buildings and most profitable tenancies through their command of zoning, environmental and landmarks rules. 
 Their search for development potential even took them under water. For Trump City, a 1988 version of the Riverside South proposal on the West Side, Rosenman & Colin proposed to exploit some 4.5 million square feet of development rights attributable to that part of the property between the shore and the pierhead line.
Because many land-use lawyers had worked in government, they knew where political power was situated and had a bantering familiarity with city officials. As such, they were often able to fashion the 11th-hour compromises that were required when opposition arose.
Since they appeared at hearings and in the press on behalf of clients who often shunned the limelight, members of the land-use bar became the public embodiment of powerful development interests and multimillion-dollar construction projects.
As they guided projects past community boards, the City Planning Commission, the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the Board of Standards and Appeals and the Board of Estimate, land-use lawyers influenced the physical environment of New York City in the 80's as much as any developer or architect.
And, like developers and architects, they were hit so hard when the market crashed that they are only now recovering.
"To the extent there was a land-use bar, it was shattered by the recession," said Gordon J. Davis of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae. "Not in the sense that there aren't still practitioners, but it shattered a lot of firms, caused practices to be damaged and caused practitioners to move to other firms."
A formidable team headed by John E. Zuccotti at Brown & Wood scattered widely, in part because the decline in business underscored the isolation of the small land-use group from the rest of the firm. The land-use and environmental firm of Berle, Kass & Case was closed altogether, with the recession taking some of the blame. The firm of Sive, Paget & Riesel shrank by about 25 percent, although it has now rebounded. As for other lawyers, most are no longer at the firms where they were working 10 years ago -- if those firms even exist.
"There's obviously less business opportunity than there was in the mid-80's," said Mr. Zuccotti, who has been president and chief executive of Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.) since 1989. "But there is also much more competition because there are many more skilled practitioners than there were in 1970, when it was basically Sandy and myself."
ROSENMAN'S 10-lawyer land-use group survived, but not without difficulty. "There were times when I myself thought about the possibility of cutting it down," Mr. Lindenbaum said, "because it was hard to justify 100 percent of the people with 60 percent or two-thirds of the work."
Most members of the land-use bar are in their mid-40's to mid-50's, reflecting the fact that they came of professional age as the development boom got under way. There are few practitioners in their 20's and 30's.
"Business dried up and people stopped coming up," said Howard J. Goldman, a 44-year-old partner at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. "There's no young land-use bar, which is good, because when business picks up again, that will mean we'll get all the work.'
And, by almost all accounts, business is finally picking up.
"It's not constant," Mr. Lindenbaum said. "It's selective. But there is more activity, more interest. We are seeing it somewhat in institutional projects and very much in residential projects." On the institutional front, Rosenman represented the Museum of Modern Art in its recent acquisition of the adjacent Dorset Hotel. On the residential front, it represents Millennium Partners, developers of three apartment towers around Lincoln Square. The "innovative mixed-use formula" devised by Millennium may also prove to be the key to successful redevelopment of the Alexander's site at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street, said Michael T. Sillerman, a partner at Rosenman.
Such prospects recall the high-stakes undertakings of the 80's. But to survive, the land-use bar has had to expand its horizons beyond office towers, mega-projects and the five boroughs.
Robert S. Davis and Judith M. Gallent, formerly of Berle, Kass and now at Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman, are representing the Town of Mamaroneck, N.Y., in a pending constitutional challenge to the rezoning of two golf courses, which precluded residential redevelopment of that acreage. They also represent the Sterling Forest Corporation, which has proposed a new community of 13,000 homes, with 8 million square feet of commercial and industrial space, on a wilderness tract 40 miles north of New York City.
Paul D. Selver, a Brown & Wood alumnus who is now at Battle Fowler, has found himself in New Orleans, advising clients in a dispute with an adajcent property owner over a new street that had been mandated as part of a special zoning district. "It seemed natural to look beyond New York," Mr. Selver said. "The New York City Zoning Resolution is so complex and the problems here are on so many different levels that when we focus on a problem somewhere else, if we have local counsel, we can really be helpful."
Few land-use lawyers have wandered farther afield than Shelly S. Friedman, who founded the specialized "boutique" practice of Friedman & Gotbaum in 1994, with Irving J. Gotbaum. Both men had been partners at Brown & Wood.
Mr. Friedman represented the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China in its recent deal to move its United Nations mission from 155 West 66th Street to 35th Street and First Avenue, which freed an adjacent parcel for development by Millennium Partners. The negotiations included what Mr. Friedman believes to be the first zoning lot merger written in Chinese.
Typically, however, the firm operates on a smaller and more local scale. "Our position as a boutique has enabled us to work with groups like restaurateurs and retailers that never felt comfortable coming to larger firms," Mr. Friedman said. These include the Bowery Bar, at East Fourth Street, and several stores in the Upper East Side Historic District and Special Madison Avenue Preservation District, including the new four-story Giorgio Armani building, 760 Madison Avenue, at 65th Street.
On the other end of the retail spectrum are the "big-box" stores of 100,000 square feet or more, like Price/Costco, Home Depot, Kmart, Caldor's, Pathmark and Finast. Since these projects require discretionary approvals and special permits, they have proved to be a staple for a number of land-use lawyers, including Jesse Masyr of Gold & Wachtel.
ONE of the largest projects on Mr. Masyr's plate is a 1-million-square-foot retail development on 122 acres in the Charleston section of Staten Island, for the Breslin Realty Development Corporation and Blumenfeld Development Group. Mr. Masyr, who was Deputy Borough President of Manhattan under Andrew J. Stein, estimated that his business had increased 400 percent since the darkest days of 1990 and 1991.
Sybil H. Pollet of Pollet & Pollet said her business did not suffer, because she represented lenders that had an interest in troubled or difficult developments, like the Chase Manhattan Bank at Riverside South and the European American Bank at Cityspire, 150 West 56th Street.
"My practice frankly boomed in the recession," she said. "The banks during those years were the owners of some of the major projects in the city."
And there was ample work for the little firms and sole practitioners who handled matters as small as one-family dwellings in need of a variance, said Adam W. Rothkrug of Rothkrug & Rothkrug. (His father, Leonard F. Rothkrug, was renowned in the land-use bar for his license plates: "ZONING.")
The 1980's left in their wake any number of proposals that were either fully approved by city agencies or well on their way through the review procedure before being stymied by the recession. Some of these are now being dusted off.
Borrowing the language of Broadway, Robert Davis has dubbed these "revivals," adding that he was "seeing serious expressions of interest."
Raymond H. Levin, a Brown & Wood alumnus now at Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding, also sees potential "revivals," including an office tower on the former site of the Museum of American Folk Art on West 53d Street; apartment towers on the block bounded by First and York Avenues, 60th and 61st Street and Brighton-by-the-Sea, a large residential project on the site of the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.
Other potential "revivals" include the completion of the 1,000-unit Shorehaven project on the East River in the Bronx and the construction of Rockefeller Plaza West, a 55-story tower proposed on Seventh Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, said Stephen Lefkowitz, a Berle, Kass alumnus who is now at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts.
There is another kind of revival -- that of older buildings.
"We may well be in an era where we see as much focus on the reuse of existing buildings as on new development," Mr. Sillerman said. A Rosenman associate, Kenneth K. Lowenstein, helped draft the tax incentives enacted last year by the State Legislature to stimulate residential conversion and commercial renovation in downtown Manhattan.
The planned coversion of the landmark Bowling Green Offices, a 98-year-old building at 11 Broadway, is providing work for Robert A. Kandel of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. Mr. Masyr is representing the Rockrose Development Corporation in the proposed conversion of 127 John Street, a 25-year-old office tower. Mark A. Levine, of Sive, Paget & Riesel, is representing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the $300 million renovation of 11 Madison Avenue, its 64-year-old North Tower, at 24th Street.
Institutional work has been one of the mainstays for Mr. Davis, who was Parks Commissioner from 1978 to 1983. Among his clients are the American Museum of Natural History, which plans to replace the Hayden Planetarium with a new planetarium; Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, which is considering the construction of a new theater on the 66th Street site of the Chinese Mission, and the New York Public Library, which is looking for tenants to occupy expansion space in the new Science, Industry and Business Library at Madison Avenue and 34th Street.
Although he also has clients like Viacom, which he advised on the sale of Madison Square Garden, Mr. Davis said, "I never had a practice that was primarily representing private developers, so when the recession hit and all building stopped, my life didn't come to an end."
But he can pinpoint the moment that the building boom came to an end -- a snowy day in January 1991, as the United States was preparing to go to war against Iraq. A hotel development group he represented had balked at paying a deposit, subject to forfeiture, for a site at Battery Park City.
"I sat there watching my clients not willing to put $25,000 at risk on a $400 million project," Mr. Davis recalled, "and I thought, 'The world is about to change.' And then, at lunch, when they stuck me with the bill, I knew the world had changed."
Indeed, it had.
"It didn't just slow down -- it shut down," Mr. Lindenbaum said. He was obliged to use his persuasive powers on the Rosenman partners, as he tried to keep the land-use group intact. "I'd assembled an extraordinary team," Mr. Lindenbaum said. "I foresaw that there would be five difficult years and some degree of over-capacity, but when turnaround time came, we'd be in the best position to get into action quickly."
MR. LINDENBAUM, who is 60, was virtually born to the practice of land-use law. His father, Abraham (Bunny) Lindenbaum, was a lawyer whose first retainer came in April 1949 from a Brooklyn builder named Fred C. Trump, who had a two-year-old son, Donald.
The younger Mr. Lindenbaum joined his father's Brooklyn firm, Lindenbaum & Young, in 1962. A new Zoning Resolution was in effect, which had leveled the land-use playing field, since older practitioners had to learn new rules and forget a lot of what they knew.
One of Mr. Lindenbaum's first coups in the 1960's was to persuade the Buildings Commissioner to allow the Tisch family to provide transient parking in garages at their hotels. While the Zoning Resolution said such parking was intended "primarily" for hotel guests and employees, it did not say "exclusively." Therefore, Mr. Lindenbaum argued, it could not be construed as ruling out the use of parking spaces by the general public. In 1974, with his practice growing, Mr. Lindenbaum moved to the Manhattan firm of Rosenman Colin Kaye Petschek Freund & Emil. Howard Alan Zipser came with him from Lindenbaum & Young, forming the nucleus of the Rosenman land-use group.
The rival land-use practice of Tufo & Zuccotti was founded in 1970 as Tufo, Johnston & Zuccotti, by Peter Tufo, Joseph Johnston and Mr. Zuccotti, all of whom had been at Davis, Polk & Wardwell. Mr. Zuccotti stepped away for five years in the mid-70's to serve as a member of the City Planning Commission, then chairman of the commission, then First Deputy Mayor, under Mayor Abraham D. Beame.
(Not surprisingly, the Planning Commission has bred a number of members of the land-use bar, including Donald H. Elliott and Victor Marrero, former chairmen; Martin Gallent, former vice chairman; Gordon Davis and Howard B. Hornstein, former members; Norman Marcus, former counsel to the commission; Robert Davis, former counsel to the chairman and Carol E. Rosenthal, former associate counsel.)
In 1986, Tufo & Zuccotti merged with Brown, Wood, Ivey, Mitchell & Petty and the new practice was named Brown & Wood. "There was a feeling that there was going to be a cross-fertilization," Mr. Levin said. "It never happened. The zoning area had always been on its own. During the late 80's, when business was going like gangbusters, that was overlooked and we operated as a firm within a firm."
Most members of the land-use group left in 1994, a year that also saw the closing of Berle, Kass & Case.
TWENTY-THREE years earlier, over a couple of beers, Albert K. Butzel, Peter A. A. Berle and Stephen L. Kass discussed the dream they once had of forming a small practice devoted substantially to public interest. When one of them asked, "Can anyone think of a reason we shouldn't do that?" nobody answered. The firm of Berle & Butzel was founded in 1971.
The firm sometimes found itself in the position of representing the government -- on the 42d Street redevelopment project -- at the same time it was fighting the government -- on the Westway project.
For all that variety, Robert Davis said, "We were somewhat hampered by not having an active transactional practice, which is required to complement environmental and land-use practice."
Mr. Kass attributed the closing to the fact that lawyers at Berle, Kass "had had their turn doing the mix we had set out to achieve," and were ready to move on to different clients, larger firms or more lucrative practices.
Now at Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, Mr. Kass was among the land-use and environmental lawyers who gathered Feb. 13 at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West 44th Street, for the group portrait that appears on page 1. "It was a reunion of a club that had never met before," he said. (Those not otherwise mentioned in this article were Elise Wagner of Battle Fowler, Robert S. Cook Jr. of De Forest & Duer and Jeffrey L. Braun, Richard G. Leland and Gary R. Tarnoff of Rosenman & Colin.)
After the portrait was taken, Mr. Hornstein, a partner in Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding, noted that the good old days had their own perils.
He spent the latter part of the 80's working for Ian Bruce Eichner, whose Cityspire project entered civic lore. Because it was built 11 feet taller than permitted, Cityspire's dome had to be partly dismantled while a settlement was reached with the city. Then, the dome emitted a high-pitched sound in the wind that disturbed neighbors for many blocks around.
"I don't have any more whistling buildings and domes that have to be chopped off," Mr. Hornstein reflected. "It's a calmer life."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Hybrid Pension Plan Gains Ground

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
IT has taken a decade, but the Internal Revenue Service has finally proposed rules on the tax status of a new type of pension plan. Benefit consultants say the proposal is favorable enough to employers that the plans, now offered by about 200 large companies, may become much more popular.
In the few weeks since the I.R.S. proposal was made, dozens of companies have taken steps to adopt these plans. About 6 percent of all workers with a pension are covered by the new plans, and some experts say that will jump to 20 percent by the end of the decade. The most widely used pensions will remain 401(k) plans, which have increased in popularity in the last 20 years. 
 The new plans, often called cash balance pensions, are a hybrid of two older types of plans. Employers like the new plans because they can be inexpensive to finance, but employees may find some disadvantages. The key benefit of the new plans is that they permit employees to take their pensions with them when they change jobs, allowing the money to keep growing in value. But the rate of return is often tied to bonds, and some employees would earn more in another type of pension. Older employees, especially, are cautioned to avoid the new plans.
The cash balance pensions are a long way from the traditional pension plans that generations of Americans have taken into retirement. Under those defined-benefit plans, the pension of a worker who moves to a new job stays put, never growing another penny and steadily losing ground to inflation.
With those plans, employers take on all the investment risk and guarantee an annual benefit upon an employee's retirement; they pay their most generous benefits to workers who spend a lifetime with one company. But that type of employee has become rarer after a decade of layoffs and corporate revamping. It is now estimated that workers will change jobs a half-dozen times in their careers.
Defined-contribution pensions, such as 401(k) plans, were made to solve the problem created by a mobile work force. Under the plans, employers contribute money, usually based on a percentage of pay, to each worker's pension account. In most of these plans, workers invest the money, choosing from several options provided by their employers.
Most importantly, employees typically are allowed to take that money with them when they move to another company. Workers who roll over their pension money can then either put it into an individual retirement account or into their new employers' pension plans.
But the defined-contribution plans create another problem: There is no guaranteed return. Employees, not the employer, take on all the investment risk. While workers who are savvy -- or lucky -- can build fortunes, others invest so cautiously that their pensions will not grow enough to sustain them in old age and a few will even squander the money before retirement.
"Everybody wants to jump on the defined-contribution bandwagon," says Raymond Sharp, an actuary at Buck Consultants. "I think they are very dangerous things. Just wait until we see a bear market," when many people will bail out, locking in their losses.
BENEFIT consultants say that by the end of the decade, 90 percent of all workers with a pension will be in defined-contribution plans, with 30 percent in traditional plans. Many workers will be covered by more than one plan.
The new cash balance pensions take the portability of defined-contribution plans and combine it with the security of defined-benefit plans. Employers guarantee to pay an interest rate, often tied to 30-year Treasury bonds, thus taking the investment risk. And they allow employees to take the money with them if they change jobs. Employees may also leave the money with their former employers, where it continues to earn interest.
Workers who switch jobs four times in a 40-year career can collect 50 percent more money from the cash balance plans than they would after making four moves involving traditional plans, according to Kwasha Lipton, a benefits consultancy in Fort Lee, N.J., which created the first modern cash balance plan in 1984.
Until last month, the I.R.S. had not established guidelines on the new pensions, and benefits consultants say the uncertainty had kept many companies from adopting the plans. But in its recent proposal, the I.R.S. suggested setting requirements on the interest rates that the plans must pay and ordering that interest payments continue if employees who move on to new jobs decide to leave money with the old employers.
And for employers meeting these requirements, the I.R.S. made a key ruling: All the contributions they make into the pensions are tax deductible. The money and the earnings are tax free to employees until the money is withdrawn, usually after retirement. The I.R.S. is expected to give final approval to the rules within the next few months.
 Michael Miller, the former director of worldwide benefits with Borden, helped the company set up such a plan in 1985. Last year, after 16 years with the company, he was forced out during a corporate cutback and experienced the value of the plan firsthand.
When he left the company, Mr. Miller opened an I.R.A. with $10,000 rolled over from his pension, and invested in stocks. Under the rules of his plan, he had to leave the rest of his pension with Borden, where it is earning about 5.6 percent a year. When Mr. Miller, who is 50, turns 55, he can take the balance of his pension and put it into his I.R.A.
"Under the old plan I would have gotten a letter saying, 'Come see us at age 65,' " Mr. Miller said. "I would have had 15 years of deterioration with a frozen benefit, but instead my money will keep growing."
Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, Owens-Corning Fiberglas, the Tennessee Valley Authority and Woolworth have all adopted the new plan within the last few months.
Employers say that the new plans, in addition to being less expensive, can eventually pay for themselves. If a company invests the money and makes, say, 25 percent a year when the stock market is rising, the money left over after making contributions to employees can be used to pay for the contributions in subsequent years.
The new plans can also be financed out of any surplus in traditional pension plans.
Benefits consultants said the plans also eliminate what companies see as a perverse incentive for some employees to stay with a company when changing employers might be smart for both the worker and the company. Under the new plans, workers can typically collect their pension whenever they retire, without having to wait until they are 65.
Bell Atlantic adopted its cash balance plan for nonunion workers last month, after concluding that its traditional defined-benefit plan was not a good value for the company or its workers.
"We did a lot of research," said Gary M. Simko, Bell Atlantic's director of benefits planning, "and we found that the defined-benefit plan was a nonissue in the recruitment process. It was very rare for potential employees to even ask about it."
But the new plan, he said, could be useful in recruitment "because employees could calculate and project its worth to them."
Not everyone is as enamored with the new plans. Karen Ferguson, executive director of the Pension Rights Center, an advocacy organization in Washington, said she believed that workers needed more time to understand who benefits and who loses.
"Originally I was told they were the best of all possible worlds," Ms. Ferguson said. "They do great things for shorter-service workers."
But, she said, "now I am beginning to wonder what the hidden pitfalls are."
ONE is the investment return. Because it is typically based on an I.R.S. interest rate schedule and many companies choose a rate tied to 30-year Treasury bonds, employees do not benefit from a stock market that has historically returned more than bonds. Employees in defined-contribution plans who invested in the stock market would likely have larger retirement benefits than employees in cash balance plans. The trade-off, of course, is that cash balance returns are guaranteed by the employers, while the defined-contribution returns are not.
Another pitfall, for some employees, is that the new plans, like 401(k)'s, tend to favor younger workers.
The eventual retirement benefit that employees receive under the new plans is based on their companies' contributions and the interest rate the companies promised to pay on that money. So the contributions that will earn the most interest are those made early in an employee's career.
Older employees do better under traditional plans. Companies usually pay a percentage of a worker's annual pay during the last three or five years on the job. A worker who spends 40 years with one company often earns half of his pension benefit in the last five years on the job, said John Ehrhardt, an actuary with Milliman & Robertson benefits consultants.
Some companies are setting up transition plans, promising to pay long-term employees at least as much as they would have received under a traditional plan. Such transition rules typically are in effect for 5 or 10 years to protect workers near retirement.
But not all companies offer such transition plans, which can cause resentment among older workers. Ms. Ferguson said the lack of transition rules might also spark lawsuits by veteran employees who believe they are being shortchanged.
"Most companies we see trying to put in cash balance plans are trying to save money," said Ethan E. Kra, chief retirement actuary at William M. Mercer, the nation's largest benefits consulting company, "which means some people will get less, and that will tend to be older workers."
While only about 200 companies have such plans now, all of them are large employers, some with tens of thousands of workers.
Mr. Kra said that "cash balance plans would have been killed if the I.R.S. had gotten its act together right away when they first appeared. But now so many companies have them that the I.R.S. is going to accommodate them."

One has only traditional pension plans, the second only cash balance pension plans, and the third only defined-contribution plans. (Source: Kwasha Lipton)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 10; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1278 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Coping With the Big Headaches 'Big Boxes' Bring

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
DIFFERENT as they are from each other, urban Stamford and semirural Wallingford face the same issue -- what to do about an influx of "big-box" stores that they perceive as threatening their prized community characteristics.
"Unlike some municipalities that try to prohibit 'big boxes,' we welcome them," said John Condlin, chairman of Stamford's Downtown Special Services District, a business improvement organization, referring to the trend toward superstores. "We just don't want the city to allow them into noncommercially zoned areas, drawing away from our downtown retailers and converting much-needed industrial space on the outskirts to commercial." 
 In defining big boxes, Neil Sherman, director of the Stamford Chamber of Commerce, drew distinctions. "Really big boxes like Home Depot, that require loading docks, warehousing and outdoor space, belong near the turnpike," he said. "But 'category killers' like Toys 'R' Us, Staples, Barnes & Noble, should be downtown, maintaining our strong retail core."
It has taken many years for Stamford's local retailers to overcome the powerful competition they faced with the opening of Town Center Mall in 1982, and to reach the current state of peaceful coexistence. But in the small Town of Wallingford, the arms aren't quite so open. David Smith of People for a Better Wallingford, fears that "the proliferation of big-box retailers here is hurting the town."
"They are pulling enormous amounts of traffic through our historic National Register neighborhoods, devaluing the community," he said. He noted that a crossing guard was hit by a car last year at Christian and North Main Street, an intersection near an elementary school and bordering the campus of Choate Rosemary Hall, one of the nation's most prestigious prep schools.
Some 900 students on their way to classes and dormitories criss-cross Elm, North Main, Christian and other streets that have become alternate routes for motorists headed toward the big new stores on Route 5. "We are actually teaching some remedial street-crossing skills to survive the increased traffic," said Charlotte Murphy, a spokeswoman for Choate.
Wallingford is a prime target for regional retailers. Just 12 miles from New Haven and 23 miles from Hartford, with direct access to Interstate 91, Routes 68, 150, 70 and 71 and the Wilbur Cross Parkway, its commercially zoned Route 5 runs through the center of town.
Not everyone supports the campaign to limit growth on Route 5. Fred A. Valenti, who owns Valenti Auto Sales, said "Wallingford is growing, building a lot of new homes on the east side -- that's where the traffic is coming from. They have to come downtown to shop." Indeed, planning department figures show 583 single-family homes and 541 multifamily units have been built since 1991.
Like some other auto dealers in town, Mr. Valenti owns land on Route 5 that is available for development. "Kmart and Wal-Mart had enough faith in Wallingford to spend $15 million apiece on new stores where they will employ 300 people each," he noted. "Free enterprise built the country. I think that's what we need."
But even real estate agents are divided on the issue. Lucille Trzcinski, a local realtor, said she regretted that "we did not have the foresight to follow a mayor's committee report five years ago that could have resulted in keeping the stores out."
"People have to look to the long term," she said. "If we let Route 5 become unmanageable, homes that are still on it, and the centuries-old houses on Christian, North and High Streets, will decline in value or become worthless."
Both Wallingford and Stamford are trying to stanch or at least direct the tide of mammoth retailing. Stamford's planning commission will hold a public hearing on March 17 to scrutinize proposed changes to its master plan, recommended in a study by Farandino Associates of Elmsford, N.Y. Under consideration will be a category for large sites near Connecticut Turnpike interchanges where big-box stores could locate, but only if 50 percent of the sites are maintained for industrial development.
Wallingford's planning commission passed an interim regulation in November stating that any development that generates 100 or more peak-hour vehicle trips a day cannot submit plans until September -- in effect, a moratorium on big-box stores.
O N March 4, a controversial application by Shaw's Supermarket that predates the moratorium will seek approval at a public hearing to build a total of 115,146 square feet of retail space on an 11.45-acre Route 5 parcel, including its 69,406-square-foot-store.
"Wallingford is approaching saturation," said William Kane, a partner at Wellspeak, Dugas & Kane, real estate consultants and appraisers in Cheshire. Mr. Kane believes that the retail property market is saturated throughout much of the state.
Last month a Super Kmart and a Wal-Mart opened on Route 5, covering a total of 300,637 square feet on 28.9 acres. An existing Kmart, Bradlees, Caldor, Super Stop & Shop, Marshall's, Staples, and other stores make up an additional 582,033 square feet on a total of 65.2 acres. "Not all will survive," Mr. Kane said. "Caldor and Bradlees are in Chapter 11, and there's just not enough population to support them." Wallingford's population is 42,860, but the stores draw from surrounding towns as well.
A two-part study of traffic and land use in Wallingford by Milone & MacBroom of Cheshire and Harrall-Michalowski Associates of Hamden will soon be released. Linda Bush, the Wallingford town planner, said, though, that some of its findings for Route 5, where an added 102 acres are ripe for development, suggest that part of the road south of North Street would have to be widened from two to six lanes, and that the current 35 percent land coverage should be reduced to 10 percent.
Stamford, on the other hand, "is not over-stored," said Mr. Kane. "The city has few large sites appropriate for big boxes, and anyone interested in building one is looking at over $1 million an acre."
"A few years ago," said Robin Stein, Stamford's planning director, "nobody wanted big-box stores downtown, but they are going into cities now with a modified, upscale approach." He received the first application relating to big-box stores three weeks ago. Heymann Properties, which owns the former Yale & Towne Lock Company complex on Canal Street between Exit 7 and 8 of Interstate 95, wants to amend the zoning regulations to redevelop the property with a big-box store. It is in a mixed-use zone and does not require a change in the master plan to become a big-box location.
The master plan changes would apply directly to two industrial-zoned sites off Exit 6 of I-95: 30 acres on Commerce Road and the 35-acre former American Cyanamid property, now called Cytec. If the changes are enacted, "there will be some unhappiness among developers who will not be able to sell or lease 100 percent of their property to big boxes," Mr. Sherman said.
The inevitable increase in traffic that more retail would bring to downtown Stamford, which is already clogged during the day and strangled at rush hours, is thought to be surmountable, Mr. Sherman said, with more on-street parking and retail incentives for a new parking garage.
"If you want successful retail you've got to have traffic -- that's the good news/bad news," said Edward Stockton, the former state Commissioner of Economic Development who now heads the Stockton Associates economic consultancy in Bloomfield. But with the state's population dwindling and worries about unemployment rising, he warns that retailers should pay close attention to supply and demand.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 10; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1431 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Brokerage Employment;
In Recruiting, Seasoning Now Comes Before Youth

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IN the early 1980's, when Sholom & Zuckerbrot was opening real estate offices all over New York, it hired scads of youngsters fresh from college. The idea was that they would cut their teeth on cold calls and other necessary but not particularly remunerative work and in the process learn to be brokers.
Wrong. "We'd devote tremendous time and expense to teaching them, yet we'd lose most of them within a year," said Sanford H. Zuckerbrot, president of the firm, which is based in Long Island City, Queens. 
 Now, Sholom & Zuckerbrot hires people who are looking to switch careers, who have extensive business experience and contacts and who have enough cash to get them through the requisite lean years. At first, the newcomers show property, handle paperwork and do other scut work for the senior brokers, in return for a small part of the deal. If they demonstrate ability, they become full-fledged brokers after two or three years.
"The young people are testing the waters, but these older people come ready to make a commitment," Mr. Zuckerbrot said.
That is no isolated view. With the recessionary doldrums fading, many real estate firms are hiring again. But few have returned to the more-the-merrier approach of the booming 1980's, when entry-level broker's jobs were easy to fill and to find. Now, many are eschewing greenhorns.
"I will hire someone who does not have real estate skills, but today there's no room for brokers who don't have analytical skills," said Bruce E. Mosler, vice chairman of The Galbreath Company.
Benjamin Fox, a partner in the New Spectrum store brokerage, which has stopped hiring youngsters, explained. "It's just too difficult to figure out on paper whether someone has what it takes to be a good broker," he said. "Every hour taken to train someone for brokerage is an hour taken away from transactions, and you can't tell in advance if that hour will ever be worth it."
Of course, that has always been true. What has changed, real estate experts say, is that deals have grown longer and more complex, and commissions must be spread among a larger number of teammates.
Both developments are turnoffs to young people, many of whom, their elders say, still seem to expect to tap into the free-flowing money of a decade ago.
When Dan Gronich began building Gronich & Company some 20 years ago, he routinely hired brokers out of college, and paid them nothing until they did a deal. "They viewed this as graduate school," Mr. Gronich recalled. "And, usually, they could make their first deal after six months."
NOW Mr. Gronich is head of Grubb & Ellis New York, and he is primarily hiring experienced entrepreneurs -- he recently hired someone who ran an automobile dealership -- who are used to fluctuating incomes.
Mr. Gronich brings a stream of experts in to teach real estate classes a few times a week.
"Today's kids have a lot of difficulty living in New York without cash," he said. "And while you still can make a lot of money in real estate, in the short run there's not a lot to show for your work if you're new."
Those companies that do still hire youngsters rarely put them on a broker's track. LaSalle Partners confines its college recruits to a three-year program, where they get a crash course in the rudiments of real estate, and then are assigned to crunching numbers and other support functions.
"We no longer think of this as leading to a career here," said Robert C. Spoerri, LaSalle's chief operating officer. The young employees, he added, "are useful while they are here, but we know they are just trying to get enough experience to get into a good business school."
Other firms are confining their gambles on tyros to suburbia. The Edward S. Gordon Company, for one, stopped hiring inexperienced people in Manhattan about five years ago, but still welcomes them in Westchester and New Jersey. In Westchester, they first spend six months in market research, on a small salary, generating data that other brokers can use.
In New Jersey, an older office whose data bases of primarily industrial space are up to date, newcomers to the firm live on a small draw against commission and are immediately assigned to mentors.
"It's easier to train young people in a smaller office, where the senior people are less concerned about taking the time, and where costs of living are lower," said Joseph R. Harbert, a senior managing director in charge of human resources.
Still, Mr. Harbert readily admits that brokers trained in the more genteel atmosphere of suburbia rarely can transfer their skills and attitudes to Manhattan. So, if training programs like LaSalle's do not yield brokers, and if suburban trainees stay put, where is the next generation of New York City brokers going to come from?
The answer seems to be, from other industries entirely.
Galbreath, for one, raids accounting firms for its newest people, and has budgeted a hefty amount this year for "Dan Galbreath University," a formal program to train its new employees -- and retrain more than a few veterans -- on sales and financial analysis techniques.
CUSHMAN & WAKEFIELD has a 12-month career-development program in which people with, say, five years of unrelated business experience -- preferably in sales -- take courses, rotate through various different disciplines, learn to canvas for clients, and work on special projects.
"People who know they want a career in real estate really benefit from this kind of highly structured training," said Kenneth Krasnow, the firm's director of business development.
"It doesn't work as well for a youngster who says, 'I want a job now and later I'll decide what to do with my life.' "
It certainly does work well for Cushman & Wakefield's existing staff: Since June, the trainees set up more than 50 meetings for seasoned brokers with potential new clients, and added data on some 125 buildings and about 1,500 tenants into the firm's data base.
AT other companies, particularly plush welcome mats are being rolled out for would-be brokers who demonstrate a knowledge of an industry from which the brokerage firm draws its most lucrative accounts.
Garrick-Aug, a retail brokerage, has been hiring people who were laid off from high-level retail jobs.
"They may never have been brokers, but they certainly understand the client's real-estate needs," said Peter Botsaris, Garrick-Aug's president.
Similarly, Colliers ABR recently hired Wendy Miller, who had been working in the development office of Georgetown University, to work on the Colliers team servicing Teachers Insurance, an important Colliers client that deals with many universities. The theory is that her experience in fund-raising gave her a thick enough hide to handle the inevitable rejections a broker faces, and her college background would help her communicate with the Teachers executives.
"We can teach real estate, but we can't teach the ability to identify with a client," said Robert L. Billingsley, Colliers ABR's executive vice president.
Of course, some firms do continue to hire novices. The Julien J. Studley brokerage just resumed recruiting on college campuses. It will put newcomers on a salary -- no more than $40,000, often less -- for a year while they learn the ropes from a senior broker.
"Young people bring an energy and enthusiasm that is always of benefit," said Julien J. Studley, the firm's head.
Williams Real Estate is looking to experienced people to manage its growing staff -- "Managerial skills is my hot button this year," Michael T. Cohen, Williams' president, said -- but it still generally keeps 15 or 20 inexperienced people on the broker track.
"I ask college people for anecdotes that show they are good salespeople," said Mr. Cohen. "The guy who organized a student strike in high school probably has a saleserson's powers of persuasion."
OTHER firms figure that, even if the attrition rate is high, the data that trainees gather or the clients they turn up will, as they do at Cushman & Wakefield, offset part of the costs of having them on staff.
The Peter R. Friedman firm has a training program in which fledglings spend about 20 percent of their time in class, and the rest of the time canvassing for leads. If a lead pans out, the trainee joins the team assigned to follow up, then usually rejoins the training pool when the deal is done.
The trainees get a draw against commission, but it is small. "The goal is to keep everyone hungry so they are focused on learning and bringing in business," said Jeffrey M. Sussman, director of leasing.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Floating in Limbo

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
CAPT. SRETO PETROVIC'S hands are stuffed into the pockets of his brown sports coat, and, standing on the deck of his cargo vessel docked at Red Hook, he looks cold. His face is covered with a lively brown shrub of facial hair and his eyes seem tired even though he hasn't done much of anything today.
"It's better here," the 43-year-old seafarer says. "We are not on duty. We are usually in our cabins or the television room." 
 There is not a lot to do on his ship, the Lovcen. When the vessel set off from the former Yugoslavia in 1992, it was on a simple mission to New York to pick up lumber. Now, that seemingly mundane task has left the crew stranded, a casualty of an international political quagmire.
The Lovcen (pronounced LUV-sen) was seized by the United States Treasury Department after it sailed into New York Harbor on Aug. 3, 1992, under economic sanctions against the Yugoslav Federation republics of Serbia and Montenegro. While most of the crew of about 20 were reassigned by the ship's owner, Captain Petrovic and a skeleton crew of six stayed aboard to maintain the 490-foot cargo vessel, where they have remained ever since. Technically, only the ship, not the crew members, is under arrest, but the crewmen are effectively confined because they have no visas.
When they are not tending to their undemanding responsibilities of maintaining the engine, updating navigational charts or monitoring the radar aboard the deteriorating ship, the crewmen spend most of their time holed up in a musty cabin watching television or sleeping. Sometimes they risk violating immigration law by slipping into Brooklyn to shop or see a movie. Often, they wait for visitors.
"They were bored, frustrated, angry, confused and impatient," said the Rev. Jean R. Smith of the Seamen's Church Institute, who has been visiting the crew regularly for more than three years. Unpaid for months at a time and faced with broken septic systems and failing equipment, they were quickly faced with sagging spirits, she said.
"These were people who were hired to do a job and weren't able to do it," said Ms. Smith, who is a Port of New York chaplain "The crew knew how to live and spend their lives as seamen. And they couldn't."
The crew members especially look forward to the weekly visit of Peter Renehan, the American representative of Milena Ship Management, a Montenegran company that owns the Lovcen. Mr. Renehan delivers supplies and takes orders for his next visit, but what excites the men most is his cellular phone. With it, they call their wives in Montenegro.
One of the sailors, Rajko Jelic sits cross-legged in front of the Lovcen's radio system, chain-smoking L & M cigarettes. He said he had not seen his wife and 4-year-old son for three years. He sounded more like a prisoner than a sailor when describing corralled life on the Lovcen.
"For small times, I go to Brooklyn and Manhattan," he said. "I used to take the small boat to Staten Island and take a ferry into Manhattan. Now, it is easier to go into town. It is O.K. New York is beautiful. Brooklyn beautiful."
Mr. Renehan said five of Milena's ships, including the Lovcen, had been seized in ports around the United States. Milena has lost millions, and the financial troubles of the company, a vital economic entity in Montenegro, have rattled the Serb-dominated country, he said.
He said he admired the men aboard the Lovcen, who could have abandoned the ship long ago for a better life. "They never complain," he said, descending the gangplank to the Red Hook pier. "They do show a tremendous amount of loyalty to their owners, their country and pride in their vessel. This is their job. If they had the option to leave, they wouldn't."
But they do not have the option to leave because, although the Clinton Administration lifted the economic sanctions in December, the Treasury Department will not release the vessel until Milena Ship Management repays American creditors. In addition, the ship has fallen into disrepair and could not make a trans-Atlantic voyage.
Before the Lovcen docked in Red Hook last July, it languished in the Bay Ridge Anchorage Flats, designated anchoring waters near Brooklyn. Visitors would sidle boats up to the gangplank to offer the men meals and magazines. If the crew wanted to reach land, they would use a launch to putter to Staten Island. After the ship was deemed a hazard to navigation, the Coast Guard petitioned the Treasury Department to allow the vessel to move to the Erie Basin off Red Hook, said Comdr. John O'Brien of the Coast Guard.
"We were getting a lot of complaints that this was an accident waiting to happen," said Commander O'Brien, the chief of port safety for the Port of New York. "When it was on anchorage, they had to keep the vessel operating. Alongside a pier, it's not a problem anymore."
Today, the gray-and-white Lovcen is a rusting craft. Tattered plastic shopping bags, broomsticks and a broken lawn chair lie on the deck. Though the ship's auxiliary engine keeps running with an even hum, the main engine cannot run for long periods. And with the touch of a hand or step of a foot, paint chips and rusting lead crackle to the floor.
Down in the television room, a crew member, Vasilije Zelalic, 55, is watching Maury Povich's show. The curtains are drawn. Like Mr. Jelic, he continually clutches a cigarette and relies on a steady diet of heady coffee. "I like watching soccer, N.B.A. basketball, and some good movies like horror and action," he says, turning the sound down. "Every day there's something to do. I relax myself. I watch television. I read books."
But later, he is brooding. "We wait to sail from here as soon as possible," he said.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Kia Sportage and Kia Sephia;
2 Tigers, at Least on Paper

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
IN America, where the phrase "Korean car" inspires the same sort of consumer confidence as the words "Albanian software" or "Canadian football," Kia's entry into the market has been inauspicious.
But setting aside the 1994 debut of the first, not-ready-for-prime-time Sephia, and this year's aborted entry of the 1996 Sportage -- just as the mini-sport utility craze caught on -- Kia's products carry prices that tempt the most skeptical American shoppers. With so few low-budget new cars, even skepticism must yield to arithmetic. 
 The Sephia was renovated last year to include a larger engine, a 1.8-liter four-cylinder that produces 122 horsepower (Californians can opt for a 1.6-liter, 105-horsepower version), dual air bags and other mechanical and esthetic improvements.
The test car was the midline Sephia LS, complete with standard features like a four-speed automatic transmission, power steering and brakes, 14-inch tires and dual remote outside mirrors. Options included air-conditioning, floor mats and stereo cassette player, for a bottom line of $12,695.
That price makes the Sephia LS a serious contender in the window sticker derby. In fact, its few head-to-head competitors include its Korean cousin, the Accent from Hyundai -- a brand that also wears its J. D. Power ratings albatross-style.
If the Sephia's price tag coaxes you into the driver's seat, you'll find a snoozy, generic interior in the fashion of many Asian economy cars. The seats are firm and shallow, and on long trips one's backside becomes sharply aware of the seat frame. The cockpit works well, except that the radio controls are munchkin-sized and the cup holder, ashtray and gearshift lever interfere with one another when deployed.
Reviews of last year's Sephia raked the car for poor workmanship and ugly materials, but Kia seems to have addressed those problems in the main. The seams lined up and the plastics and vinyls were compatible.
The performance of the Sephia is its strong suit, quite above the curve of expectations for the thrift-car class. Its 117 foot-pounds of torque flings the 2,500-pound sedan crisply into action, and the car acquits itself nicely in passing lanes and on freeway on-ramps. The independent suspension, tuned by Lotus, dishes up fair doses of firm, controlled response without sacrificing ride quality. This year's 14-inch wheels, up from 13, lay a smooth, grippy foundation under the 97-inch wheelbase. All things considered, the Sephia is a fun bit of commuter fluff.
The car also got a nose job and a fanny tuck, so it presents a smoother, more aerodynamic profile. Even so, the Sephia's styling electricity wouldn't draw a moth in May. Of course, buyers of entry-level sedans are not shopping for matinee idols.

 
 The Sportage, on the other hand, has great curb appeal. Its high, rounded shape and cute derriere bring out the curiosity seekers in any parking lot. Think of it this way: If you carved a Toyota Land Cruiser out of soap, after two dozen showers it would look like the Sportage.
While compact, this is no mini-ute. Its wheelbase, at 104.3 inches, is 1.6 inches shorter than a Grand Cherokee's and the Sportage is wider than the Isuzu Rodeo or Toyota 4Runner. Inside, it has plenty of room and great sight lines in every direction except out the back window (where the headrests and the spare-tire carrier block the view). It just looks smaller than it is.
And it lives smaller than it is, by virtue of small infelicities in interior design. For example, the power window buttons on the door are flush-mounted and hard to find; the gearshift pokes out of a chintzy gray-vinyl sleeve; the ashtray is concealed behind the gearshift; the rear door armrests prevent the seat backs from lying flat; the roof liner is playing-card thin, and the cup holders in the back of the console are no help to drivers without double-jointed shoulders.
The Sportage has fit-and-finish issues to deal with, too. The upholstery in the test model was crudely fastened with staples.
But the Sportage has lots to like as well. On the road, it's a surprisingly docile and manageable four-wheeler, smooth and stable on top of its MacPherson strut front and coil-sprung rear suspension, and it strides robustly on its thick ladder chassis. Its 1.8-liter dual-overhead-cam engine, a 130-horsepower affair derived from a Mazda design, is gritty for off-road use. But it complains loudly when pushed into the wind.
Kia's five-speed manual pairs nicely with the engine, but an automatic transmission is available on four-wheel-drive models for an extra $1,000. The Sportage 4-by-4 has a shift-on-the-fly transfer case that provides an extra-low gear range for extreme conditions. Rear anti-lock brakes are standard. A rear-wheel limited-slip differential is available on the fancier Sportage EX. And for 1996 -- when and if the '96 model arrives -- the Sportage will have a driver's side air bag and can be fitted with dealer-installed front locking hubs.
Best of all, the Sportage is cheap. The test vehicle, a '95 EX with a manual transmission and options like air-conditioning, stereo and roof rack, rolled out for $18,475. This in a market where most sport utilities you can live with start at $20,000 and keep going.
For all of its extras, the Sportage's best bit of equipment may be the piece of paper in the window.
INSIDE TRACK: What Kias lack in polish -- plenty -- they make up for in price.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATIRON / CHELSEA;
Flatiron Unites to Fight Clubs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Ten years ago the neighborhood did not even have an established name. The Flatiron District has come a long way since then, attracting loft dwellers, design firms, shops, clubs and restaurants. Now the area is beginning to come of age politically as new civic groups strive to deal with the growing pains that have accompanied the growth.
Concern over the neighborhood's burgeoning bar and club scene has been the prime catalyst. Residents, block association members and merchants have complained about the noise, filth and violence associated with clubs at meeting after meeting of Community Board 5. On Feb. 15, they incorporated as the Flatiron Alliance to protest the clubs in a more organized fashion. 
 "This is not a disco zone," said Michele Golden, the alliance's vice president. "We're just overloaded. We're talking about security and physical violence, not just noise. The situation is so bad we had to make an official alliance of the block associations. We formed together as a mass to push our weight around."
The members of the alliance have traversed the city directory in search of help. They have written to the Mayor, met elected officials and lobbied city and state agencies. And, this being part of an area sometimes called Silicon Alley, they have put the fax number of every local official they can think of on a Flatiron Alliance homepage on the Internet.
One of the most dangerous clubs, the alliance says, is Club Vertigo, a dance club on 20th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. Laura Michaels, president of the Flatiron Alliance, said there have been several shootings and a slashing at Club Vertigo in the last six months.
Lee Gounardes, the club's manager, said he employs 24 security guards who search every patron. "Vertigo is one of the safest clubs in the city," he said. . "This is about economics, race and politics. They don't want blacks and Hispanics on the block. They're worried about property values."
Ms. Michaels said that the alliance does not care what kind of businesses operate in the area as along as they are clean, safe and quiet. A more cooperative club, she said, is the Limelight, just down the street. Ms. Michaels said that the Limelight stepped up block patrols, planted new shrubbery, agreed to turn down the music and opened their courtyard to the public.
Ms. Michaels placed a color map on the alliance's Internet home page listing 73 cabarets, bars and restaurants from 16th to 23d Streets between Seventh Avenue and Park Avenue South. Now she and other members are upset about Splash, a gay bar on 17th Street that has asked the city's Board of Standards and Appeals for a permit to allow dancing.
"You can't allow another cabaret in this area if you can't control the clubs that are here now," Ms. Michaels said.
Fredrick A. Becker, the lawyer representing Splash, said: "We understand the community's concerns, but this is not the opening of the floodgates. These types of uses are permitted in the district."
The nightclub crowds are the downside of the neighborhood's popularity. "Sometimes," said Ms. Golden, "I wish we had stayed undiscovered." MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Daily News Missed by Old Haunts

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The steel-case letters above the time-and-temperature sign still read "Daily News." But no reporters write about "Mob Bigs" from East 42d Street anymore. And they don't order take-out lunch from the Lantern, or buy flowers from the Alisan Florist, or unwind with a mug at Donahue's Bar and Restaurant, "home of the coldest draft beer in New York City."
Last May, The Daily News moved out of its landmark Art Deco skyscraper, taking its last 500 employees two miles across town to a modern skyscraper on 33d Street and Tenth Avenue, facing a windy expanse of auto repair shops and the John D. Caemmerer West Side Storage Yard Complex, where the Long Island Rail Road keeps some of its trains. 
 No one has replaced The News yet. The old neighborhood has long suffered one of the city's highest vacancy rates because many buildings lack the wiring and other requirements for computers, a reason cited by The News for moving.
Rents have remained stable, both in the Daily News' old neighborhood and current neighborhood. But at least some small businesses around East 42d Street did see a big drop in their economic fortunes, the latest setback for the neighborhood after other nearby big companies, like Mobil, downsized their work force.
One immediate casualty was Maguire's Cafe, a 125-seat restaurant and bar across the corner of Second Avenue and 42d Street from the old News building and next door to Ryan McFadden's, a 15-year-old bar that was a favorite of reporters and editors.
Maguire's closed shortly after Christmas. "It wasn't just The News that shut us down, but it sure didn't help," said Louis Maguire, owner of Maguire's and one of Ryan McFadden's three owners.
Business also dropped sharply at Donahue's, an 80-seat Irish bar and restaurant a block south on Second Avenue. With the News around, Brian Maguire, the owner, who isn't related to Louis, said he had as many as 125 regular customers, "the ones who pay the rent." Now, the number may have dropped to as few as 50.
"The News people were great customers," Mr. Maguire said. They had other sterling qualities, too. "You could also call them up to help settle bar bets," brain-busting questions usually involving sports.
Not just bars were hurt. Angelo Katsanos, manager of the Lantern coffee shop, figures he has lost $400 a day. "They ordered a lot of lasagna," he said.
If the tabloid's move drained business from its old East Side neighbors, the exodus did little to bring new life to the desolate West Side neighborhood that seemed to be stirring in 1994 before the paper's move.
The expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, which would have been an important stimulus, is postponed. Olympia & York, the giant Canadian real estate developer, declared Chapter 11 bankruptcy last year and never built two skyscrapers planned at 34th Street and Ninth Avenue. The land will go to major creditors.
But O'Farrell's, the Irish bar across 10th Avenue and 33d Street from The News's new headquarters, does see a lot of reporters and editors.
Larry Sutton, a veteran reporter at The News, said most people eat at their desks or grab a quick lunch at the featureless delicatessen in the ground floor of the building. "It's a lot like living in a suburban office mall," he said. "We're prisoners of the building." ANTHONY RAMIREZ
