HEADLINE: The Koreans Are Coming! (But Where Are They Going?)

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
THE South Korean auto maker Kia -- rhymes with Pia, as in Zadora -- opened 35 dealerships this month in Florida, a state already sagging into the Caribbean from the weight of new-car lots.
But a crowded market doesn't seem to bother Kia as it continues its region-by-region march on the United States. The Florida dealerships will join 140 Kia kiosks the company has opened in the West and South in the last two years, a period in which Kia Motors America went from zero sales to 25,000 annually. By the end of 1997, the purveyors of the econo-sedan Sephia -- rhymes with Kia -- and the perky Sportage sport utility expect to have 550 dealers seeded throughout United States. 
 Kia is here. Get used to it.
The company's growth projection calls to mind the ambitions of other tricky-to-pronounce companies like Mitsubishi and Suzuki. Can Korean car companies like Kia -- and two that are coming soon, Samsung and Daewoo, neither of which rhyme with anything -- swamp the United States market as the Japanese did a generation ago?
Probably not, said Greg Warner, executive vice president of Kia Motors America. There are many more competitors now and more technological parity. Korea doesn't enjoy the labor cost advantage that Japan had in the 1970's. Nor does it have Japan's immense production capacity. Besides, Mr. Warner said: "There was a period of incredible weakness on the part of American manufacturers that just doesn't exist today. There are no opportunities to bulldoze 25 percent of the American market."
Mr. Warner can tell you all about it. The former head of Hyundai Motor America, he presided over that company's roller-coaster fortunes in the late 1980's. Hyundai, a South Korean industrial giant, entered the American car market in 1986, ambitiously -- some might say even arrogantly -- ready to duplicate Japanese companies' success. Hyundai's sales of 168,882 units in 1986 set a record for an importer's first year.
Then increased competition, poor quality and rock-bottom satisfaction ratings caught up with Hyundai. Sales tumbled from a high of 264,282 in 1988 to 107,378 in 1995.
Hyundai's experience, Mr. Warner said, shaped Kia's strategy of doing a slow march across America. "The greatest single problem would be selling too many cars too rapidly without being prepared to support them by the parent company," he said.
Company officials admit that Kia rushed in in 1994. Their first, callow Sephia had no air bag and a rude 1.6-liter single-overhead-cam engine, and it earned Kia a dead-last ranking in the 1995 J. D. Power Initial Quality Survey of new owners. The first Sportages, though well received, arrived in 1995 with a single-cam engine, no air bag, a manual transmission only and no two-wheel-drive alternative.
Worse yet, the company announced in December that production of the Sportage would be delayed for re-engineering of a new air bag system, leaving product-hungry dealers in the lurch. Those dealers may well wonder if they can bank on Kia's promises to expand the product line; the two-seat KMS-II sports car and midsize Credos sedan are all but pledged to reach the United States within a couple of years.
"It will be interesting to see how they fare," said Bill Wolf, who is now the president of Hyundai Motor America. And he has more than a passing interest in his rival's fortunes. If Kia fails, he said, "it could tarnish other Korean manufacturers."
Those others include the industrial heavyweights Daewoo (pronounced DAY-ew) and Samsung, which also have grandiose plans to wrestle in the American ring.
Daewoo is a world automotive power, No. 52 on Fortune's list of the world's 500 largest corporations, with the capacity -- spread from Uzbekistan to the Philippines -- to build 700,000 vehicles a year. Under its chairman, Kim Woo Choong, the company is pursuing a frantic global strategy. Daewoo will spend $11 billion by 2000 to raise production to two million units for a staggering worldwide sales level of $134 billion.
Part of the plan is to enter the American market by next year with three cars. But that seems unlikely, given that Daewoo has yet to secure an American top executive and has not even established a field staff. Compare that with Kia's methodical entry, five years in the making.
No less ambitious are the plans of Samsung. It recently said it would invest $13 billion to become one of the world's top 10 auto makers by 2010. Samsung plans to enter the United States market in 2001. In December, it hired a former Honda product planning manager, Matt Lewis, as the American car division's top executive. It has also acquired a design studio in California and opened a research office in Detroit.
The kicker? Samsung, a world leader in electronics, has never built cars before.
All of which raises the question, Why are the Koreans in such a rush to get into America? The answer may have less to do with sales figures than with national pride.
"It's the prestige of the American market," Mr. Wolf of Hyundai said. "Everybody wants to be here. It's the toughest market in the world, and the perception is that if you're not here, you're not a player."
And Seung Hwar Oh, Samsung's public relations manager, said: "We are the sixth-largest car-making country. We want to be the No. 1 country in each field we enter. It's a matter of national pride."
It is also a matter of national ambition. The Korean industry is highly regulated; companies need Government approval to get in. Last year, Seoul approved Samsung's application to become the country's fifth car maker, after Hyundai, Kia, Daewoo and Ssangyong (no rhymes, alas, for the maker of jeeplike vehicles). The goal? To fulfill the predictions of the Korea Development Bank that by 2005 the country will be the world's fourth-largest car maker, after the United States, Japan and Germany.
In Seoul's global vision, the road to the future goes right through the United States. Get used to it.

LENGTH: 982 words

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF: VALERIE FOLEY;
No Credit Where It Is Due

BYLINE: By VALERIE FOLEY; Valerie Foley is a bilingual secretary in Manhattan at the law firm of Graham & James.

 BODY:
IF there is any other woman on the face of the planet who has ever had an income exceeding the old standard of $1,000 for each year of age, more than a year's salary in savings and an excess of $10,000 in material assets with no outstanding debt since 1980, but was still unable to get a bank to trust her with a credit card, I would like to meet her to commiserate.
In 1977, I did get a credit card at a department store where I worked. For purchases elsewhere, I relied on my husband's Mastercharge (the predecessor to Mastercard), which he had received unsolicited during the early heady days of charge-card expansion. 
 My credit problem really seems to date back to 1981, when my husband and I accepted teaching jobs in Japan. Mastercharge was valid there, but bills had to be paid in United States dollars. Because we were paid in yen, converting money on a monthly basis was a nuisance, and we decided to use the dollar-based card only on rare forays to the United States.
We then applied for a card in the local currency, but to our surprise we found that this option was not available to noncitizens. We therefore learned to live frugally and developed a thriving cash economy.
It wasn't until my husband and I divorced, and I returned to the United States alone, that I began to pay the price of self-sufficiency. The 10-plus years we spent abroad were enough for my solid, if brief, credit record to be expunged, but Merrill Lynch, with whom I had had a banking relationship for five years, furnished me with a debit card.
Because I was temporarily unemployed, I didn't even think to ask for a credit card.
When I found work, I began furnishing my new apartment, and sales clerks petitioned me to open store accounts. Knowing that this was a first step toward establishing credit, I obliged happily. It was only after repeated rejections (for credit never exceeding $300) that I learned that in the eyes of the credit services I did not exist -- partly because Merrill did not make its clients' records public, but also because neither solvency nor debit-card use had the least bearing on whether I could be trusted to pay for a $300 armchair over three months.
I was content to continue with my cash economy until one day when, without warning, Merrill Lynch closed my international account to convert it to a domestic account. The procedure almost completely blocked my cash flow for more than three weeks.
Vengeful as a spurned lover, I withdrew everything and sought solace in the arms of other banks, although I knew I would lose my debit card. Citibank alone assured me both immediate access to my money and a credit card, so I opened my new account there, only to receive yet another rejection letter two weeks later.
It was suggested that I sign up for Citibank's secured card, whereby an 18-month certificate of deposit for the desired amount of credit is purchased, serving in effect as hostage in the case of nonpayment. This seemed a reasonable solution until I learned that, in addition to an uncompetitive interest rate, there was a $20 fee for the card, regardless of how much money the customer might have in other accounts there.
On the advice of a gentleman at Republic Bank, I then made several credit card inquiries at local banks because, he noted, each bank has its own criteria for acceptance. (Republic and the three or four others I approached all rejected me.)
My hopes were raised when I stumbled across student applications for the American Express Optima and the Citibank Visa cards. If students with no salaries or credit histories were eligible, I reasoned, I must be, too. The Citibank application trumpeted: "No fee. No worries." It was even cavalier: "Breed goats in your dorm," it said. "No co-signer or minimum income required."
When I made phone inquiries, however, I was turned down for both cards on the grounds that I was not a student. That I am a former student with an advanced degree, income, savings and no debt cut no mustard with the telemarketers or their supervisors. Statistics, I was told by a supervisor at American Express, show that students (perhaps especially those who breed goats?) are better credit risks than adults.
 But the final blow came when the American Express supervisor told me my record now indicated an unusual number of requests for credit in a short time, which credit companies view with suspicion. He advised me to make no further credit applications for six months to erase this blemish. Suddenly I was not only without credit but penalized for seeking it.
The strict adherence of all these institutions to cookie-cutter requirements was baffling. No one benefits if I am unable to spend my pent-up earnings at will.
DETERMINED to pursue this black comedy to a conclusion, I asked a Citibank branch executive why I couldn't have a no-fee secured card if students could have a no-fee unsecured card. The affable vice president told me the fee on secured cards had long since been dropped, paving the way for me to receive my plastic a few weeks later.
Although I am no longer subject to the petty irritation of seeking out A.T.M.'s and the recurring humiliation of credit card rejections, the satisfaction I should feel is tempered by the nagging suspicion that the secured card has bought me only a kind of second-class citizenship, and I am probably still ineligible to buy a car or a home, despite the fact that I could well afford either.
The mystery to me is how people with incomes below $25,000 a year can rack up $40,000 in credit card debt (and then, if the horror stories are true, go into bankruptcy and still be allowed to keep the house and car at taxpayer expense), while someone with an enviable track record has to move heaven and earth to get credit when she doesn't really need it because she learned to live without it when she really could have used it.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLLEGE POINT / FLUSHING;
Anatomy of a Deal For Vacant Land

BYLINE: By Jane H. Lii 

 BODY:
Proposals by a Pepsi-Cola bottler to find a developer for a vacant 26-acre tract it owns north of the old Flushing Airport -- possibly for megastores like Kmart and Price Club -- have left area residents and businesses bitter and angry.
The tract was sold by the city to the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York in 1986 for $4 million for use as a bottling plant. But Don Thomas, a senior vice president of the company, said it had decided to approach developers instead. 
 A lawyer for the company, David Stadtmauer, said on Friday that it was in final negotiations with a developer called Related Companies, which has approached Kmart, Price Club and other retailers. He said the bottler had paid the city $500,000 to change the deed from industrial to retail use.
Fred Mazarello, president of the College Point Board of Trade, which represents local businesses, said he is angry because Pepsi received a favorable deal on the land sale in order to keep jobs in Queens, not to make money by developing it.
Officials of the city's Economic Development Corporation said, however, that the sale price was discounted because the land had holes that needed to be filled before construction could start. And Mr. Thomas denied that the company had received special treatment.
Residents and businesses say they fear that stores will worsen the existing traffic problem.
"Right now, it's a free-for-all," said Josephine Mercurio, president of the College Point Civic and Taxpayers Association. "Trucks use the streets whether they are truck routes or not." Ms. Mercurio said her association does not oppose the development as long as the city and developers resolve the traffic problem.

HEADLINE: Out From Under

BYLINE: By Herbert Stein; Herbert Stein is a former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the author of "The Fiscal Revolution in America," now in a second, revised edition.

 BODY:

THE ROAD FROM SERFDOM
The Economic and Political Consequences of the End of Communism.
By Robert Skidelsky.
214 pp. New York: Allen Lane/The Penguin Press. $26.95.
Economists will be forever grateful for Robert Skidelsky's superb biography of John Maynard Keynes, of which two volumes have already appeared and a third is promised. After such arduous effort on the life and ideas of another, Robert Skidelsky, a professor of political economy at Warwick University, is surely entitled to some speculations of his own. In "The Road From Serfdom" he tackles big questions about the character of our economic system: where are we, how did we get here and what do we do next? If he does not answer these questions entirely satisfactorily -- well, who does? At least we have the thoughts of an intelligent, well-read and open-minded person. And, thank the Lord -- Robert Skidelsky became a lord in 1991 -- the book is not very long. 
 The title is an echo of the famous book by Friedrich Hayek, "The Road to Serfdom," first published in 1944. These "road" metaphors are likely to be misleading. The idea that we are on a road suggests that history moves in a one-dimensional way inexorably to some extreme destination or from some extreme origin. By describing the world now as being on the road from serfdom, Lord Skidelsky is implying that we have all moved a substantial way along the road that Hayek visualized and that we are now experiencing a grand reversal toward freedom. That historical movement, in his view, includes as essentially similar the fall of Communism in the Soviet Union and the emergence of Thatcherism in Britain and Reaganism in the United States. Now these developments do have some things in common, just as a beheading and a haircut have some things in common. But the differences are so great that to discuss them as part of the same continuum is misleading and confusing.
Neither Lord Skidelsky's book nor Hayek's earlier one is really about serfdom. Both are about the suppression of individual freedom by the state. But serfdom denoted a relation between private individuals, like slavery in the United States. The serfs in Russia and the slaves in America were liberated by the state, and their experience shows that freedom is not entirely a matter of the relation between individuals and the state, and that an increase in the role of the state is not necessarily a movement away from freedom. Failure to recognize this gives both books an unduly narrow perspective. What Hayek foresaw as the road to serfdom and what Lord Skidelsky now sees as a realization of Hayek's fears until the advent of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher was in fact a new birth of freedom, at least in the United States. Blacks and women, and others as well, gained greatly in freedom.
After we get beyond the title, Lord Skidelsky's word for the evil from which we are now recovering is not "serfdom" but "collectivism." He defines that as "the belief that the state knows better than the market, and can improve on the spontaneous tendencies of civil society, if necessary by suppressing them." But no one believes that the state knows better than the market or than civil society about everything, and no one believes that there is nothing about which the state knows better. In fact, Lord Skidelsky lists a number of areas in which state activity or interference is perfectly legitimate. As he says, "collectivism is therefore a matter of degree."
But once that is said we are in a whole new ball game. We can no longer say a priori whether more state activity is a good thing or a bad thing. We cannot escape the difficult task of trying to judge whether particular state activities are legitimate in a free society, whether they are conducted on too large or too small a scale and whether they are effectively managed.
When we get beyond this semantic underbrush we come to the core, or two cores, of the book: one is what has been happening in the societies of Western Europe and the United States, which have on the whole been highly successful; the other is what has been happening in the previously Communist, failed societies that are trying to become normal -- that is, like us.
With respect to the Western societies, Lord Skidelsky's story in bare bones is essentially this: During the 19th century and even more in the 20th century, the role of the state increased. This was partly the result of objective forces -- urbanization, industrialization, the rise of large private institutions like corporations, wars (including the cold war), the Great Depression and democracy. It was also the result of ideas generated by a number of thinkers -- a list that begins conveniently with the German economist Friedrich List and includes Marx, of course, and the Webbs and Carlyle and many others. Keynes makes an ambiguous appearance, first as a savior of the free system and later, through his disciples, as a threat to it. Sometime around 1965, according to Lord Skidelsky, the expansion of the state had gone too far, had become excessively collectivist, and public resentment against it produced the Thatcher and Reagan revolutions, which were our part of the road from serfdom.
This is not exactly the story as I would tell it. Lord Skidelsky places more weight on thinkers and less on politics and politicians as determinants of policy than I would. He relies too much on the generalizations of intellectuals for descriptions of what was actually going on. He is taken in too much by rhetoric about planning, even though he notes that in the British case the plan was on paper only. (In 1973 the Romanian Minister of Economic Planning thought that I, as chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, was his opposite number. Nothing could have been further from the truth.) Lord Skidelsky gives insufficient weight to what must be a major factor in any history, which is plain miscalculation. He too readily attributes the ills from which we have obviously suffered -- inflation and slow real growth -- to collectivism, but says too little about the problems stored up for us for the future by the unwise undertaking of obligations in the 1960's and 1970's. And he does not examine what 15 years of experience might tell us about the success of Thatcherism and Reaganism.
Lord Skidelsky has admirably organized a large body of information into a plausible story that is surely true in the main. It deserves attention. But it is not the whole truth. I fear that in the present political atmosphere it will be seized upon by American politicians as support for their claim that we need them to liberate us from our Government.
Lord Skidelsky's discussion of the collapse of Communism and the sequel up to now is the most informative part of the book for me, as I believe it will be for most American readers. He explains why the inefficient Communist planning system could not go on just yielding very low or even slightly negative rates of economic growth but had to collapse into a rapid decline of output. Recovery from this collapse required two kinds of development. One kind included tight fiscal and monetary policy, decontrol of prices, international competition and convertible currency. The other kind of development was to generate the internal structural conditions for free markets -- to get state-owned industry into the hands of businesslike private management, to establish legal codes for the conduct of private business, to maintain law and order and to provide a sufficient social safety net to make the inevitable adjustments tolerable. There was initially some debate over the speed with which the first set of requirements should be met -- the shock-therapy-versus-gradualism debate. This debate was not settled but it has been rendered moot, because most of the shock that was going to occur has occurred already. Now the main question is whether the other conditions can emerge fast enough to yield the economic normality that will support political stability.
While this seems to be happening in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, Lord Skidelsky leaves the question in doubt with respect to Russia itself. Ironically for a book that is in general so anti-government, the lesson seems to be that for Russia to get on the road from serfdom will require more effective performance there of the functions of government that are so normal in the West. And even more ironically, Lord Skidelsky thinks that a critical condition for success in Russian normalization is a large inflow of economic aid from the West -- a bigger injection of Western collectivism in support of Russian freedom. Which only goes to show that the road of history is not a straight line.

HEADLINE: High Heels and Hangovers

BYLINE: By Jane O'Reilly; Jane O'Reilly is the author of "The Girl I Left Behind" and "No Turning Back: Two Nuns Battle With the Vatican Over Women's Right to Choose."

 BODY:

At the Still Point A Memoir.
By Carol Buckley.
Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23.
Last fall I taught a class in memoir writing. My students were adults, and each possessed the basic requirements: a life and the story of its living. Too soon, I urged them to take Vladimir Nabokov's "Speak, Memory" as an example of the best that can be done with those basics. They recoiled. One, to the applause of the others, described the effort of reading Nabokov as "like wading through wet sand." In revenge, I produced the vanity press recollections of a Middle Western utilities executive notable for its range of platitude and the absence of the personal. After that it was easier to persuade them that having a memory is not the same thing as writing one. 
 Next semester I will be able to make a more congenial beginning. Carol Buckley's "At the Still Point" will serve as a perfect example of how to accomplish the task of writing a memoir. The author is one of those Buckleys, the rich, conservative, multitudinous Roman Catholic Buckleys. But she was the baby, the last, born six years after the ninth child. "I was born an only child in a family of 10," she writes, and the first thing she knew about herself was that her birth nearly killed her mother. She was too young to know all her siblings, or even to sort out fully which was which. They were Buckleys, and she was somehow "different, not really a bona fide member of the family. I was still in grade school, they were 'grown-ups'; I was dumb, they were smart." Her childhood was spent in "a kind of opulent neglect," bewildering and filled with the echoes of family games long since past.
As an adult she furnished a doll house for her own daughter, filling it with servant dolls but forgetting to include parent dolls. Every fall, baby Carol was sent ahead to Camden, S.C., where the Buckleys had a winter house they opened in December. While she stayed in a hotel with a governess, the family congregated back in Connecticut for the Thanksgiving holiday. The first time she tried to kill herself, years later, was on a Thanksgiving
afternoon.
Ms. Buckley flunked out of college, married, contributed four children to the pool of 50 Buckley cousins. Her most beloved sisters died. Isolation and depression, pills and alcohol, shock treatment and suicide attempts took over her life. Somehow she acquired a new husband and became half of a glamorous New York City couple. Her parties were famous. She served on boards.
"The men are gray and businesslike -- there are fewer of them but they talk more. The women, early to late middle age, are uniformed: caps of blondish hair done by Kenneth or by
M. Marc, bright polished nails, big gold earrings, slender gold chains, Cartier watches, silk blouses, Adolfo suits (Nancy Reagan is First Lady), panty hose, heels. And hangovers." One peaceful summer evening, in her pretty summer house, alone, she became so drunk she crawled up the stairs to the bedroom, pushing a glass of grapefruit juice and vodka ahead of herself. Three weeks later she stopped drinking. The marriage crashed. With the help of her brother Bill she finished college and became a social worker. "A sense of my own autonomy would develop slowly as I learned to focus on others and to leave myself behind." Briefly, she moved back to Connecticut, back to her childhood geography, and finished growing up. Then she moved to the shore, settling into what she has discovered to be "the still point of the turning world," as Eliot called it.
"At the Still Point" is an interesting story, but there is nothing special about having an interesting story, except perhaps the surviving of it. Everyone has an interesting story. That's life. The challenge is to write it so that the reader cares. That's art. And that is what Carol Buckley brings to, or extracts from, her story. The writing is graceful, evocative and economical. Technically, her choices of what to tell and how much and in what tone are extremely deft. She is a generous memoirist, casting no blame and telling no secrets but her own. And she has only one message, so quietly and unobtrusively argued that its truth comes as a surprise and a comfort. "I once heard a man say about becoming sober: 'I was given permission to be ordinary.' What a relief! Not to be better than or less than, to be special only as a part of. What is special is to be ordinary."

HEADLINE: China, in Flux, Must Integrate Values

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "China's Quest for Respect" (Op-Ed, Feb. 19): 
 As China undergoes leadership succession and the uncertainties of economic growth, it needs integrative values. Lucian W. Pye's proposal that the United States engage China in public debate rather than behind-the-scenes discussion ought to be a challenge.
If the debate between Mao Zedong and Nikita S. Khrushchev in the 1960's could help China define itself in terms of its own socialist value system, let the United States encourage China to regenerate national values and integrate them with an expanding free market. Perhaps there will also develop a greater mutual understanding.
Let the Chinese respond publicly to the notion that a tolerance of human rights and an evolution toward freedom of expression might serve as an impetus to market competition and creativity.
There is in China a craving for ideological identity. A 16-year-old girl told me in Shanghai last year that China will lead the world in the next millennium. What she wanted to know from me was what contributed to America's development. President Clinton should tell her and China, too.
 
DAVID M. RADDOCK
Brooklyn, Feb. 21, 1996
 
The writer, a China specialist and political psychologist, was until recently a visiting senior research scholar, Columbia U.

HEADLINE: Defining Evil

BYLINE: By John Gray; John Gray is a fellow of Jesus College, Oxford, and the author of the forthcoming "Enlightenment's Wake."

 BODY:

A HISTORY OF FASCISM, 1914-1945
By Stanley G. Payne.
Illustrated. 613 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $39.95.
IS fascism a thing of the past? The question has both a theoretical and a practical interest. On the theoretical side we are curious whether fascist movements and regimes are so linked to the conditions of Europe between the world wars that nothing having their peculiar combination of features can be found in other historical contexts -- such as our own. Practically, we are anxious about the future of liberal democracy. We wonder if the increase in economic insecurity that affects almost all of us -- but particularly the middle classes, for whom it remains in some ways a novel experience -- may not provoke a revival of movements of the kind that swept away fragile democracies in the 1930's. Looking at the world around us, it seems that powerful fascist movements do belong to the interwar period and pose no major danger to us now. Except perhaps for Russia, where Vladimir Zhirinovsky's bizarrely misnamed Liberal Democratic Party has evoked comparisons with Hitler's National Socialists in Weimar Germany, no democratic state faces anything that could reasonably be described as a fascist threat. Most democracies contain small groups that are estranged from democratic institutions, some of them -- like those who inspired the Oklahoma bombing or those who daubed European synagogues with anti-Semitic slogans -- willing to resort to terrorist violence. Yet none of these groups are in a position to mount a challenge to a democratic state. Can we then safely write off fascism as largely banished from the world? 
 Anyone seeking a guide to thinking about the history and essential characteristics of fascism could do no better than read Stanley G. Payne's invaluable book, "A History of Fascism, 1914-1945," which is likely to be the definitive study of its subject for a considerable time. Mr. Payne, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, has given us a study that is a model of historical narrative, analysis and interpretation. His account of European fascism, and of fascist-like movements in Latin America, Asia and elsewhere, is authoritative, exhaustive and suggestive. One of the vital distinctions he is concerned to make is between fascism and the political movements of the right. In most countries, fascist movements distinguished themselves from even the authoritarian far right by their uncompromising modernism, their rejection of any kind of reactionary nostalgia for the past and, in many cases, by their pronounced hostility to Christianity.
Mr. Payne makes the interesting and perceptive observation that, insofar as fascism had anything resembling a coherent framework of distinctive ideas, this owed much to the European Enlightenment as that had been interpreted and developed by thinkers like Nietzsche and Henri Bergson. In fact, as he rightly argues, fascist ideology is in many ways an echo of Europe's fin de sicle intellectual ferment in the arts, literature and philosophy. In support of this interpretation we may note that in many countries fascism in its earlier stages attracted the sympathy of avant-garde artists -- particularly in Italy, where the Futurist painter Filippo Marinetti was for a time a prominent supporter. Again, fascist economic programs were a mixed bag of proposals that were rarely worked out seriously and never implemented, yet they all involved large changes in existing economic policies. In important respects, the claim of the early fascists that they were not conservatives or reactionaries but rather radicals or revolutionaries who repudiated the bourgeois culture and institutions of the 19th century is well founded in the realities of history. One conclusion to be drawn from Mr. Payne's account is that we will not advance our understanding if we rest content with the clich that fascism represented a regression into atavism, a step backward in historical development. It is often better understood as a form of perverse modernity.
A t the same time, fascism was from its beginnings allied with antiliberal and xenophobic forms of nationalism. In many countries -- Spain, Portugal and much of the Balkans, for example -- it was virtually indistinguishable from movements and parties of the authoritarian, clerical right. In these countries a reactionary political mythology of peasant life was an important component of fascism. In much of central and eastern Europe, anti-Semitism -- which was not a defining element in fascism in Italy or Spain -- was a central and fundamental theme both of the authoritarian right and of fascist parties that modeled themselves on the example of National Socialist Germany. In Nazism, fascism was able to combine the most contradictory tendencies, representing itself as at once the embodiment of a new world order and the savior of the social order in Germany and Europe. A small part of the measureless moral horror of the Holocaust may derive from its combination of the most atavistic human impulses with some of the more advanced applications of technology and modern science (or its perversions, in Nazi eugenics and racist theories). This fusion of apparent opposites in the prototypical Nazi exemplar makes any simple definition of fascism unhelpful. Perhaps, in the end, fascism has no essential nature at all, and there is really nothing more to it than its history.
Mr. Payne concludes his inquiry with the observation that "the Western world has been inoculated against fascism," so much so that even a major new economic crisis could not bring it back to life. It is almost certainly true that, except possibly in post-Communist Russia, we will not again see anything that resembles the classical fascism of the interwar period. The principal threat to liberal democracy now comes more from a revival of the radical right. In continental Europe, radical rightist parties, like those of Jean-Marie Le Pen in France and Jorg Haider in Austria, maintain a consistently strong electoral performance on the basis of new economic insecurities and the revival of old anti-immigrant sentiments. True, none of these parties can hope to challenge democratic institutions; but they nevertheless mark a break with the political culture of postwar Europe, where parties of the far right were everywhere excluded from serious political influence. In the United States, the ranting evangelists of welfare cuts and "family values" on the Republican right have discovered that it is difficult, in a functioning democracy, to implement evolutionary policy changes that flout long-established expectation.
Yet it is these populists and doctrinaires of the anti-government right who probably pose the most serious threat to stable democratic institutions today. Their combination of economic Darwinism with a deeply reactionary view of family life is a recipe for widening social division, deepening political alienation and intractable cultural warfare. In any less historically myopic age this would at once be recognized as a radically unconservative agenda. The ruling project of today's radicals of the right, in the United States and similar countries, is an anachronistic dystopia -- reinvention of the laissez-faire capitalism and minimum government of a century ago, together with the re-creation of what they believe to have been the family life of that period. If this project has an intellectual pedigree it is in the thought of libertarian doctrinaires like the philosopher Herbert Spencer and the conservative journalist Albert Jay Nock. There is a cruel paradox in the truth that the chief danger to liberal democracy now should come not from fascism but from the rebirth of a primitive form of liberalism.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Lordship Has Its Price: Blue-Chip Bids for Blueblood Titles

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
WHEN Victor Podd decided to rustle up some new business three years ago for Powertex Inc., his packaging company, he didn't join an association or double his advertising. Instead, he wrote a $30,000 check to the Manorial Society of Great Britain and became the Baron of Newcastle, buying a 900-year-old title put on the block by an aristocrat in need of quick cash.
The acquisition paid some fast dividends. Formerly sequestered at Powertex headquarters in Rouses Point, N.Y., a hamlet near the Vermont border, Mr. Podd suddenly found himself mingling with others in America's corporate gentry. Joseph Hardy 3d, chairman of the 84 Lumber Company in Pittsburgh, invited Mr. Podd two years ago for his annual summer retreat in Farmington, Pa., although the two had never met. 
 As it turns out, Mr. Hardy had shelled out $180,000 four years earlier for the Lordship of Henley-in-Arden and enjoys hobnobbing with fellow aristocrats. The introduction was a boon for Mr. Podd, who met several British executives just as he was increasing his company's presence in Europe.
"I would have never made such fast inroads without those lordships of the manor," said Mr. Podd, who has scooped up six titles in the last three years. "Once you buy one, it's like you become a member of an exclusive club."
Scooping up British titles may appear to be an odd hobby, but it's quickly becoming a consuming passion for some celebrities and common folk alike. This spring's auctions -- set for March 20 at the Manorial Society and March 26 at Strutt & Parker in Essex -- are expected to draw near-record prices.
The auctions will probably be similar to past ones, at which some of the writers of the biggest checks were Russian and Japanese executives who enjoy counting themselves among Europe's nobility, and Canadians and Americans out to reconnect with their ancestries.
The big difference at this year's auctions should be the size of the checks. Two years ago, with Europe in a recession, manorial lordships typically went for $6,000 and baronies for $30,000. Next month, they are expected to fetch $7,500 to $90,000.
"Now that demand for British lordships has picked up again, we're seeing interest from all over the world," said Robert Smith, chairman of the Manorial Society, the largest auctioneer of British titles. "Many of the buyers are curious about the British nobility or are avid students of history."
Counted among Britain's newly anointed lords are a top-level aide to the former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev; the founder of Norton Utilities, Peter Norton, who paid a six-figure sum to become the lord of Shakespeare's hometown, Stratford-on-Avon, and the composer Ole Georg, also known as the Lord of Sheldowne in Sussex.
Why all the noble hubbub? It has been caused in part by the cinema. Two Jane Austen novels that were made into films recently, "Persuasion" and "Sense and Sensibility," are but the latest in a number that have sparked an interest in British history. But more important, every title now up for grabs is a British heirloom, passed down from one generation to the next.
Some buyers collect them like fine art. Lordships and baronies are some of Europe's oldest titles, dating back to the Domesday Book, which recorded a land survey for William the Conqueror in 1086. In the golden days, the lord collected rent from people who lived within his domain, pocketed a cut of the profits from street fairs, oversaw the local legal system and dispatched troops to help the king.
Unfortunately, the titles up for grabs today have lost virtually all that power. Some manorial lordships come with no benefits other than the title. Most offer the lord first dibs on the manor's minerals and rights to the roadside, the narrow strip of land between a thoroughfare and the front yard of the property owner, who could be anyone from a farmer to a big corporation.
About 90 percent of British titles that are auctioned are bought my men. Women who buy titles, Mr. Smith said, are usually of independent means and buy for the same reasons as men: They want to connect with a British ancestry or consider the titles to be collector's items.
"A common misconception is that people get manorial titles confused with peerages," Mr. Smith said. "Peerages entitle the owner to sit in the House of Lords. These titles we sell at auction do not."
If being a lord of a manor isn't what it used to be, you'd never know it by some current owners. Many people, like Mr. Podd, own more than one title. "I'd like the titles to become part of our family's belongings," Mr. Podd said. "I plan to pass them on to my children."
Several titles on the block this year are prime properties. Scottish baronies are rare, and one that is for sale, the Barony of Finavon, comes with the remains of a castle on two acres in central Scotland. The bidding should top $90,000. If you want to be a top lord, make a bid for the manor of Towton, one of Europe's most historic sites. One of the fiercest battles of the War of the Roses took place there, and the title should fetch more than $12,000.
Buying a title is relatively easy. Both these properties are being auctioned off by the Manorial Society. To make a bid, buyers can contact the society (011-44-17-1735-6633) or one of the other top British auction houses -- Strutt & Parker (011-44-12-4525-8201) or Cluttons (011-44-17-1408-1010) -- which have a separate selection of titles. Cluttons rarely conducts an auction, but titles can sometimes be purchased through a private sale.
All three auction houses have catalogues listing the titles on the block, with a brief history of each. "It helps to be present at the auction or visit England ahead of time," Mr. Smith said. "That way we could point them to the manor itself and they could go visit. But it's not necessary."
Regardless of the title they buy, most lords of the manor seem to enjoy their new notoriety. A few years ago, Arnold Davis, a retired real estate executive from New York, visited Barnham Broom, a small town in Norfolk, England, after he had bought the lordship of the manor. "When the people at the local pub found out that I was the lord of the manor, they bought my wife and me a round of drinks," Mr. Davis said. "I eventually christened a building and got to know the local vicar. My wife and I have made a lot of friends there."
The titles have a few other subtle perks. Auctioneers frown on buyers who snap up titles for investments, but clearly the title of lord has behaved recently like a solid blue-chip stock. Denis Woodfield, a retired executive at Johnson & Johnson, paid $1,400 for the Lordship of Hamptonet in Worchestershire in the early 1980's. Today, it is estimated to be worth at least 10 times that.
"You shouldn't buy a title thinking that you're going to make money," said Mr. Woodfield, the Manorial Society's United States chairman. "But the titles do seem to pay off over time, if you ever wanted to sell them again. I wish I could say all my investments have done as well as this one."
But other lords have pocketed even greater bonanzas. Mr. Woodfield remembers a British executive who bought a lordship only to discover that a real estate developer had violated his manorial rights without permission. The executive's lordship included rights to the roadside, meaning he could charge rent for anyone trespassing on it. The developer had built 24 houses along the road, allowing the driveways to cross the easement. The executive sued, pocketing $10,000 in damages for each of the 24 driveways. Not bad, considering that he paid only about $15,000 for the title.
"A windfall like that is very rare," Mr. Woodfield said. "And you can't really watch your rights unless you're in the country. After I heard that, I approached the local authorities about some poles they had put on my roadside that I thought I could get some money for. They quickly reminded me that the county was cutting my grass and taking care of my roadside. They'd be more than happy to start charging me for that. I told them that I'd see them later."
While demand for British titles is increasing, plenty more should come on the block over the next few months. Charles Chetwynd-Talbot, the Earl of Shrewsbury, plans to unload about 40 of his 60 titles this May to raise money to buy more farmland. "Some of these titles have been in my family for more than 300 years," Mr. Chetwynd-Talbot said. "But I consider them part of my stocks and bonds. Usually the people who buy titles really appreciate their history or enjoy the feeling of nobility."
It is a safe bet that not all of the potential buyers for Mr. Chetwynd-Talbot's titles will be celebrities or chief executives. Ronald J. Shaw, a lawyer in San Antonio, recently bought the Lordship of Hunworth for $9,000. Mr. Shaw wanted the title to leave to his 5-year-old daughter, Kaitlin.
"Right when I found out about the titles, I thought they'd be a great gift," Mr. Shaw said. "I figured, hey, this way I'll always know that my daughter will be a lady."

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
The Forms Look About the Same, but Beware of the Tinkering

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RADICAL overhaul of the tax system may dominate political debate these days, but there is remarkably little change in the rules for filing your return for 1995.
Just because no major new legislation has been put on the books, however, does not mean there are no refinements to wrestle with or costly traps to avoid. Indeed, it is still conceivable -- although more unlikely each day -- that the capital gains tax will be cut retroactively, a situation inspiring "a lot of prayer" at the Internal Revenue Service, which hopes it will not face a blizzard of amended returns, according to the I.R.S. Commissioner, Margaret Milner Richardson. 
 Other legislation could also pass that would affect 1995 taxes but prospects seem dim for most of the package approved by a House-Senate conference in November and then rejected by President Clinton.
But strange and unpredictable things happen, especially in election years. Some analysts contend that chances for major legislation will improve if Senator Bob Dole continues to falter in his quest for the Presidency because he may want to prove to Republican primary voters that his biggest presumed asset -- Washington experience -- gets results.
On the other hand, if Mr. Dole closes in on the Republican nomination he may not want to risk a big collaboration with the President for fear that Mr. Clinton, his rival, would get most of the credit.
For 1995 returns, there are some new substantive and procedural benefits, like the option to have refunds deposited directly into your bank account and the less burdensome treatment of the so-called nanny tax.
The I.R.S. will not issue Publication 553 this year, its list of tax law changes, even though the instruction book refers to it as a source of detailed information.
But these are some things to watch:
STRICTER VERIFICATION OF DEPENDENTS Taxpayers must now supply a Social Security number for any claimed dependent who was born before Nov. 1, 1995, which means the I.R.S. will have evidence that all but newborns actually exist. Without the number -- or with an incorrect one -- refunds are subject to delay and filers could be hit with a $50 penalty.
Last tax season 800,000 dependents "mysteriously disappeared," the agency says, reflecting progressively more stringent documentation requirements. For returns covering 1996, things will tighten further with a Social Security number required for those born before Dec. 1.
 
STREAMLINED PAYMENT OF THE NANNY TAX Employment taxes on wages paid gardeners, baby sitters, health aides and other household help are now reported with your income-tax return and collected annually, rather than quarterly. You report this on Form 1040, line 53, attaching the new Schedule H. You are liable if you paid any domestic worker -- students under 18 excepted -- as much as $1,000 in cash during 1995 or paid total domestic wages of $1,000 in any calendar quarter of 1994 or 1995. Your payment is for Social Security, Medicare and Federal unemployment coverage and for Federal income tax you have withheld.
 
DIRECT DEPOSIT OF REFUNDS One way to speed up your refund -- and eliminate the possibility of a lost check -- is to fill out Form 8888, which is new this year, and put it directly behind the form you file and ahead of any schedules or other attachments. Form 8888 is simple, but some taxpayers may find it slightly tricky to decipher from one of their own checks the bank's routing transit number that needs to be provided to the I.R.S. And some banks will not allow a refund from a joint return to be deposited into the individual account of a husband or wife.
 
FINAL PAYMENT ON 1993 TAX INCREASE If you are one of the 750,000 or so taxpayers who owe a final installment on the 1993 tax increase, make sure to send in the check for it separately -- accompanied by the tear-off voucher you should get with a reminder notice in March -- so it will not be mistakenly credited for 1995. Last season there was considerable confusion, mostly because of errors by the I.R.S.
However, if you are due a refund for 1995, you can apply some or all of that refund to your remaining 1993 balance by indicating this on your return, as long as your check for any shortfall tax is sent separately.
 
LAPSED EDUCATION EXCLUSION Without fresh legislation, you can no longer get an exclusion for up to $5,250 of education assistance provided by your employer. It is now deemed income for which tax has very probably not been withheld. The exclusion, benefiting about 800,000 people, expired at the end of 1994 and efforts to restore it have bogged down. Still, many tax experts think it could yet be restored, even retroactively. If you received tuition reimbursement, you might want to hold off filing until close to deadline to minimize the chances of needing to amend your return.
 
RECEIPTS: A MIXED BAG To deduct charitable contributions of $250 or more, you now need a written acknowledgment from the recipient, a requirement that many seem to have neglected. "I don't think clients have clearly focused in on this," said John Kearney, senior tax partner at Israeloff, Trattner & Company.
You must also get a written statement from a tax-exempt organization if you gave it more than $75 and received any goods or services in return, like football tickets or a dinner. The statement must put a value on what you receive, which cannot be deducted.
On the other hand, as of Oct. 1, 1995, the Government no longer requires that business people have receipts for meals and other travel and entertainment expenses of less than $75, triple the previous threshold that had prevailed since 1962. Many companies, however, are sticking with the $25 figure to keep a tight lid on costs.
 
RELIEF FOR RETIREES While it does not directly affect this filing season, legislation signed by President Clinton last month will no doubt prompt a fresh look at tax planning by many current and soon-to-be retirees.
The new law bars what is known as "source taxing," the practice by states of reaching beyond their borders to tax retirement income of former residents. Two of the most aggressive states are New York and California. The relief, which applies to deferred compensation as well as retirement money, applies to amounts received after Dec. 31, 1995.
"Residents of states with high income-tax rates may wish to consider relocating to low- or no-tax states after retirement," specialists at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts advise.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Outlook Clouded on a Capital Gains Rate Cut

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
AS taxpayers prepare their 1995 returns and do tax planning for 1996, no area is more clouded than capital gains. The rate may or may not drop, and if it does, the drop could be effective in 1995, or maybe in 1996.
Adding to the confusion, the traditional ways to defer or evade capital-gains taxes are under attack, and could yet be thrown out, retroactively. On the other hand, some Presidential candidates want to get rid of capital-gains taxes. 
 Capital gains are the profits an investor makes when selling an asset, most often stock or bonds, real estate or collectibles like art or antiques. Over the years, the taxation of such profits has varied substantially, depending on which of two arguments was heard the loudest. Those who want to cut such taxes cite the advantages to the economy of encouraging investment; those who wand to raise them contend that capital gains are mostly realized by affluent investors and argue that it is not fair to grant the richest taxpayers lower tax rates.
The current law splits the difference. For long-term capital gains -- profits taken on assets held more than one year -- the rate is the same as the rate on ordinary income for investors in the two lower marginal brackets of 15 and 28 percent. But taxpayers in higher brackets, up to 39.6 percent, pay only 28 percent on long-term gains.
Under the tax bill passed by the Republican majority in Congress, rates on capital gains for all taxpayers would have been cut to half their marginal rate on earned income, effective Jan. 1, 1995, creating five rates ranging from 7.5 percent to 19.8 percent. But in the continuing budget wrangles with Congress President Clinton vetoed that legislation.
Congressional Republicans are still officially committed to that bill, and to a 1995 effective date. But the more time passes, the less likely that becomes. Still, if a budget deal is ever reached in Washington, capital-gains taxes would probably be cut.
With confusion rampant, what's an investor to do? There are clearly reasons to take capital losses quickly, but there may be advantages to delaying capital gains, in hope of lower rates. But, of course, opinions on market value should take precedence, since tax savings can quickly vanish if the value of an investment should plummet.
Some of the flat tax plans being talked about by Republicans would end taxation of capital gains altogether. Whether such a tax plan could be enacted is doubtful, but anyone who expects one eventually might want to delay selling, even if capital-gains tax rates are lowered, hoping instead to avoid taxation altogether.
Avoiding such taxation now is possible if you are willing to pay your broker a fee -- and if you have enough profits to make the fee worthwhile. But, again, there is uncertainty, for the Clinton Administration is proposing essentially to bar such tactics and to make that bar retroactive to Jan. 4.
The most popular such tactic is called "selling short against the box" (a reference to old practice of keeping securities in a safety deposit box). Let's say you own 1,000 shares of Intel, bought years ago. If you sold them now, you'd have a profit of about $40 per share, or $40,000. At a 28 percent capital-gains tax rate, you would owe Uncle Sam $11,200.
On the other hand, you might tell your broker to borrow another 1,000 shares of Intel, and sell them. That is what is known as a short sale. Under tax law as it now stands, the Government figures you have two separate positions, a long one and a short one, and you will not owe any taxes until you close out one position or the other. In fact, you no longer care whether or not Intel goes up, since any profits you make on one position would be offset by losses on the other one.
Using a form of derivatives called equity swaps accomplishes about the same thing and has advantages for large holders because it does not require borrowing shares.
The Clinton proposal would create a concept of constructive sale, essentially what some people call the "smile test." If you don't have a good reason to smile when a stock goes up, or to frown when it goes down, you don't own it anymore. And you should pay taxes, the Administration contends.
If it is approved, then anyone who entered into such a transaction after Jan. 4 would have 30 days to reverse it, said Robert Willens, a tax analyst with Lehman Brothers. If the deal is not reversed, then the stock would be deemed to have been sold, with capital-gains taxes due.
Most people on Wall Street are now acting as if that law had been enacted, and shorting against the box is now an unusual tactic.
"The general view is that if there is a budget compromise, that will be in it," said Robert Gordon, the president of 21st Securities.
Capital losses are not as much talked about as capital gains, but they can be just as real to investors. One little noticed aspect of the Congressional tax bill that President Clinton vetoed was a provision to treat such losses more harshly, even as capital gains were getting a break.
Since that provision, too, is likely to be in any new bill, it is a good idea if you have any large capital losses to take them quickly, Mr. Willens said. Whether that will help is uncertain, since no one knows what the effective date would be. But it would not hurt -- from a tax perspective, at least. Of course, if a battered security suddenly recovered, investors would regret selling.
Capital losses now can be used to offset capital gains, and excess losses can be carried forward to future years to offset gains in those years. That would not change. It is the other use of capital losses that would change. That affects a taxpayer who has a large capital loss and no prospect of immediate capital gains.
Under the current law, a person who reports a capital loss of $24,000 and has no capital gains could use $3,000 of the loss to offset ordinary income, carrying $21,000 forward to future years. And next year, that person could offset another $3,000 of ordinary income. If there were never any capital gains, over eight years the entire loss could offset income of $24,000. income.
The proposed change is to require $6,000 of capital losses to offset $3,000 of income. So that $24,000 loss would offset only $12,000 of ordinary income. Since the proposal would apply only to capital losses taken after the law became effective, losses taken before that date would be worth more to taxpayers.
Capital gains on securities porfolios cannot be offset by passive losses. Even though investors often think of real estate and partnership holdings as investments, under the tax laws those are passive activities, and passive losses can be taken only against passive income.
There remains one way to avoid paying any taxes on capital gains. Never take the gains. When a taxpayer dies, his or her estate will owe estate taxes based on the value of the assets owned by the taxpayer. But it does not matter what the taxpayer paid for those assets. There is no capital-gains tax on the estate.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
In Confusion Over Tax Law, Don't Overlook Some Changes

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WITH the nation's tax rules in seemingly constant flux, even tax professionals are occasionally tripped up. Ask Nadine Gordon Lee, a partner with Ernst & Young, the Big Six accounting firm in New York.
Ms. Lee, a mother of two boys, prepared the paperwork and paid the Federal unemployment tax for her baby sitter in January, when she received the forms in the mail from the Internal Revenue Service. She had grown accustomed to the quarterly blizzard of paperwork needed to pay Social Security and unemployment taxes for baby sitters and other domestic employees. 
 So it completely slipped her mind that there is a new, simpler way to do it: complete the new Schedule H as part of your tax return and make those payments along with your income tax.
But having filed the old way, Ms. Lee said that it would not be simple for her, at least not this year. "I'm expecting to get into a long letter-writing campaign with the I.R.S. to get the tax I already paid offset against what I owe," she said.
Here are some other recently changed areas that tax professionals say many people may stumble over, as well as perennial snares. Being alert to them can help you pay as little as possible on April 15 and avoid trouble with the I.R.S.
If you are self-employed and not covered by your spouse's health insurance, do not overlook or understate the deduction for your health insurance premium. That would be easy to do, because after letting the insurance deduction for the self-employed lapse at the end of 1993, Congress reinstated it retroactively, and increased the size of the deduction to 30 percent of the premium amount for 1995, from 25 percent previously.
Furthermore, eligible people who did not claim the deduction for 1994 may do so by filing an amended 1994 return, 1040X, using the 25 percent figure.
Be sure to get a Social Security number for your baby. Seeking to reduce fraud, the I.R.S. has whittled away the age at which Social Security numbers are required for dependent children, and the number of children claimed as dependents has dropped in tandem. Now Social Security numbers are needed for children two months or older to claim them as dependents on returns, compared with two years previously.
Take any business deductions for travel, meals and entertainment to which you are entitled, even if some of the small receipts have been lost. In an audit the I.R.S. could demand to see receipts for business expenses of $25 or more until last Oct. 1. After that, receipts are required only for expenses of $75 or more. You still need a business diary to back up the expense by stating reasons, location, date and who was entertained.
The maximum earned income tax credit has increased for families of all sizes -- although only by $8 for the childless -- and the amount you can earn and still qualify for the credit has increased. More military personnel will qualify, but many nonresident aliens are cut off. Beginning with 1996, you cannot claim the earned income credit if you have investment income of more than $2,350.
Be careful not to overpay taxes on mutual fund dividends reported on Form 1099. Ordinary dividends are indeed taxable at your marginal rate -- up to 39.6 percent -- but the gross dividends figure sometimes includes capital gains generated by a fund's sale of securities, said Jeff J. Saccacio, the West Coast partner in charge of personal financial planning services for Coopers & Lybrand, a Big Six accounting firm, in Los Angeles. And capital gains are taxed at a top rate of 28 percent.
Furthermore, you owe no tax on any "return of capital" dividends. So it pays to read all the details on the 1099 to sort out exactly what kind of dividends are being reported.
Don't ignore incorrect 1099 statements. The I.R.S. cross-checks nearly every dividend and interest payment reported by taxpayers against the amounts reported by the banks and financial institutions that paid them. When they do not match, the I.R.S. computer kicks out a return for a closer look, and the examiner might find something else to question.
What is the best solution? Write the bank or other payer and have it issue a corrected 1099. When there is not enough time to do that, Ms. Lee advised, write the correct figure on your return and then attach an explanatory schedule to the return.
Even if you do not have the money to pay the taxes you owe, be sure to file your return, or a request for an automatic extension, by April 15. Failing to file could cost you a bundle unnecessarily, Ms. Lee said. If you do not file on time, you will owe an I.R.S. penalty of 5 percent of the unpaid taxes a month up to a maximum of 25 percent, plus taxes and interest. If you file without paying what you owe, the penalty is just a half-percent a month plus taxes and interest on whatever is owed.
If you pay or receive alimony, remember that it is taxable income to the recipient and an above-the-line deduction for the payer. The I.R.S. cross-checks nearly all alimony payments because Social Security numbers are required. People who fail to report income are likely to be audited and owe not only taxes but also penalties and interest.
If you own or rent a pied-a-terre in town or a vacation home elsewhere, bone up on the legalities of residency and keep careful records to avoid being taxed as a resident unexpectedly. It is possible legally to be a resident of two or more cities or states.
Ms. Lee had clients who lived in Westchester County, N.Y., but also bought a small apartment in Manhattan, where they worked. They used the apartment only 8 to 15 days a year, but had to pay resident income taxes in New York City, which considers anyone a resident who has a home in town and is present more than 183 days a year; part of a day counts.
Do not automatically file joint tax returns if you are married. True, married filing jointly will generally result in a lower total tax bill, but if one spouse has a lot of medical or itemized expenses, filing separate returns might lower the liability. That is because medical expenses are permitted only to the extent that they exceed 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income; miscellaneous itemized deductions like unreimbursed business expenses and union dues are allowed only to the extent they exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income. The only way to be sure is calculate both ways.
Finally, if filing at the last minute, do not send your return to the I.R.S. by Federal Express or a similar overnight delivery service. By law, tax returns are considered filed when mailed, even if the I.R.S. receives them several days after April 15. If the United States Postal Service is not used, a return is not legally filed until it is delivered to the I.R.S.


GRAPHIC: An excellent way to save for a child's education is to put income-earning assets like corporate bonds and C.D.'s in the child's name. Under the kiddie tax rules that apply to children younger than 14, only investment incomes in excess of $1,300 is taxed at the parents' marginal rate. With interest rates currently around 5 or 6 percent, large sums can often be shifted to a child before that threshold is reached.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Behind the Gains, Unhappy People

BYLINE: By ANNA D. WILDE 

 BODY:
TO understand the effect the budget impasse in Washington is having on taxpayers, one need look no further than Washington, Mo., where, the Washington Savings Bank, 99 percent locally owned, mostly by farmers and retirees, sold out to a large St. Louis-based bank last November. Believing that Republican members of Congress would slash capital gains tax rates for 1995, the bank's directors took cash for their assets.
"We took them at their word that they were going to do this," said Winston Brunjes, former chairman of the board for the bank and a pork producer. "It wasn't a pipe dream, if you would have listened to them, it was a sure thing." 
Now, he said, as prospects for a tax plan this year grow dimmer and dimmer, former Washington stockholders must bite their nails waiting to learn if they will lose lose unexpectedly big chunks of their nest eggs. "We can't make a good business decision with this uncertainty," Mr. Brunjes complained.
Capital gains this year fall into a genre unusual in tax literature: the suspense story -- though certainly not a thriller. Filers and tax experts are annoyed at the delay.
"Nobody thought we would go into a black hole and not emerge from it," said Tom Sherman, a tax partner in the Minneapolis office of Coopers & Lybrand. "It's very hard to go to a client and say, 'I really don't know what's going to happen.' "
The stalled budget plan would have effectively set a capital gains rate of half a taxpayer's marginal rate on earned income for 1995, and possibly whittled the liability further by linking gains on assets held a long time -- like the Washington Savings Bank holdings -- to inflation. But those who bet on the Republicans now feel jilted.
John J. Castrenze, a partner with the accounting firm of Kaufmann & Castrenze, in Egg Harbor, N.J., said one client was trying to stall a potential buyer for his auto dealership. "He's afraid to make the move," Mr. Castrenze said. "It's a huge chunk he's going to have to pay that he wouldn't have had to pay."
For now, accountants and other tax planners have few definite answers for clients like the car dealer. But most advise taxpayers not to bet on a change this year, and to make no deal that is based on the assumption that capital gains rates will go down a set amount.
"My advice is going to be that the chances of retroactivity are small," said Gary C. Rohrs, a former president of the National Society of Public Accountants who practices in Missouri.
Another option for cautious taxpayers was to design an installment payment plan for large transactions that would delay big capital gains, on the assumption that a cut may be enacted for next year or possibly the year after.
"A lot of capital gains transactions were structured to delay receipt of the gain into 1996," said Michael L. Gracik, a tax partner in the Richmond, Va., firm of Keiter, Stephens, Hurst, Gary & Shreaves.

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Tax Preparers Aren't Ruffled by Proposals for an Overhaul

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
"THE reports of our death are greatly exaggerated," said Ozzie Wenich, a spokesman for H & R Block, the nation's largest tax preparation service, responding to calls along the campaign trail to simplify the nation's income tax system, even allowing taxpayers to file postcard-size returns.
Mr. Wenich is not alone. So far, no tax professionals, whether tax preparation chains, large accounting firms or independent preparers, are lobbying Congress against proposals to adopt a flat tax or otherwise greatly simplify the system. 
 In fact, it seems the entire industry is taking a wait-and-see stance.
"It's a little premature because the flat tax issue is still evolving, but it's being talked about this year more than ever," said Phyllis Borghese, director of government relations at the National Association of Tax Practitioners, a Wisconsin-based organization of certified public accountants and other tax preparers and planners. "I think it's obvious that reform is in the air."
But no matter how the tax code may be overhauled, tax preparers are confident that people with relatively complex returns will continue to rely on tax professionals. Still, a radical change in the code could virtually eliminate the simple returns, the current 1040A and 1040EZ.
But tax preparers contend that, at least in the short-term, business should increase because people will be confused about any new system.
"I've never lost one night's sleep thinking about a flat tax," said John Hewitt, chairman and chief executive of Jackson Hewitt, the nation's second-largest tax preparation company, based in Virginia Beach, Va. "Our average customer is the Wal-Mart customer, under 40 with an income under $40,000. They'll continue to come to us for their taxes."
The Internal Revenue Service says about 50 percent of all filers use a tax preparer. Firms like Jackson Hewitt and H & R Block, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., and has a similar clientele, charge around $35 to $45 to complete a 1040 form. Tax preparation makes up, 95 percent of Jackson Hewitt's business and 68 percent of H & R Block's business, but given last week's plan to spin off Compuserve, H & R Block expects tax preparation to make up 85 to 90 percent of its business.
The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, is also professing there is no cause to worry.
"We're not lobbying on the Hill for or against a flat tax," said John Hunnicutt, the group's senior vice president for public affairs. "We think our role is to analyze the various proposals and make sure there is reasoned debate."
THE "Big Six" international accounting firms -- Arthur Andersen, Coopers & Lybrand, Deloitte & Touche, Ernst & Young, KPMG Peat Marwick and Price Waterhouse -- also appear unruffled.
"Most flat tax proposals are a result of the Presidential campaigns, so we haven't gotten down to the nuts and bolts issues yet," said Bernard Shapiro, national director for tax policy at Price Waterhouse in Washington. "Right now, we're looking at the various impacts tax reform would have on the economy and our clients' business, so when it occurs we'll be ready to consult with customers regarding how they should position themselves."
Coopers & Lybrand recently introduced two sophisticated economic computer models that are able to calculate tax on 100,000 returns and provide data on how various tax proposals would affect the economy, specific industries and individual companies.
Deloitte & Touche is Sponsoring seminars and slide shows for clients on fundamental tax reform.
Despite potestations of indifference, most government liaisons for the accounting industry agree that some form of tax simplification is likely to be enacted within a couple of years, with heated discussion over transition rules, followed by a phase-in period. And once a specific structure is under serious consideration, no doubt tax preparers will spring into action, lobbying against the components they expect will affect them or their clients adversely.
"If we go to a postcard-type tax return, and your business is doing individual returns, it will put a large dent in your business, if not put you out of business altogether," said Bryan Schmitt, academic assistant at the National Endowment for Financial Education in Denver.
Perhaps H & R Block and Jackson Hewitt are placing their hope in another of Mark Twain's observations: "Habit is habit, and not to be flung out of the window by any man, but coaxed downstairs a step at a time."

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Late-Model Tax Software Can Accelerate Filing

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
FEW consumer goods have run so counter to inflation in recent years as computer software, and nowhere is that truer than for tax-preparation programs, which have gotten much easier to use and more comprehensive, even as their prices have tumbled.
In the early 1980's, when PC's with dual floppy disk drives emerged as status symbols for executives and as the prize possessions of nerds, software publishers began offering tax-preparation programs, typically for $200 to $300, that were little more than specialized spreadsheets for the most frequently used forms and schedules. 
 They seemed great at the time: The computer crunched all the numbers, and if you needed to change an entry or add one, no problem, it recalculated the entire return within minutes. But, doubtless, Model T's seemed great in their time, too.
Today, individual income-tax software generally sells for $20 to $50 for Federal tax programs, plus $20 to $30 for optional add-ons for state returns, and handles a myriad of forms, schedules and worksheets.
What's more, the two leading programs, Taxcut and Turbotax, are remarkably easy to use, even for people who know next to nothing about computers or income taxes. Simply answer the plain-English interview questions on the screen, and the program will see to it that you've reported all your income and claimed all your deductions and credits. It takes care of filling out and calculating the return properly, almost faster than you can say "nanosecond."
Both programs are available on floppy disks or CD-ROM's, and users who take the time to read the on-screen help files and listen to the CD-ROM videos will get a personalized education on tax and financial planning as they work their way through the interview.
And there is more help available in cyberspace. The stalled budget talks in Washington have left proposed retroactive changes in the nation's tax laws unresolved, and software publishers have established home pages on the World Wide Web for this filing season to keep taxpayers posted on any changes that might be forthcoming, and to provide software updates.
Such software bells and whistles, of course, depend on today's powerful hardware -- PC's with Intel 386 chips or better for Windows disk programs and 486 or Pentium chips for CD-ROM versions, as well as a lot of hard-disk space.
ASK yourself a few questions when deciding whether to use your computer to prepare your 1995 return and to help plan your 1996 finances to whittle down tax liability: Do you have an obsessive-compulsive streak? Do you keep all receipts and financial records so you can enter the right numbers? Do you have the patience to work through the interview question by question to see how it all relates and study the on-screen resources to see where changes might be in order? If so, tax software is for you.
Practically speaking, today's tax software is a two-horse race, but the contest between Intuit's Turbotax and its cousin Macintax on the one hand and Block Financial Software's Kiplinger Taxcut on the other is like a Derby between Citation and Northern Dancer. The other entrants can be sent to the knackers.
Turbotax has a number of innovations this year. One is that it includes a version of Netscape Navigator, the Internet browser, so users can visit Intuit's home page on the Internet (http://www.intuit.com/turbotax).
 There Turbotax has already confessed to seven sins. These software flaws affect mainly people with depreciation, real estate professionals, those with Keogh plans for income within a limited range ($15,252 to $18,753) and those using the Form 1040EZ with the earned income credit.
USERS who think they might be affected can click on an item to get more detail and to learn how to correct the program's errors. In addition, Tracy Benelli, a Turbotax spokeswoman, said Intuit was sending corrected copies to any registered users who requested them.
The Web site also offers technical support and advice from Mary Sprouse and Jeff Schnepper, whose tax books, "The Money Income Tax Handbook" and "How to Pay Zero Taxes," are included on-screen in the CD-ROM version of the program.
Kiplinger Taxcut from Block Financial Software, a subsidiary of H& R Block, loads onto a computer rapidly and is remarkably easy to use. It includes software and 10 hours of free access for the Compuserve on-line service. In addition, users can find Taxcut support on America Online, Prodigy and the Web (http://www.conductor.com).
So far no major flaws have been identified in this year's Taxcut program, which includes videos from Kiplinger's editors. More important, the program's interview and on-screen help are clearly written.
One limitation is that only 23 state tax programs are available, whereas Turbotax has a program for every state that has an income tax.
Still, if you are new to tax software, don't delay the purchase until April 14. Get a program soon and work with it. And if you feel unsure of the return you prepare, go to a professional to check it. The combination of the cost for that service and for the software should still be far less than an accountant's hourly fees for going through bulging files and preparing a return.
