HEADLINE: Cuba's Nuclear Plant Project Worries Washington

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: JURAGUA, Cuba

 BODY:
From the day the Cuban Government began building an atomic reactor here in the early 1980's, American officials were alarmed at the prospect that a nuclear power plant of Soviet design and questionable safety would be going into operation less than 200 miles from American shores, but powerless to do anything about it.
So when President Fidel Castro came to this beachfront site on Cuba's southern coast three and a half years ago to tell thousands of workers that construction of "the undertaking of the century" was being suspended, the United States, along with Cuba's Caribbean neighbors, breathed a sigh of relief, certain that Cuba's nuclear adventure was finally at an end. 
 But now the project, which has already cost more than $1 billion, has suddenly come roaring back to life. Late last year, Cuba and Russia announced the formation of a joint work group to raise the $750 million they estimate will be required to finish construction of a 675-megawatt reactor here by the end of this decade, and began looking for a foreign partner.
Completion of the mothballed plant hinges on many factors, not the least of which is raising so much money during a period of severe economic austerity both here and in Russia. But Cuban officials argue that they must plunge ahead to bring down their energy costs, end their almost complete dependence on expensive imported oil and alleviate the power shortage that has resulted in rotating blackouts in Havana and other areas.
"Our country needs energy, and so far, at this point, we do not have a better option" than to resume the Juragua project, said Daniel Codorniu Pujals, head of Cuba's Nuclear Energy Agency. "We have something here that appears feasible to finish, that has people who are interested in investing in it and which will not take a long time to complete."
For the Clinton Administration, Cuba's effort to revive its nuclear power program represents a complicated challenge to American policy. The United States outlaws trade with Cuba and has limited diplomatic contact with the Castro Government, so it can do little to dissuade Cuba from going ahead with the Juragua project or to monitor its completion to insure that it conforms to American safety standards.
As a result, the Energy Department has not included Cuba in the $180 million nuclear safety program it has established with Russia and former Soviet bloc states in Eastern Europe at 59 reactors.
The limitations on contacts would also appear to prevent the sort of negotiated settlement that Cuban officials have repeatedly hinted might interest them: a buyout somewhat like the one Washington reached with North Korea to end its nuclear weapons program.
Even though Cuba has not fully ratified the treaty that makes Latin America a nuclear nonproliferation zone, the United States does not appear to think that Mr. Castro is intent on manufacturing an atomic bomb. Rather, American officials have repeatedly expressed concerns about the safety of the plant here, which uses an updated version of the VVER-440 Soviet design found in Eastern Europe.
Located in a rural sugar-growing area of the central province of Cienfuegos, the Juragua plant lies 260 miles south of Miami. A recent study by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration calculated that within four days of an accident here, radioactive pollutants could be carried as far west as Texas or as far north as Washington, D.C., depending on the prevailing wind patterns at the time.
Citing declarations of reactor technicians who later defected, Cuban exile groups and conservative think tanks like the Center for Security Policy maintain that the bulk of the Soviet-made materials used in the reactor are defective.
They also say that a high percentage of welds are flawed, that key pieces of equipment have suffered corrosion from prolonged exposure to the salty tropical air and that containment procedures are inadequate.
Rejecting those accusations as propaganda, Cuban officials note that the reactor project has consistently met all international guidelines. "We've just recently passed another inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency," said Rosa Elena Simeon, Cuba's Minister of Science, Technology and the Environment, in an interview in Havana.
In addition, officials have emphasized that the reactor here differs in several ways from the unit at Chernobyl, Ukraine, which in 1986 was the site of the world's worst nuclear accident. The smaller Juragua plant is a pressurized water reactor, rather than one that uses graphite, and has additional safety features including a secondary containment dome.
Cuba has also decided to equip the plant with Western-made controls and instruments, since the original control system no longer meets Russian safety standards. No provider has yet been chosen, but talks with Siemens of Germany were under way even before the suspension of the project, which throughout the 1980's was headed by Mr. Castro's son Fidel.
The project is being enthusiastically pushed by Russia's Nuclear Energy Ministry, which diplomats say has seen most of its customer base disappear and is under pressure at home to justify its existence. Cuban officials said the third partner they were seeking would earn back a $300 million investment in seven years, but it is not clear how many foreign investors are interested.
If completed, Juragua would be the first Soviet-design reactor to be built in the Western Hemisphere or in a tropical climate. Many of the safety and design changes being incorporated into the model V-318 reactor here are prototypes that have not been tested in other Soviet reactors in Eastern Europe, though the overall design is similar to plants operating in Finland and Hungary.
Harold Denton, the former director of the Office of International Programs of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, is one of the few American officials to have visited the plant. Because the Juragua plant raises security concerns, he said, "we ought to bend the rules a little bit" regarding the embargo "and allow cooperation on safety matters."
"If they really are going to finish this thing," Mr. Denton said in a recent telephone interview, "our only choices are to complain about it and not be actively involved, or try to find some way to interact with them and make sure they have as well-trained a staff as they can get."
Cuban officials said they would welcome the involvement of the American Government and would even be interested in buying equipment from American companies if allowed to. "We need only to reach an agreement," said Rodrigo Ortiz, who as Deputy Minister of Basic Industry is one of the supervisors of the nuclear power program.
In an effort to reduce American uncertainty about its nuclear program, Cuba let two American delegations visit the plant this month and meet with Cuban Government officials. Former military officers and disarmament experts toured the site first, followed on Feb. 16 by a team of nuclear physicists and other energy experts from the Natural Resources Defense Council, a Washington-based environmental lobbying group.
During their three-hour visit, the 10-member delegation from the council, accompanied by an American reporter, inspected the reactor building, which is about three-quarters finished. The bulk of the mechanical and electrical work remains to be done, and reactor components, bathed in grease to minimize corrosion, are being stored outdoors in corrugated metal sheds.
The head of the Cuban Government's nuclear regulatory agency promised that he would not succumb to any political pressure to finish the plant.
"Until it is proven from all points of view that our facility has the same degree of safety as those in the rest of the world, this plant will not be granted a license," said Fidel Santana, director of the National Center for Nuclear Safety.
But the Americans said it was unclear how the agency's independence would be protected. And they argued to their hosts that it would make more sense, economically and in terms of safety, for Cuba to exploit renewable forms of energy like biomass, especially the bagasse left over from the sugar harvest, and solar power.
Senior Cuban officials expressed interest in developing such programs, saying they were years away from developing promising offshore oil deposits. But they also indicated that they saw alternative energy sources as an eventual complement to the nuclear power plant, not as an immediate substitute.
"Nobody is more interested in not having to build this power plant than us," said Pedro Miret, a vice president of the Council of Ministers, the Government's top executive body. "But the problem is that we have no choice."

HEADLINE: 60 Miles to Baton Rouge: A Tiny Band of Marchers

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MOUNT AIRY, La., Feb. 23

 BODY:
Nathan Parker is a walking man. The other day he quick-stepped ahead of a tiny band of marchers, leading them around a long, green curve on the River Road in this little town northwest of New Orleans. The breeze from the Mississippi kissed his face as the words of the marchers' old civil rights spirituals drifted up against his back, pushing him toward Baton Rouge.
Mr. Parker, a retiree from New Orleans, is 58, and he has been marching for one civil rights cause or another for most of his life. He does not know whether this 60-mile march, against Gov. Mike Foster's attack on affirmative action, will register in the long history of such protests. He knows only that when the call came from the New Orleans chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., he had to get up and start walking. In the racial climate of 1996, these marchers say, standing still is the same as lying down. 
 "It's not fair," Mr. Parker said of an executive order, issued by Mr. Foster last month, to end race- and sex-based preferences in state hiring and contracting among those programs over which the Governor has control. "It's not right." Then Mr. Parker walked on.
This was not a Million Man March, only a symbolic local reaction to an act that was in itself largely symbolic: the Governor's executive order has no effect on programs that are protected by Louisiana or Federal law, and those programs account for most of the state's affirmative action operations.
Parading by the small wooden houses of blacks who live by the river, the marchers motioned for the onlookers to come along. Most of those watching waved back, and one man cheered, but none fell in step.
Indeed, as the marchers made their way through Mount Airy on Thursday, the day after they had set out from New Orleans, they numbered only about 20, all of them from the starting point, walking toward the State Capitol in Baton Rouge and a protest there on Saturday.
[The marchers joined about 6,000 protesters at the Baton Rouge rally, The Associated Press reported, while about 175 counterdemonstrating whites gathered about 12 blocks from the Capitol. There were no reports of confrontation between the two groups.
[The counterdemonstration was organized by the National Association for the Advancement of White People, founded by David Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan. Mr. Duke, who is running for the United States Senate from Louisiana, addressed the crowd, asserting that affirmative action discriminates against whites.]
Some marchers said their small number was not important. Others were disappointed, but none would concede that the era of the grass-roots protest had passed.
That method, they said, even in a modern age of E-mailed press releases and faxed declarations of outrage, is the best way to bring issues of race into hearts and living rooms, since you have to believe in something badly to blister your feet. And history has proved that if even only a few people come out to sweat and sing, reporters will sooner or later be on them like a duck on a June bug.
"I wish there had been more people," said Avery C. Alexander, a State Representative from New Orleans who is a 30-year veteran of civil rights marches. "But when you talk to someone in the year 2030, there will be a million people who will say they were here."
One difficulty in getting people out might be that the issues have become more subtle. Mr. Alexander, who is in his 80's, marched for the first time when Louisiana wanted to do away with free milk for babies in the 1960's. This is little different, he said, and to pretend otherwise "is the greatest lie ever told."
"Forty years ago we were struggling for something with great resolve," said Pat Bryant, an organizer of the trek who rode ahead of the marchers in his car, keeping watch for trouble, guiding them. "Now we are struggling to retain what we won."
If times have indeed changed since the 1960's, said Mr. Bryant, in one way nothing has. "We see the very same forces who tried to marginalize us before," he said, only with different tactics now. Mr. Foster, a Republican, announced his executive order while also declaring a state holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The Governor said he believed that Dr. King would have supported him. "He just wanted an end to all discrimination based on color," Mr. Foster said.
Mr. Bryant said the cause was simpler 40 years ago, when he was baptized into the civil rights movement as a child, trying to integrate the swimming pool at Morrow Mountain State Park in North Carolina.
His father was a Carolina minister who marched in the early civil rights days. "He showed me how to be a man," said Mr. Bryant, who now lives in New Orleans and is executive director of Gulf Coast Tenants, a group that battles inequality in housing and other services.
His father also showed him the value of the march as a tool, and Mr. Bryant said the tool still worked. Blacks have used economic boycotts and other weapons to fight racism, he said, and it may take a black economic boycott of Louisiana to make Mr. Foster retreat. But there will always be marches as the spiritual backbone of the effort, he said.
Although it may have been dwarfed in size by civil rights marches of the past, the New Orleans-to-Baton Rouge march mirrored them in many ways.
The marchers were fed along the way by churches, which also provided them places to sleep. They moved to the sound of spirituals. And they carried simple homemade signs that demanded fairness.
Behind them, moving at a crawl, was a short caravan of cars with window signs that said, "Join Us."
It gets hot in this part of Louisiana, even in February, and the sweat rolled off the marchers. Among them was a cadre of middle-aged men who for 50 miles carried a paper banner, four abreast, and never tore it once.
"Where else can black people be," said Mr. Bryant, "but marching?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: State Representative Avery C. Alexander, top left, marched to Baton Rouge, La., and was restrained in the Governor's Mansion yesterday as he protested an executive order against affirmative action. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD MUSCLE -- A special report.;
In Era of Shrinking Budgets, Community Groups Blossom

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the residents of a housing project had had enough of the pockmarked patchwork of drug corners and shuttered stores, so they formed a neighborhood group, worked with housing police and got Government money to start a nightly patrol.
In a neighborhood in Ozone Park, Queens, people who were distressed when the city slashed its budget for youth programs last year turned to their neighborhood association, which lobbied for a $5,000 city grant and rounded up volunteers to start after-school tutoring and art classes. 
 In Broad Channel, Queens, an island community used to meager political clout and little government largess, the revitalized neighborhood association's efforts have paid off with three new parks, a new school and a new library.
Across New York City and the country, neighborhood groups are growing in number and in strength, in some cases taking on responsibilities once the sole province of government, and in other cases turning themselves into effective lobbying groups for their communities.
Fueled by shrinking local, state and Federal budgets and armed with fax machines, newsletters, a mastery of legal nuance and enthusiastic members willing to give their money and time, they are moving beyond their traditional role of pestering officials to get potholes filled and streetlights fixed.
"People see a sort of decline in quality of life, institutions like the school system deteriorating around them, and they feel that they have to get involved," said Michael Krasner, an associate professor of political science at Queens College.
In New York City, the growth in these neighborhood groups -- voluntary organizations of residents in a community, some called civic associations -- is significant, according to experts. A survey by the Citizens Committee for New York City, which trains and advises such community groups, found that their numbers had grown to 8,000 last year from 3,500 in 1977.
Communities that never organized before are forming neighborhood associations, groups that had fallen apart or fallen silent have started making noise, and immigrants have found a voice in neighborhood life through such organizations. These groups are often banding together -- forming, for example, a coalition of communities and businesses in Flushing, Queens, or an umbrella organization of neighborhoods in Manhattan.
Many of these groups are becoming partners with government agencies: They are removing their own graffiti, hiring their own security guards, refurbishing their own parks and patrolling their own schoolyards.
Last year, City Council Speaker Peter Vallone added $3,000 from his own budget to help 16 Queens neighborhood associations and businesses buy bicycles for police officers in the 115th Precinct, which spans the communities of Jackson Heights, Corona and East Elmhurst. The residents had repeatedly asked city officials for the money -- $15,000 for 15 bicycles -- but finally decided to raise the money themselves.
"Five years ago, there wouldn't have been 16 groups to do this," Mr. Vallone said. "They wouldn't have thought they could get things done."
Robert H. McNulty, the president of Partners for Livable Communities, a nonprofit organization in Washington that advises communities and cities on how to solve economic and other problems, said: "Increasingly, as resources get scarcer and the public purse to afford the nice things in life, let alone the essential things in life, is greatly reduced, most of the angry citizens' groups that were there to protest have now turned to delivering services close to home. Now, instead of hand-biting, it's hand-shaking."
The number of neighborhood organizations in New York and across the country are not documented in any formal way, but all indications suggest that their numbers have swelled in recent years. Their growth mimics an increase seen in another group that has arisen in recent years to fill in for government cutbacks -- business improvement districts in which business and property owners pay to clean, patrol and upgrade their communities.
Nationally, one snapshot of the growth of these groups is the membership list of the National Association of Neighborhoods, a Washington organization that advises block associations and other citizens groups. Membership has jumped to 2,200 this year from 2,000 last year and 1,500 five years ago. And the group's director, Ricardo Byrd, said he had recently been peppered with calls from state and local governments seeking ways to cooperate with these groups.
In Austin, Tex., neighborhood groups volunteer their time to work with a Parks Department health and nutrition program for children. In Santa Barbara, Calif., a neighborhood responded to gang shootings by organizing a block-watching program. In St. Louis, one neighborhood association has a staff of about 40 people and has set up programs like a skills bank, in which people trade hours of baby-sitting for, say, hours of plumbing, Mr. McNulty said.
These groups are taking on "a very, very important role now, because as government prunes its services, they are going to be more involved in making sure the ones they cherish get preserved," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Institute. "What helps them is a crisis, and they have a crisis now."
In New York City, budget cuts are not the only force behind the growth of neighborhood groups. Political and demographic changes over the last decade have also contributed.
One factor, Mr. Krasner said, is "the decline of other institutions, the decline of political parties, the decline of the Democrats in New York City, and the disinclination of people, particularly younger people, to join political parties." In the past, these institutions would fight for their neighborhoods' share of city services and spending, considered the spoils of victory. But their influence has weakened as the role of clubhouse politics has declined.
Mr. Krasner said these institutions were seen by many as "a corrupt and dirty business that no right-thinking human being would want to get involved in."
"Civic associations are clean," he added, "They are not seen as dirty-dealing or political."
Another political force at work is the 1990 revision of the New York City Charter. The change eliminated the Board of Estimate and thus divested borough presidents of their board votes and much of their influence over the city's budget. Before the change, the borough presidents had been powerful advocates for community projects and dollars. Now, neighborhoods have found that they must vie for the attention of Council members, agency officials and the mayor's staff.
This has meant "less response on a local level to solve problems," said Sean Walsh, chairman of the United Civic Council of Queens, an umbrella group of 35 civic associations. "The borough president says, 'I ran out of money' and says 'Office of Management and Budget -- what can I do?' "
Immigrants in the city have found a new civic and political voice, spawning dozens of new groups in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. In Queens, for example, the Hillcrest Estates Civic Association had been dormant for years until George Yee, a real estate agent, revitalized it, drawing in many families from the neighborhood's growing Chinese-American community.
"A number of new emerging civic organizations are tied to immigrant populations, a Chinese association, an Indian women's group," said Alexandra Rosa, the chief of staff for Queens Borough President Claire Shulman. "The trend is that civic associations continue to be very, very focused on local issues, but they are beginning to focus on systemic issues, boroughwide issues and citywide issues."
Since these groups are largely concerned with neighborhood quality-of-life issues -- a campaign theme of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- some of them are a natural potential constituency for the Mayor. Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter said she often sat down with such groups, adding that "they're getting greater entree than they may have in the past."
Some politicians are promoting these constituents more actively. In Flushing, Queens, Councilwoman Julia Harrison encourages and helps residents to start civic associations, said her chief of staff, John Watts. Mr. Watts himself serves as president of a group called Coalition for a Planned Flushing, whose members include 45 civic associations, businesses and churches.
"The civic associations are the voters," said Mr. Vallone, the City Council Speaker. "The politicians are going to listen to the voters."
The effect of these groups, however, is difficult to measure. Even in cases where neighborhoods have got what they wanted, it is not always clear whether the associations were responsible for the changes, or whether other political or economic factors were at work. Still, communities that have weak citizens' groups or none at all seem to get noticeably left out. And, naturally, neighborhoods that are politically sophisticated fare better than those that are not.
"You can point to measurable differences for blocks that are organized," said Michael Clark, executive director of the Citizens Committee for New York City. "You can almost drive around and see the differences in the neighborhoods."
 
Start-Up
Winning the War In No-Man's-Land
In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, gunfire had been so common in the neighborhood around the Walt Whitman Houses housing project that at times "you couldn't even go to the grocery store and you had to be in by 5 P.M.," said Maxine Croft, 45, who has lived in the project almost all her life.
About a year and a half ago, Ms. Croft and another longtime resident, Roslyn Williams, began talking with housing police officers, as well as Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol about what they could do to make things better.
Officer Rafael Orozco helped them write a proposal for a $10,000 grant and Mr. Lentol's office helped them get the money. Their group, the Fort Greene Coalition, bought two-way radios and is presently training teen-agers to patrol the neighborhood and escort elderly residents to stores on Myrtle Avenue.
The Fort Greene Coalition, organized in a neighborhood that has long been improbable territory for such groups, is an example of the broader reach and increasing appeal of neighborhood associations, for both residents and politicians.
Traditionally, civic associations have been made up of homeowners in middle- class neighborhoods, and were especially prevalent and vocal in Queens. Poverty, transience and political disconnectedness have, in the past, left some residents of neighborhoods like Fort Greene feeling left out. But increasingly, residents in these neighborhoods are finding that they can get concrete results from these organizations and that politicians are learning that theirs are the voices of a neighborhood's voters.
Fort Greene is also an example of what is becoming one of the most successful civic formulas, the ability to cooperate with government officials and capitalize on government programs by finding pockets of government grant money at all levels or using neighborhood manpower to supplement government services.
"Before this, I don't know of a single group in Fort Greene that was really doing anything," said Ed Powell, the leader of Umma Group Inc., a Brooklyn organization that is training the teen-agers in the Fort Greene patrol. "The crime kept mounting. The fear in the community kept mounting. Before this, it was like a no-man's-land."
 
Expansion
Reaching Out To Newcomers
When Carl Giuffre and his girlfriend, Laura Snidersich, moved to the Tudor Village section of Ozone Park, Queens, last year, it did not take them long to decide that joining the Ozone Tudor Civic Association "just seemed like the thing to do."
Mr. Giuffre, a 34-year-old tow truck driver, had grown up in Queens but had never joined any civic group before. But over the summer, Mr. Giuffre found himself helping to prune trees, cut grass and paint mailboxes in the tidy neighborhood. Once, he even left work early to make civic meetings on time, showing up with his tow truck.
In the past, members of civic associations usually were people who believed in investing in their neighborhood because they had lived there for many years; many were older residents who had the time to attend meetings regularly and work for the group.
But increasingly, civic associations and neighborhood groups, even those that have existed for years, are building up their ranks with people like Mr. Giuffre, younger neighborhood newcomers who find a broad range of reasons for taking part in these groups. They are also reaching out to recent immigrants who have historically felt uncomfortable or unwelcome in such organizations. In this way, they are bringing in new constituencies that, experts believe, are making these groups stronger political forces.
The Ozone Tudor Civic Association has been around for decades, but has become increasingly active under its new president, Joseph Addabbo Jr. He has made a deliberate effort to reach new members, who pay dues, with the goal of sustaining the group's influence even when there is no urgent neighborhood issue.
"Every month we make sure we have some accomplishment to show people so that we get a few more people to come each time," Mr. Addabbo said. Last year, in an anti-blockbusting campaign against real estate agents who were trying to get residents to sell their houses, Mr. Addabbo got about 50 homeowners to sign "cease and desist" cards asking the agents to stop such soliciting. The cards were given to the local assemblywoman who had the state investigate some of the real estate agents.
Mr. Addabbo has also began planning family-oriented programs. He has held Halloween and Easter hunts and has sent a Santa Claus to bring gifts door to door.
More substantively, Mr. Addabbo led the drive for the city grant that allowed the neighborhood to plan its own youth program, complete with classes in computers, nutrition and art, bus trips to museums and bowling nights for parents and children.
"I thought it was the civic's place to pick up the slack," Mr. Addabbo said. "As everybody tries to fight for their slice of the pie, the civic is basically the army that's sent out to try to get as much as it can for its residents."
 
Lobbying Power
A Land Deal In Broad Channel
Just a few years ago, the 2,700 residents of Broad Channel had to make do with decaying school and library buildings and few places for their children to play.
They were also clashing with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which, in the interest of wetlands protection, was trying to force the residents to take down the boardwalks and decks attached to their houses.
Gradually, the Broad Channel Civic Association turned itself into a potent lobbying force. Rallied by the boardwalk issue, they bent the ears of everyone from Representative Charles E. Schumer to the deputy commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation. The result was a compromise that let the residents keep their wooden structures.
Peter Wierzbowski, a 30-year-old bank officer in Manhattan who moved to Broad Channel seven years ago, joined the group. A relative newcomer in a neighborhood where mostly working class families have lived for generations, he is one of a number younger professionals who are taking the helm of neighborhood groups.
"We've learned to be a little more official and document what we do, leaving a paper trail with letters to our elected officials," Mr. Wierzbowski said. "In the past when the politicians would come to a civic meeting, they would basically do a commercial. Now when there's a question-and-answer session, in more cases than not, they are put to the task."
Using these tactics, more than 60 Broad Channel residents won the right last year to buy the land beneath their houses, which they had long been forced to lease from the city.
The civic association also persuaded the city to fix up or build three new parks, a new school and a new library. And the group has raised thousands of dollars to help refurbish a baseball field, buying the clay and the backstops and asking the Parks Department for the laborers.
And when residents complained that they had to pay a highway toll just to mail a letter at the nearest post office in the Rockaways, the group persuaded officials to work out a discounted toll for people who live in Broad Channel.
"Now we're being a little more aggressive, seeking out issues that would improve the community, rather than just prevent harm from occurring," Mr. Wierzbowski said. "If they didn't have a civic association, people would move out, because it's a matter of survival as a community."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: SOUTH CAROLINA;
Dole Soldiers Are Set For Buchanan Brigade

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 24

 BODY:
The South Carolina Presidential primary looms a week away as a particularly redoubtable castle for Patrick J. Buchanan's self-proclaimed peasants to storm. The well-financed legions of the Republican state machine, loyal to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, are defending the primary as the critical gateway to a string of primaries that quickly follow across the South.
More directly than in other states, the Dole defenders here are drawing the line over the issue pressed by Mr. Buchanan: job losses in the global economy. Ranking Republican officials are going directly to the voters to argue that this state, now well into economic recovery, has benefited far more than it has suffered in the assorted job shifting of modern world trade. 
 The state Republican Party scheduled the primary on Saturday in an effort to give the winner an edge in the series of Southern primaries starting on Tuesday. South Carolina's state's primary helped President George Bush in 1992 in rebuffing a Buchanan challenge.
With former Gov. Lamar Alexander's campaign nowhere in sight yet, and Steve Forbes fading after early interest, Dole campaign workers are hoping for a one-on-one showdown with Mr. Buchanan that produces a dominant Dole performance.
"Stuff has got to happen now if we're to win this thing," the Dole state campaign chairman, Chris Neeley, said on Friday.
Seventy miles to the east, in Florence, a half dozen Buchanan supporters sipped soft drinks at a roadside Shoney's and planned to teach Mr. Neeley and Mr. Dole the difference between the comforting logistics of the party machine and the genuine insurgence of voters heeding a call to political arms.
"We are working in the boondocks where the little people are," said Barbara Leonard, a party chairwoman from the Sixth Congressional District, who is joyfully bucking the establishment's endorsement of Mr. Dole. To either side of her at the table, she counted Buchanan volunteers from the state's anti-abortion movement, from Ross Perot's third-party movement and from the state's troubled textile industry.
Such is South Carolina politics, where the campaign arts of Lee Atwater, the native-born legendary political consultant, were honed in behalf of Senator Strom Thurmond, President Ronald Reagan, and a generation of campaign opportunists who have succeeded him, reading his prescribed Machiavellianism.
"Lee would tell you, every politician is virtuous when he starts out," said Tim Petersen, a boyhood friend of Mr. Atwater, "but then he has to pay back his contributors."
Like many other South Carolinians, Mr. Petersen is not yet seized by the contenders in the fast-moving roulette of state primaries. Mr. Petersen, who owns Gilligan's barbecue grill, where he tracks and feeds the politicians, thinks that South Carolina voters will prove canny enough to recognize that Mr. Buchanan is as much a Washington politician as Senator Dole.
Mr. Neeley, the Dole chairman, is one of South Carolina politics' many Atwater wannabes. Only 28, he was handed the Dole job after directing the party's forces to a historic victory in 1994 when Republicans won a majority in the State Legislature for the first time since Reconstruction.
A full-time salaried party chief for the past year, while other campaigns were nowhere to be found, Mr. Neeley commands hundreds of loyalists in 46 counties under the twin banners of Gov. David Beasley and his predecessor, Carroll A. Campbell Jr.
From the castle ramparts, Dole radio and television commercials rain like arrows on Mr. Buchanan. He is being denounced for "extreme and dangerous" positions, a man who should be believed less for his latest empathizing with lunch-bucket voters than for his earlier opinions on extending nuclear arms in the world and characterizing women as less competitive than men.
Beasley and Campbell forces have been accusing Mr. Buchanan of focusing on selective job losses in some textile mills while ignoring the larger prosperity that the state says workers enjoy because of free-trade policies rooted in aggressively courting overseas markets.
"Nonsense," said Mack Todd, owner of a textile plant in Lake City, who agrees with Mr. Buchanan that the industry is so threatened by cheap foreign wages that competitors should face the threat of tariffs. "South Carolina people are the same as New Hampshire people, hearing the drumbeat about job security." Mr. Todd said. "I been telling my workers, 'Listen carefully to Mr. Buchanan. He's the only one talking about your job. Be sure to vote.' "
On the table at Shoney's lay a copy of The State newspaper with a banner headline about the loss of 400 textile jobs this week in the small town of Iva: "Upstate's Silent Looms Weaving Votes For Buchanan."
Contradicting the message of the article, Governors Beasley and Campbell appear in Dole ads against Mr. Buchanan's proposed tariff barriers. They insist that thousands of jobs have been added in a decade of statewide industry shifts and growth, with textile revenues more than doubling, to $6.6 billion a year.
"Ask Buchanan about the former textile workers who got better paying jobs at the new BMW plant in Spartanburg," Mr. Neeley declared, summarizing the Dole case.
The group at Shoney's flatly disbelieves such information, finding anecdotal evidence about troubled mill workers more convincing. Mr. Todd noted that executives from 17 textile companies took the unusual step of meeting together on Thursday in Lake City to challenge the state government's outlook.
Ms. Leonard, underlining the group's enthusiasm for Mr. Buchanan, said: "I'm tired of wimpy men in politics. Pat talks straight, not like a wimp." She said her candidate would do better in this primary than he did in 1992. Then, President Bush won with 67 percent of the vote, while Mr. Buchanan had 26 percent and David Duke, the former leader of the Klu Klux Klan, drew 7 percent.

HEADLINE: Exiles Say Cuba Downed 2 Planes And Clinton Expresses Outrage

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Two small aircraft belonging to a Cuban refugee and exile assistance group based here were shot down by Cuban Air Force MIG jet fighters off the northern coast of Cuba on Saturday afternoon, American Government officials and survivors of the incident said tonight.
President Clinton was immediately informed of the attack and tonight expressed his outrage at what he described as "the shooting down today in broad daylight of two American civilian airplanes by Cuban military aircraft." But he said the United States was not yet sure whether the confrontation had occurred over international waters or within Cuban territorial waters. 
 "I condemn this action in the strongest possible terms," Mr. Clinton said in remarks made in the suburbs of Seattle. He also said he has ordered the American Interests Section, which in the absence of normal diplomatic relations between the two nations is Washington's de facto embassy in Havana, "to seek an immediate explanation" for the attack on the two unarmed light planes.
A third aircraft was reported to have escaped the aerial confrontation and to have returned here after notifying American authorities of the attack. Four people, all of them Miami residents of Cuban descent, were said to be missing, and a United States Coast Guard search and rescue mission for them was underway tonight.
All three aircraft belonged to members of Hermanos al Rescate, or Brothers to the Rescue, a Miami-based Cuban exile group that specializes in plucking from the waters of the Straits of Florida people seeking to flee Cuba and reach the United States. Recently the group has also organized nonviolent protest flights over Cuban territory.
In a telephone interview this evening, Lt. Comdr. Marc Woodring, a spokesman for the Coast Guard here, said that a Coast Guard aircraft had located "two oil slicks, but that's about all" at "a position north of Havana" beyond the 12-nautical-mile boundary internationally recognized as the limit of Cuba's territorial waters.
Commander Woodring said two cutters were on their way to join a helicopter and a C-130 aircraft in "searching international waters for possible wreckage or debris," as well as possible survivors. Mr. Clinton said he had also ordered American military forces into the same areas to provide support for the Coast Guard operation and "to ensure that it is fully protected."
A White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, said the Coast Guard effort was being concentrated in an area about 18 nautical miles north of Havana. He added that the pilots had filed a flight plan indicating that their destination was not Cuba but the Bahamas, where the group regularly ferries food and other supplies to Cubans held in refugee camps.
American officials here said the group's flight plan would have been rejected had it indicated that the planes were bound for Cuba. George Llares, a spokesman for Brothers to the Rescue, said tonight that all three planes were engaged in "a normal search and rescue mission" when they were attacked at about 3:30 P.M., well outside Cuban territorial waters.
"I can guarantee they were in international waters," he said. Other members of the group identified the pilots of the plane that returned to Miami as Jose Basulto, leader of the organization, and Arnaldo Iglesias, and said both men were being questioned by United States Customs and other government officials tonight.
After being released, Mr. Basulto told reporters that as he approached the Cuban coast, "we called the Cuban authorities" and sent the appropriate transponder code to alert them of his plane's position, which he said was never any closer than 15 miles from Havana. He also said that "everything was recorded on tape," a copy of which he has supplied to American authorities.
Brothers to the Rescue was founded in 1991, when large numbers of Cubans began leaving the island on rafts and other rickety crafts, hoping to reach the United States and apply for political refugee status. The group was especially active during August 1994, when more than 30,000 Cubans took to the seas because of worsening economic and political conditions in their homeland.
But after the United States and Cuba signed an agreement last year that ended a 30-year-old American policy of granting political asylum almost automatically to Cuban refugees, the group shifted the focus of its activities somewhat. Though it continued to patrol the Straits of Florida in its Cessna Skymaster planes, it also began engaging in more overtly political actions directed against the Cuban Government.
In a incident last July that was widely publicized here, for instance, a Brothers to the Rescue flight buzzed downtown Havana and returned to a hero's welcome in Miami. The Cuban Government responded by moving antiaircraft guns to the waterfront and issuing a warning that it would feel free to shoot down any planes intruding into its airspace that it regarded as hostile.
Last month, another Brothers to the Rescue flight dropped hundreds of leaflets over Havana containing the text of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and condemning the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro. Several members of the group are former Cuban Air Force pilots or technicians, and as such have knowledge of Cuba's air defense system.
Cuban exiles have also clashed in recent months with the Cuban Armed Forces on the high seas, fanning the anger of exile groups to even higher levels. Last year, a flotilla of exiles protesting Mr. Castro's rule was rammed by Cuban military vessels, leaving one man dead and several others injured.
The attack on the aircraft occurred during a crackdown by Cuban authorities against dissidents and human rights campaigners on the island. More than 50 opposition figures have been arrested, detained or had their homes searched by Cuban state security officials during the last two weeks.
Those arrested have all been members of Concilio Cubano, a coalition of 130 opposition groups that had been scheduled to hold a national conference, its first, in Havana today. That meeting was called off earlier this week, though, as a result of the roundup of opposition figures.
