HEADLINE: What Happened to Fred Cuny?

BYLINE: By Scott Anderson; Scott Anderson has written for Harper's, Outside and other publications. This is his first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
ASA BASAYEV BELIEVES she saw him. "I remember him because he was very big and a little bit heavy," she said. We were standing on the front steps of the burned-out municipal building in Samashki, a small agricultural town in war-battered western Chechnya, and Basayev, an elderly woman with piercing gray eyes, was pointing toward the debris-strewn main street. "I saw him passing right by here," she said. I had come to Samashki, or what was left of it, with a small entourage -- a driver, a photographer and a translator -- and a question: What happened to Fred Cuny?
At the time of my conversation with Basayev, in early November, it had been seven months since Cuny, perhaps America's preeminent disaster-relief specialist, and three of his colleagues had disappeared in Chechnya -- and nearly three months since the international efforts to find them had been called off. They were presumed dead. The manhunt, one of the most extraordinary in recent times, had not uncovered where they had been killed or why. 
 Around midday on March 31, 1995, Cuny, along with two Russian Red Cross doctors, a Russian translator and a local driver, had set out from Sleptsovskaya, in the Russian republic of Ingushetia, and headed east through the Caucasus Mountains toward the Chechnya frontier. Cuny had been to Chechnya a few months earlier, just after the tiny Russian republic had become engulfed in a war of secession. His second trip was notable for its modesty: a quick humanitarian "needs assessment" tour of an area held by Chechen-separatist rebels. He planned to be back in Moscow in a week to brief the staff of the Soros Foundation, which was sponsoring Cuny's ever-more famous -- and ever-more risky -- guerrilla-style relief projects.
Four days after driving off in a beat-up Russian-made ambulance, the driver, Ruslan Muradov, turned up at the Soros Foundation offices in Nazran, Ingushetia's capital. He was alone and on foot, and bore a cryptic note from Cuny. Betraying little anxiety, Cuny explained in the letter that he and his team had been delayed in Bamut, a rebel-held mountain town. "Everything that's happened has, of course, knocked us off schedule," Cuny wrote. "Shooting on the road, bad weather, mud on the road. . . . [I]t's most likely we will still be held up for two or three days." A postscript added by Galina Oleinik, Cuny's Russian translator, struck a very different tone: "Everything above I wrote under Fred's dictation, and now I would like to say something for myself: we, as always, have gotten into a mess. The situation doesn't depend on us. . . . If we're not back in three days, shake everyone up."
Throughout the late spring and summer an unusual array of American investigators searched for the missing party: Cuny's son, Craig, and his brother Chris, F.B.I. and C.I.A. agents, American Embassy personnel and staff members from the Soros Foundation, which spent some $80,000 a month on its investigation. At one time or another Russian intelligence officers, Chechen rebel chieftains and even a Cossack historian turned detective and a Muscovite psychic said they were looking for the Cuny team. The case brought appeals from a host of international humanitarian agencies and drew the personal involvement of President Clinton and President Ruslan Aushev of Ingushetia, as well as that of both principal protagonists in the Chechnya conflict, President Boris Yeltsin of Russia and the Chechen secessionist leader, Dzhokhar Dudayev. Everyone, it seemed, was anxious to find Fred Cuny. No one did.
What searchers found instead was a thicket of rumors and wildly conflicting theories. Most implicated the Russian Army in some way -- a revenge killing for Cuny's very public denunciations of its brutal campaign in Chechnya. A number of Americans were convinced that the end had come at the hands of Russians in Samashki. Asa Basayev seemed to agree.
She recalled seeing Cuny about the time of "the storming." For three days early last April Russian ground troops laid waste to Samashki -- indiscriminately torching houses, machine-gunning people who crossed their path, dropping hand grenades into cellars where families hid. At least 125 residents were killed. Had Cuny happened upon the massacre-in-progress and been executed by the Russians to insure he would never live to tell?
The administrator of Samashki's small, rough-hewn hospital, keeps a black-and-white photo of Cuny -- one she obtained from a search party that came through in May -- under her desk's glass cover. While she herself did not see Cuny last April, she said that many in town as well as in villages nearby believe they did. Despite the claims of Basayev and others, I never found hard evidence that Cuny had been in Samashki when the assault began, and I don't believe that's where he died. Samashki, like so many of Chechnya's towns and villages, exists in an eery, apparitional twilight, where nothing is quite what it seems. Wandering around Samashki, I recalled what a State Department officer had told me about Chechnya and its war: "I've been in a lot of bad places around the world, but I've never encountered such a murderous, lying atmosphere anywhere like Chechnya."
Underscoring the Cuny mystery is a central riddle. The last documented sighting of the missing group was in territory held by the Chechen rebels, who appear to have had little motive for harming Cuny and his colleagues. The Russian Army may have had a motive -- Cuny's outspoken condemnation of Russian conduct in the war -- but there is no proof that Cuny ever entered territory they controlled.
TRYING TO FIND OUT WHAT HAPPENED TO FRED CUNY in Chechnya was further complicated by the nature of the man : a 6-foot-3, 51-year-old Texan who was well known in the world of international relief yet a mystery, even to close friends and colleagues. I had received an intimation of this in September at a reception held in his honor at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. A few weeks earlier Cuny's son and his brother ended their search in Chechnya and announced their belief that the members of the group were dead. Nevertheless, the Carnegie organizers had stressed that their event was to be a "celebration" of Cuny's life and work, not a memorial service. Sipping soda or jug wine from plastic cups, the 200 or so guests gathered in the eighth-floor conference room were a veritable who's who of humanitarian-aid politics and international disaster relief: presidents of nonprofit organizations, ambassadors and diplomats, Foreign Service officers. Even Anthony Lake, the National Security Adviser, was there.
Eventually the testimonials began, and they did not soon end. For a quarter-century Cuny had traveled the globe battling the disasters wreaked by both nature and man, and there were many Cuny victories to remember. "Fred always looked beyond an immediate crisis," Morton Abramowitz, the Carnegie Endowment president, remarked. "He saw how important it was not just to save lives, but how to restore a way of life." As the United States Ambassador to Turkey in 1991, Abramowitz had watched in astonishment as Cuny orchestrated the swift return of 400,000 Kurdish refugees from the Turkish border region to their homes in Iraq, a feat that not only averted a potential health catastrophe but quite possibly a military confrontation that could have imperiled the NATO alliance.
Aryeh Neier, for years the head of Human Rights Watch and now the president of the Soros Foundation, recalled how in 1992, with astonishing ingenuity and pinpoint planning, Cuny had restored Sarajevo's water and gas systems and introduced a seed program that enabled residents to supplement their subsistence diets with vegetables grown on their apartment terraces. "The contributions Fred made to that city," Neier said, "are simply beyond anybody's ability to describe."
On and on the stories went, an exotic litany of disasters -- famine in Ethiopia and Somalia, monsoons in Madagascar, an earthquake in Armenia, war in Biafra, Sri Lanka and Guatemala -- all somehow abated by the work of Cuny and his Dallas-based consulting company, Intertect. There were also lighter moments: reminiscences of Cuny's ability to tell very convincing tall tales; recollections of the way he entranced women, many women, with his soft-spoken charm; a story of the time he arranged for the Texas Lone Star flag to replace the Stars and Stripes in Sarajevo as the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John Shalikashvili, arrived on a state visit.
The accolades and anecdotes said much about Cuny -- an "American hero" in the words of several speakers -- but they also said a good deal about the treacherous post-cold-war landscape. The mid-90's are a time of messy wars in unfamiliar places -- places where borders are unclear and alliances tend to shift and blur. There has been a blurring, too, of the role played by those forces that respond to international crises, the nongovernmental organizations, or NGO's, involved in disaster relief and humanitarian assistance. Traditionally what protected these groups in such perilous places was their official neutrality, which staff members worked hard to maintain. But with less "superpower" resolve to bring these crises to an end, and more of the world's wars resulting in the wanton slaughter of civilian populations, aid organizations are increasingly involving themselves directly in social, political and even, at times, military matters.
Fred Cuny was the very personification of this phenomenon, a man working at the murky confluence of humanitarian assistance, diplomacy, military operations and intelligence -- the disaster specialist who in northern Iraq, to cite but one example, could commandeer United States Army helicopters to shuttle Kurdish guerrilla leaders across national frontiers. He had long since given up quietly cleaning up the damage the warriors had done; rather, he had become something of a warrior himself. The result was that in the Bosnias and Chechnyas of the world no one seemed to be really sure who Cuny was or what, precisely, he was up to. With his disappearance in Chechnya, a thousand hypotheses bloomed.
Even now, nearly a year after his disappearance, Cuny has not lost his power to fascinate. He remains a topic in the highest circles in Washington and Moscow, and among NGO types wherever they gather: in New York at the United Nations, in cafes in Sarajevo. Upon my return to Moscow from Chechnya, Thomas Pickering, the American Ambassador to Russia, set aside nearly two hours to question me on what I had learned, displaying a remarkable grasp of the most minute permutations of the myriad theories. Am American aid worker who had briefly assisted in the search last summer recently told me: "I find I'm constantly going over it in my mind, every little story or innuendo I heard. Not to be coldblooded about it, but a mystery like this only comes around once in a lifetime, if that."
It is a mystery that can be endlessly embroidered upon. As I left Samashki in the fall, an encounter at the Russian Army checkpoint on the western road produced a couple more random threads. By military fiat, Samashki had been "sealed" that morning -- declared off-limits to all but local residents -- and the checkpoint commander seemed somewhat chagrined to discover that an American journalist had slipped through the security perimeter. He decided to let the matter pass with a cautionary lecture.
"This is a very dangerous area for you to be visiting," he said. "Don't you know that another American has already disappeared here? His name was Fred Cuny. He was very famous, and that is where he disappeared." He pointed toward the low buildings and trees of Samashki. "You could disappear here, too."
With little prompting, he then offered a Cuny story of his own. "He was traveling with the [Chechen] terrorists and he came here to Samashki. We were able to learn even the house he was staying in. I gave all this information to the search party, but I don't know what they did with it, because I hear he is still missing. Maybe the terrorists killed him, or he was caught in a crossfire -- there was a great battle here, you know, and a lot of people died."
He gave a wry smile and motioned toward his own garrison, a muddy sprawl of bunkers, tank emplacements, mine fields and barbed wire. "It is even possible he was killed at a [Russian Army] checkpoint. After all, this is Chechnya, and you cannot trust anyone here."
SITTING IN THE GLASS ATRIUM LOBBY OF THE Freemanmillican engineering firm in Dallas, Damir Lulo recalled the last time he saw Fred Cuny. It was an evening last year in late March, just before Cuny left for Chechnya, and Lulo and his wife, Arida, had invited him over for dinner.
"There was something different about Fred that night," Lulo said. "He was quieter, more subdued than I think I'd ever seen him." Lulo had met Cuny in Sarajevo and worked with him on the water project there; his had been one of several Bosnian families Cuny had helped relocate to the Dallas area, lining them up with jobs and apartments. Cuny was more than a benefactor;Lulo considered him a close friend and made a point of getting together with him on those rare occasions when Cuny returned to his Dallas home from the world's hot spots. "I have to say I was worried about him that night," Lulo went on to say. "I think he was preoccupied by Chechnya."
Two months earlier, in late January, Cuny had made his first foray into the tiny Russian republic. The Russian military, having completed its carpet-bombing "pacification" of Grozny, the capital, was beginning to expand its campaign into the countryside, devastating villages and forcing the Chechen fighters into the wintry mountains. Under a broad-mandate contract from the Soros Foundation, Cuny had gone to Chechnya with a characteristically grandiose plan: to arrange a cease-fire between the Russians and the Chechen separatists, then lead an evacuation of the tens of thousands of civilians still trapped in the capital. Just a glimpse of Grozny told him it was futile.
Even Cuny, a veteran of some 30 war zones, had never seen anything quite like the Russians' total-war strategy in Chechnya or felt more helpless in ameliorating its effect. After meeting with several rebel leaders, including the Chechen military's commander in chief, Aslan Maskhadov, and overseeing the establishment of a small emergency medical team in the Ingushetia border town of Sleptsovskaya, Cuny left what he would later call "the scariest place I've ever been." According to a number of friends and associates, he returned to Dallas a somewhat changed man.
"I don't think Fred had really been prepared for how bad it was," said Rick Hill, Cuny's deputy at Intertect and now the acting director. "In most other war zones there's a certain method to the madness, and after awhile you learn the ground rules. In Chechnya, there were no ground rules. I think he was truly frightened by what he saw there, maybe for the first time in his life."
To Cuny's only child, his 29-year-old son, Craig, his father seemed uncharacteristically grave, even shaken, upon his return. Craig, who had spent time with his father in Sarajevo, recalled him saying: " 'Compared to Chechnya, Sarajevo had been a Sunday stroll.' He said that for sheer terror and unpredictability, he'd never seen anything like it."
But for Cuny, it seemed, fear quickly transformed into a kind of goad. Back in Dallas last March, he had the choice of a number of projects to which he could devote his considerable energies: a school reconstruction program in Albania, a water desalinization project in Bangladesh and, most ambitious of all, the establishment of what was to be called the International Crisis Group, a wholly new sort of nongovernmental organization that he and other disaster-relief specialists had been planning for some time, one that would take preemptive action against man-made disasters-in-the-making. Instead, as Cuny told Lulo at dinner last March, he was returning to Chechnya. "I thought it was a big mistake, and I was really very concerned about it," Lulo said. "After our dinner, I remember my wife and I followed Fred to his house in our car, which was not something we would normally do, and I said, 'Fred, why don't you go to Bangladesh instead?' He gave this sad sort of smile and said, 'Damir, I'm afraid the Bangladeshes of the world just don't interest me much anymore.' "
THE FIRST "BANGLADESH" TO CAPTURE CUNY'S Interest had been a modest one close to home: the plight of Mexican migrants in southern Texas. For people who knew the young Cuny it seemed a fairly surprising turn. Born the eldest of four boys to parents who had been theater people in New York before returning to their native Texas in 1952, Cuny was raised in Forest Hills, a neighborhod of Dallas, where his father managed a radio station. As a teen-ager, Fred thought of himself as a Goldwater conservative, and his youthful dream was to become a Marine pilot. He had started flying at 15 and received his license while still in high school. His plans were threatened when he was kicked out of Texas A&M and its R.O.T.C. program in 1964 --a prank went awry, the story goes, and his dorm room burned -- and they were dashed altogether a couple of years later when he was struck by a taxi while crossing a Houston street and one of his legs was shattered.
After his ignominious departure from Texas A&M, Cuny went south to the Texas Agricultural and Industrial College in Kingsville, where he studied engineering. It was there, as part of a class project, that Cuny began looking more closely at the way the local migrant workers and their families lived. "I think it was the first time Fred really came face to face with true poverty," his brother Chris recalled. "Practically overnight, he went from being this gung-ho, pro-Vietnam hawk to being a field organizer for the migrant workers." It also sent Cuny on the path of social crusader, a path he would follow the rest of his life.
He married while at Kingsville, and his son, Craig, was born there, but the marriage didn't last long, and Cuny went on to study city planning at the University of Houston. After graduating, he worked as a planner for a Houston firm, spending much of his time along the Texas-Mexico border, alleviating the problems of poor migrants with the kinds of practical solutions he would later become known for -- getting roads repaved, for example, to prevent stagnant pools of water from forming and disease-bearing insects from thriving. Then, in 1969, he found his way out of Texas and an outlet for his love of flying: he signed on with a relief agency to airlift supplies to famine-ravaged Biafra. What he saw there appalled him -- not only the callous indifference of the Nigerian Government but also what he considered the incompetence of international relief agencies. He returned to Texas and started his own consulting company, International Architects, or Intertect.
Outspoken and impolitic, Cuny criticized both nongovernmental and government entities, like the Agency for International Development, for having too many remote policy planners at the top and too many inexperienced "do-gooders" in the field. Cuny pressed for hard-nosed solutions that took the local culture and economy into account and could yield benefits long after the crisis passed. He devised simplified plans for latrine design. He advised that refugees be grouped in refugee camps by village and that their tents be arranged not in rows but around an open central area so villagers could gather. He believed in the self-help powers of hand tools and plastic sheeting.
In the mid-1980's, Cuny's focus began to shift -- away from natural disasters and increasingly toward those made by man, specifically war. "I think Fred began to realize that even he couldn't do much preemptively against a tidal wave," Rick Hill said. "Man-made disasters gave him more room for creativity." Perhaps Cuny, always restless and drawn to adventure, saw war as the ultimate challenge. As Hill put it, "Frankly, I think he liked the adrenaline rush it gave him."
This shift also marked the beginning of his acceptance into the upper echelons of American foreign policy making. He secured a place for himself one morning in April 1991 when he sat down with the American Ambassador to Turkey, Morton Abramowitz at the U.S. Air Force base in Incirli, in southeastern Turkey. Turkey, a NATO member, had been warring with its own restive Kurdish population and was now confronted with 400,000 Iraqi Kurds, who had just streamed across the frontier into Turkey to escape the onslaught of Saddam Hussein's army in the wake of Operation Desert Storm. Quite suddenly, the American military in the region found itself diverted from its war to something dubbed Operation Provide Comfort -- the goal being to return the Iraqi Kurds to their homes before an epidemic broke out in the squalid refugee camps or the Turkish Kurds began trying to draw their Iraqi brethren into their fight.
Ambassador Abramowitz had gone to operation headquarters in Incirli to discuss possible strategies with American military commanders. "Fred came to see me," Abramowitz recalled, "and he said, 'Look, I've got a plan -- we can get all the Kurds back home and resettled in two months.' Well, I'd been in Turkey for 18 months, Fred had been there for two days, and I said, 'That's great, Fred, but you're out of your goddamned mind.' He didn't blink an eye, just kept talking -- like Fred often did -- and by the end of two hours, he even had me convinced."
Going directly to Kurdish guerrilla leaders and tribal chieftains in the refugee camps, Cuny worked tirelessly to convince them that the American military would provide protection if they returned to Iraq. To buttress the point, Cuny commandeered American Army helicopters to shuttle the Kurdish leaders back to their homes so they could judge the situation for themselves.
"No one gave Fred authorization to do that," Abramowitz said, and laughed. "And no one deputized him to run the operation. Fred simply saw the vacuum there and he stepped in and filled it."
But Cuny's success in Kurdistan, and later in Bosnia, raised eyebrows. The huge water-filtration system he had built for besieged Sarajevo was flown into the city on American military transport planes; how did he swing that? The Bosnian Serbs manning the airport checkpoint never stopped the trucks hauling the system to town in parts; how did he swing that? These were not simply technical solutions to disasters. Cuny was undertaking direct negotiations with armies and rebels. He was a long way from Bangladesh.
Aid workers began whispering among themselves that Cuny might have a more than informal connection to the American intelligence community. There was almost certainly no such connection. Nevertheless, Cuny seemed to enjoy the talk, and not infrequently fueled it. Even those closest to him wondered at times what deals he made, and with whom. When asked how Cuny had managed to get the transport trucks past the Bosnian Serbs at the Sarajevo airport -- it was the Bosnian Serbs, after all, who were trying to strangle the city in every way -- Rick Hill of Intertect grinned and replied, "I never did figure out exactly how Fred did that."
Questions of how things get done can take on a life-and-death importance in war zones, for they can very quickly lead to the essential question: Which side are you on? Relief specialists and aid workers have traditionally gone about their work in ways to insure that the question never comes up. But in recent years, in Bosnia and Somalia and elsewhere, the role of nongovernmental organizations has become both larger and less strictly neutral, and this has not gone unnoticed among the warriors.
Ambassador Pickering acknowledged that this new role carries considerable dangers. "I think there's been a growing sense in the past few years of the need to intervene preemptively to forestall crises, and governments have found that nongovernmental institutions can be useful in these situations," he said. "What you are starting to see is [humanitarian] assistance deliverers playing a mediatory role in resolving problems in a way that governments often can't. The downside for these people is that it puts them at risk at a time when military types are becoming increasingly paranoid. And the smaller the conflict, the greater the paranoia."
At the time he was planning his return to Chechnya late last winter, perhaps no one in the field was more at risk than Fred Cuny. And yet he did nothing to cool things down -- no avowing neutrality, no keeping a low profile. Quite the opposite, in fact: for Cuny, Chechnya had became something of a crusade. In a much-discussed article published in The New York Review of Books last spring he described the Russian military in Chechnya as "bogged down in a fruitless combat for an objective that is ultimately meaningless." A few days after his dinner in Dallas with Damir Lulo, Cuny flew to Washington, where he met with people on the Hill and excoriated the Russian military's brutal tactics in Chechnya.
The following afternoon he was ushered into a conference room at the State Department to expound on the topic. Among the dozen or so in attendance were most of the department's top officials responsible for Russian policy. "I've never sat in on a briefing quite like it," an official who attended the meeting said. "Cuny must have talked for over an hour. I don't think any of us up until that time had really grasped just how bad the situation was, the absolute depravity of the Russian [military] operation. And I don't think you can overestimate the impact that Cuny's talk had on those of us in that room. In fact, I think if you go back and chart this thing, you'll see that it was when guys like Fred Cuny started coming in and talking to us that American policy on Chechnya changed."
Whether or not Cuny's lobbying was behind the Clinton Administration's stepped-up criticism of Russia's campaign in Chechnya, he was seen as someone with a role in shaping American foreign policy. It was a perception that began to set off alarm bells in a number of places. Particularly anxious was the Soros Foundation, which, at the behest of its founder, the billionaire-financier George Soros, had begun financing several of Cuny's projects after his success in Kurdistan.
Not long after setting up operations in Russia in 1987, the Foundation became the target of a persistent whisper campaign there charging it with being a C.I.A. front. Those whispers grew louder through early 1995; it was precisely the kind of Soros projects that Cuny was planning in Chechnya and neighboring Ingushetia -- refugee assistance, medical relief to Chechen war victims -- that seemed most suspicious. Then on the morning of March 21, three aid workers under contract to Soros who were based in Ingushetia -- Galina Oleinik, Andrei Sereda and Sergei Makarov -- were among a group of travelers stopped at a particularly notorious Russian Army checkpoint near Assinovskaya, a village in western Chechnya. After being interrogated for several hours and threatened with execution if they didn't "confess" to carrying supplies to the Chechen guerrillas, the three women detained, Oleinik among them, were hustled aboard an army helicopter and taken away for further interrogation by the Russian Federal Security Service (F.S.B.). According to Oleinik, the women were inexplicably left at an airport without any guards. Rather than wait for their F.S.B. interrogators to show up, they hitched a ride back to Nazran, the capital of Ingushetia. There, Oleinik was able to win the release of the three men still held in Chechnya, quite possibly saving them from execution.
In the wake of the Assinovskaya incident, several Foundation officials urged George Soros to consider ending the mission in the northern Caucasus or, at the very least, to remove Cuny -- whom they viewed as increasingly and noisily partisan. At this critical juncture, Cuny arrived in Moscow planning to enter a Chechnya that had grown ever-more treacherous in the months since his first visit. At many of the isolated army checkpoints Russian units were operating as little more than autonomous armed gangs, detaining, robbing and sometimes murdering travelers at random. Meanwhile, a bunker mentality had set in among the Chechen rebels, fueled by persistent reports that the Russians were infiltrating their areas with spies and agent provocateurs. The separatist rebels, or boyeviki, had begun to view any outsider as a potential enemy.
Despite the fact that a dangerous place seemed to be growing more so every day, at a meeting on March 29 the Soros administrators in Moscow bowed to Cuny's considerable powers of persuasion and agreed to extend, at least temporarily, his projects in Chechnya and Ingushetia. But they did suggest two precautions. Before leaving Moscow, Cuny was advised to first meet with Sergei Kovalev, a highly respected human rights activist who had recently returned from the northern Caucasus and knew the current situation intimately. And before considering any venture into Chechnya, Cuny should wait in Ingushetia for the arrival of Slava Mihailovich, the Soros liaison who had been overseeing the Foundation's projects in the northern Caucasus and who was en route to Ingushetia with a convoy of relief supplies.
Cuny did neither. Instead, after meeting American Embassy officials, he boarded a flight from Moscow to Ingushetia on the morning of March 30. The very next day he set out for western Chechnya accompanied by the three Soros contract employees -- the translator, Oleinik, and the two doctors, Sereda and Makarov -- who had been detained there 10 days earlier. Eschewing the paved highways that cut across the Chechen plains, the party took a grueling dirt road that led to the very heart of the Chechen war.
It was not until mid-April, some 10 days after the driver returned to Ingushetia alone, that concern over the group's whereabouts escalated to alarm. Back in Dallas the news rekindled an uncomfortable sense of premonition in Damir Lulo. "As we drove away from Fred's house that night," Lulo said, "my wife turned to me and said, 'You know, I don't think we're going to see Fred again.' "
SOON AFTER CUNY WAS REPORTED MISSING, AMERICAN officials in Moscow and Washington took note of a disturbing trend: right-wing Russian newspapers were carrying outlandish reports that Cuny was alive and well -- and working directly with the Chechen rebel leader, Dzhokhar Dudayev, as a C.I.A.-sponsored adviser. The source of these reports, the State Department privately concluded, were high officials in Russia's F.S.B., the domestic branch of the old K.G.B.. To officials in the United States this smacked of a disinformation campaign and suggested that the Russians had something to hide. Had they killed Cuny?
"Why come up with these absurd stories that Cuny is alive and working with Dudayev?" one State Department official asked. "About the only conclusion you can make is that these guys [in the F.S.B.] are throwing all this out because they're trying to cover up."
In Moscow in the fall, I met with the F.S.B. press attache, Aleksandr Mikhailov, at his office on Lubyanka Square in the old K.G.B. headquarters. "Who was Fred Cuny?" he asked rhetorically upon hearing Cuny's name. He was seated behind his desk and smoking a cigarette. "We had never even heard of Cuny until after he and the others went missing. At that time, we were asked by the American Government to help search for them, and we did so. We had our people in the field look, we contacted all the [Russian] Army commanders in the region, but we have never been able to say definitively what happened -- only that our forces were not involved in any way."
And the stories in the newspapers?
"Are there no irresponsible journalists in your country who make up stories?" he asked. "Well, we have journalists who do the same. The F.S.B. has never told these stories." (Last month, Mikhailov was stripped of his post after acting as spokesman for the Russian Government's ever-changing account of the Chechen hostage-taking fiasco in the village of Pervomayskoye.)
The specter of high-level Russian involvement in the disappearances added a whole new layer of intrigue to the hunt for Cuny. Through the summer, a steady stream of current and former American Government employees trekked to Chechnya to assist in the search -- C.I.A. agents, political affairs officers, a retired defense-intelligence colonel, even two F.B.I. agents. In Moscow, Ambassador Pickering held regular status-report meet himself confirming, Cuny was in the Bamut region -- a region held by Chechen rebels?
And what of the fact that they were detained by rebels for at least four days?
It was clear, however, that Gilayev did not want to talk about Cuny in detail. He had given his answer. The matter was closed.
IN CALLING AN END TO THEIR search in August, Cuny's brother and son posited their theory of what had happened to the missing group, blaming both sides in the war in roughly equal portions. Just before the group's arrival in Bamut, the Cunys charged, Russian intelligence agents had begun a disinformation campaign in the Bamut area suggesting that Cuny and the others were anti-Chechen spies. Duped by this "black operation," the Chechen rebels had seized and murdered the party. It was a theory the United States Government carefully shied away from endorsing, and for which there was really only one piece of concrete evidence: a "spy list" said to have circulated around Bamut carrying the names of Cuny, the translator and the two Russian doctors.
Even before arriving in Chechnya I had come to doubt this theory. In Moscow I had learned that after the Assinovskaya checkpoint incident in which the doctors barely escaped with their lives, they had been barred from returning to Chechnya by their Soros superiors. While they obviously disobeyed the directive when Cuny arrived in Ingushetia on March 30, how could Russian intelligence agents have known they would do so in time to draw up a "spy list" and circulate it around Bamut?
Eventually, near the end of my journey, I got to put this question to a Chechen fighter I will call Magomet. (He requested anonymity for fear he would be killed.) It was in Grozny, the capital, in a neighborhood that had been heavily damaged by the Russian shelling last winter. Magomet had worked on one of the Chechen search parties organized in the summer, and I had been advised to seek him out -- that he had let slip certain things that suggested he knew more than he had let on. After spending an afternoon walking around the devastated streets of downtown Grozny, he took me to a bomb-damaged house in the suburbs, where we would spend the night. Sitting at a kitchen table, and talking by candlelight while sporadic fighting went on half a mile away, Magomet began to tell me what he knew about Cuny.
"I know what happened, and there is no longer any reason for the truth not to be told," he said.
He said that Cuny and the others were executed by a band of renegade boyaviki. It happened in a bunker in the woods outside Stary Achkoi. It was on April 14, around 2 in the afternoon. There was a six-man firing squad.
"It was because the Russians sent this spy list into the area, and some of the more wild boyaviki believed it," he said.
Why didn't they kill them outright? I asked. And if they were held for 10 days, how could local commanders not have known?
"Well, maybe somebody knew," he replied warily. And as the night wore on, he began to acknowledge that two commanders, then three, then five, had known the group was being held. What was impressive in Magomet's account were the details: the precise location and time of the execution, even names of some of those in the firing squad.
The following morning his account took a new turn. "I've got something more to tell you," he said as he made tea. He seemed troubled. In a soft voice he went on to say that it went beyond local commanders -- that the final order to execute Cuny and his team had come from Gen. Abu Musayev, who was the head of Chechen counterintelligence and one of Dzhokhar Dudayev's closest advisers as well as a member of the Cuny search team Dudayev established last spring. The reason Cuny and the others were held so long, Magomet said, was that the rebels were waiting for approval from on high. "It was because of that spy list," he said again. "We were fooled."
But that's impossible, I said. The Russians couldn't have known who would be traveling with Cuny in time to have created such a "spy list." As I told Magomet what I knew about the doctors being barred from traveling to Chechnya, he became increasingly anxious and finally began to cry. "I am ashamed," he said. "Fred Cuny came here as a friend of the Chechen people and we killed him."
But why would the Chechen rebels murder such a friend?
IN MID-NOVEMBER, THE Russian authorities received a videotape from a boyeviki commander directing them to a popular Moscow park. They found buried there a 30-pound box bundled with explosives and laden with non-weapons-grade radioactive material. The Chechens had placed it there; it was a bold warning that the separatists were not only prepared to carry the war into the heart of Russia but also that they possessed radioactive material.SCOTT: FIX
Since almost the beginning of the war in Chechnya, the separatists' leader, Dudayev, has hinted that his forces possess nuclear weapons. If Dudayev actually does have them, there is one place under his control they are most likely to be: the old nuclear missile base in Lower Bamut. The Russian Government maintains that all missiles were removed from Bamut five years ago, and all nuclear material with them. Yet even if this is true -- and, given Russia's record on keeping track of its radioactive material, there is every reason to doubt it is true -- one can imagine that the Chechens would not want their bluff called.
Nowhere I traveled in Chechnya were the rebels more edgy than in Bamut, and nowhere have outsiders faced a more terrifying reception. One Russian journalist who was taken prisoner there in May was made to dig his own grave and was mock executed every morning for six days before finally being released. The group I traveled with was also detained there for a time one day, and threatened. Two cameramen with the independent Russian television network NTV disappeared in the vicinity of Bamut last June. Like Cuny and his team, they have never been found.
There would seem to be one factor determining whether a visitor to Bamut lives to tell, or not. I, like most other journalists who have made the journey, was stopped in Upper Bamut and barred from going farther. By traveling with Ruslan Muradov, a Bamut native, Cuny and the others had managed to enter Lower Bamut, the site of the nuclear missile base. Cuny surely knew of the base: did he imagine that his driver would protect him? Was he looking for something? No one will ever know. But as they drove into Lower Bamut on the afternoon of March 31, their fate may well have been sealed. Whatever they saw there -- or whatever the Chechen high command feared they saw there -- was perhaps too important to risk letting them live.
In the kitchen in that wreck of a building in Grozny, I tried this theory out on Magomet.
"I don't know, " he said warily. "I don't know what is in Bamut, except that it is a very bad place to go." He produced a map, and trailed a finger along the highways leading from Ingushetia into Chechnya. "They had the choice of all these roads," he said. "They are all good highways and were open at the time -- they could have passed with no difficulty. There was no reason to go to Bamut. It was crazy."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
No Park Is an Island, As Yellowstone Proves

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT isn't possible to wrap a national park as if it were a compact disk. Developments outside a park's boundaries can seep in, and what happens inside can be felt beyond the broadest borders.
That is why a United Nations conservation committee voted in December to designate Yellowstone National Park a World Heritage Site in Danger, citing plans to dig a big gold mine just outside the park. 
 Indeed, economic growth in the greater Yellowstone region -- an area much bigger than the park itself, which is sometimes called the largest nearly intact natural ecosystem in the temperate zone -- is "one of the greatest long-term threats to the ecological integrity of Yellowstone National Park," said Michael Finley, the park superintendent. The populations of some communities are growing at the rate of 4 percent a year, he said, and if nearby counties in Idaho, Wyoming and Montana that surround the park were taken together as a single state, it would be one of the fastest growing in the country.
The biggest dispute over growth at the moment involves plans by Noranda Minerals Inc. to build a huge gold-mining operation in the Gallatin National Forest in Montana, just outside the Yellowstone boundary. Environmentalists warn that the mine's tailings impoundment, where acidic waste rock would be stored, would threaten streams that flow into the park and wetlands that provide important habitat nearby. An environmental impact statement is being drafted, and the Clinton Administration has been putting up other barriers to the development.
The mine's opponents are worried about more than water pollution, which they say could be especially serious if a catastrophic earthquake were to shake the area, where hot springs and geysers testify to the inherently unstable terrain. Phil Hocker, president of the Mineral Policy Center, an environmental group that focuses on mining issues, said that if the mine were built, the road east of the park from Cooke City, Mont., to Cody, Wyo., would be plowed all winter. That will inevitably increase traffic through the park on the section of road from Cooke City west to Gardiner, Mont., he said, and that will mean more winter visitors.
Indeed, the increase in winter visits to the park is just one of the new stresses it faces from beyond its borders, its managers say. Although far more people visit in the summer months, the number who come in the winter is also growing about five times as fast as those who come in summer, partly because many winter visitors are not traveling from afar, but live within easy driving distance of the park and come back repeatedly.
In 1990 the park wrote a 10-year estimate of the increase in the number of winter visitors; the projections for the year 2000 were surpassed in 1992, Mr. Finley said.
Snowmobiles are one of the most popular ways to visit the park in winter: up to 2,000 enter each day at the season's peak. But their noise and exhaust cause environmental problems. They can disturb wildlife in a season when food is scarce and bodily energy must be conserved, and they emit significantly more carbon monoxide and particulate matter than cars.
The Park Service has begun researching the problems. In one partial remedy, a new "green" lubrication oil for the snowmobiles' two-stroke engines is being sold at park refueling stations. (Unlike auto engines, two-stroke engines mix the oil that lubricates them with the gasoline that they burn.) But Mr. Finley has also called for public meetings this month to discuss whether to limit snowmobile access. It's not an easy question, he said; limiting access inside the park might just push snowmobiles out into already overcrowded national forests nearby.
As the snowmobiles migrate into the park every winter, the park's bison migrate out, sometimes onto adjacent cattle-grazing land. There, hundreds of them are shot each year because ranchers fear that they spread brucellosis, a bovine disease. Under legal pressure from the State of Montana, the park has proposed a new, temporary plan for controlling the bison, capturing them or chasing them back into the park when possible, testing them for the disease, and allowing them to range unmolested on some public lands outside the park. Infected bison or those that trespass too far will be shipped to slaughterhouses.
In Yellowstone Lake, meanwhile, foreign trout have arrived. Lake trout, introduced accidentally or illegally, were discovered there two years ago, and they are decimating the native cutthroat-trout population. Unless costly steps are taken, park officials say, the world-famous cutthroat fisheries in the Yellowstone River between the lake and the upper falls will be destroyed. As always, there will be a ripple effect: 42 species of mammals and birds, including bald eagles and grizzly bears, eat the native trout.

LENGTH: 692 words

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Trump's Michelangelo

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
MICHAEL IRVIN carries a beeper and drives a BMW. "I'm no starving artist," he said affably, contemplating the latest of 30 murals he is painting for the Trump World's Fair Casino, opening in April.
"I am paid extremely well for my work," he added. "I could drive a Porsche, but I don't have to. I'm not that kind of a guy." 
 Nor, Mr. Irvin insisted, is Donald J. Trump, who for three years has been his patron and, in Mr. Irvin's words, "a close personal friend."
"If the truth were known, Donald's more a normal kind of guy than you'd think," Mr. Irvin said. "He doesn't believe in paying $80 million for a van Gogh. He'd ask me to paint it instead."
He mentioned a mural he painted in the nursery at Mr. Trump's private apartment at the Trump's Castle casino hotel. It shows Mr. Trump's wife, Marla, as a mermaid, looking over their daughter's crib. "They really love it," he said.
Mr. Irvin, 32, a Detroit native, freely talked of parties he attended with Mr. Trump, meetings at which he advised Mr. Trump on casino design details, tete-a-tetes in which the two analyzed each other's signatures, and their philosophy about art.
They met after Mr. Trump saw a 1993 CNN feature depicting Mr. Irvin as an entrepreneur who was thriving in a recessionary economy. Mr. Trump had a project in mind.
"He wanted me to paint 'the biggest picture in the world' on the Taj Mahal parking garage," Mr. Irvin said. "I took a look at the Taj and tried to see myself hanging on a scaffold, working for a year outdoors in all kinds of weather for $2 million. I told him I'd rather work indoors."
He went on to paint some 20 murals and trompe l'oeil design details in the Taj Mahal in such unlikely locations as the casino's simulcast betting area and around the hotel's indoor swimming pool.
An entirely self-taught illustrator, Mr. Irvin dropped out of art school and barely survived as a freelance artist until, at 22, he sold his services to a suburban Detroit shopping mall. For $10,000 he painted a trompe l'oeil mural of a mall shop on the Sheetrock and plywood used to cover an empty storefront. Alfred Taubman, the shopping mall developer and chairman of Sotheby's, the fine-art auction house, was so impressed that he had Mr. Irvin do similar work at other malls.
"As the economy got worse, more stores closed, and every time a store closed in one of his malls, I got another job," Mr. Irvin recalled. "And it wasn't just covering up empty space. I was a legitimate attraction. People would come up to me and talk to me while I worked."
Of the 200 murals he has painted in 10 years, Mr. Irvin estimates that about half were of the "disposable" variety in shopping malls. Others, he said, still hang in hotels and banks.
In 1993, Mr. Irvin said, he was paid as much as $70,000 for a mural, "and that didn't include the paint." He said he took a pay cut when he moved to Atlantic City to become the full-time executive creative director at the Taj Mahal.
Mr. Irvin resigned from the Taj Mahal in October when Mr. Trump commissioned him to paint 30 murals for the conversion of the Trump Regency Hotel, now a part of Trump Plaza, into the World's Fair Casino.
Since November, Mr. Irvin and his assistant, Susan Daly, have worked on this commission nearly every day. They spend about two days sketching the mural from photographs and period detail supplied by a researcher, then three to four days painting canvases ranging in size from from 5 by 9 feet to 18 by 20. Each mural represents a world's fair or national exposition from history in a Social Realist style reminiscent of Thomas Hart Benton.
Next month Mr. Irvin will do his first work for casinos that are not in the Trump family, but he said he expected to do more work for his patron in the future.
"There's one large unpainted space that could be a mural, and there's talk of me doing one that would, you know, honor Donald," Mr. Irvin said. "But we'll have to be careful how we hang it. This is a casino and his name is on it, and people do lose money and occasionally get mad. It makes sense not to put anything with Donald's picture on it where people can get to it."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
All for One, One for All

BYLINE: By MARK GREEN; Mark Green is New York City's Public Advocate.

 BODY:
AT first it doesn't sound very cooperative, I admit. The day after the Regional Plan Association released its third long-range plan, warning of dire consequences if the people and governments of the tristate metropolitan region didn't work together to solve common problems, my office released a report that was sharply critical of the most important interstate agency we have: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The report documented how the agency -- which operates the region's major airports and shipping ports, the Hudson River crossings, the PATH system and much else -- has systematically favored New Jersey over New York in the last 15 years, spending 52 percent of its capital budget on New Jersey even though that state accounts for only 29 percent of the port region's population and 34 percent of the Port Authority's revenues. 
 New Jersey operations of the Port Authority lost $588 million from 1980 to 1993, while New York operations generated $669 million. And the authority heavily subsidizes drivers and riders from New Jersey. Although the city subway fare has increased three times since 1987, to $1.50 today, the PATH fare is still $1; round-trip tolls on the Hudson River crossings are $4, compared to $6 for crossings of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Why, we asked, should city straphangers, who make 50 percent less on average than New Jersey PATH riders, pay 50 percent more to get to work, especially since subway fares pay 60 percent of operating costs, while PATH fares pay just 25 percent?
I don't expect New Jerseyans to fork over extra money cheerfully every time they cross the Hudson just to satisfy New Yorkers' sense of fairness. But the larger point of our critique of the Port Authority -- like the point of the R.P.A.'s new long-range strategy -- is that the relationship between the states needs to be looked at in a new way.
Instead of perpetuating disparities that fuel interstate rivalry, we need a regional ethic of all for one and one for all. Unless we figure out how to finance capital investment so we have a seamless, efficient transportation system linking New York and New Jersey, the suburbs and the central cities, we won't be competitive with Munich, Paris, London, Phoenix and the Pacific Rim in the global economy of the 21st century.
While all of us like low fares and tolls, the Port Authority's patterns of investment in New York have put the entire region at a disadvantage. Simply equalizing fares and tolls could generate $170 million a year. The authority could use this money to finance $1 billion for redevelopment in the port region. These additional funds would create thousands of construction jobs and begin the task of upgrading and extending the region's transportation system.
While New Yorkers are of course concerned about any bias in capital spending, we are equally concerned that interstate bidding wars for jobs have served only to deplete needed public revenues for investment and encouraged companies threatening to flee. We need to develop a truly regional body that will be able to resist corporate extortion, represent all of our interests fairly, integrate our mass-transit systems and create economic growth in our inner cities.
While there is no shortage of work to be done in New York City, Newark or the entire metropolitan region, there has been a shortage of economic vision and political will. Just as the founders of the Port Authority, like the authors of the first regional plan in 1929, had a vision for the metropolitan region, we must decide what our future will look like -- and develop ways to finance it.
In light of the Regional Plan report and our critique, I urge the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to bring together leaders from all over our region to begin a discussion of how to work together better to expand our lagging economy. We cannot afford to enter the 21st century with a plan from the early 20th.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Reasons to March: Bill Bradley on the Costs of Poverty and Racism

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt from "Time Present, Time Past" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1996), a political memoir by Senator Bill Bradley.
Thirty-seven million Americans live in poverty. Ten million are black. Nearly 54 million Americans earn under $35,000 a year. Slightly more than eight million of them are black. Almost six million of the country's 97 million households earn over $100,000 a year. Of these households, 170,028 are black. When it comes to distribution of wealth, the disparity is even greater. The median net worth for white households in 1991 was $44,408. For black households, it was $4,604.
The problem of the poor is inadequate economic growth unfairly shared. When growth soars, the wealthy benefit disproportionately, which partly explains why the wealthiest 0.5 percent of Americans own 37 percent of the financial assets and 56 percent of all private business assets. When economic growth plummets, the wealthy lose, but they have more flexibility and options to protect themselves than do the poor, who stand defenseless, watching their jobs go and their savings dwindle. For politicians in tough economic times to take the frustration of white workers and channel it toward black workers bespeaks a callous mean-spiritedness. It will do nothing to improve the standard of living of either poor whites or poor blacks. Affirmative action didn't cause poverty, and it there were no affirmative action poverty would remain. The African-American that a poor white has to make room for because of affirmative action seems insignificant as a job threat in comparison with government mismanagement of the economy or companies that fire workers for short-term boosts to the bottom line. If whites of modest means could see their class interest as clearly as they see what they think is their racial interest, they would stand a chance of advancement -- perhaps even through interracial political solidarity. 
 But even well-off whites need to see how racism hurts their long-term self-interest. In this global economy, Americans can't compete with the burden of an increasingly larger population in poverty or just above the poverty line. A society 40 percent of whose citizens have high skills, 40 percent low skills, and 20 percent no skills cannot be a prosperous society. If America can't offer all its citizens the hope of a higher living standard through work, then the American dream will become a nightmare and we will all be at each other's throats. Only by reducing poverty sharply and providing increased job opportunities will America be able to maintain its optimism.
Racial thinking obstructs America from seeing how to reduce poverty, because many in the white majority view many blacks as undeserving and unwilling to work. But to refuse more resources to fight poverty because you don't want to help blacks actually hurts more whites than blacks, because poor white people outnumber poor black people by 13 million. Only be reducing poverty, the bulk of which is white, can Americans achieve economic security. Only by ending racial thinking can America sharply reduce poverty. White America has to see its own self-interest clearly.
Nowhere is the issue of race more urgent or less candidly faced than in urban America. Race and the American city are inextricably bound together in fact and in the public perception. The people who live in America's cities are poorer, sicker and less educated, and their circumstances are more violent than at any point in my lifetime. The physical problems are obvious: old housing stock, deteriorated schools, aging sewers and bridges, a diminished manufacturing base, a doctor-starved health-care system that fails to immunize against measles, much less educate about AIDS. The jobs have disappeared. The neighborhoods have been gutted. The tax base has withered. A genuine depression has hit cities, with unemployment in some areas at the levels of the 1930's. Rather than devising ways to cut poverty, too many politicans talk only about affirmative action or welfare.
What is less obvious in urban America is the crisis of meaning. Without meaning, there can be no hope; without hope, there can be no struggle, there can be no personal betterment. Absence of meaning, derived from overt and subtle attacks from racist quarters over many years and furthered by an increasing pessimism about the possibility of justice, offers a context for chaos and irresponsibility.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Hispanic Population Making Inroads on the South Fork

BYLINE: By MERYL SPIEGEL 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago a young man from Mexico City who identified himself as Juan left his family and illegally crossed the border to the United States. With no prospects of earning a living and with a wife and two children to feed, he hoped to find a better life here.
Instead of heading toward California like most Mexican immigrants, Juan traveled to join his brother-in-law on the South Fork, where he was immediately employed as a painter. 
 "He told us it was a safe place, less crowded than the city and that our children would receive better care," Juan said in Spanish.
Sister Cathi Kugler, a social worker for Apostolado Hispano, a Roman Catholic program on the South Fork, translated the interview with Juan.
Juan, 35, is one of many workers from Latin countries, including Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Mexico and Nicaragua, who are settling on the South Fork.
Hispanic immigrants had historically been attracted to the region to be migrant field workers in the growing season and dishwashers and maids in the tourist season. But as winter approached they frequently returned to their home countries.
Despite the fact that many continue to be seasonally unemployed, more immigrants are staying longer and calling for their families.
The community is growing quickly, because of a "colony effect," Sister Cathi said, adding that after a family member finds work, other relatives, as well as their children, often follow. And as the community grows, schools, municipalities and church groups are helping the immigrants cope with their problems.
In 1990, 812 Hispanic people lived in the Town of East Hampton, accounting for 5 percent of the population, and 1,201, or 2.6 percent, lived in the Town of Southampton, according to Census figures from Roy Fedelem of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
On Long Island, Hispanic people made up 6.3 percent of the population in 1990, the second largest minority group after blacks. Spanish-speaking people are the fastest-growing segment, and, Mr. Fedelem projected that in the Census for the year 2000 they would surpass blacks.
Asians, however, including Chinese, Filipinos, Indians and Koreans, are the fastest-growing minority group by percentage on Long Island, Mr. Fedelem added. In 1990, 2.4 percent of Long Islanders were Asian, compared with 1 percent in 1980. Large groups of Asians have settled in several North Shore communities, including Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay.
Because many Hispanic immigrants are not legal, officials say, it is difficult to estimate their numbers on the South Fork.
But Anthony T. Rosalia, editor of El Mensajero, or The Messenger, a free newspaper in Southampton, said he thought that the number of Hispanic people more than doubled since 1990. He estimated that 2,500 Hispanic people lived in East Hampton.
Mr. Rosalia founded the newspaper with his mother, Lucille, five years ago "to help the Hispanic and English communities get to know each other," he said. Published in Spanish and English, its circulation ranges from 3,100 to 4,000, he added.
In most public schools on the South Fork, the number of Hispanic students has more than doubled in five years, according to education officials. The Town of East Hampton, including Montauk, reports that it has 200 Hispanic students, or almost 13 percent of the enrollment in the district. Five years ago the district had 76, or 5 percent, according to an administrator, Joseph Frascino.
Mr. Frascino, who recently started a multicultural program in the district, said that most of the Hispanic students were in the high school and lived in Montauk.
"In 1986, there was not one English as a Second Language teacher in the district, the principal of the elementary school in East Hampton, Dennis Donatutti, said. "Now there are five."
In the Southampton district, the increase in Hispanic students is consistent with the rest of the South Fork, according to the district psychologist and supervisor of the E.S.L. program, Dr. Harmon Cohen. The number grew, from 30 in 1990 to 65, or 4 percent of the total enrollment in the district last year, and the number of E.S.L. teaching positions has increased, from one and a half to three, he said.
Many Hispanic singles migrate here, experts said, hoping to save enough money to move their families, a process that can take years.
But Juan was lucky. In two months, he said, his wife and two children joined him in Southampton. "I worked day and night to bring them here," he recalled.
However, they are "wetbacks," said Sister Cathi. Late one night they waded across the Rio Grande, escorted by an illegal guide called a coyote, she said. They have no legal documents, she added, and "they have no hope of getting them."
Sister Cathi said it was extremely difficult for Mexicans to obtain the documents unless they were part of the government's seasonal farm worker program or family reunification program or were sponsored by an employer.
In addition to the difficulty of obtaining documentation, the immigrants often face other obstacles.
At the time of the interview Juan had been out of work for two months because of an accident. While painting a house, he fell off a ladder and knocked a leg bone out of place, he said. Although his supervisor deducts 4 percent of his salary for accident insurance, Juan has been told that his particular fall is not covered, he said.
Because he has no documentation, he does not have a strong case, Sister Cathi said. And since they have no recourse, she added, immigrants are often taken advantage of. "I tried five or six lawyers," Juan said. "But they all said they couldn't help me, since I have no papers."
The family plans to live here indefinitely, because they have nowhere else to go. They share a house with two other families in Southampton, and Juan's wife cleans a few houses each week.
Although Hispanic immigrants are a frequent target of criticism, Sister Cathi said, they are the backbone of the local economy. "Commerce on the East End," she added, "depends on them."
The Hispanic workers are in jobs that Americans are not seeking, Mr. Rosalia added.
A landscaping manager in Southampton, Chris Bishop, agreed that Hispanic workers did not take jobs from other residents. In season, from March to November, Mr. Bishop said, he hires seasonal workers, including 10 who speak Spanish.
He said that all his foreign laborers had to have legal documents and that all were paid on the books. They start at $8 an hour and can work up to $10. Overall, he added, the foreigners are hard workers who often have two full-time jobs in the summer.
People are under the impression that the immigrants pay no taxes, Mr. Rosalia said, but most are paid on the books.
Last year Juan and his wife earned $14,000 before taxes, he said. Acccording to Sister Cathi, even workers without legal documents pay taxes because they often present false Social Security numbers to obtain jobs.That means that taxes are deducted from the paychecks, but that the workers do not receive refunds.
"We pay taxes but get none of the benefits," Juan said.
Another immigrant, 31 years old, qualified for a green card, or residency visa, one year after moving to East Hampton in 1990. He left his wife and two children in Guatemala, he said, where "people were fighting and being killed."
In five years, he said, he has seen his family once, when he was issued a visa.
"I've tried to bring my family here, but nobody has helped me, and a lawyer costs too much," he said in broken English. Although he would like to stay, the worker said, he will probably return to Guatemala next year because he misses his family.
While on the South Fork the Guatemalan has found work eight months out of the year, he said, but right now he is unemployed until next month. "I tried to find a job doing anything, but there is no business," he said.
In the last year he has worked steadily for an irrigation company in East Hampton. After completing the paperwork, he said, he was hoping to receive unemployment benefits.
Learning the system and breaking the language barrier are the biggest problems, according to Anne Bernard, an outreach worker for the Town of East Hampton. Ms. Bernard is an advocate for Hispanic residents, whether they need her to fill out forms, drive them to doctors' offices or translate.
The Human Services Director of East Hampton, Edna Steck, said Hispanic people were frightened of most authority figures. For example, they are afraid to question the school system, because they fear that "their situation will be jeopardized," she said.
Ms. Steck emphasized the need to teach Hispanic parents the importance of being involved in their children's educations.
Sometimes a family asks Ms. Bernard to make telephone calls for them. They think that with their accent "they will not get good service," Ms. Bernard said.
In addition to the outreach program, which serves 60 families, East Hampton offers free E.S.L. classes for adults and an after-school tutoring club for schoolchildren.
Many students leave school for up to three months in the winter, when their families travel, and the program helps them catch up, the director, Audrey Gaines, said. About 50 students attend the program, half of whom are Hispanic.
"We could have a lot more," she added. "But the program is full, and I have had to turn many away."
In the schools, teachers say, most Hispanic students attend year-round, and few parents continue to take their children out of school.
Some students have motivation problems, said Sandy Vasquez, an E.S.L. teacher in East Hampton. Because many have been separated from their parents for up to four years, "they have a lot going on emotionally" when they are reunited.
In Southampton, Joaquin Mendez, a high school guidance counselor who is from the Dominican Republic, also said "reunification" posed problems. About half the Hispanic people, Mr. Mendez said, are "people in transition," people who live with three or four other men or women who are single or have left spouses and children behind.
At food pantries, workers say, the number of immigrants has increased substantially over several years. The coordinator of the Southampton food pantry at the Sacred Heart church, Mary Ann Tupper, said many Hispanic people were part of the "invisible poor" who worked in the seasonal tourist trade and went to the pantry in the winter, when they were out of work. "You don't see them unless you deal with them," she said.
The director of a pantry in East Hampton, Bob Fariel, said, "A lot of Hispanics are bunching up and living in motels here and in Montauk." Because the pantry, in Montauk, is open only once a month, many Hispanic people apparently go to East Hampton weekly for food.
In Hampton Bays a 19-year-old from Puebla, Mexico, moved to Long Island two years ago and found work as a landscaper. But in the winter he does not have a way to earn a living, he said, and he lives in a small apartment with four other young men, also out of work.
In another residence in Hampton Bays, a 22-year-old woman from Chiapas in southern Mexico, lives with three other Mexican women, including her mother. She works preparing salads in a restaurant, but her mother, a housekeeper, is out of work.
Sister Cathi, who translated that interview, too, said the women lived "abstinently" to send money to their families.
On the positive side, 20 percent of the Hispanic immigrants are part of "intact families" that are moving ahead, Mr. Mendez said. They have lived in the region for seven or eight years and their lives have become more stable because they found year-round work. "Their children are able to compete in school," Mr. Mendez added.
In fact, the salutatorian at Southampton High School in 1993 was a girl from Ecuador, Carolina Avendano. When she moved to Southampton, she entered high school not speaking English. Today she is a sophomore at the Massachusetts Institue of Technology in Cambridge.
Another more subtle success story involves a Costa Rican family in East Hampton. A housekeeper; her husband, a carpenter and their three children migrated from the capital, San Jose, six years ago.
Although the woman loves Costa Rica and would like to return someday, she said, "there are no good jobs" and the cost of living is high.
Looking back, she said times were tough, but "things are better now." The couple are saving to buy the three-bedroom rental home where they live.
In addition to public programs, private services are also focusing on the immigrants. One prime example is Hampton Community Health Care in Water Mill, run by a pediatric nurse practitioner, Harriet L. Hellman.
While working for a pediatrician in East Hampton, Ms. Hellman recounted, she noticed that no one was serving the medical needs of the growing immigrant community. She said she was the only professional who spoke Spanish in the office.
In May she opened a large clinic on Montauk Highway with bilingual personnel. It has seen 500 children and adolescents. "Ninety percent are Spanish speaking," she said.
Ms. Hellman offers a sliding-fee scale based on income. Some patients pay right away in cash, andothers "bring me $5 each week."
Ms. Hellman stressed that Hispanic culture was centered on a strong family unit. "These people love their kids and have good values," she said. In a recent snowstorm, she said, a young man with asthma went to her office to pay for a $20 influenza vaccination.
The area has a dire need for additional Spanish-speaking health practitioners, Ms. Hellman said, and Southampton has no bilingual social workers or public health nurses.
"There are huge pockets of poverty," she said. "The white middle class either doesn't know about it or chooses not to know. Large numbers can't read and write or use the system. The church groups have been most successful at helping them."

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
The Conflict Between A.M. and P.M. People

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; David Bouchier of Wading River is an essayist and commentator heard regularly on public radio.

 BODY:
THE world is full of irresolvable conflicts, and I almost hesitate to recommend another one. But it's time that more attention was paid to the deep divide in our society between Morning People and Night People.
Fully 56 percent of the American population claim to be Morning People. My wife is a typical example of this unfortunate syndrome. She leaps happily out of bed in the gray, freezing hour before dawn, sings happy songs in the shower and makes optimistic plans for the day, even though it's still virtually the middle of the night. 
 The remaining 44 percent of us are Night People, who prefer to get up at a responsible hour, between 9 and 10, and crawl around with eyes half closed contemplating suicide and predicting the end of the world until it's time for our afternoon nap. Then we take a warm bath and begin to make plans for the evening.
You can see the contrast on any L.I.R.R. morning rush hour train. Half the passengers are reading and chatting and gazing brightly out at the icy landscape. The other half are slumped in their seats like extras from "The Night of the Living Dead," eyes glazed or completely closed, clutching paper cups of cold black coffee. There is no point in these Night People going to work at all until after lunch. Economists complain about our falling rate of productivity, but a little creative re-scheduling of Morning and Night People would bring the economy roaring back to life, save millions of marriages and send the sleeping pill industry into terminal decline.
And if we want to talk about Equal Opportunity, think how this affects the chances of students. I once taught an 8 A.M. class at Suffolk Community College, and I might as well have given out the grades on the first day. It was clear that the Morning People would get all the A's, and the Night People would be lucky to escape with D's or F's. Zombies don't make good students or, for that matter, good teachers.
The morning/night divide is another basic conflict between civilization and barbarism. Clearly, the Morning People are on the side of barbarism, because they are closer to nature. Most animals get started at dawn and go to sleep at dusk. Humans have civilization, in the form of electric light and central heating and David Letterman, so there is no need for us to live like animals.
So it is all the more puzzling that an actual majority of Americans claim to be Morning People. It doesn't seem like a rational choice. And if they are telling the truth, why didn't the natural process of evolutionary selection kill them off years ago: murdered by their loved ones, debilitated by cold showers and sleep deprivation and brain dead from a lifetime overdose of "Good Morning America"?
Perhaps the key is in the word claim. They claim to be Morning People because their job forces them to be, or because some ancient memory of the Protestant work ethic tells them that it's virtuous to be active in the mornings. Ben Franklin, a typically annoying morning person, said "Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise." It hasn't worked for any of the men I know. It's just made them grumpy and tired and liable to fall asleep in their beer. Perhaps it works for women.
It is a law of nature that Morning People will always marry Night People, and vice versa. This explains the residual figure of 12 percent who never marry, because they can't find the wrong partner, and also why the average duration of marriage is now down to six years. People hide their chronological orientation before they get married. It is one of those many awful truths that emerges only after the wedding papers have been signed, like a taste for porridge or a partiality for cats. After all, if you tell these secrets before the marriage is nailed down, you will certainly stay single all your life.
It is painful to watch Morning People, in the throes of love, propping their eyelids open at all-night parties and pretending to enjoy it. Or Night People putting on a pathetic show of cheerfulness at 7 A.M., when the object of their desire is there to see it. Perhaps the only reason we have marriage is so that we can give up these pretences, and be ourselves, for six years or so.
As in all such deep human conflicts, both sides feel oppressed. And I see here the opportunity to identify two more huge groups of victims, just when we are getting bored with all the old ones. When you have victims, you must have support programs to put things right. For Morning People, perhaps night clubs in the daytime, midnight movies at noon, candlighted dinners at breakfast time, and New Year celebrations at midnight in Scotland, which is 7 P.M. Long Island time.
And for Night People, just to be fair, no more puritanical abuse, no more false moral superiority. And above all no more alarm clocks, especially not those that have "humane wake-up systems" (a contradiction if ever I hear one) and those that play jolly little tunes, like "It's a bright, bright sunshiny day" and "Oh What a beautiful morning."
Because it never is.
