LENGTH: 1157 words

HEADLINE: Shifting Sands at the Advertising Club

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN the going gets tough, the tough hang out together. Or, why, despite the economy, two professional organizations are certain of attracting new members.
"The Advertising Club of Westchester has consistently maintained membership of about 140," said Andrea Graw Weinbaum who was formerly the salaried manager of the 400-member Advertising Club of New York and now serves as the volunteer manager of the Westchester club. "Although some of our members have fallen on hard times and are no longer in business, others have taken their place, but we would certainly welcome more new members." 
 The Westchester/Fairfield chapter of the Public Relations Society of America now has 80 members, but Judith S. Lederman, the group's new president, said: "We would like more. Corporate downsizing has taken its toll. We have noticed that our membership base has shifted from corporate to entrepreneur, which is a reflection of the times. We used to have a majority of corporate and not-for-profit members, with a few public relations consultants thrown into the mix. Now half our members are consultants, and corporate and not-for-profit members combined make up the other half of our membership."
Ms. Lederman added that many of the sole practitioners came from the ranks of Fortune 500 public relations positions. "They are seasoned professionals," she said. "But their experiences in P.R. departments of some of the largest corporations in the world have been vastly different from that of the entrepreneurial public relations practitioner. And so we've shifted the activities of our club along with the trend. We're having new entrepreneurial programs besides those that have always interested corporate P.R. professionals."
At the Advertising Club, the monthly luncheon meetings are one of the best attended activities, said Susi Dugaw, president of the club.
"Now when members are still feeling the effects of the economic slump, the opportunity to network and exchange ideas is extremely important," Ms. Dugaw said. "We have recently begun special-interest round-table discussions geared to different disciplines. Our advertising agency members, for example, have a round-table discussion group of their own. And our annual awards event not only gives our members a chance to showcase what they can do but it also brings them outside recognition. And as I know from my own happy experience of being a winner, that recognition leads to new business."
The club's newsletter with information on job and marketing opportunities has always been another valuable tool for members, Ms. Dugaw added.
It was through the club's newsletter that Rocco Cipriano and Milton Kapelus were brought together to their mutual advantage. "I spotted a notice in the Ad Club Newsletter, put out by Milton," Mr. Cipriano said. "Milton was a former Grey Advertising vice president who lost his job when his department was shut down. What he wanted in the ad was to start an advertising agency in Westchester as an equity partner." Mr. Cipriano, who was heading his own graphics company at the time, immediately contacted Mr. Kapelus.
"We discovered that we complemented one another," Mr. Cipriano said. "I have graphics and computer skills, and Milton has a creative copywriter side and an account executive marketing background."
Four years ago, Mr. Cipriano said that he and Mr. Kapelus bought out an existing advertising agency in Hartsdale from Michael Schoen and started their own agency, SKC (for Schoen, Kapelus and Cipriano), in Harrison.
"We certainly went into business at a tough time," Mr. Cipriano recalled. "Competition for every piece of business was fierce. We realized we had to come up with the out-of-the-ordinary campaigns if we were going to get noticed."
An unusual presentation, Mr. Cipriano said, was recently made to the new Castle Hotel in Tarrytown. "It involved hiring an actor who we outfitted as a knight. He went up to the hotel and delivered a proclamation written on a scroll describing our services to the manager. We were one of four agencies pitching the job, and it got us attention and a new client."
SKC now employs a staff of 10, Mr. Cipriano said, adding that in 1995 $2.1 million in sales was generated from clients ranging from the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, of which Georgia Kalayjian is the president, to international companies.
"The Ad Club itself can be a good source of business," said Norman Liss, who joined the club in 1972 and remains active even though he retired years ago.
"I tell new members that the club is the best place to get to know your peers," Mr. Liss said. "And working on committees is the best way to network. I know first-hand because I have gotten business from other members and I have given business to other members."
The face of both organizations is changing with the times, said Elizabeth Bracken, who is a member of both. Ms. Bracken, executive vice president of Thompson & Bender, a public relations, advertising and graphics-design concern in Pleasantville, said: "Although the Ad Club has a broader group of members and the public relations group is solely limited to public relations practitioners, both have new members who need guidance and the opportunity to learn how their peers do business."
Joint programs, she added, are under consideration. "They provide an economy of scale that is appealing," she said. "Programs such as those dealing with 'now' subjects like doing advertising and P.R. on the Internet would be good."
Rob Seitz, who is an information management consultant, moved his business from his office in Manhattan to a semi-attached office at his home in New Rochelle five years ago. Mr. Seitz, who fits into both groups, has decided to join the Advertising Club.
"I've never been a big networker," he said. "I tend to get comfortable in my rut, but this winter, when things were slow, I decided I'd better stir myself up and become better known. Also, I had just finished tabulating the results of a campaign I did promoting my business, and I guess I wanted to talk to others in the industry about its success."
So Mr. Seitz attended his first meeting of the Advertising Club. "I was impressed with the quality of the event and the program," he said. "The people were a very friendly group. When you work almost alone, you need to exchange ideas with others in your field from time to time."
And in order to attract new members and infuse some spirit into the Public Relations Society, Ms. Lederman said, "We're planning a bold event for May 3. It will be a program featuring a panel made up of disgruntled clients who will discuss their bad experiences with P.R. firms and P.R. people. The bottom line is that we hope to educate ourselves by hearing about our mistakes."
Those who want to take advantage of the opportunity to flay public relations practictioners should call Ms. Lederman at 591-5502.

HEADLINE: Limiting Teen-Age Access to Cigarettes

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
EVAN KENNEDY started smoking when he was 12 years old. All his friends smoked; it seemed like the cool thing to do.
At first, he said, he liked the idea. But now, at the age of 15, the Milford boy is having second thoughts. Back when he started, he didn't need to smoke; he just lit up when he felt like it. "But then it got like you had to go out and have a cigarette or have one as soon as you got off the school bus and I got kind of addicted to it," he said. Although he still likes to smoke, he often wishes he had never started. 
 Mr. Kennedy is just the sort of young person the state's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, is interested in. He wants to stop pre-teen smoking "before the first cigarette ever touches their lips."
Mr. Blumenthal is calling for legislation that would limit teen-agers' access to cigarettes -- banning cigarette vending machines except in bars, increasing penalties to $5,000 from $50 for stores found selling cigarettes to minors, in short, giving Connecticut the toughest laws in the nation regarding teen-agers and tobacco products.
Mr. Blumenthal cited worries about the spiraling use of tobacco among younger and younger people, particularly girls.
"The tobacco industry spends hundreds of millions of dollars to get their message across with images like the Marlboro Man and Joe Camel," Mr. Blumenthal said. "We need to aggressively educate our children not to take up smoking."
"The fight will be very difficult," he said, noting the strength of the tobacco industry. "But I'm encouraged by the positive response so far of many legislators."
Each year, about 1.3 million children and adolescents in the United States take up smoking. Even more startling, Mr. Blumenthal said, is that 22 percent of all smokers begin before they are 9 years old and 60 percent begin before the age of 14. The National Institute on Drug Abuse claims that nicotine "seizes a tighter control over its addicts than crack or alcohol."
Mr. Blumenthal's office has received mixed reaction from teen-agers, he said.
Many say the proposal is an infringement of their rights, but others express relief that this might lessen the considerable peer pressure to start smoking.
Outside a West Haven fast food restaurant last week, one teen-ager stood smoking with friends and called the proposals "ridiculous." He said he was not concerned about a health risk. Nor were his two friends.
But Mr. Kennedy feels otherwise. "I think it's good," he said of Mr. Blumenthal's plans. "Kids who smoke are getting younger and younger," he said. "But the thing is, you can get cigarettes anywhere if you really want them -- from your sisters and brothers or your parents or some older kids. There are ways."
The proposals have been hailed by many parents, by health educators and a coalition of health groups including the American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association and the American Heart Association as well as by pediatricians, pharmacists and health care directors.
David Woodmansee, vice president of marketing and communications for the American Cancer Society in Connecticut, said of the 17,500 cancer deaths predicted for 1996, 5,250 will be due to tobacco use.
"Ninety percent of anyone who smokes started as an under-age teen-ager," he said, adding that age plays a key role in addiction.
Mr. Blumenthal said that beyond the health risk to young people, the state has to consider the medical costs of cigarette smoking.
"The public health costs from smoking are staggering," Mr. Blumenthal said. "The hospital costs, insurance premiums put a burden on all of us."
The proposed legislation, which is expected to be heard in the General Assembly in the next few weeks, has its sometimes-vocal critics. Owners of cigarette vending companies have they have been unfairly singled out. "It's outrageous taking a group of businessmen and confiscating their businesses," said Stanley Seligson, chairman of S & S Companies, a vending machine operation. "Lots of people are going to lose their jobs."
Mr. Seligson said that most cigarette vending machines are already in areas off limits to minors -- in bars or diners and restaurants where they are in plain view of staff and can be monitored. He said the state could also propose a locking device, preventing sales until proof of age is presented. Mr. Seligson argued that it's just as easy for an 11-year-old to go into a gas station or a convenience store and pick up a pack of cigarettes, but they won't be banned there.
There are currently about 6,000 over-the-counter sale sites for tobacco products in Connecticut and 3,000 registered cigarette vending machines.
Jonathan Dentz, owner of the United Vending Company in Fairfield, said he's worked all his life to build his business, started by his father 40 years ago. "I'm a hard-working person who pays his taxes, why target me?" he said. "I'd have to lay people off, people with families to support."
Grace Nome, president of the Connecticut Food Association, which represents grocery chains, small independent grocers and convenience stores, said the grocery industry is trying hard not to sell tobacco products to minors. Mr. Blumenthal spoke at training seminars for store clerks around the state, she said, to encourage them to ask for identification from any young person buying cigarettes.
But she said she can't agree with the $5,000 penalty. "The fine is astronomical. It will put people out of business," she said. "In these economic times, the profit margins are so slim. We absolutely support the Attorney General's goal but we don't feel it's right to assume that grocers are trying to make a buck on a kid smoking. "
Ms. Nome questioned why there weren't penalties or warnings issued to the young buyers, arguing that they and their parents should bear some of the responsiblity for not smoking.
Mr. Blumenthal said the state doesn't have the police staffing to fine or ticket or jail young people who are caught smoking and that's not his intent. He said under-age smoking has to be stopped where it starts -- with the people who sell cigarettes to under-age youth.
As part of the legislative package, money would be made available to hire personnel to investigate complaints of stores selling to minors. They will report to the State Department of Mental Health and Addiction Services. On the first offense, the store owner would pay the $5,000 fine, on the third offense, the state would revoke the store owner's license to sell tobacco products.
Mr. Blumenthal said he was concerned about the health threat to young people and because "nicotine is an addictive drug and it's also a gateway drug. Adolescents who take up that habit are more vulnerable to other habits," like drinking alcohol and taking other drugs.
The legislative package calls for an education campaign on the dangers of smoking aimed at children and conducted by the Regional Action Councils in the state that run anti-drug programs. The programs will be funded by an increase in the state's cigarette tax to 62 cents from 50 cents a pack. Karen Martin of Greenwich, president of the Western Middle School Parent Teachers Association, has six children ranging up to college age.
"I think anything that's going to try to make it harder for elementary and middle school-aged kids access to cigarettes is good," she said. "Kids in middle school smoke. Knock on wood, mine don't but there is always pressure out there among children to smoke, for acceptance, to look cool. Unfortunately, I think the parents who aren't in touch with their kids, who aren't involved with them, those seem to be the ones who have kids who are smoking, from what I can see."

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
People, Places, Politics: A Sampling of New Jersey History Projects

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
These are some recent projects supported by the New Jersey Historical Commission:
1. In 1989, Gov. Thomas H. Kean gave the commission a one-time appropriation of $109,000 to create 11 history books. One, "A History of the State House," was written by William Dwyer, a Trenton Times reporter. The others are a series of state history books for public high schools, written by New Jersey historians. They cover topics like architecture, politics and immigration. So far, five have been published. 
 2. In 1992, to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's first voyage to America, the commission organized a traveling slide show and presented it at schools, libraries and historical societies around the state. The cost to the commission was $900, plus staff time.
3. In 1992, the commission gave $3,500 to the Oberlin Smith Society of Cumberland County for an oral history project about Oberlin Smith, an inventor from Bridgeton who was a contemporary of Thomas Edison.
PUB-DATE: UNKNOWN 4, 1989,
5. The commission has a continuing project with the New Jersey Network called "New Jersey Legacy," a series of documentaries about the state's history since the 17th century. Three films have been completed, and a fourth, about the state's role in the American Revolution, is in production. Each documentary costs about $35,000 to produce, and although the commission does not pay any of that cost, it helps obtain grants and provides two staff members as producers. The films are used by public school teachers.
6. The commission's Ethnic History Project produced a radio program, "Seabrook at War," about the immigrants who harvested crops and packed vegetables for Seabrook Farms in Cumberland County during World War II, including Japanese-Americans who had been held in internment camps. The total cost of the project was about $20,000, of which the commission paid $4,000.
7. The commission sponsors an annual conference on New Jersey history, which costs about $3,000. Recent conferences have focused on the state's architectural history and women's history. This year's conference, which would have been in December, was to be about New Jersey's role in the Civil War.
8. The commission was planning a biography of Paul Robeson to commemorate the 100th anniversary of his birth in 1898. The project, which would have cost about $4,000, has been suspended.
9. The commission was planning to produce a radio program about New Jersey's immigrants from India, looking at their cultural, economic and political impact since the 1960's. This project, which would cost about $20,000, is also delayed.
10. In 1995, the commission gave the State League of Women Voters a $7,600 grant for a lecture series on the women's suffrage movement in New Jersey. ABBY GOODNOUGH

HEADLINE: SIGNOFF;
On 'Law and Order,' a Real Idealist

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS

 BODY:
At the end of a recent episode of "Law and Order" (NBC, Wednesdays at 10 P.M.), the battle-seasoned District Attorney Adam Schiff, played by Steven Hill, rallies his younger fellow prosecutors (Jill Hennessy and Sam Waterston) after a galling setback in court. Apparently guilty of killing a teacher, an anti-'Semitic teen-ager has received a reprieve in the form of an intractably hung jury that the prosecutors learn voted 11 to 1 to convict.
 
 The law is like that, Schiff reminds his colleagues. So it is and so it always will be. Let's get back to work.
 For Mr. Hill,, who is in his early 70's, the role of patriarch of the prosecution team mixes private beliefs with professional experience gained over a 50-year acting career onstage, in films and on television.
 Legal vagaries aside, Mr. Hill is a law-and-order man. "There's a certain positive statement in this show," he says. "So much is negative today. The positive must be stated to rescue us form pandemonium. To me it lies in that principle: law and order."
 Each week the show takes a crime, steeps it in a social issue, does the police work and sends the case to court, where it often goes through plea bargaining and other machinations. Personally, Mr. Hill says, he is no plea bargainer. "But our stories are about real life, and that's how life is today," he says. "We plea gargain all over the place."
 But whatever disarray that suggests, he adds, it is positively orderly compared with the life of an actor.
 "What we have here is a story of profound instability and impermanence," he says of his own career. "This is what you learn at the beginning in show business; then it gets planted in you forever."
 Judging from his credits, instability can't hurt. Between what he calls "tremendous periods of unemployment" lie the nuggets. Arriving in New York in 1945, Mr. Hill fed himself by acting on radio while he looked for work in theater. The break came when he landed a small part in "Mr. Roberts," starring Henry Fonda. "The diretor, Joshua Logan, thought I had some ability and he let me create one of the scenes," he says. "So I improvised dialogue and it went in the show. That was my first endorsement. It gave me tremendous encouragement to stay in the business."
 About that time he was selected by the director Elia Kazan to join the likes of Marlon Brando as a charter member of the Actors Studio. "That was another feeling of acknowlodgment," he says.
 Theater work, however, was contributing to what Mr. Hill calls "my career in starving." In the 1950's he turned to television, then in its golden age, and landed roles on Playhouse 90 and Goodyear Theater. In the first season of "Mission Impossible," he was Daniel Briggs, who later became Jim Phelps in a role played by Peter Graves ("Your mission, Jim, should you decide to accept it. . . ."). And he often appeared on "Ben Casey," "The Untouchables" and other series.
 On screen, Mr. Hill has had supporting roles in about a dozen films, from "For Whom the Bell Tolls," with Gary Cooper, to "Legal Eagles," with Robert Redford, and "Yentl," with Barbra Streisand.
 Then it was 1990. While he was filming "Billing Bathgate," in which he played the gangster financier Otto Berman, another opportunity presented itself. "Here comes this show called 'Law and Order,' " he says. "The whole concept of that title hit me."
 Schiff, he says, is the toughest role he has ever had because of all the legalese he has to absorb. "It's like acting in a second language," he says. And as in court, there are compromises. As a young actor, he sought roles that had a social purpose. "Later I learned that show business is about entertaining," he says. "So I've had to reconcile my idealistic feelings with reality."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Abortion: the Rate Vs. the Debate

BYLINE: By ANNE CRONIN

 BODY:
REPUBLICAN voters leaving polling places in New Hampshire on Tuesday were asked which one of seven campaign issues mattered themost to them. Two-thirds of the voters responded with the economy, taxes or the deficit. But the top social issue was abortion, cited more frequently than education, trade or the environment. And of the 9 percent of New Hampshire Republicans who said that abortion was the issue that mattered the most, 60 percent voted for Patrick J. Buchanan.
 
 On Friday, Mr. Buchanan promised he would end abortions if elected President, guaranteeing that the subject will loom large in the campaign.
 But while a woman's right to an abortion is being debated, the rate and number of abortions are falling. The rate of abortions per 100 births has fallen an average 1.5 percent a year since 1983. Even the total number of abortions dropped a bit in the early 1990's, after holding steady for a decade.
 Some of the decline can be traced to the demographic dominance of the baby boomers. The population of women in their childbearing years grew rapidly through the mid 1980's, then leveled off.
 AIDS has helped lower the abortion rate, because more couples are using condoms.
 Escalating demonstrations by anti-abortion groups have also changed things - not attitudes on when abortion should be allowed (those have remained steady for decades), but in intimidating women who want abortions and the doctors who perform them. Now, in parts of the United States, it is not unusual to have to drive more than 100 miles to get an abortion.

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as two- and five-year notes and a 52-week bill being auctioned tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

HEADLINE: Ford Move on Natural Gas

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 25

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company is adding vehicles powered by natural gas to the fleet of cars and trucks driven by its employees while on the job. Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for environmental and safety engineering, said 10 percent of the vehicles ordered for the company fleet this year would run on natural gas. The goal is to have 30 percent of the 4,000-vehicle fleet using natural gas by 1998. The program involves Ford Tauruses, Crown Victorias, F-Series pickups and Econoline vans. They will be used first in southeastern Michigan and Southern California.

HEADLINE: Pace of Hiring Seen Improving This Spring

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The pace of hiring is expected to improve slightly in the spring because of the start of the construction season, a new survey reports, but the job market will be sluggish compared with last year.
According to the quarterly survey released by Manpower Inc., the nation's leading temporary-help agency, 26 percent of employers in the United States intend to increase hiring, beginning in April. The telephone survey of 15,000 employers reported that 8 percent intended to decrease hiring; 63 percent reported no changes. 
 Nationwide, construction jobs are expecting the biggest growth, with 36 percent of employers intending to hire, Manpower said.
Manufacturing of durable goods -- long-lasting, high-cost items like cars and appliances -- is second, with 31 percent of employers responding favorably. In last place, with only 11 percent of employers intending to hire new workers, is the education and mining sectors.
"Our new figures indicate that a continuing uncertainty prevails among the nation's employers which inhibits job growth," Manpower's president, Mitchell S. Fromstein, said in a statement.
The survey by Manpower looked at 10 sectors of the economy in 481 cities, and has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points.

HEADLINE: U.S. Tool Orders Up 23% in January

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MCLEAN, Va., Feb. 25

 BODY:
Orders for American-made industrial tools surged during January from the previous month, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said, suggesting that capital investment by businesses continues to boom.
"We are encouraged that 1996 began on a robust note," Albert Moore, the association's president, said. 
 Total orders rose 23 percent, to $462.3 million, from those of December. Domestic customers increased their orders 22.4 percent during the month, while demand from abroad advanced 26.8 percent, the trade group said.
The report also showed that machine tool orders rose a revised 16.3 percent, to $375.9 million, in December, down from the 16.8 percent increase originally reported. January orders rose 22.6 percent over the corresponding period a year ago.
Economists follow orders and shipments of machine tools -- used to shape and assemble metals in products ranging from motorcycles to microwaves -- to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
One sign of manufacturing weakness came earlier this month, when the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production fell nine-tenths of 1 percent during January, as the blizzard that hit the Northeast restrained output. More news on the pace of production is due this week, when the National Association of Purchasing Management issues its February index of manufacturing activity.
By category, January orders for metal-cutting tools like drills rose 12.2 percent from the previous month, to $312.3 million, while orders for metal-forming tools like stamp-press machines increased 53.7 percent, to $150 million, last month.
Machine tool shipments fell 31.4 percent in December, to $328.2 million. The backlog of orders, which tracks pent-up demand for tools, rose 6.4 percent, to $2.215 billion, during December.

HEADLINE: An Aerial Assault On the Wired Nation

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Jim Robbins is a cable television executive, but these days he sounds more like the cellular telephone billionaire Craig O. McCaw.
Mr. Robbins, the chief executive of Cox Communications, oversees the nation's fifth-largest cable operator. And while he remains enthusiastic about serving Cox's 3.2 million subscribers, he really comes to life in describing the company's foray into wireless telephone service. 
 Along with Sprint and two other big cable companies eager to break into the local phone business, Cox has invested $2.1 billion for licenses to offer a new cellular service, called personal communications services, or P.C.S. The partners -- the other two are Tele-Communications Inc. and Comcast -- are spending $2 billion more to build a national network capable of reaching 144 million people.
"Wireless is absolutely exploding," Mr. Robbins said.
Three weeks after President Clinton signed a bill uncorking competition in the telecommunications industry, the battle among local and long-distance phone companies and cable operators has taken an unexpected turn. Rather than waging a ground war for each other's wired network, many companies now seem intent on taking their battles to the skies -- trying to infiltrate the well-protected markets of their rivals by beaming telephone or television signals directly to customers.
"People ask when local competition is going to happen; that's the wrong question," said David J. Roddy, chief telecommunications economist at Deloitte & Touche, the big accounting and consulting firm. "The real question is: When is wireless competition going to happen? The answer is: now."
Mr. Roddy said Americans spent roughly $22 billion on wireless services in 1995, and he expects that to double by the turn of the century.
Long-distance carriers are particularly keen on catching the air wave, because they have national networks but lack direct connections to individual telephone and cable households. Late last month AT&T announced that it would invest $137.5 million in a satellite broadcasting service, DirecTV. A week later MCI paid $682 million for an orbital slot to offer its own high-powered satellite broadcasting service. And just last week, Sprint and its cable partners reorganized their alliance to focus on wireless, rather than wired services -- even changing the venture's name to Sprint Spectrum, an allusion to the radio-frequency spectrum used by wireless services.
Meanwhile a frenzied Federal Communications Commission auction continues in Washington for an additional round of P.C.S. licenses, with the total bids approaching $7 billion through last Friday.
To be sure, the popularity of wireless stems partly from the fact that the business has already grown so rapidly. The cellular industry that made Mr. McCaw so rich went from almost nothing in 1980 to a $20 billion business last year. And in the last few years, refinements in digital technology have also made wireless transmission suitable for a broader range of services, including computer-precise television transmissions and high-speed data transfer.
But the current craze also reflects a more sober business reality: Even after the telecommunications market is fully deregulated, the high cost of stringing wires or laying cables, and the expected resistance of the local cable and phone-wire monopolies to interlopers, will make it tough for long-distance carriers, local telephone companies, or cable operators to break into each other's traditional land-line markets.
"It is very hard to develop a wired strategy," said William T. Esrey, chairman and chief executive of the Sprint Corporation. "You can pursue a wireless strategy far more easily."
Consider Sprint's strategy for breaking into the $90 billion local phone market. As part of its original cable alliance, Sprint's partners were supposed to upgrade their coaxial cable television networks to begin carrying telephone traffic. Earlier this month, however, the partners dropped the wired component of the deal, in part because they feared that the schedule for renovating their networks -- 10 million homes by the end of 1996 -- was overly ambitious.
Some analysts said the decision stemmed from a more basic fear -- that the cable industry might never be able to compete economically for local phone customers. Already, cable companies have locked horns with regional Bell companies in negotiations over issues like how much they should pay for handing off calls to the Bell network.
"I think there could still be a tremendous revenue stream from telephony," said Brian L. Roberts, the president of Comcast. "But until all these issues shake out, it's prudent to keep your options open."
Just as the cable industry has qualms about taking on the Bell companies, the Baby Bells have lagged behind in their efforts to go after the cable industry. Several of the Bells announced plans a few years ago to upgrade their copper-wire networks to carry video services. But while Bell Atlantic is still rolling out a small video service over phone lines in Dover Township, N.J., most of the other efforts have quietly disappeared.
And though both AT&T and MCI have tried to get a direct link to households by broaching deals with cable operators like Tele-Communications or Time Warner, neither has succeeded.
By plunging into the satellite broadcasting business, however, AT&T and MCI will eventually be able to beam 150 channels of programming directly from satellites to pizza-pan-sized dishes on rooftops. So far, direct-broadcast services have only two million subscribers in this country. But with the muscle of AT&T and MCI, some analysts estimated that the industry would have 10 million customers by 2000.
If anything, the local telephone business is even harder to penetrate than cable. The Baby Bells own the wires that snake into most American households. And would-be rivals like long-distance carriers face an unappetizing choice. They can either negotiate to lease capacity on the local network, try to duplicate the network or find ways to bypass it.
"If you want to duplicate that kind of a network, you've got to dig up streets or put up ugly telephone poles," said Lee Cox, the president of Air Touch Cellular, the wireless company that was spun off from Pacific Telesis, a regional Bell company. "We're shooting an arrow straight at the target, and there are no front lawns or streets in the way."
So far cellular has been too expensive to become a viable competitor to local phone service. But personal communications services may have a better shot.
P.C.S. networks, using digital radio transmissions for voice and data communications via small hand-held devices, can serve many more customers simultaneously than current cellular networks. That fact, and the cut-throat competition as several wireless companies compete in many of the larger metropolitan markets, should result in prices much lower than cellular companies have typically offered.
In the first P.C.S. auction, AT&T, like Sprint, was a heavy bidder for licenses, spending $1.6 billion for a potential market of 107 million people. Add that to AT&T's cellular franchises through its 1994 acquisition of McCaw Cellular, and the company has considerable ammunition in its battle to bypass the Bells.
For their part, the Bells are also seizing on wireless as a weapon to compete for customers outside their regions. Air Touch Communications is part of a four-company alliance -- including Bell Atlantic, Nynex, and U S West -- that paid $1.1 billion for P.C.S. licenses.
And some Baby Bells are using wireless as a stalking horse for their foray into long-distance. SBC Communications, formerly Southwestern Bell, recently filed for permission to offer long-distance service in 16 states, including New York. SBC has chosen states where it already owns cellular franchises operating under the Cellular One name -- a brand that SBC plans to use for marketing long-distance services.
Still, not every telephone executive thinks the future is wireless. Richard C. Notebaert, the chief executive of Ameritech, has largely eschewed the costly wireless investments of his Bell brethren. Mr. Notebaert said he was spending the bulk of Ameritech's capital resources -- $2 billion a year -- to upgrade the company's existing wired network with fiber optics for data services, and in some cases to build coaxial cable television systems alongside the phone networks.
"You won't know for five years whether P.C.S. was a good investment or a bad investment," Mr. Notebaert said.
Given that the telephone industry is spending $30 billion on P.C.S. and other forms of wireless communications, the next five years promise to be nerve-racking ones indeed.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PRIMARY SPRINT;
COMING PRIMARIES ARE UP FOR GRABS AFTER MIXED VOTE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 25

 BODY:
As the Republican Presidential race enters its most consequential and chaotic phase, the combination of an unexpectedly competitive field and the most accelerated schedule of contests ever in American politics has thrown the competition in several pivotal states into a virtual free-for-all.
For months, Senator Bob Dole had been widely viewed as the candidate to beat in upcoming races, including the primary in Arizona on Tuesday, followed by states including South Carolina, Georgia, Colorado and Massachusetts. But the clouded verdict after the first four primaries and caucuses has upended the calculations of Mr. Dole and his rivals, leaving no clear front-runner in those states. 
 That is why the rapid-fire schedule of contests that are lined up like a string of firecrackers -- 15 states will select delegates to the Republican National Convention in the next nine days -- is crucial.
The focus is no longer on set-piece battles like Iowa and New Hampshire but on campaigns that are often taking place simultaneously. Because so many states sought more influence by moving up their primaries this year, 34 contests will be held by the end of March.
"It's going to be like guerrilla warfare, where people are picking and choosing targets," said William B. Lacy, Mr. Dole's deputy chairman.
Every candidate needs a first-place finish -- and soon -- before the competition moves in less than two weeks to delegate-rich states like New York, Florida and Texas, and then to the industrial Midwest.
Mr. Dole, hobbled by his narrow victory in the Iowa caucuses and his loss to Patrick J. Buchanan in the New Hampshire primary, is banking on his financial and organizational edge to recharge his candidacy -- and silence Republicans who think he is too weak to win the nomination.
Still basking in his upset victories in the New Hampshire primary and the Louisiana caucuses, Mr. Buchanan hopes put down efforts by leading Republicans who think he is out of step with the party, and to prove that his campaign is more than a fleeting sensation.
Even after his victory in the Delaware primary on Saturday -- in which most of his rivals did not campaign -- Steve Forbes hopes to prove that his candidacy can regain the steam it had before his fourth-place showings in Iowa and New Hampshire. And Lamar Alexander, who has presented himself a mainstream Republican alternative to Mr. Dole, wants to demonstrate that he can win a contest outright.
While polls and interviews with local Republican strategists suggest that Mr. Buchanan, the former commentator and columnist, is coming on strong in the next series of contests, it is perilous to assess the fortunes of these candidates.
The outcomes may depend less on conventional measures like money and organization and more on ever-shifting dynamics, like who did how well in the preceding state. There are other complications as well, from the differing rules in states over how convention delegates are selected to whether there are larger turnouts, as happened in New Hampshire.
"It's so confusing all of a sudden, like a three-dimensional Rubik's cube, and no one's got it figured out," said Benjamin L. Ginsberg, a former general counsel of the Republican National Committee. "We all used to filter our prognostications through the experience of what's gone on in the past. There really are different dynamics this time."
The race here on Tuesday is the biggest prize so far, with 39 delegates at stake. It is generally viewed as a two-way competition between Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Dole.
Mr. Forbes, the wealthy publisher, is still a factor since he has pumped about $2 millions from his personal fortune into television commercials in this state and, before his losses in Iowa and New Hampshire, was even with or leading Mr. Dole in the polls here. And Mr. Alexander is also making an effort in Arizona, and has a new commercial attacking Mr. Dole.
Other contests on Tuesday are in North Dakota and South Dakota, where Mr. Dole is widely favored.
The upcoming primary that is shaping up as most crucial, and the most fluid, is in South Carolina on Saturday Mr. Dole has been endorsed by the party hierarchy, and has set out to prove that the elected officials can pull him through even though such support did him little good in New Hampshire.
Mr. Buchanan is counting on vigorous backing from religious conservatives and for his outspoken championing of economic nationalism. But even with the shuttered textile mills in South Carolina, many workers there are prospering by working for foreign companies. And Mr. Alexander, a former Governor of Tennessee, wants to make the case that he is the most formidable candidate in his native South.
Yet the race in South Carolina could be decided as much by turnout. If it is low, Mr. Buchanan would likely benefit the most because his troops are the most motivated to go the polls.
Perhaps indulging in hyperbole, Henry McMaster, Republican state chairman in South Carolina, had a point in saying: "The momentum generated in our first-in-the-South primary will be the decisive factor for the rest of the South. When our results are tabulated, the field will narrow considerably and, although some battles will remain, we will likely know who the ultimate victor and the next President will be."
Whatever the outcome, many strategists agree that before the costly contests in Florida and Texas on March 12, Mr. Dole or Mr. Alexander will emerge at the prime candidate to take on Mr. Buchanan.
"There is no possible way that both of them will have advertising budgets for Texas and Florida -- it's inconceivable," said Charles Black, who was chief adviser to Senator Phil Gramm of Texas before he withdrew. "You're not going to have both of them equally on the radar screen. It just won't happen."
Here is what the major candidates are likely to face in trying to survive the crush of upcoming contests and capturing the 996 out of 1,990 delegates needed for the nomination:
 
Dole
As important as it is for Mr. Dole to start winning states, he should be just as concerned that Mr. Alexander not win any either. He needs to quickly establish a face-off between himself and Mr. Buchanan, and can do that most successfully by squeezing Mr. Alexander out of the race, and to a lesser extent Mr. Forbes and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, who are also eating into his support.
Mr. Dole's campaign hopes that the accelerated succession of races will give his competitors little chance to raise money and match his state organizations.
 
Buchanan
With his low-budget organization, Mr. Buchanan can stay in as long as he wants. He is best off if several of his competitors stay in the field, dividing the anti-Buchanan vote. That would give him an opening to continue his hot streak.
Mr. Buchanan said he was making a special effort in Arizona, a "winner take all" state where the victor captures all the delegates, not divided proportionally as in many other states. But given the controversy surrounding his views, Mr. Buchanan's support is not as potentially broad as that of other candidates, so he is less likely than his rivals to win an overwhelming number of votes in any state.
 
Alexander
He is counting on Mr. Dole to perform so poorly that the party will rally around his candidacy as an alternative to stop Mr. Buchanan. But before that can happen, Mr. Alexander needs to prove he can break from the pack and win somewhere in his own right; he is the only one of the four leading contenders who has not won a state, and has not even come in second.
His less hard-edged message may be most popular in the New England states that vote on March 5, but he would be in a far better position if he can score a victory before then. But even if he wins somewhere soon, the truncated calendar gives Mr. Alexander little time to capitalize on the victories to raise money and organize ground workers in states.
"The compressed primary schedule is like the good news and the bad news," said Colleen A. Pero, the director of ballot and delegate programs for Mr. Alexander. "You get your momentum but everything has to be put in place so quickly. It could be construed as more difficult."
There are other possible outcomes, like the prospect that Mr. Dole will flounder, and Mr. Forbes will win here, thus re-establishing himself as a Washington outsider who is best position to capture the nomination. Or that Mr. Lugar will win big in New England and ride a late-surge to victory, with his opponents splitting up the vote.
Another possible result is that every victory by a candidate in one state will be canceled out by another candidate's win somewhere else, and no candidate will amass enough delegates to avoid a brokered convention in San Diego in August.
"The scenario that's emerging is the one that says, gee, maybe we'll be deadlocked in San Diego," said Mr. Ginsberg, the former Republican Committee official.
"That's the one that captures the imagination. Deep in our heart of hearts, all of us would love to live through a brokered convention."

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONSIDERS PUNISHING CUBANS FOR PLANE ATTACK

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
The United States called an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council today as President Clinton weighed retaliating against Cuba for downing two civilian aircraft carrying anti-Castro Cuban-Americans.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said two Cuban MIG fighter jets failed to warn off the American pilots before blowing two Cessna aircraft out of the sky with missiles on Saturday. He said such a failure violated international law and "the norms of civilized behavior." 
 But United States intelligence officials said that at least one of the American aircraft -- the lead plane, which returned safely to Florida -- and perhaps all three had violated Cuban airspace. They also said the air traffic control tower in Havana had warned the pilots that they were in danger.
At a 90-minute meeting tonight, the United States asked the Security Council to condemn and investigate the downing, and the Council is to consider the request on Monday.
Beyond the United Nations, Mr. Clinton was also trying to decide if and how the United States would react on its own. With a tight United States economic embargo of Cuba already in place, Mr. Clinton has few ways to singlehandedly make life much harder for Cuba and its leader, Fidel Castro.
Mr. Clinton is trying nonetheless to fashion a political and diplomatic response that will satisfy Cuban-Americans opposed to Mr. Castro, the only Communist leader in the Western Hemisphere, without unduly punishing Cubans on the island who are seeking political changes.
The most powerful anti-Castro activist in Florida, Jorge Mas Canosa, said the deaths of four Americans offered Mr. Clinton "a golden opportunity" to win votes among Cuban-American conservatives by imposing the harshest possible sanctions, including severing all American diplomatic, economic and political ties to Cuba.
He said the President should halt telephone service, ban charter flights, stop wire transfers of millions of dollars from Cuban-Americans sending money to relatives, close the United States interests section in Havana and withdraw all American diplomats from the island.
But imposing those sanctions would be "shooting ourselves in the foot," said Wayne Smith, who was the chief United States diplomat in Cuba as head of the interests section in Havana from 1979 to 1982.
"That would be absolutely absurd," Mr. Smith said. "The Administration has been talking about the need to expand contacts, reach out to the Cuban people, let light into the island. Closing our interests section, cutting off communication -- that goes against what we want to do, and what all the dissidents that I know on the island and all the religious leaders want to do."
Mr. Smith said the American sanctions against Cuba were already so severe that there was little left to do except go to the United Nations.
The attack on Saturday came after months of a dangerous cat-and-mouse game played between the Cuban Air Force and the anti-Castro group, Brothers to the Rescue, made up largely of Cuban exiles. The group, based in Miami, had flown over Cuba at least twice before. Last month it dropped thousands of leaflets on Havana, urging Cubans to "Fight for your rights" and proclaiming "Your problem is mine."
Each time, the Cuban Government protested the action as a violation of international and American law. It put Washington on notice that it would take "all necessary measures" to halt the planes, including shooting them down.
Eugene Carroll, a retired admiral with the Center for Defense Information, a Washington-based group that advocates dialogue between the United States and Cuba, said a veiled warning was issued at a meeting he had this month with Gen. Ulisses Rosales del Toro, chief of staff of the Cuban military, and other Cuban officials.
"They said, 'What would happen if we shot down one of these planes?' " Mr. Carroll recalled. " 'We can, you know.' " He relayed the information to United States intelligence officials last week, on his return from Cuba.
On Saturday, three planes from the anti-Castro group left an airfield in Opa-Locka, Fla., shortly before 2 P.M. The group's founder, Jose Basulto, was flying the lead plane.
The pilots' stated mission was to look for Cuban refugees floating toward the United States. The flight plan they filed with the F.A.A. called for a five-hour trip to the edge of the 24th parallel, a line on the map north of the 12-mile perimeter of Cuba's legal airspace. F.A.A. officials said the flight plan was transmitted electronically to the air tower in Havana.
Under international law, territorial airspace and waters end 12 miles from land. But nations can declare "air defense identification zones" and warn aircraft of danger beyond them. Cuba has legally declared the 24th parallel, which ranges from 40 to 60 miles from its jagged northern coast, as an air defense zone.
At 2:57 P.M., according to a chronology prepared by United States intelligence officials, one of the planes contacted Havana's civilian air traffic controllers. The pilot said the planes would be headed south of the 24th parallel, in violation of their flight plan.
The Cuban controller warned the planes of the danger of crossing that line. The pilots said they were well aware of the risks, but were flying south over the line anyway, the intelligence officials said.
At 3:01 P.M., the planes crossed the 24th parallel. Eight minutes later, two Cuban fighter jets, a MIG-23 and a MIG-29, took off in pursuit. By 3:22 P.M., Mr. Basulto's plane was about 3.5 miles deep into Cuba's 12-mile limit, the officials said.
At 3:24 P.M., the MIG-29 pilot locked his radar on the second plane in the group and requested and received permission from his military commanders to shoot it down.
Eyewitnesses on a cruise ship below the confrontation said the Cessna suddenly exploded. United States officials said the plane was downed about 5.75 miles north of Cuba's 12-mile limit; Cuban officials said the shooting down took place over Cuba's territorial waters.
At 3:31 P.M., the MIG-29 pilot requested and received permission to destroy the third Cessna, and did. Again, United States officials said it went down in international waters; the Cubans disagree. Mr. Basulto, meanwhile, was returning to Florida.
At a news conference today at the airport in Opa-Locka, a Miami suburb, Mr. Basulto said the Cuban Government had "used their Air Force as hit men" and that "there is no excuse whatsoever to attack light planes that are unarmed."
Mr. Basulto said his position at the time of the attack was 23 degrees, 25 minutes north, which would have placed him outside the 12-mile limit. He played a flight tape recording that he said proved it. "We were in international waters," he said. "So were they. This happened with the full knowledge and planning of the Castro Government."
At a White House news conference today, Mr. Christopher said permission to shoot down the Cessnas was granted at the highest military levels in Cuba.
Mr. Christopher and other United States officials, who would not allow their names to be used, said that the MIG-29 pilot made no effort to contact the pilots, to wiggle its wings in warning or to escort them from the area before firing. This failure, they said, violated international law.
No law permits a military plane to shoot down an unarmed civilian aircraft, the officials said. The United States acknowledged as much last week by agreeing to pay tens of millions of dollars in damages to the families of 248 Iranians killed when a United States warship, fearing attack, shot down an Iran Air airliner in July 1988.
In a statement issued in Havana today, the Cuban Foreign Ministry said the "pirate planes" were shot down in retaliation for "irresponsible and criminal attacks."
It said the planes were between five and eight miles off Baracoa, a western suburb of Havana. It also said the pilots had ignored a direct warning from the air traffic control tower in Havana.
On this last point, United States officials agreed.

Four members of the group were killed when Cuban fighters shot down two planes on Saturday. (Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times) (pg. A7)

LENGTH: 586 words

HEADLINE: Better Tools Needed on China

 BODY:
China's brazen export to Pakistan of magnets used in nuclear bomb production is creating more problems for the Clinton Administration than it has for Beijing. That is because Washington now finds itself with no credible way to respond that does not also inflict serious harm on United States business interests.
The best answer for now is to give priority to nuclear security and impose the penalties specified by law. But the Administration must also work to avoid similar dilemmas in the future by equipping itself with sharper policy tools. One obvious approach is to persuade America's allies (and business competitors) to join in coordinated economic penalties against reckless nuclear suppliers. 
 The magnets sale violates the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, signed by Beijing. Under United States law, this violation automatically triggers a cutoff of taxpayer-backed loan guarantees for many of the biggest American business deals with China. The Administration can protect American business interests by waiving the penalties, but only at the cost of severely undermining its efforts to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.
The Administration, pressured by Congress to signal disapproval to China and pressured by business to avoid sanctions, is preparing to split the difference. It intends to impose, and then immediately waive, the statutory punishment and then apply less drastic economic penalties. Such a compromise would confirm Beijing's impression that Washington will never carry out its threats of damaging economic sanctions for fear of hurting American business. If that impression is correct, the United States urgently needs to find other policy levers that it is actually prepared to use.
Chinese challenges over nuclear technology and missile sales, copyright piracy and Taiwan cannot be ignored just because Washington has no available responses that do not also impose costs on Americans. Until less problematic forms of retaliation are developed, the United States must be prepared in cases as serious as this one to invoke the economic sanctions that are now on the books.
But the Administration is not wrong in thinking that penalties that affect only American business deals, leaving European and Japanese companies free to pick up the contracts United States companies might lose, are neither the smartest nor the most effective way to punish Beijing.
It would be far more effective if all major trading powers applied concerted economic penalties, from the withdrawal of government subsidies to tightened restrictions on high-technology imports. Some American allies might be reluctant to go along with a coordinated approach. But they can be reminded that any reduction in America's ability to influence Beijing on security issues damages them, too.
America has tried to discourage dangerous Chinese behavior in recent years by rationing high-level official visits and imposing limited economic sanctions. These measures have had little apparent effect. Futile as these calibrated policies sometimes seem, they are clearly preferable to flaunting the Seventh Fleet or making implicit military threats.
To restore its credibility, Washington must now try stronger forms of nonmilitary pressure. That means signing up American allies to apply coordinated penalties when international treaties are seriously breached. But until that can be achieved, Washington must be prepared to apply the full rigor of American law in cases like the magnets sale to Pakistan.

HEADLINE: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Greenbelt;
Necklace of Space Rings Golden Gate

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24

 BODY:
New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?
The Regional Plan Association, an organization based in Manhattan that issued a 25-year agenda this month for the 31-county three-state region, has violated that taboo. The group studied metropolitan areas all over the world searching for urban ingenuity and found inspiration in a greenbelt around San Francisco, a broad-based travel card in London, a regional government in Portland, Ore., business district development in Tokyo and work force training in Pittsburgh. The final report from the planning group, after five years of research, identified these lessons as important ones for this region. 
 In the late 1960's, a developer planned a new city in a bucolic valley in the Marin headlands just across the Golden Gate Bridge from here. But outraged citizens helped kill the planned high-rise dwellings and the land was incorporated into the Golden Gate National Recreation Area, part of an enormous greenbelt that circles the urban San Francisco Bay region.
This nine-county area sprawls over 4.5 million acres, 3.7 million of which are open space. About 570,000 acres, mostly agricultural land, is at risk for development over the next 30 years, but 900,000 acres are considered untouchable open space.
"It's one of the most amazing features anywhere -- it's extremely unusual," said Jim Sayer, executive director of the Greenbelt Alliance, a nonprofit organization dedicated to land conservation.
This greenbelt is a mix of public and private land running from Point Reyes in the north to near San Jose in the south and sweeping around to the east side of the bay. The vital ingredients have been an active citizenry, ambitious long-term planning and money spent to buy important tracts.
One of the most scenic pieces is the Presidio, the huge and hilly former Army base at a corner of San Francisco that is now run by the National Park Service.
Mr. Sayer said that the best guarantee of open space is local public opinion. In Marin County years ago, voters ousted a county board that had agreed to open up a vast coastal tract to builders.
"The critical concept is that Marin established boundaries," Mr. Sayer said. "They said we're going to draw a firm line and they sent a clear signal."

HEADLINE: Essay;
The New Socialism

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A specter is haunting free enter prisethe specter of the New Socialism.
The old Socialism failed. The Marxist notion that state ownership could triumph over capitalism led to the disintegration of the Soviet Union. In its other form -- the democratic welfare state -- the old Socialism is being abandoned. 
 Privatization is in; from Sweden and Britain to Israel and throughout Asia, tight state control of business is unraveling. In the U.S., even the majority of Democrats read the public mood against tax-and-spend and turned away from the stultifying excesses of income redistribution. For more than a decade, the pendulum has been swinging toward free enterprise and its handmaiden, free trade.
What were the world's leftists to do? How to reassert central control in the face of public revulsion of corrupt or intrusive state bureaucracy?
After years of thrashing about, they have come up with an answer: the New Socialism.
Unable to command the economy directly, leftists propose to coerce corporations to act as government's surrogates. Under the banner of "social responsibility," the idea is to place the costs of education, health care, training, day care and environmental purity -- costs that voters are unwilling to assume -- on companies that now measure success in terms of profits and dividends.
This goes beyond "industrial policy," that liberal scheme to let Washington decide which industries to subsidize and which to let fail. That cherry-picking didn't fly.
Enter the New Socialist Person. He or she is called the "stakeholder." Remember that word; it has replaced "proletariat" in the lexicon of the left.
The leader of Britain's resurgent Labor Party, Tony Blair, advocates a "stakeholder society." The leader of House Democrats, Richard Gephardt, told the annual gathering of A.F.L.-C.I.O. executives in Bal Harbour, Fla., "We've got to encourage, cajole and persuade our corporations . . . to recognize the role of their stakeholders as well as their shareholders."
At Bal Harbour, Clinton Labor Secretary Robert Reich went further, urging that Washington reward companies who practice "good corporate citizenship" and punish, by taxation or regulation, those driven only to make profits (by delivering quality products at a low price).
Who are the stakeholders? Workers, often seeking protection from competition; middle managers, even the unnecessary; the local community, including extreme environmentalists. In the New Socialism, share-owners come last -- including all those investing through pension funds and mutual funds -- despite the fact that these investors provide the capital to support profitable business and generate jobs.
The fifth stakeholder, usually unmentioned in the New Socialism's attack on "corporate greed" and demonization of the downsizers, is the consumer. His stake is his cost of living, which would shoot up if Reich punishments and Buchanan tariffs were slapped on the goods the middle-class family buys at Wal-Mart or Sears. The protected worker is also the cheated consumer.
Capitalism's defenders know that only stupidly shortsighted executives overlook the need for a loyal, motivated work force; we also know that good community relations help attract the best managers and innovators to a company. And easing the shock of necessary belt-tightening on workers who are not producing is "good P.R.," which makes business sense -- provided it does not squander assets on ego-satisfying do-gooding or becoming the new delivery system for politicians' largesse.
What are the primary "social" responsibilities of a corporation? To serve its owners by returning a profit and its community by paying taxes; to earn the allegiance of customers by delivering value, and to provide a secure future for employees who help it succeed in the marketplace. A new responsibility is to resist the wave of resentment stirred by politicians whose geese cannot lay those golden eggs.
The old business-bashing populism of Buchanan and some unions has linked up with the new business-using socialism of Clinton's advisers. If this pernicious bedfellowship is not rejected now, at a time of low unemployment, who will stand up for competition, productivity and free trade when the recession bites?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
Fierce Winds Cause Deaths
Fierce winds that whipped to more than 60 miles an hour caused at least three deaths in the metropolitan region and contributed to the collapse of at least two buildings in Brooklyn. In Midwood, Brooklyn, a sharp gust ripped a tree from its roots and sent it flying across the street, where it crushed a 40-year-old construction worker, the police said. In Farmington, Conn., a man and his 6-year-old son were killed when the wind splintered a pine tree and sent it crashing onto their car, critically injuring the boy's mother, brother and sister. The man, Anthony Bouckums, 44, and his son, Christopher, were killed instantly when the tree crushed the car, the police said. [Page B1.] 
 Focusing a Light on Abuse
The abusive death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo focused attention on the city's faltering child welfare agency. And now the murder of Galina Komar, who was beaten, stalked and ultimately murdered two weeks ago by a convicted felon, has opened a window on a system that treats black eyes -- especially black eyes of domestic violence victims -- as if they were stubbed toes. In a dispute that legal and medical experts say is both highly unusual and indicative of gray areas in New York State law, administrators at a Queens hospital have said they will go to court for permission to remove a 5-month-old girl from a ventilator against her parents' wishes. [B3.]
Bitter Feuds Split Local G.O.P.
A longstanding rivalry for the leadership of the Republican Party in Queens has produced a series of showdowns in court, more than a few shattered alliances and a large dose of bitterness. As the party has made political inroads around the city in the last several years, the promise of power may have spurred the internecine warfare. The Queens Republicans are not alone. In Brooklyn, Republicans are devoting far more energy to fighting each other than to opposing Democrats. [B3.]
In Giving, Better Late . . .
Countless well-meaning people have a tendency to procrastinate. In the last several weeks, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has heard from several of them. Their letters suggest that many people have already decided to give to the fund, but that it may take weeks, months or even years to turn that thought into action. [B2.]
Looking for a Broadway Home
The rapid rise of the rock musical "Rent" Off Broadway is the story of the New York theater season, a surprise triumph in an industry short on sensations and starved for a fresh, home-grown musical hit. "Rent" seems to have rekindled faith in the American musical when many in the theater, particularly younger people, believed it had reached an artistic dead end. Broadway's two biggest landlords, the Shuberts and Nederlanders, are vying to win the musical. The Arts. [C9.]

A rare paralytic neurological disorder -- Guillain-Barre syndrome -- has since December popped up suddenly and inexplicably in the suburbs of western Bergen County. State and local health officials stressed that the general population in the county is not in any danger, noting that Guillain-Barre syndrome is neither infectious nor contagious. In the Bergen County cluster, six patients suffered respiratory illnesses, but health officials have so far been unable to identify any specific infection common to them and have found no shared medical or environmental circumstances. HEADLINE: Give Them the Maximum;
Small Towns Clamor for the Boon a Big Prison Could Bring

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: JOHNSTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
Richard Smullen, Supervisor of this upstate mill town, got all worked up the other day when he heard that the state might build a maximum-security prison here to house murderers, rapists and the like.
But his was not the predictable not-in-my-backyard battle cry. Far from it. 
 "We've been trying to get a prison built here for years," Mr. Smullen explained. "It would bring a lot of jobs, and that would be pretty nice for the town."
Residents of New York City and its suburbs would shudder at the thought of having a prison built in their neighborhoods. But that feeling is not shared in many of the economically depressed towns of rural New York, where a new prison is as welcome as a new factory, department store or office building.
Not surprising, then, people in communities like Johnstown all but rejoiced when Gov. George E. Pataki recently proposed building three maximum-security prisons somewhere in the state at a cost of $476 million.
The announcement spurred an all-out contest among many communities, with elected officials, business leaders and residents lining up to urge the state to bestow the coveted prize on their hometown.
In Altamont, a small town in the Adirondacks, officials have 100 acres of land set aside to entice the state into building there and have asked their state senator to lobby the Pataki administration.
In Friendship, a town in southwestern New York about 25 miles from the Pennsylvania border, officials have been sending letters to legislators, correction officials and the Governor to request a prison.
And in Romulus, a community 60 miles west of Rochester, the Town Board scheduled a referendum to show state officials the support they would have if they chose to build there. The Town Supervisor, Raymond Zajack, said he plans to have his state senator deliver the ballot results to the Governor.
"There's much more competition today for a prison than there was a few years ago because of the economy," said Dean D. Lefebvre, Supervisor of Altamont. "But we've been after a prison a lot longer than anyone else and have the best site."
Of course, all this could be wishful thinking. At a time of tight budgets, it is by no means clear that the Legislature is even prepared to adopt Mr. Pataki's prison building plan.
The prison proposal is one of the few areas of increased spending in the Governor's proposed budget and is part of his broader plan to stiffen sentences for both adult and juvenile offenders. The new prisons each would have 1,500 beds and employ at least 500 people.
But critics question the need for any prison expansion, arguing that many Republican legislators support the plan not only because they want to get more criminals off the street but because they want to pump jobs into their districts.
Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the Assembly Corrections Committee, said that a study he conducted showed that 85 percent of the state's prison population is housed in rural Republican districts.
"It's not only lock them up," he said, "it's lock them up in my district."
Mr. Feldman and others also contend that Mr. Pataki has misplaced his priorities by suggesting more spending on prisons while proposing cutting social programs that could help keep people out of jail in the first place.
But those complaints are not likely to elicit hand-wringing in places like Johnstown, a town of about 33,000 that is one of the Republican communities considered a good candidate for a new prison.
"People have been very anxious to get a facility there," said Senator Hugh T. Farley, a Republican who is trying to deliver a prison to his Johnstown constituents. "They're very anxious for the jobs."
The prison advocacy movement in Johnstown began taking root around 1990, when state officials were looking to construct a medium-security prison.
Back then, community leaders built enormous support for the idea by holding hearings, producing a radio documentary and distributing fliers that, among other things, assured residents that relatives of inmates would not move into town and then apply for welfare.
But the town did not get the prison after all, dashing the hopes of residents in an area that continues to have one of the highest unemployment rates in the state and that has seen some of its leather mills and tanneries close.
"We really worked hard for that," lamented Russell V. Pollard, a member of the Fulton County Board of Supervisors who organized the campaign to have the medium-security prison built there.
This time around, though, Johnstown is hoping things will be different.
Peter H. Lewis, owner of the Rainbow Restaurant on Main Street, sat at the bar the other night imagining all the new customers a prison would bring him, as if the deal were done.
"It'll be great," he said. "Best thing in the world."
But suddenly it dawned on him just how much competition Johnstown was up against.
"We really have to sell this community hard," Mr. Lewis said. "This is a great place for the prison workers to live. It's a good rural community that's very centrally located. And we have bus service, too."
A few blocks away, at a convenience store, Bill Zajicek paused from his work behind the counter and weighed the advantages and disadvantages of allowing a prison to be built in town.
"No question about it, it'll bring a lot of undesirables," he said, fretting about the prospect of relatives coming to visit inmates.
On the other hand, he reasoned, the prison employees would be wonderful neighbors to have.
"They're solid taxpayers," he said. "They will buy homes and shop at our stores. They're the kind of people we need around here. So it's probably worth putting up with the undesirables."
Of course, there are opponents. Recently, the County Board of Supervisors voted to inform the state that they were not interested in a maximum-security prison; some members figured it was too large.
But Anthony C. Buanno, the chairman of the board, dismissed the vote as a hasty act of people who really did not understand what was at stake.
"I don't think the supervisors had enough information to make an intelligent decision," he said.
So he is toying with the idea of taking his colleagues on a field trip to a town that already has a prison. "That way they can see what a prison is like with their own eyes," he said.
But he has yet to decide on a town. "We're still working that out," Mr. Buanno said. "Maybe we'll go to -- what's that place called again? -- Greenhaven. I think they'll learn a lot from that."
