HEADLINE: Cozumel Journal;
Where Cruise Liners Intrude, Nafta Tests Waters

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: SAN MIGUEL DE COZUMEL, Mexico, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The reef is named Paradise, and it is an underwater heaven to a host of colorful sea creatures and the scuba divers who love to see them up close.
The coral outcropping, washed by a languid current in azure waters, is one of the most popular diving sites near the island of Cozumel, which lies off the Yucatan Peninsula. 
 Now Paradise Reef is testing the power of the North American Free Trade Agreement to promote environmental conservation. With the blessing of the Mexican Government, a private Mexican resort developer is sinking thousands of tons of concrete into the white sands and translucent waters near the reef to build an 1,800-foot pier for luxury cruise liners.
The move has met with fierce opposition from divers and others who say the project is "paving Paradise to put up a parking lot for cruise ships," in the words of Bob Sterner, a scuba diver from Hoboken, N.J., who edits a diving magazine called Immersed.
In January, Cozumel ecologists and divers filed a formal complaint with the environmental watchdog commission set up under the 1994 trade agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada, charging that the pier and the enormous ships it will receive imperil the reef's survival. The complaint accuses Mexico of sidestepping its own laws requiring extensive environmental impact studies.
On Feb. 12, the Nafta Commission for Environmental Cooperation agreed to take up the Cozumel project, the first time since the agency was created that it has decided to investigate a case and issue a judgment.
The commission was set up during the Nafta negotiations to allay the fears of conservationists that freer economic relations with Mexico, with its comparatively lax environmental laws, would lower ecological standards throughout the continent. But the commission cannot impose sanctions; the most it can do is to chastise a country its deems is tolerating egregious environmental abuses.
By taking on the pier case, the commission is wading into conflicting interests as tangled as the mangroves that line Cozumel's shores. For the pier has opened a rift among the people of Cozumel over what they want their island to be: a retreat for low-budget, reef-loving divers or a port of call for high-paying cruise ship passengers.
Cozumel is a basically lazy-living island that has received a jolt of development from the overflow of its mega-resort neighbor, Cancun, 40 miles to the north on the mainland. For decades Cozumel's vibrant reefs have been magnets for divers. Then, 25 years ago, the Mexican Government built a dock for cruise ships on the island's west coast, unleashing an inundation of day-tripping tourists -- some 1.6 million a year, local officials say -- and a chaotic hotel-building boom.
In the mid-1980's, Mexico's Transportation Ministry decided, without consulting island residents, that it was time for a second cruise pier.
Although there are miles of beach without reefs north of the existing cruise ship dock, ministry officials decreed that the new dock should go about a quarter-mile south -- 400 yards from the head of Paradise Reef.
The ministry bid out the job, which went to a private Mexican company, Consorcio H, whose ambitious $230 million plan included not only the pier but a shopping mall, two hotels and a golf course as well.
Opposition on Cozumel, which has more than 70 shops for divers, came swiftly, in the form of petitions, demonstrations, state and federal lawsuits, and protests from international diving organizations and environmental groups.
"From the beginning we always said we are not against the pier or the investment," said Dora Uribe, a Cozumel lawyer who heads the anti-dock forces. "We are just against the pier where they are putting it."
In a March 1995 referendum, 60 percent of the island's voters called for the dock to be built elsewhere.
Jose Manuel (Pico) Castello, a Cozumel dive master, explained: "Over time the constant backwash from those big ships is going to raise sand that is going to choke the reef. Besides, you can't put those boats and our divers in the same place together. It's too dangerous."
But federal environment authorities disagreed. In 1990, Consorcio H presented its own environmental impact study showing that only about 3 percent of the reef would be damaged. The National Ecological Institute accepted the study's conclusions and gave the go-ahead, but tacked on 84 clauses to control the damage.
The complaint recently filed with the Nafta commission charges that the company impact study accepted by the Government was inadequate.
Consorcio H, anxious to complete work and begin recouping its investment -- so far, at $37 million -- dutifully complied with the Government conditions. In his Mexico City headquarters, the company's president, Joaquin Haces Calvo, displayed the six-inch-thick volume of documents he has filed with different bureaucracies.
"Instead of building a dock I should be writing an encyclopedia about what it's like to invest in Mexico," Mr. Haces said. "Very, very difficult."
Mr. Haces said environmental measures alone had cost the company $2 million so far. He hired 11 biologist-divers who transplanted 23,000 corals, sponges and other organisms from where the dock is going to an area beginning 100 meters south. Eight months later, 96 percent of the resettled coral is still alive, the company biologists say, which apparently would make it the first successful coral transplant on record.
Mexico has until March 8 to present its views to the Nafta commission. Because the commission does not have the authority to levy penalties, it is unlikely to stop the completion of the pier, which is already one-third built. But it can organize a team of experts from its three member countries to issue what could be the first disinterested, scientific opinion regarding the reef and its future.
Mexico's environmental authorities stand by their original approval and contend that they complied with the law.
"As far as we are concerned that case is closed," said Gabriel Quadri de la Torre, director of the National Ecology Institute.
Yet even the biologists who work for Consorcio H have expressed concern about the health of Paradise Reef after years of exposure to the sandy wake of the huge cruise ships. They are calling for new regulations requiring that tugboats be used to ease the ships up to the docks.
Meanwhile, the protests continue. Last Tuesday, members of the international environmental group Greenpeace swarmed over the pier and chained themselves to the top of a giant crane, halting work for the day. Consorcio H's director in Cozumel, Javier Herndez, greeted them with a big green sign saying "Welcome Greenpeace!" and gamely invited them into his offices for a debate.
"Why are you making us ground zero?" Mr. Herndez asked. "Frankly, it would have been a lot easier for us if the Government had just said 'no' at the start."

HEADLINE: In Immigration Bill Debate, Divisions and Odd Alliances

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Congress will begin final debate this week on the most restrictive immigration laws in 30 years and the first cuts in the number of foreigners entering the country legally since the 1920's.
As lawmakers return from a three-week recess, Republican leaders are counting on passage of a major immigration bill to enhance their thin legislative record this term. But the bills in the House and Senate face resistance from an unlikely alliance of high-technology companies, grass-roots immigrant groups, civil-liberties organizations and conservative research groups. 
 There are Republicans and Democrats on both sides of the issue, but Republicans are most deeply divided. Both parties support tightening the country's borders against the estimated 300,000 foreigners who enter the United States illegally or overstay their visas each year. But many Republicans also want to cut levels of legal immigration, now about 775,000 people a year, by 30 percent or more.
"The current legal immigration system is indefensible," said Representative Lamar Smith, a Texas Republican who is the chief sponsor of the House bill. "We just can't admit everybody who wants to come."
However, free-market-oriented Republicans like Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader; former Education Secretary William J. Bennett, and former Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp support high levels of legal immigration as a wellspring of economic growth and innovation.
"Immigration today simply is not in the crisis stage that critics portray it to be," Mr. Armey has written to constituents who ask his views on immigration. "Most immigrants today are not sponges off the system; they are hard-working, and they carry with them that work ethic that made America great."
The demographics of immigration raise the political stakes dramatically in a Presidential election year. More than 70 percent of the nation's legal and illegal immigrants live in six large, voter-rich states -- California, Texas, Florida, New York, New Jersey and Illinois -- where many officials are worried that immigrants unduly burden local services.
In California, for example, immigrants make up 21 percent of all households but receive 40 percent of public assistance like Medicaid, food stamps and housing subsidies, said George J. Borjas, a professor of public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
But some Republican strategists fear the immigration bills could backfire by angering vast numbers of potential voters who are sponsoring nearly two million family members now on waiting lists in visa categories that would be eliminated.
Morever, many high-technology companies that need more skilled workers than the United States produces, including Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Texas Instruments, have expressed anger that the Senate bill would hinder their ability to hire skilled foreign workers.
"As a political issue, this could blow up in the Republicans' face," said Stephen Moore, a former aide to Mr. Armey who is director of fiscal policy at the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization that opposes restrictions on legal immigration.
The three leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination have given only very general positions on the politically charged issue. Patrick J. Buchanan favors a five-year moratorium on most legal immigration. Senator Bob Dole supports modest cuts in the number of foreigners entering the country legally. Lamar Alexander endorses current legal immigration levels but would create a new branch of the military to patrol the border.
The Clinton Administration has taken several high-profile steps in recent months to fight illegal immigration and to open jobs for American citizens: using the military and local law-enforcement agencies to bolster the Border Patrol and barring Federal contracts to companies that illegally hire undocumented workers.
But the White House is not reminding people of Mr. Clinton's endorsement last year of a Federal advisory panel's recommendations to cut legal immigration by one-third. That position puts Mr. Clinton at odds with many of his usual supporters, like Hispanic, Jewish and Asian-American groups.
The immigration debate in Congress heats up again this Thursday when the Senate Judiciary Committee considers its version of the bill. The House is scheduled to vote on a similar bill the week of March 18.
The political drama is set against the nation's largest influx of immigrants since the turn of the century. Nearly 10 million immigrants have taken up residence in the United States legally in the last 10 years, including three million illegal aliens who were given amnesty under the 1986 Immigration and Reform and Control Act.
But economic recession and a public perception that the United States has lost control of its borders have powered popular movements to clamp down on illegal immigration and, increasingly, on which family members may be brought into the country legally by citizens or permanent residents.
"Is it in the national interest to bring in people through chain migration with no skills, who do not learn English, who join their extended family but don't join our society?" asked Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican who is the chief sponsor of the Senate bill.
Fueling much of this debate are two questions: Do immigrants displace Americans in the job market, and do immigrants receive more in public assistance than American citizens?
Both sides have marshaled statistics to support their positions. The information regarding jobs is incomplete. Some studies suggest that while immigrants may not take away jobs (in fact, in many cases they create new ones), they reduce the prospects for lower-skilled workers in weak local economies.
The welfare question is just as muddied. Each side uses definitions of public assistance and census information that supports its point.
The Urban Institute, a research organization, says that 95 percent of immigrants do not receive welfare.
But Professor Borjas of Harvard says that 21 percent of immigrant households receive some type of public assistance, compared with 14 percent of native households.
As lawmakers debate these arguments, the first challenge to the House and Senate bills is expected this week. Some lawmakers hope to separate the two issues of legal and illegal immigration; the bills now combine them.
"The current approach would dramatically hurt the American economy and cost us jobs," said Senator Spencer Abraham, a Michigan Republican who opposes restrictions on legal immigration and who is heading the effort to split the Senate bill into two parts.
Mr. Smith has fended off similar challenges in the House by accommodating concerns of business groups. Mr. Simpson suggested that he, too, was open to compromise.
"We're not out to stop Bill Gates from getting the best guy in Germany to do some kind of X chip," said Mr. Simpson, referring to Microsoft's chairman. "I'll take care of the business community."
High-technology companies are also upset at provisions in the Senate bill that would cut the number of visas issued to foreigners sponsored by businesses to 90,000 a year from 140,000, and would require companies to pay at least $10,000 for each new foreign hire.
"It strikes me as very odd that this bill is coming out of a Republican Congress," said Ira Rubinstein, a senior lawyer for Microsoft.
Mr. Smith and Mr. Simpson may have more trouble promoting a national verification system to check visa status. Critics including the National Rifle Association and the American Civil Liberties Union fear such a system would lead to a national identification card.
But the most emotional issue centers on efforts to cut family-sponsored immigration. The House and Senate bills would eliminate visa categories for brothers and sisters of citizens, and for adult children of citizens and permanent residents. Those visas would go to clear up a 1.1 million-member backlog of spouses and minor children of permanent residents.
This tradeoff between "extended" and "nuclear" family members has angered many citizens sponsoring their relatives.
Dr. Janaki Manian, a 51-year-old psychiatrist in Detroit, emigrated from India and in 1984 became a naturalized citizen. Two years later she sponsored a visa request for her older brother, Chandra Vasudevan, a tax-auditing expert who is waiting to emigrate from India. The proposed bills would eliminate Mr. Vasudevan's chances to immigrate.
"It's really disappointing they want to wipe it out completely," Dr. Manian said. "Having gone through all this paperwork and phone calls, I think it's fair to let people in who applied 10 or 15 years ago."

HEADLINE: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Work Force;
Better Training In Pittsburgh

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25

 BODY:
New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?
The Regional Plan Association, an organization based in Manhattan that issued a 25-year agenda this month for the 31-county three-state region, has violated that taboo. The group studied metropolitan areas all over the world searching for urban ingenuity and found inspiration in a greenbelt around San Francisco, a broad-based travel card in London, a regional government in Portland, Ore., business district development in Tokyo and work force training in Pittsburgh. The final report from the planning group, after five years of research, identified these lessons as important ones for this region. 
 During the recessionary 1980's, available jobs shifted from steel mills to a combination of high-technology, biomedical and service industry jobs. Demand for workers emphasized high skills. The Allegheny Conference, a board made up of many of the region's top business executives and elected leaders, was concerned that schools were producing a surplus of graduates with minimal skills and set a goal of a better trained work force.
Using a $10 million grant from a Baltimore foundation, the Pittsburgh Public Schools started the New Futures Program to improve overall school performance. Now it includes an assortment of "school to job site" programs aimed at improving student job skills. It is also trying to coordinate job-training efforts in a county with 130 separate municipalities and 43 separate school districts.
There have been successes and failures. Working through a combination of Federal and foundation money, a program has been formed that certifies high-school students in 24 basic skills required by regional employers. It is a sort of buyer's warranty for businesses that they will not have to train new employees in skills they should have picked up in the schools.
Other efforts have met with less success and point to the problems of getting the many municipalities that constitute Allegheny County to pool their resources.
The programs face another problem as well. Money is running out. On June 30, the Anne E. Casey Foundation, the educational foundation based in Baltimore that started the project with its initial grant to the city's public schools, will cease its aid. Edgar Holtz, a director of the Allegheny Policy Council for Youth and Work Force Development, which is coordinating the programs, predicted that the council would be able to attract some financing from Pittsburgh-area foundations, but probably not enough to prevent cutbacks in programs.

HEADLINE: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Business Districts;
Suburban Tokyo Focuses Inward

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK
TOKYO, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?
The Regional Plan Association, an organization based in Manhattan that issued a 25-year agenda this month for the 31-county three-state region, has violated that taboo. The group studied metropolitan areas all over the world searching for urban ingenuity and found inspiration in a greenbelt around San Francisco, a broad-based travel card in London, a regional government in Portland, Ore., business district development in Tokyo and work force training in Pittsburgh. The final report from the planning group, after five years of research, identified these lessons as important ones for this region. 
 The Regional Plan Association calls for the restoration of central cities in the New York area as a way to slow suburban and rural sprawl. In Tokyo, planners say their transportation system helps them push new development in high-density centers.
In the Tokyo metropolitan region, home to more than 30 million people, commuting is mainly by trains and development is often clustered near railroad stations, explained Hidehiko Tanimura, a professor of urban planning at the University of Tsukuba. Highways are in a star pattern, all heading toward Tokyo.
In the New York area, by contrast, some railroad stations, as in Princeton, are surrounded by parking lots, not buildings, and highways in outlying areas are better developed. Therefore, Professor Tanimura said, "It's inevitable to have development far away from the center."
Tokyo does have its own version of urban sprawl. Partly because of a fear of earthquakes, there are relatively few high-rise buildings, even downtown, with a result that the region spreads over a wide area. Many people endure commuting up to two hours each way on trains that are so overcrowded that commuters have to be pushed into the cars by conductors.
There have been some attempts to create urban cores outside of central Tokyo. In the 1980's, the national Government created Tsukuba, a research and science city about 45 miles from Tokyo.
The latest and most audacious proposal is to move the capital out of Tokyo. While removing Government offices from the city center would help relieve overcrowding, the driving force behind this proposal is not so much urban planning as the desire to decentralize power by separating Japan's political capital from its business capital. Right now, Tokyo is so important that one fourth of Japan's population lives in the Tokyo metropolitan area.
Building a new capital would also provide a lot of jobs and help stimulate Japan's weak economy.

HEADLINE: How Other Cities Succeed: Five Ideas to Revitalize New York's Region: Transportation;
A Pass for Riders All Over London

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
New York has assimilated millions of people and dozens of dizzyingly diverse cultures from around the world over the years, but it has never made much effort to borrow or imitate how other places solve their problems. The experience of the city and the surrounding region was always considered singular -- the problems were bigger, the political dynamic was different. Or perhaps the region was just too proud. New York was No. 1, and who could have anything to teach it?
The Regional Plan Association, an organization based in Manhattan that issued a 25-year agenda this month for the 31-county three-state region, has violated that taboo. The group studied metropolitan areas all over the world searching for urban ingenuity and found inspiration in a greenbelt around San Francisco, a broad-based travel card in London, a regional government in Portland, Ore., business district development in Tokyo and work force training in Pittsburgh. The final report from the planning group, after five years of research, identified these lessons as important ones for this region. 
 Londoners have been worrying for a decade that the privatization of their public transportation systems might lead to the same sort of Balkanization that has snarled the New York region's roads, rails and runways for years. "I'm afraid we may be mess-ifying things here," said Caralampo Focas, head of research and consultancy at the London Research Centre.
Nonetheless, many aspects of the transportation network that whizzes Londoners about town and ferries travelers from Heathrow Airport into the city, the world's largest crossroad for international travel, would make the native New Yorker gasp.
Most noticeable, of course, is the scrubbed and polished environment in which most of this city's commuting takes place. Even though trash baskets have been removed from most subway stations because they are ideal places to hide bombs, one never steps in old gum or slips on a cast-aside newspaper. "If you provide high-quality, clean transport with strong security, it creates a comfortable atmosphere that makes it not so much a place where you'll take out your frustration over being unemployed," Mr. Focas said.
But London's transportation system is also unified by the "travel card," a single pass that gives the bearer access to the bus, the subway and the commuter rail lines. Travel cards can be bought for weekly, monthly or annual travel around the city, and they make passage between different systems seamless.
Also, public transportation is less expensive here than in the New York area, according to another study by Mr. Focas. Of 14 major metropolitan areas around the globe, the cost of an average week's commuter travel is highest in New York.
But while a diehard New Yorker would find the London transit system a model of efficiency, Londoners are paying the price for their own government's neglect of the system. A subway overhaul this year is causing station closings and other disruptions, while repairs to an overpass on one of the major routes to Heathrow threaten to tie up traffic for almost a decade.
"We're a sort of halfway house model, perhaps, for New York," Mr. Focas said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Texas Balancing Act Is Succeeding

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
AS Southern California's experiment in balancing development with wildlife preservation approaches a critical juncture, another ambitious program may have turned the corner to success -- contrary to some recent expectations.
Seven years in the making, the Balcones Canyonlands Conservation Plan is an effort to carve out an assembly of nature preserves consisting of 70,000 to 75,000 acres just west of here, on the eastern edge of the Texas Hill Country -- a vast, picturesque landscape of juniper-clad hills and deep, wooded canyons whose biological health remains relatively good.
"It's hard to believe 650,000 people live out here," Jim Fries, the director of the Nature Conservancy's regional conservation program, said recently as he stood atop a cliff not far outside Austin and gazed across a seemingly trackless wilderness. But development is encroaching rapidly. The Balcones conservation plan was designed as part of a broader long-term strategy to reconcile economic growth with nature's requirements throughout the 19,000-square-mile Hill Country ecosystem. 
 The ecosystem is home to a handful of endangered species, chiefly the golden-cheeked warbler, and developers cannot destroy the species' habitat without a special Federal permit. In 1988, fearing chaos if each developer had to negotiate separately, Austin-area authorities invited the Nature Conservancy to help devise a countywide plan balancing building and biology. The Endangered Species Act allows such regional arrangements.
Thirty thousand of the acres to be preserved, situated where development pressure is greatest, are being assembled by the governments of Austin and Travis County and Nature Conservancy. The Federal Government is to acquire the remaining land, which lies just beyond the frontier of spreading development.
Some of the local share is land bought and donated to the preserve by developers, who are then guaranteed uncontested developments elsewhere. Some 11,000 acres have been bought by the City of Austin using the proceeds of a bond issue passed in 1992. Several thousand more acres have been assembled by the Nature Conservancy. In all, 21,000 of the 30,000 acres to be protected by local officials have already been acquired.
When a Travis County bond issue that would have completed the package failed in 1993, some observers gave the project up for dead. Among them were Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer, the authors of "Noah's Choice," an influential 1995 book about the Endangered Species Act. But alternative financing mechanisms are now in place to permit acquisition of the last 9,000 acres.
That will enable the overall plan to take effect once the United States Fish and Wildlife Service approves it, which will probably be soon. "We are ready to sign off on it shortly," said John Duffy, an Interior Department official. "It's a great plan."

HEADLINE: Push by I.M.F. Won't Serve Russia Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Here we go again as the International Monetary Fund pulls financial reins to put Russia on the path of privatization and trade liberalization to retard the growing support for the Communists that might block Russia's move toward a capitalist economy (front page, Feb. 23). 
 It is indeed shocking that the International Monetary Fund continues to push its analysis that countries adopting free-market policies are on the path toward economic recovery when there is enough proof against it.
Countries set on the path of trade liberalization have been confronted by increased unemployment and poverty, environmental degradation, drastic cutbacks in welfare programs and widening gaps between rich and poor.
Economic restructuring has led to destabilization of human resources and productive assets.
President Boris N. Yeltsin's hopes of using the first installment of $4 billion on increased social spending will not be fulfilled under this model.
The International Monetary Fund wants Russia to increase government revenues to pay for social programs. The agency's adjustment programs are based on a model that does not recognize the importance of investing in people and does not support development based on the ethical principles of justice and environmental principles of sustainability.
 
ANURADHA MITTAL
Policy Director, Institute
for Food and Development Policy
Oakland, Calif., Feb. 23, 1996

HEADLINE: Who Says Republicans Are Free Traders?

BYLINE: By Alfred E. Eckes; Alfred E. Eckes, professor of history at Ohio University, is a former chairman of the United States International Trade Commission.

DATELINE: ATHENS, Ohio

 BODY:
In the New Hampshire primary, Patrick Buchanan pressed the hot button that energized many 19th-century Presidential campaigns. Blasting one-sided trade deals that he says cost American workers jobs, he reinvigorated the economic nationalist tradition in the Republican Party.
Many Republicans think Mr. Buchanan's views are un-Republican. Since World War II, the party establishment has embraced free trade and economic internationalism as a grand panacea for global problems. However, from a historical perspective, Mr. Buchanan best exemplifies traditional Republican thinking on trade issues. 
 From Abraham Lincoln in 1860 to Alf Landon in 1936, every Republican Presidential candidate ran on a platform endorsing high protective tariffs -- averaging more than 40 percent ad valorem on dutiable goods.
A century ago, American politicians considered free trade an epithet and protectionism an accolade. Most Republican candidates proudly embraced economic nationalism and dismissed Democratic opponents as "English free-traders." Republicans thought free-traders led inexorably to low wages and economic ruin. Protectionism was associated with prosperity and independence.
Preaching class harmony, 19th-century Republican economic nationalists justified the protective tariff as essential for protecting domestic workers from imports made by cheap European labor. They considered the tariff a fee on foreign manufacturers for participating in the American market. The tariff, they said, did not raise consumer prices; it promoted vigorous domestic competition.
Lincoln, the first Republican President, advocated a moderate tariff. He adhered to the view that the "abandonment of the protective policy . . . must result in the increase of . . . idleness; and so in proportion must produce want and ruin among our people."
President William McKinley, who as a Congressman sponsored the McKinley Tariff, enjoyed castigating Democratic free-traders. In one famous speech, he warned in Buchanan-like language: "Free trade will bring widespread discontent. It will revolutionize values. It will take away more than one half of the earning capacity of brain and brawn."
Theodore Roosevelt expressed similar sympathies. In 1895, he wrote a friend: "Thank God I am not a free-trader. In this country, pernicious indulgence in the doctrine of free trade seems inevitably to produce fatty degeneration of the moral fibre."
From 1860 to 1932 the high-tariff card worked well for Republican candidates. Their position appealed to business, agriculture and working people. Republicans won 14 of 18 Presidential elections. Democrats, portrayed as dupes of English free-trade theorists, achieved few victories until the 1912 struggle between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft divided the Republican Party and helped elect Woodrow Wilson, who then reduced the tariffs on dutiable goods from an average of 41 percent to 27 percent.
But the resulting concern about cheap imports, as well as opposition to the League of Nations, gave Republicans a rallying cry. The 1920 Republican convention and its candidate, Warren G. Harding, reaffirmed the party's commitment to the protective tariff.
His victory led to the passage of the 1922 Fordney-McCumber Act, which raised tariff rates on dutiable goods without depressing the quantity of imports or disrupting world trade. Indeed, new scholarly research demonstrates that higher protective rates of the Smooth-Hawley Tariff of 1930 had little impact on American trade and did not provoke widespread retaliation.
Republicans were solid protectionists until after World War II. Then, President Dwight Eisenhower, concerned about helping our Allies and former adversaries recover from the war, continued the Democrats' tariff-cutting program. He prevailed against many Congressional Republicans who remained true to the high- tariff principles of Lincoln, McKinley and Calvin Coolidge.
Interestingly, one of the last articulate Republican trade nationalists was Senator Prescott Bush of Connecticut, President George Bush's father. The elder Bush said in 1966: "I never was a free-trader. I never felt that we could . . . do away with all protective devices, because we would have been flooded with imports which would have hurt our economy."
Do elements of traditional economic nationalism offer a road map for the 21st century? The record appears to show that it has served the Republican Party and the country well. In the generation after 1870, America protected its market and experienced economic growth more than double that of free-trade England. Exports soared and paradoxically consumer prices fell.
On trade, Mr. Buchanan's view are consistent with those of a long line of Republican leaders. He deserves credit for reopening this debate and for challenging conventional economic nostrums.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

TYPE: Op-Ed

COMPANY: REPUBLICAN PARTY (95%);

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Falling Stocks and Bonds Help To Keep Dollar From Rallying

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday in quiet trading, weighed down by declines in the stock and bond markets.
The declines raised fears that foreign investors would sell American assets and convert the dollar proceeds into other currencies. 
 "With U.S. financial markets down, it's difficult for the dollar to sustain any kind of rally," said Dan Ascani, an editor and publisher with Global Market Strategists Inc., an advisory firm in Gainesville, Ga. "Traders pretty much went home without committing themselves."
The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 65.39 points yesterday, to 5,565.10. Treasury prices also fell, driving the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, to 6.45 percent from 6.4 percent.
The dollar was also hurt by continued speculation about a possible rise in Japanese interest rates. Currency traders say that recent remarks by Japanese financial officials have suggested that such an increase is in the offing. Higher rates would bolster the yen.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 104.25 yen, from 104.77 on Friday. The dollar was trading at 1.4494 marks, up from 1.4470.
Japanese investors were assumed to be among the sellers yesterday, analysts said, because Japanese exporters typically move funds home toward the end of their fiscal year on March 31. The dollar had been rallying against the yen through late January but has fallen in recent sessions.
But the dollar was supported against the yen by concerns of further intervention by the Bank of Japan to support the dollar. Traders estimate that the central bank spent as much as $10 billion last week to weaken the yen and bolster the dollar.
In other currency trading, the dollar and other currencies rose against the British pound as traders squared positions ahead of an important vote last night for the ruling Conservative Government. The vote, which the Conservatives won by a single ballot, was on a report into the British Government's role in the sales of military equipment to Iraq. The Government's majority was pared to two seats late last week.
In New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.5397, down from $1.5410 on Friday.

HEADLINE: New Era of Robust Elderly Belies Fears of Scientists

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
They called it the failure of success. As medical scientists got better and better at treating people with fatal diseases -- but not curing them -- the nation would be burdened with an accumulation of elderly people who were living longer and longer but were crippled with pain and riddled with disabilities.
It was a notion that called into question what medicine had wrought. But, to nearly everyone's surprise, the predicted pandemic of pain and disability has not materialized. Instead, new information, some not yet published, on studies involving people at all socioeconomic levels show that not only are Americans living longer, but they are developing less chronic disease and disability. And the reasons may have as much to do with changing social circumstances, including events that occur in the first few decades of life, as they have to do with medical advances in treating diseases. 
 The National Long Term Care Surveys, a Federal study that regularly surveys close to 20,000 people aged 65 and older, finds that every year there is a smaller and smaller percentage of old people who are unable to take care of themselves, unable to comb their hair or feed themselves or take a walk.
The surveys use the Medicare population, which includes about 99 percent of all Americans, regardless of their income levels, who are 65 and older. Data from 1994 have just been compiled and analyses have not yet been published, but continue to support the picture of the healthier old.
Although the annual declines in disability rates are only about 1 percent to 2 percent a year, they have continued unabated since 1982, when the survey began, until 1994, the most recent survey. At the same time, the percentage of old people with chronic diseases, like high blood pressure, arthritis and emphysema, has steadily declined.
For example, the number of people over 65 with high blood pressure fell to 39.5 percent in 1989 from 46 percent in 1982. In that period, the number with arthritis dropped to 63.1 percent from 71.1 percent, and the number with emphysema fell to 6.4 percent from 8.9 percent.
The implications are profound, said Dr. Richard Suzman, who directs demography research at the National Institute on Aging.
"This plays to the general question of what's going to happen as the older population, and especially the oldest old, mushrooms in size over the next 50 years," Dr. Suzman said.
It could mean that the growing elderly population may not be quite the economic drain that it was projected to be. The longer people live, Dr. Suzman said, the longer they will need programs like Medicare. But the new findings indicate that Medicare costs might be much less than expected in the coming years, even with the increased life spans of Americans.
For example, Dr. Kenneth Manton, a demographer at Duke University who analyzed the National Long Term Care Surveys, calculates that declining disability rates from 1982 until 1995 have saved Medicare $200 billion. He explained that if the disability rates of 1982 had held steady into 1995, there would have been nearly 300,000 more disabled people aged 65 to 74 in the population last year than 13 years ago. Instead, there were nearly 121,000 fewer disabled people in 1995 than in 1982 in this age group, resulting in the Medicare savings.
Although some demographers have been wary of the new evidence that disease and disability rates are declining, many now say they believe the decline is real. "The evidence is limited but different people have shown with different sources of data the same thing," said Dr. Douglas Wolf, a demographer at Syracuse University. "The preponderance of evidence seems to show that this is true."
There is little doubt that the elderly population is exploding, in large part because death rates from many chronic diseases are plummeting. The annual mortality rate for Americans of all ages from strokes dropped 65.2 percent (79.7 deaths per 100,000 to 27.0 deaths per 100,000) from 1960 to 1990 and the death rate from heart disease dropped 46.9 percent (286.2 per 100,000 to 152.0 per 100,000) in that period, Dr. Manton said.
But the true picture of the steady improvement in these old people's lives comes from studies that ask about how well they go about their daily activities. The best national data, Dr. Wolf and others said, are from the National Long Term Care Surveys. The surveys follow people enrolled in the Medicare program, asking where they live, what their diseases are and whether they are able to care for themselves.
The surveys, Dr. Manton said, are "the closest thing we have to a national population registry."
The picture of a robust elderly population that emerges from these surveys is confirmed by a different kind of study, one that looks at the ability to work. Dr. Eileen Crimmins of the University of Southern California has been analyzing data from a representative sample of about 12,000 Americans aged 50 to 69 for the last 11 years. The people in the study are asked whether their physical or mental health affects their ability to work.
Over the course of the study, Dr. Crimmins and her colleagues found that fewer and fewer people said their ability to work was impaired. For example, in 1982 about 27 percent of men aged 67 to 69 said they were unable to work. But in 1992, just 20 percent of men in that age group could not work. "We regard the ability to work as an indicator of disability," Dr. Crimmins said.
The study was sponsored by the Social Security Administration.
Dr. Crimmins said the declines in reported disability that she observed applied equally to blacks and whites and to the rich and poor.
All these findings lead demographers and researchers on aging to ask why it is that older Americans are less frail and feeble than ever before.
One answer seems to be that people either are not developing the diseases that cripple and disable or are getting them at older ages, Dr. Manton said.
In his survey, he asked about 16 diseases, including diabetes, heart disease, cancer, chronic lung diseases and arthritis. The number of diseases afflicting people over 65 declined by more than 11 percent over the last decade, Dr. Manton said. The largest declines were in the number of people with arthritis or joint problems, high blood pressure and heart disease.
Of course, saying people are healthier because they have fewer diseases begs the question. Why do old people have fewer diseases today than in previous years?
One possibility, Dr. Suzman and others said, is that the changes are an effect of education. In study after study, educational level is associated with better health.
However, higher levels of education are also associated with greater wealth, and it has not been demonstrated that education itself produces beneficial effects.
"Education is one of the most powerful and mysterious variables," Dr. Suzman said. It is associated with health "throughout life and late in life." And there has been a dramatic increase in the education levels of the elderly.
Dr. Samuel Preston, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, calculated that in 1980 more than 60 percent of Americans from 85 to 89 had fewer than eight years of schooling. But by the year 2015, that figure will have dropped to 10 percent to 15 percent.
"We are at the cusp of a rapid increase in the educational status of the oldest old," Dr. Manton said. And, he said, people who are better educated tend to be more likely to change their diets to improve their health, to be nonsmokers and to seek out treatments, like hip and knee replacements, that can prevent disability, Dr. Manton said.
Another possible explanation for the improved health of the elderly, researchers said, is that old people are reaping the benefits of improvements in public health that occurred when they were young. This might mean that people today would enter old age without the subtle lifelong burdens that afflicted earlier generations who were more likely to have had marginal nutrition, poor water quality and poor hygiene.
Then, Dr. Suzman said, there is the contribution of medical advances, like hip replacements, lens replacements for people with cataracts, angioplasty for heart disease, drugs to slow the bone loss of osteoporosis. These could delay or prevent the terrible burdens of chronic diseases that afflicted previous generations.
For now, researchers say they are uncertain which factors are most important in changing the picture of old age in America. But they are convinced that the picture has indeed changed.
"I think that what we define as being elderly has sort of moved up, age-wise," Dr. Manton said. Not too long ago, it might have been expected for a 60-year-old to be frail, to seem elderly. But no more, he added.
 
Still Keeping in Touch at 85
"I feel like I'm about 30 or 40 -- until I look in a mirror," said Virginia McCalmont, 85. "So I try not to look in the mirror." She lives with her cat, Misty, in Clarksville, Md., in a rural area, driving wherever she wants to go.
She goes through three books a week. Books, she said, "keep me alive." But she has no interest in exercise. "I'm lazy," she said.
A widow, she stays in close touch with her three children and takes care of her house, where she has lived for 40 years. Her one regret? "I just wish I was young enough to understand computers," she said. But she added: "I have no need for them. There is no need to burden my mind."
 
Living Well With Disabilities
Frances Brooks, 81, and James Brooks, 87, of Great Falls, Va., live on a 50-acre farm with 20 horses near Washington. "It's a great life," Mrs. Brooks said. She said she and her husband "both have our disabilities, but we live with them."
Surgery for three skin tumors on one leg did not keep her from the things she loves: entertaining, swimming, going to exercise classes, playing with grandchildren like Jeremy Brooks and ballroom dancing.
"Yesterday, we were dancing for three hours," Mr. Brooks said. Until two years ago, he did nearly all the farm work himself. He recently gave up riding, saying he was "getting to the point where I don't want to fall." He added, "as they say, you're no rider if you ain't been tossed."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
1996's gold-price rise sets bulls, bears and bankers to predicting.

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
THIS year's mini-gold rush has opened a split of Klondike proportions between the precious metal's bulls and bears.
To the bulls, it suggests that the market is finally awakening to a fundamental imbalance between rising world demand and falling production that points to a further sustained rise in price. And that belief was supported by a sharp rally in gold that took it from $388.10 at the end of last year to $417.70 on the Commodity Exchange in New York earlier this month, its highest price in more than five years. 
 But the bears worry that one way or another the vast hoard of gold that central banks sit on -- about 35,000 tons, or roughly one-third of all that mankind has ever found -- is going to spoil the party, particularly as these supplies pass into the hands of a new generation of central bankers, trained in portfolio management and less sensitive to gold's mystique. And they may be feeling better now, as the price of gold slipped below $400 in New York on Friday and closed yesterday just above that, at $400.60 an ounce.
"This is temporary," said Bette Raptopoulos, a gold analyst at Prudential Securities. "We could still see gold reach $450 to $460 this year."
"Its just a blip," added Sam E. K. Jonah, chief executive of Ashanti Goldfields Company Ltd., the world's seventh-largest producer, based in Accra, Ghana, which this month listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The fundamentals are good," Mr. Jonah said. "There is tremendous demand potential in Asia linked to the new middle class."
"Gold is more likely to end the year at $365," countered Andy Smith, precious-metals analyst for the Union Bank of Switzerland, who said that declining mine output would have the market impact of "a small cream bun on the Empire State Building."
Explanations abound why gold finally smashed its $400-an-ounce ceiling of recent years after shrugging off the Persian Gulf war, the collapse of the Soviet Union and the Mexican peso crash.
Technically, the scene for a rally was set late last year, when South Africa moved to sell about 300 tons, which it had not yet mined, for future delivery so as to lock in the then-current price.
The South African forward sales coincided with a shortage of lendable gold to cover the sale, which helped push the current price of gold higher and caused a spike in the cost of leasing the gold to cover a forward sale.
Then, late in January, the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto announced that it was cutting its forward gold-selling by one-third in a move that some analysts expect other miners to follow. "We've become inactive as a forward seller, too," Mr. Jonah of Ashanti Goldfields said, "because we don't want to take the steam out of the rally."
Any suggestion that miners will stop selling gold they have not yet dug lifts market prices. And as prices rise, miners have even less incentive to sell forward because they might get more for their gold by waiting.
Many other factors contributed to the price rise. Although inflation is low, the weakened state of the German, French and Japanese economies suggests to some that a renewal of inflation rather than austerity lies ahead. "If Europe gives up on its single currency, there will be more inflation," said Ian McDonald of Credit Suisse.
In the meantime, generally high stock prices and relatively low bond yields encourage investors to look at other markets, and the continuing budget standoff between the White House and Congress unnerves many.
"If U.S. leaders cannot come to any kind of agreement over something as important as the budget deficit, confidence is bound to take a knock," said Rhona O'Connell, gold analyst with T. Hoare & Company of London, who expects gold to trade between $385 and $440 this year.
Then there is the underlying gap between production and demand. Mine output has been falling since 1993, reaching 2,268 tons last year, according to Gold Fields Mineral Services, a London analyst, with 590 more tons entering the market as scrap. But demand from the jewelry and electronics industries, as well as that for coins and ingots, is rising, reaching 3,550 tons last year, or more than 700 tons above supply.
Central banks have been filling this gap and holding the price steady by both selling gold directly and leasing bullion to cover forward mine sales.
What will determine the future price of gold, analysts agree, is how much metal the central banks will make available to the market and whether mining companies continue to sell unmined gold for future delivery. The imbalance between mine and scrap supply, and the demand, should have forced the price up over the last two years. But it held remarkably steady because of the central bankers' involvement.
Some major central banks, including the United States Federal Reserve and the banks of France, Switzerland, Germany and Japan, have already made clear that they will neither sell nor lease their gold.
But in a 1993 study of the gold-leasing market, Ian Cox, a British expert, reckoned that 45 to 50 central banks were lending some of their gold, seeing this as a profitable way to earn a return on what would otherwise be a sterile asset.
Certainly, all the signs are that central banks are now managing their gold reserves more actively. The cost of leasing has slipped back from November's high. And since 1983, gold held by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for foreign central banks has fallen sharply -- to 6,360 tons from 10,619, probably in part because of transfers to London, where most leasing takes place.
Those who doubt that gold will go much higher believe that central banks are likely to become even more active in the gold market and that this will encourage a return to forward selling by mining companies. "Barrick was temporary," Mr Cox said. "Hedging growth will continue."
"A new generation of central bankers is coming along who will be net sellers of gold," predicted Mr. Smith of the Union Bank of Switzerland, adding: "They understand modern portfolio-management theory. They know they are overweight in gold. That is the threat to the price."

HEADLINE: Comptroller Lists Doubts On Plan to Move Workers

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 26

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall charged today that Gov. George E. Pataki had exaggerated the benefits of his plan to move nearly 5,000 state-financed jobs out of the Democratic strongholds of New York City and Albany, signaling that he was leaning against approving it.
Mr. McCall, a Democrat who by law must sign off on the deal if it is to be approved, said he was highly skeptical of Mr. Pataki's contention that it would save the state money. The plan would shift the workers to vacant buildings owned by I.B.M. in two upstate towns that are in Republican areas. 
 After months of holding back criticism, the Comptroller suggested that Mr. Pataki, a Republican, was using the jobs as fodder for the party's patronage machine, saying that the administration was pitting regions of the state against one another.
"The perception that this is a political issue of helping one community economically at the expense of another has really been very harmful for the state," Mr. McCall said in an interview.
Mr. McCall's assertions brought a quick rebuke from Pataki administration officials. They accused him of meddling in the affairs of the executive branch to boost his standing among Democrats and lay the groundwork for an expected run for Governor in 1998.
First proposed early last year and explained as an effort to consolidate the state's data-processing facilities, the job-transfer plan has turned into one of the administration's most contentious initiatives. Cities and towns that will lose jobs have reacted angrily, while those that will gain have applauded the Governor.
Seeking to mend relations with Mr. Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has declined to attack the Governor over the part of the plan that would move up to 500 state jobs from the city to I.B.M. buildings in Glendale, which is in Broome County near Binghamton. The other I.B.M. site the state wants to use is in Kingston, in Ulster County.
The Pataki administration estimates that the plan -- which would move about 1,200 state workers and about 3,650 private workers who are on contract to the state -- would save $52 million a year.
Mr. Giuliani has said that he agrees with Mr. Pataki that the proposal will help the state. The Mayor's office declined to comment on Mr. McCall's comments today.
Mr. McCall, who is from Manhattan, said he doubted many of the figures that the Governor had used to justify the deal.
"I don't believe that their numbers add up," Mr. McCall said. "We do not think that they have made the case."
He said he would send a letter to the administration later this week outlining his concerns and, if they were not met, would reject the deal. He noted that, "These are pretty difficult things to overcome."
Mr. McCall focused in particular on the administration's estimate of $52 million in savings, questioning why that number has not changed over the last year even as the plan has been revamped.
And he pointed out that the administration had never conducted a full-scale study to examine the advantage of the moves. Only recently, he said, did it put out a contract for an outside consultant to give advice on the plan.
Originally, Mr. Pataki wanted to move only government jobs to the two sites. But after opposition from unions and State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, whose district includes many state workers in Albany, he shifted gears in September and decided to move 3,650 private jobs from Albany as well as a small number of state workers.
The private jobs are from the Fleet Financial Group, which is under contract to process state tax forms.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said the administration had developed the plan carefully and was confident that it would be successful.
"The previous administration believed in doing nothing but studies," Ms. Mucha said. "We have seen enough studies to know that this is the right course. It will save the taxpayers money, and it will increase efficiency in government."
But Mr. McCall also said he believed the Legislature might have to approve the deal because the state would be paying about $13 million to $14 million annually for lease payments, maintenance and other costs for the eight I.B.M. buildings, which have about 1.4 million square feet of space.
If the Legislature did have to vote on the plan, it would probably die because of opposition from the Democrats who control the Assembly.
Pataki administration officials have argued strenuously that the Legislature has no role in the deal, saying that the Office of General Services, which oversees state buildings, often enters into such agreements without legislative approval.
Peter W. Delaney, the Commissioner of General Services, said the state was clearly getting a bargain. He said it would be paying less than $10 a square foot and under the deal would gain ownership of the buildings after 25 years.
"If I.B.M. had built these buildings in Syracuse, we would be in Syracuse, if they had built them in Albany, we would have been in Albany," he said. "That is where they are. It is top of the line technological space that we can get for one-tenth of what it would cost to build today. And it doesn't exist anywhere in Albany."

HEADLINE: Some Hedge Funds Are Hurt By a Rise in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Several big hedge funds, which invest billions of dollars for the wealthy, have lost money in recent days as long-term interest rates have risen unexpectedly. As a result, some of these swashbuckling investment firms have given up the sizable profits they made in January, and in some cases have even registered losses, traders and analysts said.
In general, hedge fund managers seem to be sticking to their positions, expecting the earlier market trends to reassert themselves. Still, the setbacks for many big funds have contributed to the tone of uncertainty and volatility in the markets. 
 Yesterday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.45 percent, from 6.40 percent on Friday. As recently as Jan. 19, the yield was below 6 percent. And stocks continued in the erratic pattern that brought declines in the Dow Jones industrial average early last week before a rebound to record levels on Thursday and Friday. Yesterday, the Dow fell 65.39 points.
The net asset value of the Quantum Fund N.V., the oldest and largest fund managed by the investor George Soros, was down 2 percent yesterday from the beginning of the year. Before falling, the fund had climbed 5.5 percent in the first few weeks of the year from its value of $5.3 billion on Jan. 1, a spokesman for Soros Fund Management said. The Quota Fund, another hedge fund managed by Mr. Soros, with assets of $1.3 billion and a more aggressive investment approach, is down 8.6 percent from the beginning of the year.
"We did have a lot of volatility recently," said Michael J. Foley, the director for client services at Strome Susskind, a hedge fund based in Santa Monica, Calif., that manages about $500 million. He attributed some of the volatility to the strong showing of Patrick J. Buchanan in the campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, and to the weakness of Mr. Buchanan's rivals.
Mr. Foley declined to quantify his fund's recent performance, citing regulations that he said prevented American hedge funds from releasing such data. The Soros funds are based in the Netherlands Antilles.
Hedge funds are so named because they invest in options and futures, which are ways to place bets or offset risk in the financial markets. The hedge funds are closely watched by other investors because of their enviable track record: Mr. Soros, for example, made more than $1 billion in 1992 from speculating that the British pound would decline and from related investment strategies.
So-called macro hedge funds, which often place big bets on the direction of currencies and interest rates, generally performed well last year and in January. The value of Mr. Soros's Quantum Fund, for instance, rose 39 percent last year, while the Quota Fund increased by a startling 160 percent. The Strome Susskind fund is said to have had average annual returns of as much as 35 percent in recent years.
"January was very strong over all for the large macro hedge funds, but February is more difficult because we have seen trend reversals in bonds and in the dollar," said Antoine Bernheim, the publisher of Hedge Fund News, an industry publication. Such reversals "are often difficult for traders," he added, "but it's early in the year and so far we have not seen either great damage or great gains."
Sol Waksman, president of Barclay Trading Group Ltd., said, "In the last few days it has been difficult for anybody trading interest rates on a leveraged basis to make money." Barclay is a consulting firm in Fairfield, Iowa, that specializes in hedge funds and managed futures.
"Everyone anticipated continued lowering of interest rates, then Greenspan came out and said the economy is stronger than people thought it was," Mr. Waksman said, referring to the testimony of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before Congress last week. "Everyone was lined up on the other side of the fence, and they were scrambled."
Another prominent hedge fund manager said, "The combination of a big move in long-term rates, which upset the optimism in the fixed-income market, the fact the bond market had already peaked when the budget talks fell apart and Clinton's speech bashing the Fed unnerved the markets."
Some big hedge fund managers seemed particularly chastened by the sudden change in the markets because it provided a warning to them of how hedging against rapid shifts had become more difficult.
One manager said this was particularly apparent in the futures contract based on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. As stock prices have risen, the value of the lots in which this contract is sold has risen as well, leading to a decrease in the liquidity, he said. This, he added, raised the possibility that hedge funds would not be able to balance their positions properly when they needed to. "It would be like finding the fire door locked," he said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Ending Lively Era, A Dean Is Leaving St. John the Divine;
The Innovator's Work Is Done, Even if the Cathedral Is Not

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
If anything, the Very Rev. James Parks Morton is a showman. He once exhibited a sculpture of a female Jesus, complete with bare breasts, as a statement against sexism. A Hudson River blue crab lives in a murky tank in a side chapel as a statement on the environment.
The Cathedral of St. John the Divine is also home to a peacock, a tightrope walker in residence and a daily procession of homeless souls. 
 As Dean, or administrative head, of the world's largest Gothic cathedral and the nation's largest church, Father Morton has fashioned something of a new-age emporium. At the same time he has created a 20th-century version of a medieval cathedral: a bustling, intellectually provocative town common. Indeed, over the last 25 years, the cathedral under his direction has become one of the city's most significant gathering places, a prominent advocate for the poor and a political and religious forum for everyone from Jesse Jackson to the Dalai Lama.
Now 66, Dean Morton plans to announce his resignation today, effective Jan. 1, 1997. His new job, which he declines to discuss, will be head of a new organization, the Interfaith Center of New York. A search committee has begun hunting for a successor, one Dean Morton hopes has a sense of humor.
"The worst thing in the world is pompous clergy," he deadpanned.
"In terms of really new things," he added, explaining his decision, "I've moved in the directions I really wanted to move in. I could be here for another 10 years and we could be making a little more of a dent, but, I mean, the thing has started."
The rumpled cleric's once sandy hair has turned gray over the quarter century, but he has achieved much of what he had hoped to. St. John the Divine, which sits by Columbia University in Morningside Heights, started a program to reclaim abandoned housing and rebuild it through owners' sweat, creating more than 20,000 apartments. It feeds the hungry, trains the homeless for life in real homes, and each week intervenes in some 150 personal and spiritual crises.
And like the medieval cathedrals built large enough to fit the entire town, where commerce and conferences took place, St. John the Divine has become a major stage for collective dramas, a place for the nation's biggest city to examine and heal its soul. It was here that Big Bird eulogized Jim Henson and that Mayor David N. Dinkins convened the city to pray for an end to racial tensions in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. After the Persian Gulf War, Generals Colin L. Powell and H. Norman Schwarzkopf were welcomed at the cathedral as well as protesters screaming, "Murder in the cathedral!"
"This is the cathedral of our common humanity," Mr. Dinkins said.
Dean Morton takes pride in the broad function of the cathedral and points to its traditional religious practices, including at least two communion services a day, in answer to criticism over the years by some restive Episcopalians that their best-known church is more associated with spectacle than Christian spirituality.
The seat of the Bishop of New York, St. John the Divine operates as the pre-eminent Episcopal church in the diocese, but under its own governance and with money it raises itself. Cathedrals are intended as houses of worship as well as great meeting places, and St. John the Divine has built up an intimate congregation of 1,000. While Dean Morton oversees a staff of more than 150 priests and administrators, he also acts as something of a parish priest.
Dean Morton began his clerical work as a priest in Jersey City and then headed the church's national effort to minister to the poor. The Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. worked with him in the Jersey City slums and in establishing the Urban Training Center in Chicago to train clergy of all denominations in ministering to he urban poor. In 1972, Father Moore was installed as Episcopal Bishop of New York. Saying he viewed the cathedral as "a screaming anachronism," he named his protege, Father Morton, to turn it around.
Dean Morton, born in Houston, spent his boyhood in a succession of universities where his father, an Episcopalian, taught theater arts. He arrived at Harvard as an atheist intent on becoming an architect in the socialist tradition of Gropius. Then he heard Father Moore speak about the French priests who cast aside their collars and worked anonymously in factories. He sought spiritual answers in sources as diverse as Jewish Hasidism and Russian Orthodoxy. He marched beside The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and, in Chicago in the 1960's, taught the Rev. Jesse Jackson ways to combine the gospel with social action.
Part of his spiritual transformation came while watching the moon landing on television. He saw the earth, just one fragile living planet hanging in space, from the moon and thereafter he moved environmentalism to the heart of his theology.
"They call me the green dean," he said proudly, mentioning the blue crab living in a cathedral tank, a few steps from an AIDS memorial. As part of his global role in environmental matters, he has linked up scientists like Carl Sagan with religious leaders. He frequently invites scientists, even if professed atheists, to deliver sermons at the cathedral.
"This planet is God's creation and God's just a word," Dean Morton said. "I'm not talking about believing in God."
A lover of great buildings, Dean Morton says that the vast cathedral, which is the world's longest at 601 feet, has given him a sense of proportion.
"Humility is kind of an asinine word in a way, but a cathedral does make one humble in a sense," he said. "It's terribly important to realize you can't complete it."
Ambitions for the cathedral have always been audacious. As construction began in 1892, the idea was to combine three prestigious institutions founded by Episcopalians -- Columbia University, St. Luke's Hospital and the cathedral -- in what church leaders thought would become the center of the city. The motive, Dean Morton jokes, was to create "WASP Central" as well as to compete with the cathedrals of great European cities.
But then began the endless construction and money problems that long ago gave the cathedral the nickname St. John the Unfinished. Horace Donegan, Bishop from 1950 to 1972, declared that the cathedral "will not be built until the stresses of our city be ceased." Backed by conservative trustees, including the president of Columbia University, Grayson Kirk, who was fighting his own battles with rebellious students up the street, the bishop's pronouncement became gospel.
"The cathedral became a symbol of the brokenness of our city," Dean Morton said.
In 1982, after a hiatus of more than 40 years, the building resumed, with Dean Morton enlisting unemployed neighborhood youths as stone-cutting apprentices to be taught by European masters. The tightrope walker Philippe Petit, an artist in residence whose informal office is an aerie overlooking the nave 60 feet below, crossed Amsterdam Avenue on a high wire to set the first stone in four decades. (Late-night cathedral guards say he sometimes climbs the shadowy upper walls, like a giant spider.)
But for nearly two years now, the building effort has been stalled because of a dispute with a contractor and perpetual money problems.
"This is the way cathedrals are," Dean Morton said. "They start, stop, start, stop."
To many, the Dean's biggest accomplishments have been on a smaller, human scale.
Betsy Blachly Chapin, a member of a group based in the cathedral's crypt that plays medieval music, speaks of Dean Morton's making time to personally baptize her son on a day the Dean was busy entertaining the Archbishop of Canterbury, counseling her after her divorce and requiring her and her current husband to meet with him three times for more than an hour each before he married them.
She recalls both her and her fiance's squirming when Dean Morton declared, "Now, birds, I've got to tell the bishop why each of you got divorced."
Dean Morton himself has been married 42 years. He and his wife, Pamela Taylor, whose father, Francis Henry Taylor, was director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, have four grown daughters. The couple will find themselves house-hunting for the first time in 25 years when they leave the deanery, a house with no fewer than seven maid's rooms.
By August the search committee is to present its selection for dean to Bishop Richard F. Grein of New York, and the cathedral's trustees to make the final choice. But already, there is a sense of loss among the faithful.
Lore Schiroka, a congregant, remembers suggesting more than a decade ago that she help children fold thousands of origami cranes, the Japanese symbol for peace, to decorate a huge Christmas tree. "Let the cranes fly!" Dean Morton responded.
Mrs. Schiroka does not know what will happen to the Peace Tree. "I'll be doing it one more time this year," she said, "for the Dean."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, is to announce his resignation today. In 25 years, he has made the church a 20th-century version of a medieval cathedral -- a bustling, intellectually provocative town common. He stood outside the deanery, his home on the cathedral grounds, last week. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
America's Big Idea Museum

BYLINE: By KARL E. MEYER 

 BODY:
It is assuredly not what he wanted, but whatever Steve Forbes's fate in the campaign, he can now claim the rare distinction of adding a new exhibit to the American Museum of Big Ideas. His flat tax joins a procession of cure-everything formulas that, in their season, became the talk of the country and, in some cases, led to changes. This was partly because each plainly touched a tender nerve.
Such was the case, for example, with Henry George's Single Tax in the 1880's, and with the Free Silver crusade in 1896. It was also true of the now-forgotten Townsend Plan in the 1930's. 
 Interestingly, all these Big Ideas originated in the Great West, and were propelled eastward by fluently spoken and printed words. Born poor in Philadelphia, Henry George migrated in the 1850's to San Francisco, where he became a successful and mostly self-taught journalist. Resembling an Old Testament prophet and endowed with mesmerizing eloquence, George was moved by the poverty that mocked California's gold-rush glitter during the great crash of 1877.
It came to him, as in a revelation, that all social ills were rooted in the iniquitous unearned appreciation of land values. He proposed enacting a single tax on those profits in his impassioned book "Progress and Poverty," offering these claims for his idea:
"What I propose, therefore, is the simple yet sovereign remedy, which will raise wages, increase the earnings of capital, extirpate pauperism, abolish poverty, give remunerative employment to whoever wishes it, afford free scope to human powers, lessen crime, elevate morals, and taste, and intelligence, purify government and carry civilization to yet nobler height."
His book, with its electrifying message, became a worldwide best seller. Now famous and having moved to New York, George in 1886 ran for mayor as a trade-union candidate, and did unexpectedly well. His influential preaching helped prepare the ground for a new Big Idea in the next decade: the belief that devaluing gold by upgrading far more abundant silver would confer almost as many benefits as the Single Tax.
A Chicago journalist, William Hope Harvey, gave wings to this message in a book entitled "Coin's Financial School" (1893), which sold a sensational 400,000 copies within a year. Its inflationary thesis, which originated in the Western silver-producing states, provoked a furious outcry from those who soon were dubbed "gold bugs," and his Big Idea was taken up by Nebraska's William Jennings Bryan, "the Boy Orator of the Platte."
As the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1896, Bryan uttered perhaps the most famous sentence in an acceptance speech: "You shall not press down on the brow of labor this crown of thorns; you shall not crucify mankind on a cross of gold." Bryan lost, badly, but his essential point was scarcely nonsensical. Rising gold prices cruelly penalized debtors, an unfairness that was ameliorated by the discovery of gold in South Africa.
Similarly, Henry George's message was not so outlandish. Narrowing grievous inequalities between the poor and rich is a justifiable consideration in tax legislation. When the Supreme Court ruled in 1895 that the income tax was unconstitutional, a populist outcry galvanized support for an amendment to the contrary that was ratified in 1913.
The same afterlife helped redeem a seemingly outlandish idea hatched in 1933 by Dr. Francis Everett Townsend, a physician in Long Beach, Calif. Dr. Townsend was 66 when he wrote a letter to the local newspaper arguing that everyone over 60 should get Federal pensions of $150 or more "on condition they spend the money as they get it." A clever friend of Dr. Townsend's, a realtor, instantly saw the promotional allure of the plan, whose ante was hiked to $200, to be paid by a national sales tax. Soon Townsendites bloomed into a hymn-singing movement with chapters everywhere -- its message smudged, however, by its founder's ties with demagogic allies like Huey Long.
Even so, the Townsend Plan drew national attention to the plight of penniless oldsters. As Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. notes, Dr. Townsend had "shouted until the whole country heard," and his movement speeded passage of the Social Security Act. By the same token, in seizing on a flat-tax proposal put forward by California economists and embraced by a handful of other politicians, Steve Forbes builds on an old tradition. A simpler tax return may yet be his memorial. KARL E. MEYER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
