SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1728 words

HEADLINE: The Surplus That Wouldn't Die;
Matsushita Tries and Fails to Balance Its Trade Books

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan

 BODY:
Shoppers flock to the four L.L. Bean stores in Japan for the latest in rugged American fashions. And with each sale of a parka or pair of boots, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company chalks up another import.
Japan's L.L. Bean shops were opened by Matsushita, the giant maker of Panasonic electronics products, as part of its five-year program, begun in 1988, to voluntarily reduce its contribution to the country's huge trade surplus. Besides Bean gear, Matsushita also imports Famous Grouse Scotch, Schweppes beverage concentrate and other products completely unrelated to the electronics business to pad its imports. 
 But the five-year program was largely a bust. Matsushita's trade surplus -- its exports from Japan minus its imports -- dropped only 4 percent, to 1.11 trillion yen, or about $11 billion, in 1993.
The company's trade surplus with North America, however, declined steadily over the period, falling by more than one-third, to $2.9 billion in 1993. That is because, with the rise of the Japanese yen, many of the products Matsushita once sent to the United States from Japan are now being replaced by products made in Matsushita factories in Southeast Asia or made in America. That trend continued in the past two years, after the five-year plan ended, further reducing the company's trade deficit with the United States. Meanwhile, Matsushita sends components from Japan to those factories, keeping its total exports high.
A close look at Matsushita's import and export patterns, made possible by the company's willingness to release figures from its five-year plan, shows how resilient Japanese companies are as manufacturers and exporters.
"The U.S. deficit with Japan is declining," said Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, a group that argues for a tougher United States trade policy. "The U.S. deficit with Japanese companies is remaining much the same."
Even most of Matsushita's imports, which have risen sharply in recent years, come either from the company's own factories outside Japan or from the overseas factories of Japanese parts suppliers.
Matsushita's experience also offers some lessons for United States trade policy at a time when protectionism has become an issue in the Presidential campaign.
One lesson is that simply imposing a 10 percent tariff on imports from Japan, as proposed by the Republican Presidential candidate Patrick J. Buchanan, would have little effect on shutting off the flow of Japanese goods.
"Companies like Matsushita that have operations all over the world have effectively hedged against gunboat diplomacy such as Buchanan is advocating," said Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management and former Under Secretary of Commerce. (Mr. Buchanan, however, has also called for tariffs against developing nations as well.)
Another lesson is that the rise of the yen has been more effective than trade pressures in reducing Matsushita's trade surplus. The high yen made it a matter of profits, rather than politics, for Matsushita to increase imports and reduce exports.
"We used to need a corporate cheerleader," to increase imports, said Yoichi Miyata, an official in Matsushita's corporate planning office. "But now we don't need that anymore."
Indeed, Matsushita's global trade surplus, which barely budged during the five-year plan has dropped 20 percent, to a projected 890 billion yen, or $8.9 billion, in the two years since the end of the plan -- a period in which the yen soared.
The same is true for Japan as a whole, with its trade surplus with the world and with the United States dropping in 1995 for the first time in five years.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a nonpartisan economics research group in Washington, said Matsushita's response to the strong yen argued against the need for the strong tactics proposed by Mr. Buchanan. "I think this adds to the case that he is nutty," Mr. Bergsten said. "This shows that the adjustment is happening without any of that."
At the same time, a tightly focused trade pressure to increase American sales in Japan can make a difference. Matsushita executives said in interviews that the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan was instrumental in prompting the company to consider American chips. The agreement set as a goal that 20 percent of Japan's semiconductor market would be held by foreign chips by mid-1991.
Many of Japan's largest companies, prompted by Japan's Government, announced voluntary plans in the late 1980's to help reduce trade tensions. Matsushita's release of its trade figures provides a window on the effectiveness of such plans.
Looking at one company's trade patterns can be instructive because a big portion of international trade consists of movements of goods between two parts of the same multinational company. Matsushita officials think their company has the fourth-largest corporate trade surplus in Japan, behind Toyota, Nissan and Honda.
Matsushita is a sprawling enterprise with revenues of 6.9 trillion yen, or about $69 billion, in its last fiscal year, equal to the sales of the General Electric Company. It makes everything from washing machines to robots and has about 120 factories overseas, including 19 in the United States.
About 50 percent of the Osaka-based company's production is made in Japan and sold here. Another 30 percent is made in Japan and exported. The remaining 20 percent is made overseas and sold overseas. A fourth category, products made overseas and sold in Japan, has until now been negligible.
When Matsushita announced its five-year plan in 1988 it imported only 5.7 percent of the parts used in its Japanese factories.
"In 1988 we imported virtually nothing except some semiconductors," said Toshihiko Murota, managing director of Matsushita Communication Industrial Company, a subsidiary that makes telephones and car audio equipment. "We didn't have consciousness of the need to import."
Even the semiconductors, he conceded, were imported only because of the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement.
Purchasing managers were comfortable buying from Japanese companies. So Matsushita went over their heads, requiring its division chiefs to come up with annual import targets.
Slowly imports began climbing. By the end of the five-year plan, Matsushita as a whole had doubled its imports to 440 billion yen, or about $4.4 billion.
The problem was that exports had started out so much larger than imports that even a doubling of imports could not dent Matsushita's trade surplus. Exports rose only 12 percent over the five years, but in monetary terms, that increase was almost the same as the rise in imports.
Mr. Bergsten, the Washington economist, said the same initial lopsidedness was the reason the United States trade deficit with Japan had not been declining much, even though Japan's imports from the United States had been growing faster than Japan's exports to the United States.
But it is in the last two years that Matsushita's imports have accelerated because of the rising yen. This year about 20 percent of the parts used by Matsushita Communication in Japan will be imported, with the number rising to 30 percent next year, Mr. Murota said. By contrast, the subsidiary imported only 9.7 percent in 1993, the last year of the five-year plan, and 4.7 percent in 1988.
Mr. Murota said that most of his company's imports were from Japanese parts manufacturers operating abroad, which are trusted, high-quality suppliers.
But while imports of parts have been increasing, importing finished products has been somewhat of a taboo. "It's very difficult to accept seeing finished products coming into Japan when we see more unemployment in the domestic industry," said Mr. Miyata of the corporate planning office.
When the company began its five-year plan, only 2.3 percent of what it produced overseas was sold in Japan. The company set a goal of 10 percent but achieved only 7.8 percent.
But now, the pressure of the strong yen has changed that. To remain competitive against cheaper imports in its home market, Matsushita started importing television sets, air-conditioners and audio products from Malaysia and some other nations.
Still, less than 3 percent of the finished products Matsushita sold in Japan last year were imported. For televisions, the percentage was 20 to 30 percent of units, but much less than that in terms of value.
As for exports, Matsushita's total has been generally declining since 1991, in part because of the shift to offshore manufacturing. But the decline in exports has not been sharp.
While Matsushita is exporting fewer finished products like VCR's, it is exporting more components, both to its new overseas factories and to other companies. In the 1994 fiscal year, when the yen's sharp rise was felt, Matsushita's exports of finished products from Japan plunged by about $2 billion, but exports of parts rose by the same amount.
Matsushita Communication's Yokohama factory now mainly makes internal mechanisms for videocassette players, compact disk players and radios, many of which are exported to the United States. The Yokohama production lines are highly automated, allowing manufacturing to stay in Japan, Mr. Murota said.
This shift, from exporting consumer goods to exporting parts and factory machinery, has been taking place in Japanese industry as a whole. But its effect on sustaining Japan's exports might be only short-lived.
One reason is that offshore factories are under pressure to shift to local sourcing. When Matsushita analyzed its overseas subsidiaries it found that "the companies that are profitable have high ratios of local procurement," said Ryoji Mita, who supervised the five-year plan. "The companies dependent on parts from Japan have no profits," because those parts are expensive.
With the yen having weakened in recent weeks to about 105 to the dollar, the trade patterns could reverse. Kyushu Matsushita, a subsidiary, is bringing back to Japan the manufacturing of some facsimile machines that had been shifted to Malaysia.
But Matsushita officials suggested such cases would be rare. "We already have many factories overseas," Mr. Miyata said. "So we cannot bring the factories back to Japan."

HEADLINE: Thomson to Buy Legal Publisher In a $3.43 Billion Cash Accord

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
The Thomson Corporation continued its strategic move into electronic publishing and on-line information services yesterday with the announcement that it would buy West Publishing Company, a leading provider of legal research materials, for $3.43 billion in cash, most of it borrowed.
The acquisition would double Thomson's stake in the lucrative on-line legal and regulatory information research market, adding West Publishing's $825 million in annual sales from its Westlaw and other lawyers' services to the revenue from Thomson's own legal publishing division, which came to $800 million last year. 
 But the all-cash deal would produce an operating loss loss of $30 million for Thomson's new West Publishing activities for the last nine months of this year, a drop that would be reflected, however slightly, in the company's overall net income, according to Thomson officials. The acquisition would break even by the end of next year with a cash flow of better than $300 million to the parent, the officials said, though the full purchase price will not be repaid for another 9 or 10 years.
Thomson said it expected the deal, which is subject to United States antitrust clearance and other regulatory approvals, to be completed by the first part of April.
While the legal address of Thomson is Toronto, its headquarters and most of its North American staff are in Stamford, Conn., where company officials, in a telephone conference call with analysts, said that the fit between the parent and its proposed new acquisition went beyond the similarity in the two companies' on-line services.
The strengths of West Publishing are in its primary law data files, the officials said, while Thomson Legal's depth is in secondary legal references and background documents. Lawyers often need both levels of research in preparing court documents.
W. Michael Brown, the president of Thomson, said the company's biggest acquisition ever was also its most logical. Over the last decade, Mr. Brown said yesterday, Thomson has gradually divested itself of numerous small newspapers and other publishing interests that were heavily dependent on the vagaries of advertising revenues, to concentrate on specialty publishing, including on-line serv vertising revenues, to concentrate on specialty publishing, including on-line services, that generate income through subscription and on-line charges.
"We didn't want to build up a grab-bag in this area," Mr. Brown said. "We wanted products that were of high utility to the user, that had long life and for which, ideally, the customer paid the bill, that were not overly dependent on the state of the economy and not overly dependent on advertising. Those were our benchmarks."
Douglas E. Kirk, a financial analyst in Toronto with Nesbitt Burns, said yesterday that the purchase made sense.
"I think it's a very good fit with some of the businesses they have now," he said. "It's one of those things -- a slight reduction in earnings up front, but the potential for a very significant return in the longer run."
Thomson operates mainly in Britain, Canada and the United States with more than 48,000 employees and earnings of $6.3 billion last year. West Publishing, a closely held company with just 200 shareholders, employs 7,000.
Mr. Brown and other Thomson officials were at pains to justify the high purchase price -- the most Thomson has paid in a string of recent acquisitions -- for a company that deals in a product whose raw material -- millions of words from court decisions, regulatory decisions and state and Federal statute books -- are all in the public domain.
They said it was West Publishing's business of analyzing, annotating and cross-referencing this flood of information that added value to the company's product. Indeed, the company earned $206 million in operating profits on sales of $827 million, for a profit margin approaching 25 percent, for the 1995 fiscal year. Westlaw dominates the on-line legal research industry in the United States, with clients in virtually all of the nation's largest law firms.
Nevertheless, the high cost of the debt that Thomson will incur to make the planned purchase will strain the company's debt structure and will, the company expects, lead to a decline in its bond ratings in the short term.
Thomson's stock on the Toronto Exchange closed at $19.375 (Canadian), or $14.14 (United States), yesterday, down 75 cents (Canadian), or 55 cents (United States).
A year ago, Thomson announced that its newspaper division, Thomson Newspapers, would shed 25 United States dailies as part of its strategy to concentrate on its marketing and electronic information systems. The company also sold more than a dozen small Canadian papers under the same strategy.
"A decade ago, in the early 1980's, we had a mixed quantity of interest that were generally unrelated to our core interests," Mr. Brown said. "Over the decade we have divested ourselves, on a timely basis and for good prices, of most of these, and at the same time we have invested very heavily to capture our core market interests."
It is a policy, Mr. Brown said, that Thomson had followed "with utterly boring consistency ever since."
When Mr. Brown joined Thomson 28 years ago, more than 90 percent of the company's revenues were from advertising, a notoriously cyclical source of income. Today, Mr. Brown said, advertising revenue accounts for about 15 percent of revenue, most of it from newspapers in America and Canada.
Fully 40 percent of West Publishing sales come from subscriptions, said Nigel Harrison, chief financial officer of Thomson. "We like cash that comes in first, before the product goes out the door," Mr. Harrison said. It was by design that the company's income profile had made such change, Mr. Brown added.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NORTH DAKOTA;
In Farm State, Buchanan Finds No Help in History

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: BISMARCK, N.D. Feb. 24

 BODY:
Landlocked in the nation's prairie heartland, North Dakota would seem to be Pat Buchanan country.
Politics here carries the stamp of an earlier version of "Buchananism" -- a powerful populist movement that liked to envision Eastern banks, railroads and grain companies prostrate before the North Dakota farmer. 
 Using a cantankerous billygoat as its symbol, North Dakota's Non-Partisan League opposed "gang politics" in Washington and protested the American entry into World War I. To break the economic grip of big Eastern corporations, the league built a state-run development bank and a state-run wheat mill. In 1936, a North Dakota Congressman ran for President under the banner of a party organized by Father Charles Coughlin, the populist radio priest.
Sixty years later, the league still lives, but the modern standard-bearer of populism seems to have made few inroads in this farm state, long considered Senator Bob Dole's territory. One of the nation's largest wheat and barley producers, North Dakota depends heavily on exporting its grain and fears Mr. Buchanan's protectionism.
On Wednesday, Mr. Buchanan canceled his only planned visit to North Dakota and instead gave a few radio interviews over the weekend. A poll released on Thursday showed Senator Dole with 37 percent support, Steve Forbes with 16 percent and Mr. Buchanan with 11 percent.
If Mr. Buchanan does poorly here and in South Dakota on Tuesday, it will indicate that the farm belt may be one hole in a populist quilt that he is trying to stitch across the land.
Despite a flurry of Buchanan signs at Republican meetings around the state in the days before the primary, no last-minute shifts were expected, partly because of the unique characteristics of Tuesday's vote. The primary inaugurates mail-in voting here, and state officials started mailing out ballots in mid-January.
[As of Monday, about one-third of the 200,000 people expected to vote had mailed in their ballots.]
North Dakota moved up its Presidential primary this year in a bid to win more attention for the state, which ranks 47th in population. There is evidence the move was successful -- North Dakota attracted visits this time from Mr. Dole, the Kansas Senator; his wife, Elizabeth Dole; Alan Keyes and, before he dropped out of the race, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. In 1992, when the primary was in June, neither Bill Clinton nor George Bush campaigned here.
The support for Mr. Dole here is grounded in farm-belt loyalty; he is often called "Dakota's third senator." One of North Dakota's bona fide senators, Kent Conrad, a Democrat, actually boasted in his 1994 re-election campaign that he had voted with Senator Dole more than half the time.
Farm politics are crucial in a state where a main attraction of the annual state fair is a grain combine demolition derby.
"I know where Dole stands on issues that concern me, and farm issues are big for me," said Steve Perkins, who raises wheat, barley and cattle on a farm in Menoken, 25 miles east of this state capital.
That sentiment is echoed by the state's Republican establishment, which is solidly in the Dole camp. On Wednesday, when the Senator made a campaign stop in Fargo, he was warmly welcomed by the Governor, the leaders of both houses of the State Legislature and a glowing editorial in The Forum of Fargo, the state's largest newspaper.
"His farm state roots in Kansas and his demonstrated understanding of agriculture give him an edge in North Dakota," The Forum said of Mr. Dole, who since January has campaigned in the state's four largest cities, Fargo, Bismarck, Grand Forks and Minot.
"Buchanan is a city kid," the editorial continued. "If he knows the difference between production agriculture and 'Green Acres,' he's yet to articulate it.
"Buchanan's protectionist trade ideas would cripple North Dakota's export-dependent farm economy," the newspaper concluded. "North Dakota is not Buchanan country."
With half of North Dakota's grain production going overseas, largely to Asian markets, state farmers are skittish that Mr. Buchanan might provoke reprisals from the state's trading partners.
"Someone who wants to shut down trade -- that's pretty scary for us in North Dakota," Edward T. Schafer, the Governor, said in an interview.
In a far cry from its early isolationist days, North Dakota boasts the nation's only international golf course -- it straddles the border with Saskatchewan. North Dakota license plates advertise the state's International Peace Garden, a floral park straddling the border with Manitoba.
Canada is North Dakota's largest trading partner. Last year, sales to Mexico roughly doubled.
"There's one candidate in this race who wants to build a wall around America; he doesn't think we need to sell anything overseas," Mr. Dole said at the campaign rally in Fargo, attended by about 1,000 people. "Well, if you raise three bushels of wheat, two better go overseas or somebody's going to be broke."
Nevertheless, there is an anti-Nafta undercurrent here that Mr. Buchanan may tap on Tuesday.
"Nafta has done absolutely nothing for us -- zilch," said one Buchanan supporter, a 49-year-old employee of an oil drilling company who was shopping at a mall here.
On the sixth floor of the white limestone State Capitol building, that refrain was picked up by Sarah Vogel, the state Agriculture Commissioner and a Democrat.
"It's virtually impossible to get American wheat into Canada; you can't get a quart of American milk into Canada," said the Commissioner, who fills an elected post. "North Dakota is the nation's number one grower of edible beans -- and they cut back our bean quota to Mexico."
But Ms. Vogel, a board member of the Non-Partisan League, argued that Nafta should be renegotiated, not abolished.
"If you quizzed Pat Buchanan on why North Dakotans oppose Nafta, he wouldn't have a clue," she said. "I don't think that Pat Buchanan has an agriculture policy."
In 1958, Non-Partisan League members abandoned a 40-year alliance with North Dakota's Republicans and joined with the Democrats. Although there has been speculation that members of the alliance, formally called the Democratic-NPL, would vote for Mr. Buchanan to sabotage Mr. Dole' candidacy, its leaders say they have not asked their followers to do that.
Mr. Buchanan's attacks on immigrants also have had little resonance among the prairie populists of North Dakota, a state that has slightly fewer inhabitants today than in 1920. The league movement drew heavily on farmers of Scandinavian and Russian-German origin.
"In North Dakota, the populist tradition was a helping hand," Ms. Vogel, the daughter of an N.P.L. founder, said. "They were immigrants themselves, and they thought that North Dakota was a land of opportunity."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: STEVE FORBES;
The Flat-Tax Candidate Subordinates Himself to His Economic Message

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 26

 BODY:
At the end of his standard flat-tax stump speech to an attentive crowd of elderly residents here today, Steve Forbes touched lightly on what is becoming a common refrain: that his optimistic, Reaganesque message is far more important than the electoral fate of the messenger.
"I believe these issues and principles are bigger than any candidate, and that's why I'm in the race," the magazine publishing heir told the residents of the Forum Pueblo Norte Retirement Community here this afternoon. "I'm in the race for the duration." 
 Sometimes in passing and sometimes at great length, Mr. Forbes has been underscoring this rallying cry in a variety of venues lately as he tries to rejuvenate his Presidential candidacy. Buoyed by his victory in Saturday's door-prize primary in Delaware, where he and Alan Keyes were the only Republican Presidential candidates to court voters in person, Mr. Forbes is hoping to do well in Tuesday's Arizona primary. A strong showing in Arizona, he believes, would help reposition him as a credible challenger to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas; Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.
His primacy-of-message theme popped up parenthetically in his remarks after he attended services on Sunday at All Saints Episcopal Church in Phoenix. On Saturday morning in Washington, he offered a friendly and enthusiastic crowd at a convention of the Conservative Political Action Committee an unabridged version of it.
Regardless of how he makes this point, Mr. Forbes is trumpeting a theme that has all the advantages of a reversible coat: it is suitable for fair political weather or foul. And with his back-to-back fourth-place finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire, Mr. Forbes has been enduring a lot of foul weather.
Mr. Forbes's emphasis on the importance of the flat tax and other ideas he champions has now eclipsed his 4-3-2-1 rallying cry on the stump in Iowa and New Hampshire: fourth in Iowa, third in New Hampshire, second in Delaware and first in Arizona. He has abandoned predicting exactly where he will finish in favor of a much more modest sound bite -- "a very strong showing."
Mr. Forbes, who so far has underwritten his candidacy with about $25 million of his own money, including several million dollars spent in Arizona, today reiterated his intention to go the distance and compete for delegates all the way to San Diego. He said he looked forward to competing in delegate-rich California in late March and New Jersey in June.
In Washington on Saturday morning, Mr. Forbes offered the conservative group's convention the unabridged version of primacy-of-ideas theme. "The experts said that a neophyte needed the kind of experience of the traditional kind, the long resume of political appointments and elected office in Washington," he said there. "They said that I remained an asterisk in this race, that the message couldn't get through the clutter. Well, the message is more powerful than the messenger. The message is more powerful than any candidate or campaign. The message is why I'm running today and why I have no intention of quitting this race."
Even some voters who are sympathetic to Mr. Forbes's candidacy see him more as a standard-bearer for pro-growth, limited-government ideas than as a viable Presidential candidate in 1996. Ben Seaborne, 76, a retired architect, fits neatly into that category. After listening to Mr. Forbes's speech today, he spoke up during the question-and-answer with Mr. Forbes. "Whether you win or not," Mr. Seaborne said, "this will be a great benefit for the country."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE POLL;
SOCIAL ISSUES GIVE BUCHANAN BOOST, A NEW POLL FINDS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan's views on social issues like abortion and immigration are attracting voters to his campaign more than his economic populism, a new New York Times/CBS News poll shows.
The poll, which was taken last Thursday through Saturday, showed that Mr. Buchanan had established himself nationally -- and not just in the early primary and caucus states where the candidates have spent most of their time -- as the main rival to Senator Bob Dole for the Republican Presidential nomination. But some issues that Mr. Buchanan has emphasized threaten to split the Republican coalition. 
 So far, many Republican primary voters are dissatisfied with what they have seen. Asked whether they were satisfied with the active candidates or would like someone else to enter the race, 50 percent said they would welcome a wider choice of candidates.
Although Mr. Buchanan, a conservative commentator and former White House speechwriter, has often been dismissed as a mere protest candidate, the poll indicates otherwise. Most of his backers appear to think they are voting for a potential winner, not just sending a message. More than two-thirds of the Republicans who support him, or 69 percent, think he could beat President Clinton in November, while only 35 percent of those backing Mr. Dole think Mr. Buchanan could beat Mr. Clinton.
In another demonstration of Mr. Buchanan's increasing credibility, 51 percent of Republican voters said that regardless of their own voting intentions, they thought he had the ability to be an effective President, compared with 78 percent who thought that Mr. Dole had that capacity and only 37 percent who thought that a third major contender, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, had it.
Mr. Dole is still liked by Republican voters, despite his lackluster victory in Iowa and his loss in New Hampshire, with 41 percent saying their view of him was favorable, while only 20 percent said they viewed him unfavorably. But the Kansan is clearly having trouble connecting with the electorate. Only 30 percent of Republicans said he cared the most about the needs of ordinary voters, an astonishingly low number for a politician so long in the limelight.
Among all voters -- Republicans, Democrats and independents -- who took part in the poll, Mr. Dole has a much lower standing, with his favorable rating at only 23 percent. He loses a trial heat to Mr. Clinton, who is now widely considered the favorite for November, 54 percent to 36 percent.
Mr. Dole is preferred by 39 percent of Republican primary voters nationwide, compared with 25 percent for Mr. Buchanan and 12 percent for Mr. Alexander. Steve Forbes, the millionaire publisher, stood at 5 percent, but the poll was completed before his surprise victory in Delaware on Saturday.
Those standings represent a considerable change since last month, before the voting began. Since January, Mr. Dole has slipped from 43 percent as his rivals have become better known, Mr. Buchanan has more than tripled his support, Mr. Alexander has also gained and Mr. Forbes, who stood at 12 percent then, has fallen back as he stumbled to two fourth-place finishes.
Despite months of campaigning, Mr. Alexander remains relatively little known, with almost 70 percent of Republicans still unsure about him.
Mr. Forbes's problem jumps from the pages of the polling data. His heavy advertising and the media coverage that followed have made him much better known in just a few months, but three times as many Republicans (39 percent) view him unfavorably as have a favorable impression (11 percent).
The telephone poll of 1,223 adults nationwide, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, suggested that there were sharp limits to Mr. Buchanan's potential.
Republican voters are split in their appraisal of the pugnacious candidate, with 29 percent taking a favorable view, but 35 percent express an unfavorable view. Nearly half describe him as an extremist, and 48 percent say that he cannot win the general election.
Abortion is one of the issues, the poll shows, that most thoroughly disrupts the Republican coalition, with 24 percent favoring abortion on demand, 23 percent favoring outright abolition and 51 percent favoring availability with stricter limitations.
Among Buchanan supporters, 57 percent favor a Republican platform advocating abolition, but among Dole supporters, only 27 percent take that position, though Mr. Dole is also an abortion opponent, if not as outspoken as Mr. Buchanan.
No such sharp cleavage is apparent on economic issues, despite Mr. Buchanan's relentless hammering of international trade agreements and of big corporations as enemies of the American working man and woman. Republicans were asked, for example, whether they feared that an adult in their family would be out of work in the next year -- an index of economic anxiety.
Surprisingly, perhaps, in view of Mr. Buchanan's aggressiveness and Mr. Dole's defensiveness on such questions, 31 percent of all Republican voters said they thought there was a good chance they would be in that predicament, 30 percent of Buchanan backers said so, and 33 percent of Dole backers said so.
Economic anxiety there certainly is. Contrary to the historic pattern in this generally optimistic country, almost as many people (43 percent) said that the standard of living would fall in the next decade as said it would increase (44 percent). But the pessimists were not significantly more likely to be backers of Mr. Buchanan.
Mr. Buchanan has clearly hit a nerve with Republican voters when he argues that free trade costs American jobs, with 57 percent saying restrictions are needed to protect domestic industries.
After a campaign in which few candidates have said anything good about the government, an amazing number of people retain faith in its potential. No fewer than 87 percent said they thought that government can have a positive impact in people's lives.
The Republican "revolution" of 1994, meant to reform government, receives decidedly mixed reviews. Among those interviewed, 32 percent said they thought the changes that the Republicans in Congress were trying to make would be good for most people if they went through, 36 percent said they thought they would be bad and 22 percent said they thought they would have little or no effect.
By 49 percent to 31 percent, voters put the greatest share of blame on the Republicans in Congress, rather than President Clinton, for the budget standoff and the partial shutdowns of the Government that ensued.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 22 to 24 with 1,223 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of active residential exchanges in the country. The list of more than 36,000 residential exchanges is maintained by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for those who say they are likely to vote in a Republican primary or caucus this year.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: CLINTON SEEKING WIDER SANCTIONS AGAINST CUBANS

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Denouncing the downing of two private American planes by Cuba as "a flagrant violation of international law," President Clinton today suspended all air charter travel between the United States and the island and pledged to reach agreement with Congress on a pending bill to tighten economic sanctions.
Mr. Clinton also asked Congress to approve legislation to use several million dollars of the $100 million in frozen Cuban assets in this country to compensate the families of the four anti-Castro Cuban-Americans presumed killed when their Cessnas were wiped out of the sky by missiles on Saturday. 
 "Saturday's attack was an appalling reminder of the nature of the Cuban regime -- repressive, violent, scornful of international law," the President said in an afternoon appearance in the White House briefing room after a 75-minute meeting with his national security advisers.
But despite his sharp words, Mr. Clinton's response was measured, reflecting the limited options at his disposal and what senior Administration officials described as his belief that the best way to foster democratic reform in Cuba was to maintain the cultural, journalistic and humanitarian ties that the Administration sought to promote when it eased travel restrictions last October.
At the same time, Administration officials acknowledged that Cuba had been greatly exercised in recent weeks about flights by the anti-Castro group and that such flights had continued despite American warnings against them.
Last fall, the Administration moved to let more scholars and artists and family members wishing to visit sick relatives in Cuba do so. Under the new rules they still can, but only through third countries, officials said. As a result, the officials added, the number of travelers from the United States is expected to decline substantially, causing a significant short-term economic blow to Cuba.
But with the Florida presidential primary just two weeks away -- and with the vote-rich state looming as a crucial battleground in the general election -- Mr. Clinton's Republican political opponents promptly denounced the President's proposals as inadequate.
"It's a shame that President Clinton's weak actions today did not match his tough rhetoric," Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said in a statement. "I support these measures as steps in the right direction. But after months of moving the wrong way -- toward coddling Castro -- President Clinton has yet to understand that the only way to deal with Castro's tyranny is with real firmness and pressure."
Cuban-American exile groups had mixed reactions. Some, like Jorge Mas Canosa, the conservative head of the Cuban American National Foundation, called the incident "a turning point in U.S.-Cuba relations," and praised Mr. Clinton's willingness to work with Congress on tighter sanctions. But others said the Administration had allowed provocative flights by the exile group, Brothers to the Rescue, to continue despite repeated warnings from the Cuban Government.
A coalition of groups opposed to the existing embargo, headed by the Antonio Maceo Brigade and the Alliance of Workers of the Cuban Community, said in a statement, "We urge President Clinton not to approve inhumane measures which ultimately will only harm the welfare of the Cuban community in the United States and the Cuban people in the island and further erode constitutional rights such as the right to travel and free association."
For his part, Mr. Clinton vowed to "move promptly to reach agreement with the Congress" on pending legislation, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, to tighten the American economic embargo against Cuba by requiring the United States to oppose Cuban membership in international financial institutions and further restrict sugar imports, among other things.
But moments later, top Administration officials said the White House remained firmly opposed to an element of the House-approved version of the bill that would allow American courts to hear lawsuits brought by Cuban refugees against foreign companies and individuals "trafficking" in property seized in Cuba when Mr. Castro took power 36 years ago.
The officials said that measure would create tension with European allies, would be hard to defend under international law and would impede efforts to settle existing financial claims. The provision was dropped from the Senate version of the bill, and House and Senate negotiators are now trying to reconcile the two versions.
Mr. Clinton had threatened to veto the House bill, but officials said he now hoped to foster a compromise.
The Administration is also seeking condemnation of the attack by the United Nations and is likely to seek international support for restrictions on Cuban civil aviation worldwide, officials said.
Officials said that 120,000 to 140,000 people travel from the United States to Cuba each year and that if travelers decided to forgo the added burden of traveling through a third country, it should reduce revenues to the Cuban Government significantly.
Senior Administration officials acknowledged that fliers from the anti-Castro group, Brothers to the Rescue, had apparently violated Cuban airspace in the past and that a third plane did so on Saturday before returning safely to Florida at the time the other two were downed. But they said the planes obviously had no hostile intent and were clearly unarmed.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, one official said that American intelligence reports showed that the Cuban military in recent weeks had practiced intercepting planes, and may have scrambled planes on Saturday in anticipation of some provocative flight by Brothers to the Rescue on that day, the 101st anniversary of the start of Cuba's war of independence against Spain.
"It's likely that we picked up some notion that there would be flights on that day," the official said.
In Miami, Jose Basulto, the founder of Brothers to the Rescue and the pilot of the plane that made it back safely on Saturday, said he thought a member of the group who disappeared last week, and has turned up in Havana, was a Cuban spy. Cuban officials refused to identify the pilot, but exile groups in Miami said he was Juan Pablo Roque, a former major in the Cuban Air Force who swam to the American naval base in Guantanamo and arrived in Miami two years ago. He appeared on Cuban television tonight and charged that the two main leaders of Brothers to the Rescue were longtime C.I.A. agents.
Cuba had warned the United States that it might shoot down the pilots if they entered Cuban territory. As recently as Jan. 15, Cuba said it would take "all necessary measures" to halt the flights.
Wayne Smith, who ran the United States interests section in Havana from 1979 to 1982, said in an interview that the United States was well aware that the group was intent on continuing its flights but did little to stop it.
"It seems that the U.S. Government had really taken very little in the way of appropriate action to prevent them from repeating this kind of thing," Mr. Smith said. "I'm sure the Brothers tried to provoke some kind of incident to impede any further improvement in U.S.-Cuban relations."
But Federal Aviation Administration officials said they had met with members of the group on several occasions in the last two years, told them to honor Cuba's sovereignty and urged them to be careful. The F.A.A. has moved to suspend Mr. Basulto's license and has a pending action against a second member of the group, officials said.
The downing of the two planes and today's response escalated tensions that had risen last week. On Thursday, Cuba accused the United States of organizing and financing a coalition of 131 dissident groups on the island. The State Department labeled the allegation "preposterous." Days earlier, the Administration condemned a wave of arrests of coalition leaders that Cuba had begun at mid-month.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Little Joy for Mahoney As St. John's Is Defeated

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY 

 BODY:
It wasn't much of a game, but then St. John's wasn't much of a team. In its 92-79 loss to Syracuse last night in Madison Square Garden, the Red Storm took poor care of the basketball, allowed the Orangemen too many transition baskets (one came on a four-on-none breakaway) and emerged with a final score much more respectable than its performance.
For Brian Mahoney, St. John's beleaguered coach, this may have been another step toward the unemployment line. His school has a glorious history of winning basketball, but this team is not contributing to it. 
 St. John's trailed by 20 points at the half, a season high, and by 26 early in the second half.
The statistics for its heralded sophomores were good -- 16 points and 16 rebounds for Felipe Lopez, who never left the game, and 26 points and 10 rebounds for Zendon Hamilton.
But Lopez often played playground basketball, forcing his shots, and his teammates seldom looked for him. And once, when his wild pass to Hamilton went out of bounds, Hamilton stared and stared at him.
Meanwhile, Syracuse was sharp in the first half and good enough in the second. John Wallace scored 30 points and Lazarus Sims, the 6-foot-4-inch point guard, had 17 points, 11 rebounds and 10 assists, the fifth triple-double in Big East history.
With that, Syracuse raised its record to 21-7 over all, 11-6 in the Big East. St. John's fell to 10-15, and its Big East record of 4-13 is the worst in the conference. Syracuse, ranked 14th and 15th in the nation in the two major weekly polls, was a 5 1/2-point favorite.
The crowd, announced at 14,121, was unhappy with St. John's performance. One group of spectators held up placards spelling, "Mahoney Must Go!" At halftime, when cheerleaders tossed tubes containing St. John's T-shirts into the stands, many were thrown back.
"The signs are not right," said Maurice Brown, St. John's 5-9 point guard. "But throwing the shirts back, that's comedy. I don't blame them. You don't want to wear something from a losing team."
This is Mahoney's fourth season as the St. John's coach. After a 19-10 debut, his next two teams finished 12-17 and 14-14. Even if his teams win, he cannot win comparisons with such St. John's predecessors as Joe Lapchick (334-130) and Lou Carnesecca (526-200). In 20 years, Lapchick had one losing season. In 24 years, Carnesecca, whom Mahoney replaced, had none.
Mahoney's players know he is on the hot seat. "We still got to play the game," Lopez said. "If we stop playing, it might be worse."
Mahoney was asked how he felt about his job security.
"I don't have the answer for that," he said. "It's not in my hands. To tell you the truth, it's not easy. We're trying to find a way through it and work with these kids. We're doing the best we can."
The names mentioned as a possible successor include Tom Penders of Texas, who once coached at Fordham, Fran Fraschilla of Manhattan and P. J. Carlesimo of the Portland Trail Blazers, who previously coached at Seton Hall.
But Penders is said to have alienated St. John's officials in the past and Fraschilla is said to be hoping for a more lucrative coaching job. And while Carlesimo has been having disciplinary trouble with some of his pro players, a former college coaching associate says Carlesimo likes the freedom of a pro job. As this coach, who spoke not for attribution, said:
"P. J. told me, 'We practice, not too hard, and then they go home. And that's it. No recruiting. No baby-sitting. It beats college.' "
 
REBOUNDS
St. John's, which has had so many setbacks this season, had two more. A magnetic resonance imaging test yesterday showed that ROWAN BARRETT, who hurt his left foot 11 days before in a game against Rutgers, has a stress fracture. DEREK BROWN, who replaced him as the starting off guard, broke his right foot Saturday against West Virginia. Their replacement against Syracuse was TARIK TURNER, who survived the night.
The Syracuse-St. John's game was the second game of a doubleheader. In the opener, Hofstra (9-17 over all, 5-13 North Atlantic Conference) beat Hartford (5-21, 5-13) by 83-77.
ANTHONY DAVIS, Hofstra's freshman guard, scored 27 points, had 3 assists and made 3 steals.

HEADLINE: Where the Loss of Jobs Means Growing Anger

SERIES: An American Place: Downsizing at Home

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: NORTH CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 26

 BODY:
In August 1994, Lucy Smith, a secretary for Citizens Savings Bank, a very profitable locally owned bank, attended a company meeting to learn what would happen to her job now that Citizens was being sold to a larger national bank.
"The speakers were very upbeat," Mrs. Smith said. The headlines the next day in the local papers reflected that. "Takeover Not Expected To Be Traumatic for Citizens Savings," one read. 
 But it has been traumatic for the 54-year-old Mrs. Smith, who has been out of work eight months and now says: "We may have to sell our home. We're just trying to hold on to what we have."
Mrs. Smith and her husband, Jerry, both longtime Republicans, live in the pleasant middle-to-upper-middle-class suburb of North Canton. The downsizing has been the most humiliating experience of Mrs. Smith's life, she said, and she surely will take it into consideration when she votes.
Here in Stark County, in northeastern Ohio, where politics and the economy mirror national trends, the unemployment rate is several points lower than in 1992, the last Presidential election year. Several employers are posting record profits. Still, most major companies in the region have undergone some downsizing since the early 1990's, including The Timken Company, Republic Engineered Steels and The Hoover Company.
It makes for an uneasiness, an anger, that might not show up in statistics.
Mrs. Smith has always taken great pride in her secretarial skills, having graduated as the top secretarial student in the class of 1959 at Timken High School and then going straight to the secretarial pool at Hoover.
She types 70 words per minute ("80 on a computer, but everybody's faster on a computer"), takes shorthand and knows several computer programs including WordPerfect 5.1 ("that's capital W, capital P, no space") and DisplayWrite 4 ("capital D, capital W, no space").
She volunteers as secretary for the vestry at her church, St. Michael and All Angels Episcopal. After the last meeting, the priest said it was not necessary to take so many notes, but Mrs. Smith explained that she liked to get everything, then whittle it.
Mrs. Smith's last job before going to work for the bank was at Dyer Technology in Hudson, N. H., where she made $8.50 an hour. Her supervisor there, Linda Shattuck said: "Lucy kept us all organized. She was calm when the rest of us were in a dither."
In 1990, after having worked for several companies in the East, (Mr. Smith was in the Navy 20 years), the Smiths returned to Canton, and soon after Mrs. Smith took a job in the data-processing division of Citizens Savings, founded in Canton in 1899.
Mrs. Smith worked for five vice presidents in the division ("very nice people"). She admired the division president, Tom Tuersley. ("A very nice man. We'd call him Tom unless there was a visitor in the office, then it was Mr. Tuersley.")
In 1993 Citizens, which employed about 350 people, had its most profitable year ever.
The sale of Citizens to FirstMerit Corporation, a holding company with seven banks in Ohio and Florida and $5.7 billion in assets, was announced on Aug. 10, 1994. A local financial analyst explained the sale this way: Citizens' directors were aging and wanted to raise the price of the stock, which had not been widely traded, so they could take their profits.
Fifteen years ago, there were six locally owned banks in Canton; now there is one.
FirstMerit officials said it was hard to pinpoint how many from Citizens had lost jobs because there had been a corporationwide reorganization and many workers had been shifted around. Dixie Vinez, a FirstMerit spokeswoman, said the Citizens acquisition had led to a companywide drop in the number of workers, to 2,800 from 3,200.
The data-processing division was split off and offered for sale. In December 1994, the division president, Mr. Tuersley, called a staff meeting. "He told us they might not be able to find a buyer, and we better start looking for jobs," Mrs. Smith said. "I never had any doubt he regretted what was happening."
Three weeks later, Mr. Tuersley called another meeting to say there was a buyer that would take control in six months. It was a smaller company from Akron, and parties familiar with the sale said it could not afford to offer the benefits that Citizens had.
Over the next six months, a steady stream of employees quit. Two assistant vice presidents Mrs. Smith worked for, Tom Haswell and Bob Blackburn, left for Diebold. "Their offices just stayed empty," she said.
Mrs. Smith was asked to take on the receptionist's job in addition to her own. "It was hard to do your secretarial work properly and answering the phone all day," she said.
She was offered a job at the division's new home in Akron. "The benefits were not as good, plus I had to drive 28 extra miles each way to Akron," she said. "I'd be losing money all the way around."
In July 1995, when Mr. Tuersley and those remaining relocated to Akron, Mrs. Smith resigned. Though no one had been laid off, the data-processing division had shrunk to 40 workers from 70. The other day Mrs. Smith heard that Mr. Tuersley himself had recently left the new company. (Neither he nor a spokesman for the company, Casnet, would comment on his departure.)
She did not think that finding a job would be hard. There were lots of want ads for secretaries. "But when I checked," she said, "I found most were temporary agencies."
Victor Valli, a consultant for the local Job Training Partnership agency, said that with all the downsizing, there was a surplus of secretaries.
Mrs. Smith took a civil service test for a library worker position in the Canton schools, scored third out of 96 but got just one call and no job. She had an offer at a medical clinic at $5.25 an hour. "I turned it down," she said. "I didn't think I should take a step backward in salary. Maybe I was wrong."
Mrs. Smith said she believed that her age was against her, and she is angry. A column on the editorial page of the local paper, The Repository, caught her eye recently. "It was by a black gentleman," she said. "He was writing about corporate greed, about how all that counts now is profit, Wall Street, the shareholders. I thought, he's reading my mind. It's like I'm not a person. I'm a commodity, someone they can plug in to make some money."
Mrs. Smith added, "There wasn't anything wrong with Citizens, a strong, healthy, locally owned bank. It's hard to justify what they did."
Mrs. Smith is not political. "Mostly I just get the splash that hits me from the radio or the paper," she said. Still, she always votes, and has voted Republican for President for 20 years.
Going through downsizing changes you, she said. "Prior to this," she said, "I was adamant on the welfare issue. I would have sided with the freshman Republicans -- get them off the roles. But applying for unemployment was the most humiliating experience I ever had. Most people I met there are like me, not poor people in raggedy clothes."
She said that she would vote in the Republican primary but that she did not know for whom. Senator Bob Dole has not grabbed her, and she started to get interested in Steve Forbes just as the newspapers stopped writing about him. Until the New Hampshire primary, she thought that Patrick J. Buchanan's only issue was opposition to abortion. While she agreed with that, and in the last few days has heard that Mr. Buchanan has some of the same economic concerns she does, he seems harsh to her.
The latest statewide poll done by the University of Cincinnati in the days after the New Hampshire primary showed Mr. Dole ahead of Mr. Buchanan 42 percent to 19 percent.
Mrs. Smith said she did not trust President Clinton's character or his position on abortion but respected him more lately for taking a stand against Congress. She said she could vote for him, though she would rather not.
What Mrs. Smith spends most of her time thinking about these days is finding a decent job and rearing her 11-year-old daughter and 15-year-old son. And keeping her house. The Smiths paid $90,000 for the three-bedroom tri-level five years ago. From her kitchen, she can see the geese and ducks on Nimishillen Creek at the edge of her yard.
"I'm worried sick," she said. "I have so much I just want to keep."
As she sat in her dining room the other afternoon, Mr. Smith rushed in from his day job, driving a delivery truck for a restaurant supply company, and hurried upstairs to change.
He used to make $38,000 a year for an environmental cleanup firm but was laid off a little more than four years ago. He sent out 80 resumes and got nothing. "His age is against him," Mrs. Smith said.
Mr. Smith is 56. A human-resources counselor suggested that he dye his gray hair; he did, but then stopped because it embarrassed him. Four years ago, he found the delivery job through a neighbor, and he has worked his way up to $7.25 an hour.
A half-hour after rushing in, Mr. Smith had changed into a dress shirt and tie and rushed back out to his job, preparing tax forms at H&R Block. It pays $5.20 an hour. During tax season he can sometimes get 30 or 40 hours a week working nights and weekends.
That night, when Mrs. Smith went to bed at 11:15, Mr. Smith was still not home from H&R Block, and she fretted because she knew he had to be up at 4 A.M. for his delivery route.
 
About the Series
 
Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades.

Mrs. Smith worries about losing their house, and says that her employer's downsizing has been her most humiliating experience. (Scott Heckle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;
Big Tent Is Shrinking For Grand Old Populist

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TOMBSTONE, Ariz., Feb. 26

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan has progressed in the last three weeks from a long-shot candidate for the Republican nomination to the instrument of a conservative cause, then to the champion of a new political movement named for himself.
Although Mr. Buchanan continues to reject the idea of running as an independent candidate for President if he fails to win the Republican nomination, he increasingly talks about the Republican Party as though he were not a member of it. 
 Asked in an interview on Friday night whether he might form a third party, Mr. Buchanan said, "The Republican Party is so bullheaded and hostile to those of us who to try to get close to the party -- if the party insults our people enough times, by insulting me, they're going to make it impossible to bring us home."
Going far beyond other self-styled Washington outsiders, like Ross Perot and Steve Forbes, Mr. Buchanan has sharpened his language and broadened his attacks to tap into public resentment not only of Congress, the White House and the Federal bureaucracy, but also of a number of large institutions like major corporations, unions and the political party he wants to represent.
"The Pat Buchanan movement," as the candidate began to refer to his campaign last week, is grounded in two themes: opposition to abortion and profound grievances against, or alienation from, established institutions and their leaders.
"Listen, we don't get the boys at Bal Harbour," Mr. Buchanan said in Tucson, Ariz., on Thursday, mocking John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who had criticized him at the labor federation's annual policy-making convention in Bal Harbour, Fla. "We are getting the working men and women of America."
He added: "Senator Dole represents the board room, or the business round table. And some of these other fellows, like Mr. Clinton, they represent the hierarchy of big labor. We represent the working men and women."
With more voters disapproving of Mr. Buchanan nationally than approving of him, his opponents and other political analysts say they are convinced that he cannot win the Republican nomination.
His on-the-cheap campaign is still operating without a pollster, and Mr. Buchanan can seem oddly oblivious to the news coverage he is receiving. "That's outstanding," he declared, informed two days after the fact that The Wall Street Journal had published a front-page article last Thursday describing "Buchanomics." "I've got to get this stuff. This is scrapbook material."
Mr. Buchanan said he believed that since he won the Louisiana caucuses over Senator Phil Gramm of Texas nearly three weeks ago, his social and economic issues could carry him to victories in Arizona and South Carolina and ultimately to the nomination. "It has clearly settled in that we could win it," he said.
Mr. Buchanan now spends more time attacking big business than almost anything else, except perhaps his own party.
"You can't cut trade deals that sell out working people for the benefit of big corporations in New York that got no loyalty to America, no loyalty to you and me and no loyalty to any of us," Mr. Buchanan said at a forum for United We Stand America, the Ross Perot group, in Sun City, Ariz., on Sunday.
Mr. Buchanan's chief complaint against the Republican Party -- as against Washington in general -- is that it is beholden to large corporations. "They revel in these reputations as Chainsaw-this and Pitbull-that," Mr. Buchanan said, speaking of corporate executives, in the interview. "What are we doing praising these people and celebrating them?"
These days he is reveling in his own dark reputation. When he donned a black cowboy hat last week for a parade in Tucson, he was asked whether he would prefer a gray one. "No," Mr. Buchanan replied. "I'm the bad guy."
His frequent predictions that the party's establishment would unite against him, which seemed a bit presumptuous when he lagged far back in the polls, are coming true.
That is why, while they have publicly sounded hurt over attacks by party luminaries like Gen. Colin L. Powell and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, Mr. Buchanan and his aides are privately delighted. "Please, Newt, hit us," said Mr. Buchanan's communications secretary, Gregory R. Mueller, referring to Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Any such attack reinforces Mr. Buchanan's image as an obstreperous outsider, a man who "says what he means and means what he says," a slogan that is turning up on banners and hats at Buchanan rallies.
Today, Mr. Buchanan leaped at another opportunity to cast himself as an embattled maverick. He derided Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the general chairman of the Democratic Party, who on Sunday compared Buchanan supporters with skinheads.
"That is elitism of the worst kind to slander our people," Mr. Buchanan said. "They ought not to be slandered and called names simply because they believe that they ought to have a voice and a representative in Washington."
That posture of unbending principle has helped draw to Mr. Buchanan people who disagree with some of his major positions. Carol Deane, who recently heard Mr. Buchanan speak in Nashua, N.H., said that she used to think he was "some kind of wacko" and that she disagreed with his plan to outlaw abortion. But she added, "I like that he stands up for what he believes."
Mrs. Deane said that her husband was working two jobs and that she was working six days a week cleaning houses. "My parents were able to buy a brand-new house on my father's salary, and he worked at a job that didn't even require a high school degree," she said. "Something's gone wrong."
That is why, she said, she was supporting Mr. Buchanan. "I don't think the so-called elites, I don't think they understand what working people are going through," Mrs. Deane said. Asked who the elites were, she named "international businessmen, career politicians, bankers."
Mr. Buchanan, a Chardonnay sipper who seems more at home in dark business suits than in the windbreakers and bolo ties he has been experimenting with recently, might seem an unlikely populist. But he has always deeply admired politicians who he believed connected with working people. President Ronald Reagan, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, Gen. Douglas MacArthur and Francisco Franco, the Spanish dictator, were among his father's heroes.
"So many working-class people loved Joe," Mr. Buchanan wrote in his memoir, "Right from the Beginning," referring to McCarthy, the flamboyant Republican Red-hunter whose name became synonymous with an era of suspicion and investigative excess in the early 1950's. "Tail Gunner Joe was a populist."
But there is a further wrinkle to Mr. Buchanan's anti-corporate stance. He connects his antagonism to big corporations to his fears that a "new world order" is undermining American independence.
"They have become their own global institutions," Mr. Buchanan said in the interview. "You hear these executives, they talk that way. They don't care about competitiveness. They speak in this global language as though they're above government, above nation."
As he taps into the grievances of people across the country, Mr. Buchanan appears to be working through some of his own grievances, against not only the people he calls "the party elders" but also against members of the press whom he considers liberal and even hostile.
As the returns came in from the New Hampshire primary last Tuesday, Mr. Buchanan was watching CBS News when Dan Rather, the network's anchor, declared him the winner. As Mr. Rather began describing him, Mr. Buchanan, evidently recalling past slights, shouted jubilantly at the screen, "And youthful admirer of Joseph McCarthy!"

HEADLINE: Super-Counterfeit $100's Baffle U.S.

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
During the last six years, counterfeiters in the Middle East have turned out millions of dollars in exceptionally high-quality $100 bills, defying intense American efforts to find and halt their operation, senior American officials say.
Aided by the Central Intelligence Agency, teams of Secret Service agents have crisscrossed the Middle East, recruiting informants and collecting samples of the fake currency, said to be the most realistic counterfeit ever made. 
 Several Administration officials said the inquiry had turned up hints of sponsorship by foreign governments, including suspicions that Iran might be printing the bills and Syria sanctioning their distribution. There also are signs that some of the bills have been used by people with ties to terrorist organizations, the officials said.
But senior officials acknowledged in interviews that it remained unclear precisely where the currency, known as the Superdollar or Supernote, was being produced, or by whom.
And though the Secret Service has confiscated up to $10 million of the fake notes, the officials said, the United States lacks enough evidence to make public accusations against any government or terrorist group.
Indeed, a new report by the General Accounting Office, to be released on Tuesday, says that the problems combating the Superdollar show how vulnerable the United States is to counterfeiting. Nearly two-thirds of the $380 billion in American currency circulates overseas, and substantial counterfeiting could undermine foreigners' confidence in the dollar as the world's safest investment haven.
The threat from the Superdollar has been an impetus to a sweeping redesign of American currency, starting with a $100 bill to be released next month that will incorporate several new anti-counterfeiting measures that could foil most criminals. But when the Government introduces new currency, it does not recall existing bills, and it could take several years for the older notes to disappear from the market.
Treasury officials say some of the fears about the Superdollar have been overblown, and they insist that the Superdollars are only a minuscule fraction of the $100 bills in circulation. They also said they had learned how to spot the slight flaws in several variations of the notes, making the officials more confident that they can keep the problem under control.
Some officials said the Secret Service had disputed a C.I.A. estimate that $1 billion of the notes had been printed. But the G.A.O contends that the Secret Service's methods for making its own projections are inadequte. Other estimates by law enforcement officials range from tens of millions to hundreds of millions of dollars worth of the fake notes.
Administration officials and members of Congress said their biggest concern was that Superdollars could be the handiwork of a hostile country trying to prop up its own economy or interfere with that of the United States.
The matter is considered so critical that when President Clinton met President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in Geneva in January 1994 he asked Mr. Assad for intelligence information that might unmask the counterfeiters. A senior American official said that Mr. Assad said he was "prepared to help."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher renewed the request last May, and American investigators have since traveled to Syria to investigate reports about proliferation of the currency in Lebanon, where the Syrians wield considerable influence. Little of value has emerged from those talks, officials said.
"We've had conversations with a lot of the countries in the region, including the Syrians," said one senior Administration official. "We've never accused them of this. Frankly, we don't know."
Representative James A. Leach, a Republican from Iowa who is chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Financial Services and has been briefed on the inquiry, said the Supernotes were "a very serious problem."
"These do not appear to be notes that emanate from traditional organized crime elements," Mr. Leach said. "My view is that is likely there is governmental involvement in these Supernotes, partly based on the fact that they're so good."
The difficulty in stemming the flow of Superdollars also illustrates the far-reaching changes that the rise of the global economy and the fall of Communism have brought to American law enforcement.
Counterfeiting was once primarily a domestic crime, perpetrated against Americans by Americans. Today, the pursuit of phony bills often touches on diplomacy, intelligence operations and elusive efforts to recruit informants from other countries.
The G.A.O. report, and interviews with Congressmen and Administration officials, also suggest that the slow progress in cracking in the case stems from the Treasury Department's failure to station enough Secret Service agents overseas and from tensions between the Secret Service and the C.I.A.
The G.A.O. says the Secret Service has about 2,000 agents in the United States. But until recently it had fewer than 20 permanent agents abroad, even though Congress had authorized $5 million in 1994 for it to expand its overseas presence.
The G.A.O. report said that sending extra agents overseas had been delayed by disagreement at the Treasury over how broad their responsibilities should be and problems at the State Department in finding room for them at some embassies. The Treasury said it had recently filled 12 of an additional 28 overseas positions.
Spencer T. Backus 3d, a Republican from Alabama and the chairman of a House Banking subcommittee that plans to release the G.A.O. report at a hearing on Tuesday, said the study showed that "we don't have the resources in the field to gauge the problem or stop it."
Investigators said they had come across their first Superdollar, which the Secret Service officially refers to as counterfeit series 14342, in 1990.
They said the fake notes had initially appeared in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon when Muslim and Christian forces were fighting there in the early 1990's. But several new versions of the notes have appeared since, and they have spread as far as Hong Kong and Moscow.
One remarkable feature of the notes is they were printed on intaglio presses, which imprint bills from etched plants with substantial force.
Most counterfeits are printed on offset presses, which produce flat sheets. But the huge intaglio machines are used by the United States and other large governments, including Iran, that print their own currency, and smaller versions are commercially available.
Officials say the Superdollars are made with rag cotton paper, as is real United States currency. They also contain tiny red and blue fibers and an embedded plastic strip, an anti-counterfeiting feature that was added to real dollars in 1990.
The officials said the counterfeiters seemed to have been highly disciplined, appearing to have recognized that flooding the market with too many fake bills might be counterproductive and drive down their value.
Some of the bills have been used to buy legitimate goods, from fuel oil to machinery. One official speculated that if Iran is printing them, it might be doing so as "a nice way to supplement its budget."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Teledyne Raises Bid for WHX and Hints at New Proxy Battle

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The WHX Corporation has increased its pressure for a merger with Teledyne Inc., raising its offer to $32 a share, or a total of $1.78 billion, from $30 a share, or $1.67 billion.
Officials of WHX also broadly hinted that they would wage another proxy fight for control of Teledyne at the annual meeting in April. Such an effort last year gained Ronald LaBow, chairman of WHX, a seat on Teledyne's board. 
 Teledyne, a producer of aviation electronics and specialty metals based in Los Angeles, responded to the improved offer by issuing a statement saying the board would "consider the new proposal." The company said it would send proxy material to shareholders shortly and "comment on all relevant issues in due course."
The price of Teledyne's shares increased 62.5 cents yesterday, to 27.875, after the new offer was announced. WHX shares rose 12.5 cents to close at $11.625.
In the new offer, the cash portion of the bid for Teledyne is sweetened by $2 a share, to $22, with the rest of the payment in WHX stock. WHX's principal asset is the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company; its corporate headquarters, however, are in New York.
In a letter yesterday to William P. Rutledge, Teledyne's chairman, Mr. LaBow indicated that WHX had submitted a list of candidates for election to the Teledyne board.
He added, "Hopefully we can move forward promptly toward consummating this business so that another proxy contest can be avoided."
A spokesman for WHX said most of the candidates were current members of the WHX board.
Teledyne has not responded in detail to WHX's renewed merger effort, which began with the offer of $30 a share on Feb. 9, but clearly does not welcome it. Last week it hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help evaluate the WHX bid and to assist it in a proxy fight, if one develops.
Also last week, the company sent a letter to shareholders contending that the WHX offer had spoiled a planned offering of $400 million in debt, because the action prompted rating agencies to put Teledyne's credit standing under review.
"Goldman, Sachs has advised the company that despite the generally favorable current interest-rate environment, it is not advisable to proceed with the debt offering in light of the uncertainty created by the WHX proposal," the letter said. "This delay may prove very costly to the company."
The electronics company also said that WHX had sold two million Teledyne shares in September, taking a profit of $14 million, while it "was ostensibly and publicly pursuing its goal of acquiring Teledyne."
Chuck Burgess, a spokesman for WHX, confirmed that the sales had occurred. He said the company's current stake in Teledyne was 175,000 shares, or about three-tenths of 1 percent of the total.
Teledyne also said WHX had not provided it with business plans and financial projections. The information is important, Teledyne said, because a major portion of the offer is in WHX stock.
Mr. Burgess replied, "We have provided everything they requested."
Analysts have said that WHX's main interest in Teledyne, whose financial performance has been weak recently, is its pension funds, which are overfinanced. If it gained control of Teledyne, it could use the funds to meet its own pension obligations and could sell all but the specialty-metals division to raise cash.
WHX has been trying to merge with Teledyne since late in 1994. After rebuffing WHX's early advances, Teledyne put itself up for sale last year, but later reversed course, saying that operating the company was the best way to increase its value. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 28, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day yesterday about the WHX Corporation's takeover bid for Teledyne Inc. misstated the action taken on Monday. As the article noted, WHX raised its bid for Teledyne and hinted at a proxy fight for control of the company; Teledyne is not bidding for WHX.
