HEADLINE: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;
With Dole Campaign Off Track, He Puts 2 Advisers Off the Team

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MACON, Ga., Feb. 26

 BODY:
In a stark acknowledgment that his campaign has gone awry and that he has offered an inconsistent message, Senator Bob Dole said today that he had dismissed his campaign pollster and demoted his deputy chairman, just as the campaign is heading into a make-or-break period.
Mr. Dole joked to reporters today that his message had changed so often, it could be considered the "flavor of the week." 
 The moves reflect the turmoil that has beset the Dole campaign since the onetime presumptive nominee eked out a razor-thin victory in Iowa. He lost the New Hampshire primary a week ago, lost again in Delaware over the weekend and could lose in Arizona on Tuesday. "I don't like coming in second," he said today.
Advisers within and close to the campaign said the changes exposed both a candidate who does not know what he wants to say and a campaign staff split by internal power struggles and still arguing over whether negative campaign commercials were the best way for Mr. Dole to make his case.
"Dole has been tentative, cautious and uncertain," said one adviser close to the campaign, "and that's a product of advisers arguing about what he should say."
The immediate result of the changes, some of these advisers predicted, would be fewer negative commercials against Mr. Dole's opponents and perhaps more bold, defining speeches, like the one he gave last year denouncing excessive violence and sex in popular culture.
Mr. Dole, talking to reporters while campaigning today in Marietta, Ga., said that his television commercials had been "a little negative" and that his polls had been "a little too rosy." The staff changes will rectify both problems, he said.
But several people who are either involved in the campaign or close to it differed with Mr. Dole's assessment of his problems.
They said the campaign was split between those who believed in polling and conducting focus groups before setting the campaign course and those who believed it was better to go on instinct and make bold moves, like giving defining speeches.
Despite the internal debate, Mr. Dole continued to attribute his deepest problems to the barrage of negative advertising against him by Steve Forbes -- not to any inherent weakness in himself as a candidate or in his overall message, which still appears to be evolving.
He said Mr. Forbes's ads against him had done so much damage that when voters see one of Mr. Dole's own commercials, "they go, 'Uh oh, here's Bob Dole.' "
"Sooner or later, we've got to get out of these states where he's spent a ton of money," Mr. Dole said. He predicted that South Carolina, which votes on Saturday, would be the last such state.
"If he starts spending more, I don't know what to do," Mr. Dole said, "because sooner or later, we'll be out of money. He'll be out of money later than we are."
Mr. Forbes, who is not requesting Federal matching funds and therefore faces no Federal spending limits, is financing his campaign mainly from his personal fortune. Mr. Dole, who accepts Federal matching money and is bound by spending limits, is quickly approaching the $37 million limit set for the primary.
In the weekend shake-up, it was ultimately the polling proponents who lost the debate. Bill McInturff, a respected Republican pollster with Public Opinion Strategies, was dismissed outright, and William B. Lacy, the deputy campaign chairman who worked for Mr. Dole in 1988, was demoted, then quit rather than accept less responsibility.
Mr. McInturff disputed Mr. Dole's contention that his poll numbers had been too optimistic. He predicted that Mr. Dole would win 26 to 28 percent of the vote in New Hampshire, and he won 27 percent, and that he would win 27 percent in Delaware, which is what he won, Mr. McInturff said.
Mr. Lacy had been in charge of strategy and advertising; Don Sipple, a consultant who joined the campaign last year after his previous boss, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, dropped out, will assume those duties.
Tony Fabrizio, who had been polling along with Mr. McInturff, is to assume full polling responsibilities. And Fred P. Steeper, a Michigan-based pollster and consultant who worked for President George Bush, will provide strategic advice.
Other staples of the Dole team who appear secure for now are Scott Reed, the campaign manager, Mari Maseng Will, the communications director, and Nelson Warfield, the press secretary. Stuart Stevens, who has been making Mr. Dole's commercials, also remains in place. Those familiar with the campaign's internal workings said the staff changes were symptoms of deeper problems in the campaign.
"There has been a lot of debate over the message," one of those sources said, "over our inability to stay on message, the negative ads and the rapid expenditure of money last year, which has the campaign in a pretty serious situation. And the Senator was frustrated."
Similar tumult hit the failing Dole campaign in 1988 when internal rivalries erupted. The campaign manager then, William E. Brock, suddenly dismissed two top consultants, David Keene and Donald J. Devine. Mr. Brock ordered, "Get their baggage off the plane," and they were left at the Jacksonville, Fla., airport. No one suggests that Mr. Dole's campaign this year is in such dire straits.
Mr. Dole said his message was already stronger, but at a McDonnell Douglas plant here today, he did not try to make the case for his candidacy. Instead, he reminded the 200 workers that the primary was coming up and said, "I'll just let you make the judgment."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 28, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart yesterday outlining the economies and politics of Arizona, North Dakota and South Dakota, the three states that were about to hold Presidential primaries, gave an incorrect figure in some editions for the percentage of Arizona's population that is Hispanic. It is 18.8.

HEADLINE: To Privatize Faster, Try a U.S. Yard Sale

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 23 front-page article on increased risk to Federal loan programs as a result of less oversight: The era of big government may be over, but the transition will not be smooth. For example, the Small Business Administration's description of itself as "a model for how the Administration has reinvented Government by slimming the agency in partnership with the private sector" is paradoxical. 
 I have contracted with the agency to market its defaulted collateral real estate portfolio on the information highway. The good news is that I found a buyer for this $100 million portfolio. The bad news is that to get the appraisals of the properties to enhance marketability, I have to file a Freedom of Information Act request.
The notion that there is a partnership with the private sector is off the mark. The Small Business Administration and other agencies pay lip service indicating a willingness to reduce their liabilities, but are so entrenched in their old methods it takes crowbars and sledgehammers to get basic information to assist these agencies in liquidating assets.
The budget battles have reached absurd levels. The tragedy is that the Government hasn't aggressively sold assets to raise revenues and has cut staff in the name of economizing. A more productive approach is to modernize marketing and conduct an American "yard sale." That kind of downsizing will produce laudable results.
 
STEVEN A. LUDSIN
New York, Feb. 23, 1996

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
J-a-p-a-n and C-h-i-n-a

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
With the Soviet threat now gone, and U.S. soldiers increasingly unpopular in Japan because of rape incidents in Okinawa, a lot of people are wondering how long the U.S.-Japan security alliance will hold and how long the U.S. will be able to station 47,000 troops here. Well, stop worrying. While the question is a legitimate one, the answer is obvious -- even though neither U.S. nor Japanese officials want to utter it aloud. So let me just whisper it here: What will keep the U.S. and Japan together in the coming decade is C-h-i-n-a.
The U.S.-Japan security treaty used to be based on protecting Japan primarily from the distant threat from Moscow. But with the rise of an increasingly powerful and assertive China, and with the spread of Japanese investments all over Asia, Japan now has a much greater threat close to home and much greater regional economic interests to protect. Japan's only reliable partner for deterring China and keeping the peace around Asia is the U.S. (And if China isn't enough of a threat for Japan, then the prospect of a reunited K-o-r-e-a, with a few nuclear warheads in the basement, should be sufficient to frighten anyone here into making certain the Yankees don't go home.) 
 "Japan alone cannot handle China, Japan alone cannot handle a unified Korea and Japan alone cannot protect its own sea lanes -- so for all of these reasons we need the U.S. alliance," says Masashi Nishihara, one of Japan's leading defense analysts. "But the problem is, the Japanese Government does not want to talk about the C-word or the K-word."
And that is a problem. Because for the U.S.-Japan security relationship to be sustained several things will have to change here. To begin with, Japanese officials are going to have to be prepared to talk about China. Up to now they have been loath to do so, either because of guilt over Japanese war crimes against China during World War II or because the general approach here to security problems is to stick your head in the sand and hope they just go away. Fortunately, that may be changing.
As one U.S. official remarked to me: "Neither we nor the Japanese want to articulate China as the threat, for fear that it will become self-fulfilling. But when the Japanese look down the road at China's economic growth and military buildup, they inevitably ask themselves how is Japan going to manage a China that strong. Thoughtful people here keep coming back to the U.S." The Japanese press recently highlighted the fact that China, in its attacks on Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, has repeatedly referred to him as "an agent of Japan." Mr. Lee is not only a graduate of Cornell. He also attended Japan's Kyoto University and he still reads the Japanese newspapers every morning.
Japanese officials are also going to have to get comfortable with a new, more broadly defined security relationship with Washington. Right now the U.S.-Japan security treaty is very clear about what happens if Japan is invaded by China. But it is completely unclear about how the U.S. and Japan should cooperate if Taiwan is invaded by China, or if U.S. troops in South Korea are attacked by North Korea. U.S. officials have no idea if Japan would allow them to use U.S. facilities here to defend Taiwan against China.
Japan's economic assets are now regional, the threats to Japan's security are now regional, but the Japanese interpretation of the U.S.-Japan alliance, and of the Japanese Constitution, is that Japan's army can only cooperate with the U.S. to defend its own territory. That situation cannot last. "If American boys are dying for Taiwan and we don't help, we destroy the alliance," says Hisahiko Okazaki, Japan's former Ambassador to Thailand and its most outspoken advocate of U.S.-Japan cooperation to deter China.
Japanese leaders could interpret their Constitution more broadly if they wanted to -- and they better. Because Japan can only really protect itself if it works collectively with the U.S. to deal with security threats in Asia before they reach Japan's shores. Says Mr. Nishihara: "Prime Minister [Ryutaro] Hashimoto should stand up and say that Japan is prepared to work with the U.S. to promote a peaceful settlement of the China-Taiwan dispute -- the Chinese would get the message."
It will take time, but I am convinced Japan will send that message. C-h-i-n-a will make sure of that.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Reforming Civil Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell (Economic Scene, Feb. 22) cites a law professor's prediction that under California's Proposition 202 on the March 26 ballot, civil lawsuits would be settled earlier and less of the proceeds would go to lawyers. That's true. But the motivation behind the proposition isn't to see lawyers get less; it's to see injured victims keep more. 
 Mr. Passell also airs a plaintiff lawyer's claim that Proposition 202's cap on early-settlement legal fees would give lawyers an incentive to press for quick settlements "so they could collect an easy 15 percent and go on to the next case." That is not true. Under the proposition, lawyers would be less tempted to urge acceptance of a lowball offer, since they would get only 15 percent, instead of today's 33 percent.
 
ANDREW TOBIAS
Miami, Feb. 26, 1996
 
The writer is a founder of the Alliance to Revitalize California, the sponsor of Proposition 202.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The V-Chip G-String

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
The Hollywood mogul Barry Diller, half-joking, says he is looking forward to attending tomorrow's much-ballyhooed White House meeting between the President and show-biz potentates so he can "see how Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Turner treat each other." As recently as Monday Rupert Murdoch was accusing CNN of "brown-nosing foreign dictators" in retaliation for Ted Turner's recent characterization of him as a "schlockmeister."
President Clinton, meanwhile, may be looking forward to a P.R. coup. The networks, which only weeks ago threatened to fight the V-chip to the death, have now about-faced and are scrambling to agree upon a chip-activating TV ratings system -- all since Mr. Clinton announced tomorrow's meeting in his State of the Union address. 
 Newt Gingrich, not to be left out, may yet upstage the President. He has scheduled his own breakfast for the media elite just before the White House meeting -- with Sonny Bono on the marquee.
Yes, there's something for everyone in tomorrow's convergence of Hollywood and Washington -- except, perhaps, for the very parents and children who are supposed to benefit from all this ostentatious concern about their video welfare.
It's not for nothing that the networks are suddenly capitulating to a ratings system. They've finally realized that it can be as broad (and hard to enforce) as the movie ratings system it will mimic, in which a PG-13 can cover a multitude of sins. As Mr. Diller says, the entire network prime-time schedule could be rated very simply right now: "Comedies all have sex, so be advised; dramas all have some violence, so be advised." If parents activate the V-chip, they'll be able to block them all -- which once again raises the question of why responsible parents don't just turn off the set in the first place.
But as Mr. Diller rightly considers the V-chip "a genuinely dumbbell idea" that mostly serves the hypocrisy and cynicism of broadcasters and politicians, so he also believes, almost anomalously among his TV-industry peers, that broadcast TV must do much more for the public, especially children, as it enters the multi-channel digital era.
What, exactly? For starters, invest big money and talent in the creation of more programming that might entertain and inform the young so seductively that they'll be weaned away from trash. This issue is also on the White House's agenda tomorrow, but will sermons by Mr. Clinton and Al Gore, however sincere, really bring any action from an economically cutthroat industry with so little recent history of voluntarily serving kids?
The most forceful advocates for better children's television I've talked to believe the broadcasters will make a real, long-term commitment to public-interest TV only if forced to do so as part of a trade-off for that hot commodity known as "spectrum." Simply put, "spectrum" is the additional airwaves that broadcasters want for digital TV -- and want free. Mr. Diller postulates a reasonable quid-pro-quo equation instead: "If broadcasters are going to get new channels and have reinvigorated public responsibility, they should get them free." If not, "they should pay whatever the Government can gouge out of them."
The spectrum debate will come to a head when Congress holds hearings next month, as it tries to decide whether to give the airwaves away or auction them -- with or without public-service requirements. The most consistent Congressional champion of children's TV rights, Edward Markey of Massachusetts, argues that this historic decision over spectrum offers "the last opportunity for commercial broadcasting to be made safe for kids."
But President Clinton isn't seizing that opportunity; he won't link spectrum to children's television. The G.O.P. leadership, which tried to kill Big Bird, will hardly fill the vacuum; it prefers to buy off the public with William Bennett's ineffectual fulminations about Ricki Lake.
After tomorrow's meetings, don't expect network news shows to ask politicians, let alone their own executives, tough questions about the future of children's television; everyone on both sides of the camera will be hiding behind ratings and the V-chip instead. What parents may need most of all is a B-chip to winnow out the phony panaceas from whatever genuine progress is made on behalf of TV-watching kids during an election year.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
'Penny Philanthropist' Inspires Dozens to Make Small Donations

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
He spoke, and people listened. George C. Ginsberg, 96, known to relatives as Papa George and to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund as the Penny Philanthropist, has never been bashful about the amount that he gives, which usually hovers between $1 and $10. He has urged others not to refrain from giving simply because they could not give large sums.
His words were heard and heeded by dozens of people who said they wanted to join the Penny Philanthropy movement, and they credit Mr. Ginsberg as the catalyst. 
 "I am a college student, so I don't have too much to give," wrote Tiffany Refior of Harrison, N.Y. "Mr. Ginsberg made a good point when he said that you'd reach your goal if every Times reader gave a dollar. Here are five."
A $100 gift from Liane J. Revzin of Manhattan arrived with the note: "I did delay. I did forget -- until inspired by Papa George's dedication and enthusiasm."
Mrs. S. Arilotta affixed a yellow Post-It note to her $10 check and wrote, "To help Mr. Ginsberg's prediction come true."
Mr. Ginsberg, of Springfield, N.J., said he had a feeling that the fund would reach $5 million this year. As of yesterday, the fund was still $453,415 away from his forecast. The drive officially ends tomorrow, but donations postmarked by March 1 and received by March 8 will be included in the final tally.
For the last three years, the fund, which provides direct services to thousands of poor New Yorkers each year, has finished its winter appeal in the $4.5 million range. The number of contributors has been declining, but the fund has held its ground as people have given larger donations.
Like many others, Eileen Donohue of Manhattan, who gave $20, said Mr. Ginsberg's commitment to giving moved her to action. "I can only afford a small donation and never sent it before because I didn't think it would really help," Ms. Donohue wrote. "Now I know otherwise."
Judy Goldberg of Brooklyn wrote, "Even though I am currently unemployed, I was touched by the story of Papa George." She sent $5.
A Baltimore woman, Kathleen C. Novak, sent $25 and a message with the heading: "George C. Ginsberg for President." She said Mr. Ginsberg's generous spirit inspired her to "whip out the checkbook and join in the giving."
"I hope to inspire my children with tales of Mr. Ginsberg," Ms. Novak wrote. "What a great example for all."
Mr. Ginsberg's impact is apparent not only in the numbers of letters but also in the increase in donations of $10 or less. Besides the typical personal check, the fund has received dollar bills, small money orders and a traveler's check in the last week.
"I will feel somewhat less 'fat and greedy' if I send something," wrote Cathy M. Dillon of Old Greenwich, Conn., with her $23 gift. "Also, I hate to be left out of a good thing and wouldn't want to be the only reader who didn't send $1!"

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A haven for after-work volleyball shows that amenities are back in corporate office parks.

BYLINE: By Maura Webber 

DATELINE: UPPER MERION, Pa.

 BODY:
A 72,000-square-foot volleyball center in a corporate office park in this town 20 miles west of Philadelphia is a prime example of the growth of recreational amenities in corporate and industrial areas.
For VB Associates, the partnership that developed the volleyball project, the site in the Renaissance at Gulph Mills Corporate Center seemed ideal. Their complex of 10 indoor courts -- called the Courthouse -- is surrounded by office workers who can organize company teams and rent courts for $50 an hour after work. The opening was in November. 
 The partners bought their site from Pasquale Properties, the developer of the 220-acre corporate center, which already has a two-mile jogging path.
H. Donald Pasquale, managing partner at Pasquale Properties, sold the five acres for the Courthouse for $600,000. "All those little things are important," he said. "The jogging path, the recreational facilities."
Dr. Fred Balduini, an orthopedic surgeon who owns a medical practice called South Jersey Sports Medicine, and Michael Dolan of Dolan Contractors Inc. of Westampton, N.J., formed VB Associates and built the warehouse-like building for about $2.5 million. They had considered converting old warehouses but found that most of them were in sites much less accessible than Gulph Mills.
Their center has opened at a time when many business park developers have cut back on amenities. Robert Grabus, president of the Delaware Valley chapter of the National Association of Industrial and Office Properties, said it was fashionable in the 1980's to provide recreational spaces and restaurants.
But as the recession hit, he said, fewer park developers could afford such extras. Instead, outside developers like VB Associates seem to have filled the gap, building workout gyms and ice skating rinks in some parks.
Gulph Mills Corporate Center currently has about 800,000 square feet of office, warehouse and distribution space, and the capacity to add more than double that amount. Construction resumed in the center last year, after a three-year lull. In addition to the Courthouse, last year's activity included construction of two other buildings for office and distribution use with a total of 120,000 square feet of space.
The Courthouse was designed by Dolan Contractors, using a plan similar to that for warehouses. Graham Stewart, a vice president at Dolan, said thick 7.5-inch walls help support the roof and eliminate the need for perimeter columns that might obstruct play. The 28-foot ceilings let balls rise unimpeded. The regulation-size courts fit into 60-by-40-foot bays, with space for bleachers.
VB Associates subleased 7,200 square feet of the building to Novacare, a medical rehabilitation services company based in Valley Forge, Pa. The leased area includes an executive gym, whirlpools and doctors' offices.
Growing interest in volleyball has encouraged such developments nationwide, said John Kessel of USA Volleyball, the sport's national governing body in Colorado Springs. The Courthouse, he said, is one of about 60 large volleyball complexes opened or being developed, with many developers converting unused warehouse space. With the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta approaching, Mr. Kessel and others say the sport will gain even more attention.
Still, some real estate brokers say that if the state of suburban Philadelphia's office market continues to improve, Mr. Pasquale may want to reconsider whether recreational projects make economic sense. Land is worth much more for office development than for recreational use.
The office vacancy rate in the suburbs dropped from 14.2 percent at the end of 1994 to 13.2 percent in 1995, said Steven Cousart, a vice president of office properties for the Grubb & Ellis real estate brokerage firm in King of Prussia, Pa. VB Associates might ultimately want to convert the volleyball center to a more conventional business park use, he said.
"We are expecting the market to become a lot stronger in the next year, although much of it is musical chairs," said Michael McShane, leasing manager at Grubb & Ellis. "Once the vacancy rate gets below 10 percent, we can consider the market healthy. We can expect that to happen in the next year or so."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Traders Still Jittery As Prices Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The mood among bond traders remains jittery, and prices moved lower for the third consecutive day yesterday as investors focused more on this week's supply of new Treasury securities than on the long list of positive economic factors reported yesterday.
The 30-year bond fell 6/32, to a price of 93 27/32 for a yield of 6.47 percent, up from 6.45 percent on Monday. 
 Among the bullish factors that analysts cited were a friendly wholesale producer price report, some central bank buying in support of the dollar, and Fed buying of two- and five-year maturities and a weak retail sales report for January.
At yesterday's auction the Treasury sold $18.25 billion of new two-year notes at a high yield of 5.235 percent, the highest in two months.
Traders said demand appeared adequate in this Dutch auction format. It is a single price system in which notes are awarded at the highest yield needed to sell them. Today the Treasury will sell $12 billion of five-year notes using the same single price format, and in when-issued trading the five-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 5.65 percent, up from 5.55 percent the previous day. The when-issued yield for the two-year backed up about 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point.
Any early price gains quickly faded when the Conference Board's measure of consumer confidence in February reversed January's plunge and came in at a stronger than expected 97.0, compared with 88.4 in January. The rise in consumer confidence suggested to some market participants that the Fed might not feel compelled to cut interest rates aggressively. Investors and traders had expected a lot of weakness in the economy, but some numbers are indicating improvement.
Frank Sannella, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the strong confidence report "gave the market a perfect opportunity to set up for the monthly two-year note auction."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said yesterday's economic statistics brought a mixed bag of market reactions. "The P.P.I. rose 0.3 percent in January, and while this was above the trend rate of producer inflation, as opposed to consumer inflation, for the third consecutive month, it was also considerably less than both market expectations and fears," he said.
"Retail sales, on the other hand, came in somewhat stronger than expected, despite a 0.3 percent decline in January, with upward revisions to both November and December, as well." Later in the morning came the consumer confidence data, which bounced back to 97.0 in February from a depressed 88.4 in January. "However, the trend in consumer confidence appears to be waning," Mr. Fine said, "which calls into question the buoyancy of consumer spending over the upcoming months. Indeed, the evidence seen recently continues to point to an economy that is not about to enter a recession anytime soon, with a trend rate of growth above the fourth quarter's 0.9 percent. At the same time, however, business activity, particularly in the manfucturing sector, appears to be advancing at a suboptimal pace from the Fed's point of view, which certainly leaves the door open for further Fed easing."
But according to Mr. Fine, many market participants are questioning whether the Fed's next easing move will be the last for the foreseeable future.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, noted there were a lot of jitters in the bond markets. The market has broken some key support levels and has not experienced a bounce, he added. So the technical-oriented investors are using this weakness as a sign of deterioration and the market is feeding on the weakenss.
"Basically I think the short end of the market is reflecting the next Fed cut, with the long end discounting a stronger growth economy in the second half of the year," he said.
"The data we saw today serves as confirmation that we are in a weak growth environment and increases the probability of another rate cut in March."

HEADLINE: Consumers Feel More Upbeat, Survey Shows

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Consumers felt much better about the economy in February, a monthly survey showed today. Analysts took the finding as support for the recent assessment by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that economic weakness would likely prove temporary.
The survey by the Conference Board, a New York research organization, reported that confidence among its sample of 5,000 households rebounded to 97 this month from 88.4 in January, when consumers were barraged by news about layoffs, strikes, storms, a partial shutdown of the Government and swollen business inventories. 
 The January decline was a result of a convergence of mostly one-time events, said Edgar R. Fiedler, counselor to the Conference Board, "rather than a signal from consumers that severe economic hardship was on the way."
Economic weakness -- with little inflation -- was evident today in two Government reports for January on producer prices and retail sales. Still, while consumer confidence is not robust -- it was lower in only two months in 1995 -- analysts said the surge in February suggested that further deterioration in the economy was not likely.
As a result, the analysts said they did not expect that Mr. Greenspan and other Federal Reserve policy makers would be compelled to lower short-term interest rates soon.
The Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index for January climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, but only because of a second consecutive leap in the price of gasoline.
Excluding food and energy, both erratic items, the core Producer Price Index edged down one-tenth of 1 percent, the first decline since October 1994. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
"Businesses are being forced to cut prices to spur demand to reduce inventories," said Michelle C. Laughlin, chief economist at the Sanwa Bank in New York.
Analysts also said there was virtually no inflation at earlier stages of the production pipeline. Prices of core intermediate goods, such as a bolt of cloth, have now fallen five consecutive months while core crude goods, such as a bale of cotton, have fallen or been unchanged for seven consecutive months.
"The weakness in these core prices reflects not only an abatement of inflation expectations but also the weakness of the global economy," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The performance of consumer prices in January will be reported by the Labor Department on Wednesday.
The retail sales report, from the Commerce Department, showed a decline in spending of three-tenths of 1 percent in January along with upward revisions of advances for November and December.
Still, this was a smaller slump than many analysts had expected for last month considering the blizzard that buried most of the Northeast.
"The retail sales report adds to the evidence that pessimism on the consumer was overdone at the end of last year," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust.
Automotive dealers and others selling durable goods -- those intended to last at least three years -- took in 1 percent less revenue than in December while those selling nondurable goods saw a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed.
The Commerce Department figures are adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, for holidays and for quirks of the calendar but not for price changes.
The Conference Board's survey found confidence rebounding in eight of nine regions, with only the East North Central states -- Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Wisconsin -- showing a decline. This area, however, had the highest January reading.
As has been the case for an extended period, confidence is lowest in the Middle Atlantic States, with New England second weakest.
Compared with December, the report also showed, the expectations of consumers for the months ahead were modestly lower while their assessment of current conditions was virtually unchanged.
Movement in the Producer Price Index was dominated by a 2.7 percent jump in the price of energy that followed a 3.7 percent December surge. This roughly offset an unbroken series of declines over the preceding six months. The price of gasoline soared 13.3 percent on top of an 8.9 percent jump in December.
Among intermediate goods, copper and brass mill shapes and other durables used in manufacturing fell nine-tenths of 1 percent while nondurable factory items like chemicals eased seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Producers of raw materials saw receipts rise 2.1 percent but this mainly reflected a surge of 7.3 percent for natural gas, crude petroleum and other energy items.
As for retail sales, which account for one-third of gross domestic product, there were revenue declines of 1.2 percent for automotive dealers, seven-tenths of 1 percent for merchants selling furniture and other home equipment and four-tenths of 1 percent for those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
Sales were down three-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling apparel and accessories and one-tenth of 1 percent at bars and restaurants, the report also showed.
But there were increases of three-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and other purveyors of general merchandise.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Market Place: Investors might want to carefully examine the reasons for Wal-Mart's drop in earnings.

BYLINE: By Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:
SOME retail companies no longer need rising profits to keep their stock afloat these days -- they just have to be honest about a disappointing performance.
That is the apparent message Wall Street has sent about Wal-Mart Stores. The company announced last month that it would have its first quarter of declining earnings since it went public in 1970, attributing the downturn to a poor Christmas, snowstorms in the Northeast and high operating costs. The stock took a hit, then recovered much of the 14 percent it lost in the two days after the announcement. 
 Yesterday, the bad news was confirmed. The company, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., said that for its fiscal fourth quarter ending Jan. 31, earnings were down 9 percent, to $942 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with earnings of $1.03 billion, or 45 cents a share, for the comparable period a year earlier. The stock fell early in the day but recovered to end at $21.75 a share, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.
This may be because some analysts have decided that the news was actually good, and that the company would learn from mistakes made in its fourth quarter. But investors would be wise to examine the reasons for the company's earnings downturn before dismissing this disappointment as a mere blip due to bad snow and fickle Christmas shoppers.
For starters, Wal-Mart took a hard hit on its profit margins that were surprising even to those who had braced for poor earnings: gross margins were 19.8 percent, down from 20.8 last year, because of heavy promotions during the holidays. In the past, Wal-Mart has pushed Kmart and regional discounters to slash prices. Now the tables may have turned a bit.
"It used to be that when margins were low, you knew they had initiated the price reduction," said Robert F. Buchanan, an analyst at NatWest Securities. "And they offset it by lowering the expense ratio, so you didn't care," he continued. "But they are not calling all the shots anymore." Mr. Buchanan cited Toys "R" Us as one of several merchants that had beaten Wal-Mart to the markdown gun.
In its conference call with analysts, Wal-Mart executives also expressed worries that its customers were cleaning out the chain's lower-margin shelves in droves.
Further, profit improvements often depend on a retailer's growth, and Wal-Mart's potential to grow rapidly is in question. With well over 2,000 stores in every state in the nation and a few units scattered abroad, the company's expansion opportunities have become limited, according to analysts.
Wal-Mart has placed a lot of its bets on its Supercenters, stores that offer groceries and discount items. Jeffrey Edelman, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, predicts that the company will enjoy about 13 percent growth in sales next year, heavily reliant on the big stores.
But Wal-Mart will not be able to use one of its favorite tactics -- squeezing suppliers for low prices and thus better margins -- with food. "You have regional prices for food," said Gary Giblen, a managing director at Smith Barney. "For instance, Vons can buy their food at a more competitive rate than a Wal-Mart," he said, referring to a California-based supermarket chain.
And Wal-Mart's balance sheet is not helped by the the large payouts it has made to get its Supercenters off the ground.
Further, there is an increasing number of Wall Street wizards who doubt the viability of these giant stores -- a concept Kmart is also looking to for increased profits. "There is a lack of consumer impetus," Mr. Giblen said. "No one wants to buy tomatoes, then go buy tires and then go buy ties."
And if it is higher margins that Wal-Mart seeks, cookies and laundry detergent may not be the place to get them. Just ask Floyd Hall, the chief executive of Kmart, who has gotten almost nothing but grief over his plans to fill Kmart shelves with consumable goods.
Wal-Mart has other parts of its operations that it will have to get into shape before it enjoys stronger earnings, in addition to increased same-store sales, which most analysts are predicting for next month.
Its Canadian operations are suffering along with that country's recession, and its discount warehouse, Sam's Clubs, has long been a money pit. The company's international division had an operating loss of $13 million for last year, compared with a $4 million loss in the previous year.
Finally, there is little reason to believe that Wal-Mart can remain immune to vexing factors that have plagued the entire retail industry over the last few years: too many stores, too few shoppers, too much consumer debt and too much reliance on the intangible, cyclical nature of shoppers' buying whims.
"All the things that Wal-Mart is saying tell us they are suffering along with everyone else," Mr. Edleman of Morgan Grenfell said. "But what hurt them is they have typically always done better."

HEADLINE: Prices on Stocks Fall, With Dow Off 15.89

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks suffered their second setback in as many days yesterday, as Wall Street grew worried that long-term interest rates might be headed higher.
In volatile trading, the Dow Jones industrial average ended with a loss of 15.89 points at 5,549.21 after an earlier drop of more than 50 points activated the New York Stock Exchange's limit on program trading. 
 Interest-rate fears also rattled the market Monday, when the Dow dived 65.39 points to close at 5,565.10.
Some technology stocks showed strength, although the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 6.88 points, to 1,106.17.
The Standard & Poor 500-stock index also fell, declining 3.22 points, to 647.24.
"It's a market encumbered by interest-rate jitters and the outcome of the G.O.P. race," Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Company, said. Republican Presidential primaries were held in North Dakota, South Dakota and Arizona yesterday.
Analysts said Wall Street feared the increasing popularity of the Republican Presidential hopeful Patrick J. Buchanan because he favors United States protectionism, which could hurt trade. And a shaky start to the campaign of the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, has been seen as a sign that President Clinton might win the election more easily, which markets view negatively.
Investors fear that long-term bond interest rates may be headed higher because of slightly stronger economic growth and diminished hopes for a Federal budget agreement, at least in the near term. Higher interest rates could stunt economic growth and hurt corporate profits by increasing the cost of borrowing.
Economic reports yesterday showed an increase in consumer confidence, to 97.0 in February, from a revised 88.4 in January.
January producer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent; a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent was expected. January retail sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a forecast of a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 9/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, to 6.47 percent -- the highest since Oct. 2 and up from 6.45 percent at Monday's close. Only two weeks ago, the yield was at 6.03 percent.
"The recent backup is the end of the bull market for bonds for right now," said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yaimichi Securities. Among individual issues, U S West Media lost 5/8, to 21 5/8, after announcing the acquisition of Continental Cablevision, the third-largest United States cable operator, for $10.8 billion, including the assumption of debt.
Florida East Coast Industries climbed 8 1/8, to 83 1/8, after the announcement of the proposed sale of its railroad unit to the St. Joe Paper Company, which owns 54 percent of Florida East Coast. St. Joe Paper rose 4 3/8, to 59 3/4.
Microchip slumped 7 1/2, to 28 1/2, after the company warned that its earnings and revenues would be lower than expected for the current quarter.
In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,340 to 1,014, on active volume of 431.3 million shares on the Big Board. The New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 1.36 points, to 345.59. The American Stock Exchange index slid 1.49, to 563.86.

HEADLINE: Pataki Adviser Gets Subpoena Over Inaugural

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The Democratic-controlled Assembly issued subpoenas today to Gov. George E. Pataki's top economic adviser and a private lawyer, seeking information about the corporation that financed Mr. Pataki's three-day inauguration last year.
Senior Democrats in the Assembly maintained that the two men and other officials were hiding how they raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the event. 
 The move touched off what is likely to be a lengthy battle between the Republican administration and Democratic legislators over the inauguration, an elaborate affair whose records have been kept secret by the Governor's aides.
Both houses of the Legislature can issue subpoenas, but in recent decades they have seldom invoked this power. The subpoenas drew an immediate denunciation today from Pataki administration officials, who said they were considering asking a court to declare them void.
"I think that there is a real question as to the authority of what they may and may not do," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference this morning, declining to comment further.
But the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said the public had a right to know the names of the people and corporations that donated money for the inauguration.
"This is an extraordinary remedy," Mr. Silver said. "But they have stonewalled every other attempt to acquire this information."
The Governor's aides, with his assent, set up the private corporation just after his election in 1994 to raise money for the event so that no taxpayer dollars would have to be spent. The aides said at the time that the corporation, New York Inaugural '95, would abide by state campaign contribution limits and disclose the names of all donors.
Yet the corporation did neither. According to interviews with some of the contributors, it let many companies give more than is allowed under state campaign laws, and then, in November, it announced that it would not release a list of donors or any accounting of its activities.
At the heart of the dispute is the question of who gave money to New York Inaugural '95 -- and whether those people or groups wanted favorable treatment from the state government in exchange for their contributions.
The administration has denied any wrongdoing, but senior Democrats have repeatedly called for the corporation's records to be made public, hoping to turn the inauguration into a political liability for the Governor.
Though legislative subpoenas are unusual, the Assembly Democrats have issued them on a few occasions since Mr. Pataki took office. In the most recent instance, the Governor's top environmental official, Michael D. Zagata, asked a State Supreme Court justice in Albany to quash a subpoena issued by Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Westchester County.
In a ruling earlier this month, the justice, Thomas W. Keegan, upheld the subpoena, which sought documents related to a pollution settlement between the state and General Electric. Justice Keegan said the Assembly had to be able to obtain information that it needed to fulfill its job of making laws.
It appeared that the Assembly waited for the judge's decision before going forward with today's subpoenas. In explaining those subpoenas, senior Democrats said they required more information about the Pataki inaugural to determine whether to pass laws regulating such events.
"Perhaps we should do what other states have done and put statutory language on the books to deal with these kinds of inaugural functions," said Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli, a Democrat from Nassau County who is chairman of the Committee on Governmental Operations.
The inaugural corporation was dissolved in November, and Mr. Pataki's aides say it raised about $600,000. But the Democrats insist that the total was closer to $1.4 million.
The Governor's aides have said that New York Inaugural '95 is under no obligation to release its records because it is not a governmental or political group. The Democrats charge that the corporation served a fundamentally political purpose and should be subject to campaign finance laws.
Last month, three Assembly committees sent letters to more than a dozen Pataki advisers and Republican officials requesting documents relating to New York Inaugural '95. None of the officials turned over any record or specific information, and as a result the Assembly turned to the subpoenas.
Though Mr. Pataki expressed doubts about the legality of the subpoenas this morning, later in the afternoon, his spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said the Governor would have no role in determining whether to challenge them in court. She said the administration's view was that the subpoenas involved a private corporation, not state government.
She also said that the Governor would not discuss the subpoenas with the two men who received them, even though one of them, Charles A. Gargano, is now Mr. Pataki's top economic adviser.
"This is a decision that will be made independently by the officers of the corporation," she said. "He does not plan to speak to any of them."
The Assembly issued the subpoenas to Mr. Gargano and Lawrence Kalkstein, a private lawyer. Mr. Gargano was Mr. Pataki's top fund-raiser during the campaign and the chairman of a committee that organized inaugural events. Mr. Kalkstein was the corporation's lawyer.
The subpoena orders the men to testify at a hearing in the Assembly on March 20 and bring along the records of New York Inaugural '95 and a related corporation, New York Transition '95.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gargano, accused the Assembly Democrats of trying to smear Mr. Gargano.
"This is nothing more than partisan politics at its worst," she said. "It should have no place in government."

HEADLINE: Portrait From New Era Of Nation's Gambling

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: JOLIET, Ill.

 BODY:
Her nimble fingers dance across the red felt semicircle, dealing cards and sweeping up chips. She calculates at lightning speed, rewarding good luck with more chips, and grimacing as she cleans out a loser.
Jan Craven is a blackjack dealer aboard the Northern Star riverboat casino, one of two owned by Harrah's Entertainment that ply one and one-half miles of a canal through industrial wasteland, satisfying a state requirement that gambling take place only offshore. "She's got personality, personality," chants Mike Jones, a tavern owner from Indiana who has amassed a $980 stack of chips as tall as his rum and Coke. 
 In holding customers to their tables, keeping all betting and most happy, game dealers like 41-year-old Ms. Craven have helped ignite the boom in a business that has spread from Nevada and New Jersey to 21 other states since 1989. With the growth of gambling, casinos now employ tens of thousands of dealers. A divorced mother with two boys, ages 10 and 12, Ms. Craven is a silk-collar heir to the middle-class, blue-collar worker whose fortunes have sunk with the mergers, layoffs and cost-cutting in manufacturing industries. Raised in the Bronx, she previously held a lower paid job in a telecommunications plant near Dallas where she was a fiber-optics technician. Her formal education, like that of most blue-collar workers, stopped with her high school diploma.
Legalized gambling, which opened in Joliet almost four years ago, also has been the salvation of this city of 83,000 that was best known for a jail, dead factories and, in Will County, an unemployment rate that reached 27.6 percent for a month in 1983. Thanks largely to casinos, it is now about 5 percent.
Casinos became Joliet's biggest employer almost overnight, having surpassed a Caterpillar tractor plant with 3,500 workers.
All this has made Joliet, like many other once-ailing communities that have brought in casinos, a place of relative prosperity.
Two casino companies, with two boats each, operate here: Harrah's, owned by The Promus Companies, and the locally owned Empress River Casino Corporation. Ninety percent of the 4,000 employees of these companies work full time.
They earn an average of $24,000 a year, about $3,000 more than the average American worker. The 800 men and women who preside over the blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette and Caribbean stud tables earn $30,000 or more -- often enough here to maintain the fast-disappearing, one-worker family.
And even the least skilled and lowest paid workers get employer-subsidized health insurance, retirement plans, free uniforms and free meals on the job.
"Workers are buying things they never had, getting medical attention they never had," said Teri Shannon, an organizer here for the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union and bargainer for many Empress workers, but not the dealers.
"They're buying cars and motorcycles. Local gyms are doing very well. Single mothers without college educations are doing a lot better than they ever could have without the riverboats."
Organized labor has had a pivotal role in the workers' well-being. Management of Harrah's, which is nonunion, says its wages are driven by Empress, which has been organized by Ms. Shannon's union and the International Union of Operating Engineers.
"We try to stay competitive," said Patrick R. Dennehy, general manager of the Harrah's casinos here.
Efforts to organize dealers throughout the industry so far have failed. But management goes to some lengths to keep them happy, because without dealers and their skills, the business would sink.
Dealers like Ms. Craven strive to set a happy tone as soon as their patrons take stools at their tables. Within minutes of boarding for a two-hour cruise, Mike Jones, the tavern owner, in a blue Notre Dame sweatshirt, sat down and said he was prepared to bet and lose $1,000.
Essie Johnson, a correctional officer from Chicago in a gold-flecked violet sweater, beside him, said: "I'll do a couple of hundred on two cruises. That's it." Four other customers, all women, took the remaining stools.
Ms. Craven greeted four by name and encouraged the others to introduce themselves. "I try to make them feel they're at my kitchen table," she said. "If they're having fun, you're having fun, too."
Bantering started, and the customers kept it alive. "Once I get a conversation going, I don't have to talk any more," Ms. Craven said. "They're talking to each other."
Then the game began. With color-coded chips, the customers placed bets of $25, $50 and $100 toward a goal of being dealt two cards that total 21 for an instant 3-to-2 payoff. Ms. Craven, in her green silk shirt and clipped-on bow tie, her sometimes weary feet in black tennis shoes, dealt each customer two cards face up and two for herself -- one, a 9, face up, the other down.
As the game progressed, Mr. Jones got a 5, which gave him 20 -- close enough to win the round. "There you go!" Ms. Craven said, looking like she truly enjoyed handing him a fistful of the house's chips.
Ms. Craven receives no incentives to help the house win or for goading her customers to bet more or faster than they feel they should. Siding with the customer is one of the keys to the growth of casino gambling. Dealers are expected to keep customers happy because happy customers return. Without any help from dealers, the odds automatically favor the house, so dealers can dwell on keeping up spirits.
"Dealers have face-to-face contact with the customer for extended periods of time," said Mr. Dennehy, the Harrah's manager. "They have responsibility for that customer, even under adverse conditions. They set the tempo of the game and monitor the intricacies of it. They celebrate when the customers win and commiserate when they lose."
But dealers must also be technically flawless in doling out chips, and alert to cheating, like "capping," when a customer surreptitiously tries to add chips to those he has bet when he expects to win. "You need peripheral vision," Ms. Craven said.
An hour into the two-hour cruise, only one customer, a woman, has left the table. Another woman customers bet the last of her remaining chips, $50 worth. Her first two cards added up to 14. "Hit me," she said. She got a Queen, worth 10, so she was out with 24. Sad, looking drained, she rose to go. With an empathetic smile, Ms. Craven told her: "Thanks for coming. Maybe you should go home. Or try another game."
That is the down side of this job, Ms. Craven said. "Sometimes they have days when they lose all they've won," she said. And no amount of kitchen table consolation helps. "We just shuffle the cards. They make the decisions. When they lose like that, they're not happy, and you can't make them happy. It kind of brings down the whole table. It brings you down, too."
Ms. Craven works Tuesday through Saturday on day shifts at the floating casino, which operates 22 hours a day. She is paid $5 an hour, but she earns at least twice that in tips. Periodically during the game, customers add a chip for the dealer alongside their own bets. Management, which tracks all such transactions, pools the tips and distributes them among all dealers.
Near the end of the cruise, the mood at Ms. Craven's table turned boisterous as all six customers were beating the house. Ms. Johnson got a two-card blackjack with a 10 and an ace. Then Mr. Jones got one with a Queen and an ace. Next time around, Ms. Johnson, dealt a 10 and a 4, pointed to her cards showing she wanted another.
"Hit that girl!" Mr. Jones ordered Ms. Craven. Ms. Johnson got a 6, making 20.
"There you go, again!" said Ms. Craven who had dealt the house 18.
"Oh, are we good, girl!" Mr. Jones said to Ms. Johnson as they smacked their hands in high-fives. He thrusthis cellular phone in front of her. "It's the President calling to congratulate you," he said.
Joann Pankow, a games manager, came by and took in the atmosphere at Ms. Craven's table. "She's developed a rhythm," Ms. Pankow said. "She's not only good technically. She makes it fun. She makes it a game."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harrah's Northern Star riverboat casino and three others operating from Joliet, Ill., employ 4,000 people, who earn more than average Americans, taking gamblers on cruises in a bleak canal. Jan Craven, a dealer on Harrah's casino riverboat, says she keeps players happy by acting as though the game were at her kitchen table. (Photographs by Lloyd DeGrane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bellinzona Journal;
Poor Swiss Get U.S. Bill: $125 Billion and Change

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BELLINZONA, Switzerland, Feb. 21

 BODY:
This is a town of steep lanes, floodlighted castles atop rocky outcroppings and thick Alpine mists. It finds relief from February's glumness mainly in weeklong Carnival festivities.
Relief is something the burghers of Bellinzona sorely need. Word belatedly got out in the fall that Ticino, the canton of which Bellinzona is the capital, had been ordered by a court in New York to come up with $125 billion to pay American investors who say they lost their money when a tiny bank in Ticino, Inter Change Bank, failed nearly three decades ago. 
 The exact amount was $125,444,300,221, but the local newspaper, Corriere del Ticino, rounded it off when it reported the news, perhaps to avoid unnecessary embarrassment.
It was the ultimate indignity for Ticino, population 300,000, long the poor cousin in affluent Switzerland. With the powerful Swiss franc making local hotels prohibitively expensive to most foreigners, major regional industries like tourism are suffering, and the unemployment rate is 8.5 percent, roughly double the national average.
With an annual government budget of about $2.1 billion, Alex Pedrazzini, the lawyer who heads Ticino's Justice Department, said "we'd be paying for more than 70 years" to repay the fantastic sum, almost half the United States annual military budget.
The legal entanglements surrounding the case have already cost Ticino $854,000 in lawyers' fees, and the government recently turned to the Swiss Parliament for an additional $1.7 million. Its remaining hope is a Federal court hearing in New York on Feb. 28, when its lawyers want to get the lower court decision reversed.
"If not, we'll all be working for McDonald's and Burger King the rest of our lives to pay it off," Mr. Pedrazzini said.
No one really believes Ticino will have to pay, given that the plaintiffs waited until 1989 to file suit, long after the statute of limitations ran out in the bankruptcy case, which wound up two years earlier.
To Werner Abegg, the Swiss National Bank spokesman in Zurich, too many details in the case are murky, including why the investors put such a large amount of money in such a tiny bank, which had only $14 million in assets.
To local businessmen, like Franco Ambrosetti, the head of a company that makes aircraft landing gear, Ticino is probably the target of a huge scam. But he blames the local government for having handled it badly and wasting taxpayer money.
"This isn't some judge in Burundi, it's a court in the United States," he said. "You shouldn't have let it get that far."
Ticino's headaches began in 1989, when lawyers for a man named Robert Granville Higgins filed suit in New York asserting that in 1966 the estate of Mr. Higgins's late brother, Sterling Granville Higgins, deposited $600 million in options on oil and mineral deposits in Venezuela with Inter Change Bank.
The complex arrangement called for the bank to pay an extraordinary interest rate on the money of 1 percent per week, the lawyers asserted. In 1967, Inter Change collapsed under a mountain of bad debt.
In October 1994 the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled that Ticino and the bank's liquidators had to pay back the $600 million, plus interest, which brought the total to $125 billion.
"It's a bizarre case," said Paul Bschorr, a lawyer at the New York firm of Dewey Ballantine, who represents the Bellinzona government. "I've never seen one like it in my life."
Two months after the original verdict, the Brooklyn court ordered Swiss assets in the United States to be attached unless Ticino paid what it owed. Alarmed, the New York Federal Reserve sought and obtained a staying order suspending that ruling.
The Swiss are watching the case closely, not least because of another lawsuit brought in Manila against Swiss banks by thousands of Filipinos. Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former Philippine President, is thought to have put $475 million in Swiss banks, and the Swiss fear that courts in Hawaii, where Mr. Marcos died in exile in 1989, could attach assets of their American branches to pay the money to the Filipinos in compensation for political persecution suffered under the Marcos Government.
Here in Bellinzona, most people believe they are the target of a huge swindle in the New York case.
According to Mr. Ambrosetti, who heads the local chamber of commerce, people reacted by saying, "It can't be true, the guy's a crook." And indeed, both Robert and Sterling Granville Higgins had served time in jail in the United States, Robert for fraud, Sterling for issuing bad checks.
Sterling Granville Higgins died in San Quentin in 1961 at the age of 37. His net worth at the time, according to papers filed with the court, was less than $5,000. His brother Robert spent seven years in prison in the 1960's and 1970's.
What is also puzzling is how the court handed down a ruling solely on the claims of the plaintiff's lawyers. The $600 million appears to have been under Inter Change Bank's fiduciary management, so it did not appear on the bank's balance sheet.
"It never seems to have been made clear where the $600 million came from in the first place," Mr. Abegg, the National Bank spokesman, said recently. "The whole thing is extremely odd."

HEADLINE: Turkish Chief Set for Deal to Bar Islamic Party

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Jarred by a pro-Islamic party's close brush with power, Prime Minister Tansu Ciller of Turkey said here today that she was ready to make sacrifices to form a center-right coalition taking shape in Ankara, in order to block the party from any future role in government.
Invoking the image of the self-sacrificing mother in the legend of King Solomon's judgment, Mrs. Ciller said in an interview here today that she was "prepared to do what I have to do" to stop the pro-Islamic Welfare Party, which scored a narrow victory in Turkish elections last December. 
 Mrs. Ciller, in Rome to enlist the support of the Italian Government on the subject of Turkey's longstanding disputes with Greece, returned to Ankara tonight for a crucial meeting on Wednesday with her archrival, Mesut Yilmaz, leader of the center-right Motherland Party. Mr. Yilmaz's two-week coalition talks with the Welfare Party collapsed several days ago.
According to her aides, Mrs. Ciller is prepared to agree to a rotating premiership and, stepping back from her earlier bargaining stance, to let Mr. Yilmaz take the first turn. Under the terms of the deal being negotiated, Mr. Yilmaz would serve for a year, Mrs. Ciller would then returnfor a two-year stint and Mr. Yilmaz would follow her for a two-year rotation, the aides said.
Mrs. Ciller declined to be specific, referring instead to the story of the mother who agreed to give up her baby rather than see it cut in half in a test decreed by King Solomon. Mrs. Ciller, 49, a former economics professor who spent several years studying in the United States, is the leader of the True Path Party, Turkey's other center-right party.
As she has in the past, Mrs. Ciller invoked the Islamic threat in her appeal to the West for support of Turkey -- a Muslim country with a long tradition of West-leaning secularism -- in its recurring disputes with Greece. Saying that the Welfare Party had exploited the feeling, shared by many Turks, that Turkey gets second-class treatment from Christian nations, she warned that support for Greece in its attempts to block aid to Turkey would increase the perception among Turks that Europe is unfair.
A coalition between Mrs. Ciller and Mr. Yilmaz -- both pro-European free marketeers -- has been strongly favored by Turkey's business and military establishment as a way out of a political crisis that began before the December elections. But until now, the two leaders have been unable to overcome their bitter personal rivalry, and neither has given up insisting on being the lead-off prime minister in a coalition.
Angered by Mr. Yilmaz's recent overtures to Necmettin Erbakan, the mercurial leader of the Welfare Party who has been shunned by other mainstream politicians, Mrs. Ciller said she saw it as her duty to try to forge new bonds between "two parties that have similar programs."
"I felt I had two historic missions for Turkey," she said. "One, to step Welfare from becoming part of the government and two, to unite one way or another, so that our two parties will form a bloc of 40 percent and so that in the future there will not be the threat of a small radical party coming into the picture and dictating the destiny of Turkey."
Mrs. Ciller, who in recent weeks said a deal with Mr. Erbakan would plunge Turkey into "darkness," noted that even during the delicate coalition talks, the Welfare Party leader had praised the Iranian revolution, condemned United Nations sanctions against Iraq and threatened to pull out of Turkey's recently concluded customs agreement witht the European Union. But the greatest danger, she said, would be to let the strong-willed, tightly disciplined Islamic party get a foot inside the Turkish Government.
"It is a very disciplined party, and they get hold of the bureaucracy very easily," she said. "They have done that before, and we still have remnants."
Mr. Erbakan, a veteran of Turkish politics who served in two coalition governments in the 1970's, has seen his party ride a wave of economic and social discontent in Turkey, fueled by high inflation, high unemployment and disgust with the corruption and general behavior of the mainstream parties. Its success in December -- it captured 21.4 percent of the vote -- was due in large measure to the strength of its grass-roots operations, and also to the increase in parties that together divided the secularist vote.
Although he later toned down his anti-Western language, Mr. Erbakan has clearly relishes his position as a pariah among Turkey's committed secularists and has repeatedly said that as leader of the opposition, he expects to come back stronger in Turkey's next elections, whenever they may be.
A center-right coalition between Mrs. Ciller and Mr. Yilmaz would not have a clear parliamentary majority, since each party commands only 20 percent of the seats. Mrs. Ciller said today that she is not worried about the strength of the Welfare opposition, but about getting the support from Turkey's other parliamentary parties to sustain an effective government.
"We have to be successful in the coalition," she said, noting that Welfare's 158 seats would not be able to determine the majority on issues. "What is relevant is getting the support, as minority or majority government, from the other parties," including those on the left.
Mrs. Ciller came to Rome on a one-day diplomatic mission, to enlist the support of the Italian Government, which now holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, to counter efforts by Greece to block European aid to Turkey. The Greek effort to block the $487 million aid package -- part of a customs union agreement that went into effect on Jan. 1 -- came after the two countries almost went to war this month over a small uninhabited outcropping of rock in the Aegean Sea.
Mrs. Ciller again appealed for direct negotiations with Greece over the disputed islets, as well as a long list of other issues that continue to cloud relations between the two NATO members.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

AT&T to Offer Customers Free Internet Access
AT&T, pushing aggressively into the Internet business, said it would offer its telephone customers five hours of free Internet access each month for a year.
In addition, beginning next month AT&T said it would offer its residential customers unlimited Internet access, including electronic mail and nationwide phone directory services, for less than $20 a month. [Page A1.]
 
$16 Million for AT&T Chief
Robert E. Allen, AT&T's chairman and chief executive, who is now cutting 40,000 people from the payroll, got stock options last year that brought his total pay package to $16 million from $6.7 million. The company said he and other top executives could not cash their options for at least four years. [D7.]
 
Stocks Slide on Rate Fears
The Dow industrials lost 15.89 points, closing at 5,549.21, in volatile trading that saw a drop of more than 50 points during the day. Traders were nervous about rising interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index fell 6.88 points. [D8.]
 
Bond prices fell for the third consecutive day, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up slightly to 6.47 percent. [D18.]
 
Money Floods Into Mutual Funds
Net inflows to stock and bond mutual funds totaled a record $33.3 billion in January, and investors have continued to pour money into funds this month. [D2.]
 
For Wal-Mart, a Down Quarter
Wal-Mart Stores, after 99 quarters of rising earnings, missed No. 100. The retailer reported a 9 percent slide to $942 million, or 41 cents a share, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan. 31. But Wall Street had been prepared for a drop, and the stock gave up only 12.5 cents to end at $21.625. Still, some analysts see challenges ahead. Market Place. [D8.]
 
More Unraveling at Barney's
In the latest unraveling of a Barney's business relationship since the retailer filed for bankruptcy protection, the co-chairmen of Barneys New York will sell their half-interest in a restaurant in the Madison Avenue store run by Pino Luongo. [D8.]
 
Court Lifts Novo Nordisk Injunction
Novo Nordisk, a biotechnology company based in Denmark, said a Federal Appeals Court had reversed an injunction that had blocked American sales of a genetically engineered human growth hormone made by Novo Nordisk. [D4.]
 
Orange County Wooing Wall St.
Orange County, Calif., courted Wall Street, seeking an investment-grade rating for about $830 million in new debt that the bankrupt county plans to issue in May. [D7.]
 
Why Not Ms. Chairwoman?
Why aren't women ruling the corporate world? A survey found that women climbing the corporate ladder blamed male stereotyping. But male chief executives cited too little time in the pipeline. [D2.]
 
Buzz, a Selling Bee for Flora
To encourage people to buy flowers, the National Promoflor Council has engaged Deutsch Inc., a brash New York ad agency. It has dreamed up Buzz, a portly young man who will serve as a Johnny Appleseed for flora in a two-year campaign with a $20 million budget. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
V-Chip Passing Canadian Test
Canadians testing a chip to block violence on television, the V-chip, are singing its praises. Similar chips are to be required on sets sold in the United States in two years. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Still Talking About Tax Cuts, Congress Goes Back to Work

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans sought today to reclaim their party's agenda from the rhetoric of its Presidential campaign, insisting that what the economy needed was old-fashioned budget balancing and tax cutting.
Congress returned to Washington after a three-week vacation when the Presidential hopefuls from its ranks fared badly in the campaign. But one element of Capitol Hill Republican orthodoxy, tax cuts, seemed sure to survive both the upsets of the primaries and the new political buzzwords of "layoffs" and "corporate responsibility." 
 Arguing that the economy was suffering only from "the Clinton crunch" of tax increases adopted in 1993, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, scoffed at the campaign trail invocations of job insecurity and foreign trade barriers as merely "all that noise."
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, chairman of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on immigration, denounced Patrick J. Buchanan's call for a halt to most legal immigration as "a very unfortunate play to base emotions." Mr. Simpson added, "It's racist."
Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia told reporters this morning that he favored attaching a tax cut to a bill to raise the statutory ceiling on the Federal debt. "The failing Clinton economy is hurting people," Mr. Gingrich said. "I think we need something to stimulate and create jobs and keep from a recession."
The Speaker later revived the idea of a deal with the Administration on balancing the budget. "It seems to me possible that there could be an Administration agreement to get a balanced budget deal in the next couple of weeks," he said. But Senate aides familiar with the budget process said they had seen no recent progress suggesting that an agreement was any more likely than it had been since talks broke down in early January.
Another member of the House Republican leadership said Mr. Gingrich had told the group that President Clinton had telephoned him to suggest that they make one more try to reach agreement. At the White House, aides were hopeful that the discussions would lead somewhere.
One central Congressional figure who held back from comments on economic policy was Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. Paying a brief visit to the Capitol before leaving to campaign in South Carolina for the Republican Presidential nomination, he said he did not know what the budget situation was but planned to talk to Mr. Gingrich on Wednesday.
A very different note was sounded by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, who argued in a speech today "the era of deficit politics is over."
In a speech to the Economic Strategy Institute, a think tank, Mr. Gephardt said that agreement on a balanced budget could be reached next year if it was not accomplished in 1996. But far more central to Americans, he said, was the need for policies that would reward hard work because "wages have been falling for more than 16 years."
While praising Mr. Buchanan for discerning the pain of American workers, Mr. Gephardt scoffed at his solutions as blaming "our problems on immigrants, the poor, people of different ethnicities and genders."
And he asked "How can someone who opposes the minimum wage, opposes health and safety standards and opposes family leave even pretend to stand for the American worker?"
"We are living through an economic earthquake as titanic and transforming as the Industrial Revolution," Mr. Gephardt said. "For many Americans, just staying in place means a never-ending scramble of longer hours, second jobs and credit card debt. But our political system hasn't done a damn thing about it."
Mr. Armey, in a speech to the conservative Heritage Foundation, promised Republicans would take nine steps to help the economy. Besides the tax cuts on capital gains and for working families with children, he promised legislation to protect pensions, to make health insurance portable when changing jobs and to restrict the ability of labor unions to use dues for purposes other than collective bargaining.
Promising to move to avote on a constitutional amendment that would require a super majority vote to raise Federal taxes, Mr. Armey was caustic about the campaign, saying: "Political discourse is not tied in any ironclad way to the spirit of devotion to the truth. One should not rely too heavily on either words or numbers."

HEADLINE: Don't Allow Cuban Exiles to Make U.S. Policy;
Castro's Decision

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The problem with having an outcast in your neighborhood is highlighted by the downing of two aircraft by an isolated and obsolete Cuban regime. 
 Political realities have long prevented a rational discussion of how we might bring Cuba into the post-cold-war world.
I offer the following modest proposal: The President should announce that United States citizens and corporations may openly and freely trade with any Cuban company whose ownership is substantially private in nature.
This would clearly state our position and would put the ball in Fidel Castro's court.
The proposal indicates that some form of private or mixed ownership is a condition to be met before more normal relations.
An improved economic arrangement would benefit the Cuban people and could break the logjam in United States-Cuban relations. Under this policy, trade can be as open as Cuba wants it to be.
 
JOHN R. NASH
Smyrna, Ga., Feb. 25, 1996
