HEADLINE: Clinton Is Cool to Democrats' Ideas on Shielding U.S. Workers

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today gently flicked cold water on recent proposals by Congressional Democrats to change the tax laws in order to encourage business to treat workers better.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chief economic adviser at the White House, said at a daylong forum run by Senate Democrats, "The President believes that the best approach is to challenge companies to be good corporate citizens." 
 The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said, "The President wants to move forward" on measures he has proposed, like raising the minimum wage, protecting pensions, and making health insurance portable from job to job.
Complaints about layoffs and stagnant wages have been dramatized by Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate. But just as his party's leaders in Washington have snubbed his trade and immigration proposals as the wrong solutions when they already have the right economic answer in tax cuts, the Clinton Administration is brushing off the proposals offered by a variety of Democratic leaders in Congress.
The latest proposal came today from Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, head of a task force appointed by the Democratic Senate leader, Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota. He presented the forum with a plan to lower corporate taxes sharply for companies that provide their workers with pensions, education and training, health insurance and profit-sharing or stock purchase.
That is not all companies would have to do to qualify for the lower rates. Under Mr. Bingaman's plan corporations would also have to pay their bosses no more than 50 times as much as their lowest-paid worker, put at least half their new investment in research and development, keep 90 percent of new plant investment in the United States and maintain above-average or improving safety and environmental records.
When Dr. Tyson was asked specifically about the Bingaman proposal, she said she wanted to study all new ideas but felt that the Administration already had "a very ambitious legislative agenda." She cited the same wage, pension and insurance proposals Mr. McCurry was discussing with reporters at about the same time.
The plan got a slightly cheerier response from the last speaker at the forum in a Senate office building. Robert B. Reich, Secretary of Labor, said: "I think it's a very interesting proposal. It does have to be, obviously, analyzed and vetted like all proposals." Citing similar plans offered by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, Mr. Reich said, "There are a lot of interesting ideas out there that are the departure points for a conversation."
The Administration's reserved response came as no surprise to Congressional Democrats, who hope to build support in the nation first for their ideas. They think that if they do, the Administration will sooner or later follow the polls. After Dr. Tyson's presentation, Mr. Bingaman observed, "I don't think these ideas are going to go away."
Mr. Bingaman's plan, more detailed than those offered by other Democrats, would shift the basis of corporate taxation from income to a value-added basis, before establishing two rates, one for companies that look after their workers, and a higher one for those that do not. He also proposed a transfer tax on securities held for less than two years in order to encourage long-term investing and discourage short-range profit-seeking.
Both Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Gephardt have suggested reducing corporate income taxes for companies that do a series of things for their workers. Neither offered a list as detailed as Mr. Bingaman's.
But both were on hand today to cheer him on. Mr. Kennedy said Democrats hoped to put the issue "on the national agenda." Mr. Gephardt said he wished Congressional leaders and the President had spent as much time on this problem as they did on budget talks.
Mr. Daschle said, "The problem is very clear: as the stock market goes up, as the economy continues to grow, the realization is that a larger and larger percentage of working families are not experiencing the success of the economy over all."
Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota said corporate leaders would do well to start exercising "discipline and self-restraint" when it came to their own high salaries and other forms of compensation.

HEADLINE: Joseph Barr, 78, Bank Executive Who Held Several Federal Posts

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Joseph W. Barr, a former Treasury Secretary, Congressman and bank executive, died on Friday in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, where he was vacationing. He was 78 and lived in Hume, Va.
The cause was a heart attack, The Associated Press reported. 
 A Democrat, Mr. Barr began a decade of service in Washington in 1959, when he joined the House as a Representative from the 11th District of Indiana. He was defeated in his bid for re-election two years later, but remained in Washington as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Congressional Relations during the Kennedy Administration.
From 1963 to 1965 he was chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He then returned to the Treasury Department as Under Secretary.
In the fall of 1968, after the resignation of Henry W. Fowler as Treasury Secretary, President Lyndon B. Johnson nominated Mr. Barr to replace him. He served in that position from December 1968 until President Richard M. Nixon took office in January 1969.
During his Government career, Mr. Barr helped to build the Asian Development Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.
After leaving the Treasury Department, he joined the American Security and Trust Company, a leading Washington financial institution, as vice chairman. Later that year, he was named president, a post he held until 1972, when he became chairman.
He left American Security in 1974 after a dispute with fellow board members about the bank's strategy for long-term growth.
Later that year he served as head of the financially troubled Franklin National Bank of New York, but he left after some months when he determined that the bank's problems were beyond solution.
Born in Vincennes, Ind., on Jan. 17, 1918, Mr. Barr was educated at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and at Harvard University, where he earned a master's degree in theoretical economics.
After service in the Navy during World War II -- he earned a Bronze Star at the Anzio beachhead in Italy as commander of a submarine chaser -- he returned to Indiana to work in the family businesses, which included grain elevators, farm equipment financing and banking.
After leaving Franklin National, he retired to his farm in Hume.
Survivors include his wife of 57 years, the former Beth Ann Williston; a son, Joseph W., of Clifton, Va.; four daughters, Bonnie Gilliom of Atlanta, Cherry Ann Barr of Barnesville, Md., Elizabeth E. Stone of Hume and Lynn Barr of Ypsilanti, Mich.; a brother, John, of Champaign, Ill., and 17 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Solomon Asch Is Dead at 88; A Leading Social Psychologist

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Solomon E. Asch, a pioneering social psychologist who studied how peer pressure shapes human behavior but believed that most people act decently when they are not shackled by ignorance, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 88.
Dr. Asch had been an emeritus professor of psychology at the University of Pennsylvania since 1979 and professor there from 1972 to 1979. From 1966 to 1972, he was director of the Institute for Cognitive Studies at Rutgers University, where he held the title distinguished professor of psychology. 
 Dr. Asch's early experiments on compliance -- the effects of social pressure on one's perception and interpretation of the world, and on how one forms impressions of others -- are widely recognized as among the century's seminal studies in social psychology. His 1952 textbook, "Social Psychology," was reissued in 1987 by Oxford University Press.
In 1951, in a classic study of conformity, Dr. Asch asked students to participate in what he called "an experiment in perceptual judgment." Those taking part were asked to say which one of three lines on cards in front of them was the same length as a standard line, also on display.
Each time the experiment was run, one student heard the others choose a line obviously shorter or longer than the standard. Faced with unanimity among peers, the student would become uncomfortable and, about a third of the time, go along with them.
The uncomfortable student was actually the subject of the experiment, and those who chose lines shorter or longer than the standard were the professor's confederates.
In recounting that experiment, Dr. Asch told colleagues that the idea for it had grown out of his early childhood in Poland. As a boy of 7, he stayed up late for his first Passover night. He saw his grandmother pour an extra glass of wine and asked whom it was for.
For the prophet Elijah, an uncle told him.
"Will he really take a sip?" the boy asked.
"Oh, yes," the uncle replied. "You just watch when the time comes."
Filled with the sense of suggestion and expectation, the boy thought he saw the level of wine in the cup drop just a bit.
Early in World War II, when Hitler was at the height of his power, Dr. Asch, then a professor in Brooklyn College's psychology department, studied the effects of propaganda and indoctrination. Propaganda is most effective, he concluded, when fear and ignorance mix. "But the human mind," he added, is "an organ for the discovery of truths rather than of falsehoods."
Prof. Henry Gleitman of the University of Pennsylvania's psychology department said Dr. Asch was a man who understood better than most how individuals can do regrettable things in the desire to get along but who nonetheless thought that "people would behave humanely, morally, if appropriately informed."
Dr. Asch's early experiments in conformity formed much of the basis for studies of the depersonalizing aspects of modern American life, particularly big-city life. After Kitty Genovese was stabbed to death on a Queens street in 1964 while more than 30 of her neighbors ignored her cries for help, social psychologists conducted experiments in which they found that a person who was alone was more likely to come to the aid of a stranger in distress than was a person in the company of others.
Dr. Asch received numerous awards and fellowships, and was the author of dozens of books and articles. Yet he was disdainful of American academia's "publish or perish" ethos, recalled Prof. John Sabini, the chairman of the psychology department at the University of Pennsylvania. Professor Sabini said Dr. Asch had once asked, "Would it have made any difference if Thomas Aquinas had published five years later?"
Solomon Asch was born in Warsaw and came to the United States when he was about 13. He lived on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and learned English by reading Charles Dickens. He graduated from the City College of New York in 1928 and earned a master's degree from Columbia University in 1930 and his Ph.D. from Columbia in 1932.
Surviving are his wife of 65 years, Florence; a brother, Paul, of Los Angeles; two grandsons, Eric, of Scottsdale, Ariz., and David, of Silver Spring, Md.; a granddaughter, Laurie, of Silver Spring, and a great-grandson, Peter, of Silver Spring. Dr. Asch's son, Peter, a professor of economics at Rutgers, died in 1990.

HEADLINE: Castro's China Model

BYLINE: By Tad Szulc; Tad Szulc is author of "Fidel: A Critical Portrait."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For a year or so, President Fidel Castro has been relaxing Cuba's rigidly controlled economy, inviting foreign investment under highly favorable terms, visiting Europe and Latin America to woo political support and making life easier for the Roman Catholic Church. A few weeks ago, he released three political prisoners to a visiting member of Congress, who took them to Miami. It was beginning to look as if Mr. Castro, who is 69, was finally mellowing.
But on Saturday, his jets shot down two small unarmed civilian planes flown by members of Brothers to the Rescue, an anti-Castro group based in Miami, as they approached or entered Cuban air space. Earlier in the week, security services in Havana detained many leaders and members of Concilio Cubano, an umbrella organization of small opposition groups, which had planned to hold its first convention. 
 Are Mr. Castro's actions contradictory? No. They are wholly consistent with those of his 37-year reign. He is determined not to tolerate any challenge to his authority, internal or external, whatever the consequences. Mr. Castro evidently concluded that the seemingly harmless Concilio Cubano was a potential threat. And dangerous doubts about his grip on power could be raised if Brothers to the Rescue, which in the past has dropped anti-Castro leaflets on Havana, continued breaching the island's defenses.
Mr. Castro, who visited China in December for the first time, is increasingly applying what Cuban officials tell me is the "China model." In his view, China has come up with the perfect solution for the survival of a "socialist revolutionary" society: Create a market economy, with large-scale foreign investment, while brutally forbidding political freedom. Mr. Castro has often said he wants to avoid the mistakes of Mikhail Gorbachev, who he thinks brought about the collapse of the Soviet Union by permitting both economic reform and political liberalization.
Mr. Castro's two-track policy has apparently been successful. After hitting bottom in 1993, the economy has been reviving. The Government says that at the end of 1995 there were 212 agreements with foreign investors, who have pumped $2.1 billion into 34 areas of the economy, especially the tourism industry.
The punitive measures President Clinton has announced are virtually meaningless. Preventing Miami-Havana charter flights and suspending telephone connections will hurt Cubans on the island more than the regime, and the loss of revenue to Cuba will be negligible. President Clinton and Congress agreed yesterday on new sanctions that would hamper foreign investment. But this legislation is bound to anger our allies and would be hard to defend under international law.
Finally, Mr. Castro retains the "rafter" weapon. Last year, in response to exiles who hijacked Cuban coastal vessels, he let tens of thousands of Cubans leave on rafts and small boats -- until Washington agreed to prevent the hijackings. If the overflights by Brothers to the Rescue continue, Mr. Castro may pursue that strategy again.
President Clinton can try to penalize the Cuban leader, but he should understand that Mr. Castro is utterly inflexible. Realizing that he faces no real threat from the United States, Mr. Castro will continue to woo foreign investors and bar dissent.
In this election year, Mr. Clinton cannot be perceived as showing weakness. But there are no simple solutions in sight. Mr. Clinton must realize that, unfortunately, Mr. Castro has more leverage than he does.

HEADLINE: President Of Retailing Chains Quits

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In what many analysts say might signal a larger, imminent change in the Dayton Hudson Corporation's department-store unit, the company announced yesterday that the president of the unit had resigned.
Stephen E. Watson, 51, will be replaced by Linda L. Ahlers, 45, who has spent most of her career at the company. 
 Several analysts said that Mr. Watson might have felt that the future was uncertain for the division, which consists of 64 Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's stores, and that he might have chosen to leave before the unit was sold or spun off. Dayton Hudson's other units are Mervyn's off-price apparel stores, and Target, a fast-growing discount chain.
"He wanted out," said Kurt Barnard, editor of Barnard's Retail and Marketing Report. "This unit can't leverage its costs and productivity and no doubt it is nearing the end of its days. It will be divorced from the company."
Mr. Watson did not return calls seeking comment. Company executives have repeatedly denied that a sale of any division is in the offing.
The department store unit has had a poor showing for more than a year, with weak same-store sales as well as operating profits that declined last year to $158 million from $270 million in 1994. Further, the company is highly leveraged, with a debt-to-capitalization ratio of 62 percent. The industry average is closer to 50 percent. The company had said last month that it expected earnings for the fourth quarter, which ended in January, to fall 21 percent, to $3 a share, from $3.81 in the comparable period last year.
At the core of Dayton Hudson's weakness are the company's department stores, which Wall Street has urged the company to unload for some time. As the department-store business becomes increasingly consolidated, analysts argue that there is little room for small players that have neither economies of scale nor other competitive advantages to counter the move of giants like Federated Department Stores or the May Department Stores Company.
What the company should and may do, analysts say, is pare down to its best part: Target, the discount chain the country increasingly flocks to for contact lens solution, Dustbusters and sweat shirts.
"Wall Street has said it wants to own stand-alone retailers," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retail analyst at NatWest Securities, "not big conglomerates with questionable synergies."
Ms. Ahlers might be able to draw on the expertise she has picked up in various positions in the Target division and as executive vice president for merchandising at the department-store unit, her most recent job.
"My priority will be to continue to emphasize better merchandise," Ms. Ahlers said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Minneapolis. "It will be a repositioning back to our heritage as a fine department store."
But many on Wall Street seem to think the department-store unit cannot survive unless it gets a buyer.
"It has been a miserable year for them and I think that that had to take a toll at the top," Mr. Buchanan said. "Clearly, to the extent that she can't shore this thing up, the department-store division becomes even more of an acquisition target."
Dayton Hudson's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $74.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Stormy End Of Drought Is Unfolding In Nevada

BYLINE: By MIKE J. YBARRA 

DATELINE: RENO, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Water has always been scarce in Nevada, which gets six inches of rain in a good year. Not a single river crosses the whole state. The runoff from the Sierra Nevada piddles into two sizable lakes or evaporates in the desert.
The last eight years have marked the longest drought on record. Reno has undergone two years of water restrictions that have changed the face of this improbably leafy desert city: lawns have died, golf courses have browned. Instead of rushing through the heart of town, the Truckee River, which carries 80 percent of Reno's water from Lake Tahoe, is down to a trickle. 
 But the dry spell could be near an end. The Sierra snowpack, which supplies Lake Tahoe with most of its water, is more than 16 percent deeper than normal. Ten feet of snow has been dumped in the mountains above Reno over the last week alone. "And it's still snowing," exulted Mike Turnipseed, a state water engineer.
Last year, twice the normal amount of snow and rain fell in the mountains, enough to replenish the surface water lost over eight years but not underground water, like wells, whose levels have dropped as much as 25 feet.
With a month to go, the current rainy season has been a whopper, compared with the typical year. Lake Tahoe, where the water level had remained three feet below normal for several years, is now two feet above average. Last week, water had to be released from a reservoir atop the Carson River to prevent flooding. Even Las Vegas got a dusting of snow a few days ago.
Still, John James, the state climatologist and a geography professor at the University of Nevada in Reno, said he would not recommend to the Governor that the drought be declared officially over until after a snow survey on April 1, by which time the state is likely to have all the snow it is going to get.
Locally, Mr. James is famous as a pessimist. Residents joke that even Noah floating by would not convince him that the drought was over. "We have to be realistic," he countered in an interview. "We're in a desert."
That desert grew substantially during the last eight years of drought. Walker Lake dropped more than 25 feet, increasing its salinity so much that 90 percent of hatchling fish introduced during that period died. Officials expected the lake to become a dead zone. The river's normal flow is allocated to agricultural uses; the lake gets the leftovers, which until the recent storms had been nonexistent.
Pyramid Lake, the terminus of the Truckee River, has also been drying up, its level dropping 100 feet this century and threatening the survival of the cui-ui, a prehistoric fish that lives only there. The new, thick snowpack in the Sierra, while improving the situation, will not cure it, since Nevada is the nation's driest and fastest growing state.
Las Vegas, whose annual growth rate exceeds 10 percent, has the least rainfall in the nation but the highest per capita water consumption.
Water economy has been a latecomer to the region. Homes built in Reno before 1988 do not have water meters, and it was not until 1993 that a law required new residences to have low-flow showerheads.
The drought, for practically the first time since settlers began tapping into the Truckee almost 150 years ago, has led to the first water conservation measures in the history of the state. "It's really turned people to thinking, 'What should we do?' " Mr. James said. "It's been beneficial in that way at least."
Weather here, after all, is more often cruel than kind: in the last 125 years there have only been two consecutive wet years. "It's so ungodly unusual that you have to make book on the fact that next year will be a dry one," said Mr. James, who compared the last two winters to a jackpot on a slot machine. Sooner or later, he added, "Another drought is around the corner."

HEADLINE: Agency Votes To Start Talks On Lilco Plan

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 28

 BODY:
Determined to cut the highest electric bills in the continental United States, a state agency voted today to begin negotiations to replace the Long Island Lighting Company with a hybrid public-private system.
The plan's sponsor, Gov. George E. Pataki, immediately hailed the 13-to-2 vote by the agency, the Long Island Power Authority. "I'm convinced it's for real, and it's going to happen," Mr. Pataki said. "Long Islanders have suffered too long." 
 Lilco's chairman, William J. Catacosinos, who has criticized the plan, nevertheless called for "a cooperative dialogue" and said Lilco's goals were to lower rates and protect its employees, stockholders and the reliability of the Island's electric system. If talks with Lilco fail, James F. Gill, the authority's chairman, warned, the authority could start condemnation proceedings to seize it.
After a decade of failed attempts at taking over the troubled utility, there is a growing feeling among public officials and industry experts that this time is different.
"There's definitely a more concerted and realistic effort," said Steven I. Fleishman, vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds. But he cautioned that "these are going to be some very tough negotiations." Even a critic of the plan, Matthew T. Crosson, the president of the Long Island Association, a business group, said:
"We have some momentum going, and we shouldn't lose that. Let's get on with it."
The stakes are high and reach far beyond the 2.7 million people that Lilco serves in Nassau and Suffolk counties and in the Rockaways in Queens. For Governor Pataki, his re-election could hinge on Lilco's fate since Long Island voters provided much of his margin of victory last year.
"Certainly, the Governor has put his reputation on the line and pulled in his chits from Nassau and Suffolk," said Ashok Gupta, an energy economist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. A Republican consultant, speaking on the condition that he not be named, said, "We had the hand grenade of Lilco, and we passed it to the Governor."
Wall Street and the utility industry are also monitoring the takeover effort. Lilco would be the largest private utility eliminated by government, experts say, and the initial financing would require the biggest municipal bond sale in history, $4.5 billion, generating tens of millions of dollars in fees. An additional $2.25 billion would be financed later. Business leaders on Long Island, which was battered by the recession, say the revival of the Island's economy depends on relief from high utility rates.
But even if rates are cut by the 12 to 21 percent that proponents predict, frustrated Long Islanders are still likely to pay the highest or second highest electric rates in the country, outside of Hawaii. Lilco rates are double the national average. A typical bill for a Long Island home is about $100 a month.
Most of the projected savings comes from two bookkeeping maneuvers: refinancing Lilco's debt with tax-exempt bonds and avoiding Federal taxes on the public part of the proposed system.
The plan is complex, splitting Lilco into several entities, with the Power Authority running the distribution system. The approval process is fraught with hazards, requiring agreement not only from Lilco's 93,000 stockholders but also from a host of state and Federal agencies.
Although the proposal is a departure from past plans, the biggest difference is its unlikely sponsor -- Mr. Pataki, a conservative Republican who normally extols privatization, not government intervention.
As a candidate, he denounced Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's last Lilco takeover bid at the close of the 1994 campaign. Once in office, Mr. Pataki derided a revised plan from Richard M. Kessel, a Cuomo holdover on the Long Island Power Authority.
But now, Mr. Pataki has made the Lilco problem his problem. That move is both a political gamble and a necessity, given that his earliest backers were Long Island Republican leaders.
"He has always been good to Suffolk," said the county Republican chairman, John Powell, "and Suffolk has been good to him."
Under its plan, the Long Island Power Authority would assume $6.75 billion of Lilco debt, mostly for the never-opened Shoreham nuclear power plant. The authority would hire a company to run the electric lines and customer service.
Lilco would sell its gas operations, and its power plants would be divided among four or five companies. Keeping private ownership and adding competition allow Mr. Pataki to distinguish his plan from the Democratic versions he scorned.
When Mr. Gill, the authority's chairman, first estimated that the plan would cut electric rates at least 12 percent -- from refinancing debt and tax savings -- Long Islanders showed little enthusiasm. Then, he stressed that the ultimate savings could be 21 percent or more from efficiencies, savings from competition and a five-year rate freeze that, after inflation, would effectively be a cut.
Experts say there is little room for cost cutting. Lilco's transmission lines have limited capacity to import cheaper hydroelectric power. Its generators use gas and oil instead of cheaper coal. It pays the nation's highest property taxes and has a big debt because of Shoreham. And its large residential base requires an unusually big capacity to meet peak air-conditioning demand.
For three decades, electrical and political power have intertwined on Long Island. In the 1970's and 80's, protests rose against the Shoreham plant over its cost, which spiraled 20-fold, and its safety. In a court case, a jury found that Lilco had lied about Shoreham.
As anger at Lilco grew, it became a political whipping boy. Last year, the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, a Republican, ran for re-election with a commercial vowing that "I'll stop Lilco dead in its tracks." Democrats dreamed up a line on the ballot for the Ratepayers Against Lilco Party.
"Somebody once said you could use the Shoreham plant as a retirement residence for all the people who were either elected or defeated because of it," said Irving Like, a lawyer and longtime Lilco critic.
Lilco is the Island's biggest property taxpayer -- $308 million in 1994. But some of that reflected Suffolk's overassessments on the Shoreham plant. Lilco has begun winning refunds in court, and legal experts say the final amount could be $500 million.
Suffolk officials sought to resolve their tax problem through the Lilco takeover, with provisos canceling the refunds or stretching them over 30 years. But Nassau officials argued that their residents, who paid the excess taxes in their electric rates, deserved a faster rebate.
Last week, with the feud jeopardizing the Governor's plan, Mr. Pataki's aides summoned the two County Executives to the Governor's office to work out their differences.
Mr. Kessel, who opposes the Governor's plan and has one of his own, predicts many changes before an agreement is reached on a plan
"We are doing a takeover dance here, and everybody is trying to stake out a position," he said. "The bottom line is people want to know that if they put their English muffin in the toaster in the morning, it works -- and that their electric bill is not more than their mortgage payment."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against the Mark On Hopes for German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed against the German mark yesterday on growing hopes for another cut in German interest rates.
The mark also lost ground to the yen and higher-yielding European currencies like the Italian lira. 
 The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, cut rates in December to bolster the German economy. The Bundesbank's policy makers meet again today. While many traders have been betting that the central bank will hold rates steady, rates are expected to fall eventually.
"People are starting to refocus on the possibility of the Bundesbank cutting interest rates again, maybe not tomorrow but within the next few weeks," said Chris Iggo, an international economist at Chase Manhattan Bank.
A report in Bild, a German newspaper, also put pressure on the mark by drawing attention to Germany's weak labor market.
Rudolf Scharping, head of the Social Democrats, Germany's opposition party, was quoted as saying he had "reliable information" that unemployment would rise sharply in February.
The dollar's rise above 1.46 marks fueled the rally by setting off traders' previously set orders to buy.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4671 marks, up from 1.4521 marks on Tuesday. The dollar also rose to 104.53 Japanese yen from 104.35 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5338 from $1.5395.
The dollar was bolstered against the yen on the news that the United States trade deficit with Japan narrowed last year for the first annual decline in four years.
In addition, there was talk yesterday that the Bank of Japan was considering further buying of dollars for yen.
Traders estimated the Bank of Japan may have already spent $6 billion to $10 billion to defend the dollar since last week.
"The market is nervous about intervention," said Steve Barrow, an economist at the Chemical Bank in London.
Dollar strength also reflected mark losses against other currencies, particularly the yen.
Predictions for lower German rates contrast with the view that rock-bottom Japanese rates have nowhere to go but up. If the difference between German and Japanese rates should narrow, that would tend to make the yen more attractive to investors.
"You can maybe make the argument just based on short-term rate differentials that it's worth going the other way," said Kevin Weir, a vice president of institutional foreign exchange sales at the ABN-Amro Bank, referring to switching to yen from marks.

HEADLINE: New Leader For Kennedy Arts Center

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
James A. Johnson, a Minnesotan who has had successful careers in politics and business, has been selected as chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a Clinton Administration official said tonight.
The appointment is to be formally announced on Thursday. Mr. Johnson will succeed James D. Wolfensohn, who had intended to continue as the center's chairman after assuming the presidency of the World Bank last year but decided later that he could not do both jobs. 
 The job at the Kennedy Center, Washington's most visible performing arts showcase, will be Mr. Johnson's first major position in the arts. Mr. Wolfensohn had been chairman of Carnegie Hall.
Mr. Johnson, 52, is currently chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, a federally chartered but private company that markets mortgages.
A friend of Mr. Johnson's who spoke on the condition of anonymity said tonight that he would stay at Fannie Mae and make the Kennedy Center his principal outside activity.
In the past Mr. Johnson has been active in Democratic politics, having been chairman of Vice President Walter F. Mondale's unsuccessful campaign for President in 1984. He joined the Wall Street firm of Shearson Lehman Hutton as a managing partner after that election, and left active politics after taking the Fannie Mae job in 1990.
John Reilly, a Washington lawyer, said of Mr. Johnson at the time of his Fannie Mae appointment, "He's a spectacular manager, an anticipatory manager, a guy who thinks four steps ahead of everybody."
The Kennedy Center has been strapped for money in recent years. Besides trying to shore up its finances, Mr. Johnson will have to deal with criticism from some people in the Washington arts and in government that the center's artistic influence has declined in recent years.
Livingston L. Biddle, a Washington arts patron and former chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said that the center's founding chairman, Roger Stevens, "gave it an identity that was very special."
"Since then," Mr. Biddle said, "I think the Kennedy Center has not adhered to the same high standard that it had at the very beginning."
The Kennedy Center, now celebrating its 25th anniversary, has three main auditoriums -- the Opera House, Symphony Hall and Eisenhower Theater -- and is the home of both the Washington Opera and the National Symphony Orchestra. It also presents drama, music and dance by touring companies.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Chile has a good private pension plan, but would it work here?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AS goes Chile, so goes the world? While Chile's gross domestic product is smaller than Connecticut's, the born-again capitalist economy has a way of inspiring imitators. For along with having the fastest growth rate outside Asia, Chile is also the first to create a truly private social pension system. And the country's virtually painless transition from a bankrupt public pension system has policy wonks around the globe panting to learn the secret.
But the Chilean model probably will not travel as well as enthusiasts suggest -- at least not to the United States. While Chile's new social security system is working almost as well as advertised, the achievement has depended in part on circumstances that don't apply here. "They had a wide-open opportunity for a fresh start -- and we don't," said Lawrence White of the Stern School of Business at New York University. 
 Chile's half-century old "defined benefit" pension system collapsed under the weight of broken promises in 1981. "It was the first of its kind in the world and, by no coincidence, the first of its kind to collapse, said Karl Borden, an economist at the University of Nebraska and consultant to the libertarian Cato Institute.
Chile's free-market-minded dictatorship converted the system into a mandatory private savings plan in which pensions are largely determined by individual contributions and investment choices. Chilean workers must set aside 10 percent of their earnings in any of 21 private but heavily regulated pension plans. The two biggest, incidentally, are largely owned by Bankers Trust and Aetna Life and Casualty.
At retirement, the money can be used to buy a private annuity that pays a fixed monthly stipend. Alternatively, retirees can link their pensions to the continuing performance of their investment funds. Retirement is 65 for men and 60 for women. Chileans, however, are free to head for the beach earlier if they have accumulated enough to replace half their wages with an annuity.
The new system includes a safety net. Retirees and older workers caught in the transition from the bankrupt defined-benefit system are being paid their promised pensions from Government bonds that are amortized from general tax revenues. Moreover, the Government guarantees a subsistence income to everyone who has contributed to the new system for a total of 20 years if the investment funds do not perform well enough to cover the cost.
One problem here is the classic issue of defined-contribution pensions: individuals bear a lot of risk. But Olivia Mitchell, a professor at the Wharton School, points to the other side of this coin. "Governments," she said, "can always renege on their promises" to cover defined benefits -- and do once their unrealistic promises are exposed.
A more mundane but very real concern is the cost of managing the private pensions. Average fees collected by Chile's fund managers currently exceed 20 percent of annual contributions. "These numbers are way out of line with efficient pension fund management," said William Alpert, an economist at the University of Connecticut.
That said, it is hard to deny the Chilean system is thriving. For one thing, transition problems -- in particular, the need to cover underfunded defined-benefit pensions -- that might have been insurmountable in a democracy were solved with the stroke of a pen. For another, the ratio of taxpaying workers to retirees is almost three times as high as in the United States. "Chile has a very young population," which means that relatively large numbers of taxpayers are available to support those who reach old age in poverty, said Sylvester Schieber, an economist with Watson Wyatt pension consultants.
Last but hardly least, the private pension funds have benefited from the explosive performance of the local stock market. The returns to the pension funds' portfolios have averaged 13 percent in real terms -- roughly twice the rate of growth of the American stock market over the last 70 years. "The key element insuring the success of the system has been the profitability of the investments," Julio Bustamente, Chile's director of pensions, acknowledged.
It is easy to see why the Chilean pension system has become a model for Peru, Argentina, Bolivia and Mexico: all have young work forces to support retirees during the transition from pay-as-you-go finance. And all have immature capital markets begging for large, stable sources of domestic savings.
But none of this suggests that privatization of social security is a panacea for the United States -- where there are too few workers to support the retirement of the baby boomers, where promises to retirees exceed expected tax revenue by several trillion dollars and where government is seemingly always on the verge of gridlock. By contrast, Mr. Borden said, "all General Pinochet had to do was say is 'this is the way it is, fellas.' "

HEADLINE: Cuba's 2 Steps Back

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Feb. 28

 BODY:
To many, Cuba's decision to shoot down two civilian planes over the Straits of Florida last weekend came as a surprise, given President Fidel Castro's recent campaign to improve relations with the United States. But Mr. Castro has always lashed out at enemies, real or imagined, whenever he feels threatened, and he and his Government are feeling especially threatened these days.
For the first time, dissident and human rights groups opposed to his 37-year dictatorship are attempting to come together here as an umbrella coalition called the Cuban Council. That has heartened exile groups in Miami, which have formed a support group for the coalition. But it has left Mr. Castro, who has been without any real allies since the Soviet bloc began disintegrating in 1989, feeling he is more vulnerable than ever to both internal and external opposition groups.
"Fidel Castro has always been what you Americans call a control freak," said a Latin American diplomat here. "He saw a danger developing, one that was intolerable to him, and he moved to crush it, regardless of its international consequences, before it could cause him any further problems."
Even before Saturday's attack on the two airplanes, there were numerous indications that Mr. Castro was distressed with the direction events in Cuba were taking, and he was intent on halting that course. The campaign against dissident and human rights groups that began on Feb. 15 and has resulted in the arrest or detention of more than 50 people came after a crackdown on prostitution and efforts to inhibit private businesses, which in Mr. Castro's mind are all manifestations of the same social ill.
"Last year it was one step forward," a European diplomat here said recently, referring to a slight easing of political repression described as "improvement without reform" by the human rights group Americas Watch. "This year it's been two steps back."
Mr. Castro set the tone in a Dec. 26 speech in which he sharply criticized the limited economic liberalization his Government has been forced to undertake in recent years. That effort, he argued, has resulted in "the birth of a new social class" of entrepreneurs and free-thinkers, who have foreign contacts and support and who, by their very nature, do not need the Cuban state or the Communist Party to survive and thrive.
"There is a sector that is going to make itself immensely rich," Mr. Castro warned. "The more powerful it becomes, the greater will be its influence on society and the greater its challenge to socialism."
Mr. Castro watched and worried throughout the late 1980's as first the Soviet bloc in East Europe and then Communist rule in Moscow itself disintegrated. Ever since, he has been telling anyone who will listen that he does not intend to repeat the mistakes made by Mikhail Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader.
"Gorbachev seemed charismatic, and was very much applauded," Mr. Castro told an American delegation led by Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. during a meeting on Feb. 18. But at the same time, Mr. Castro has always argued, the Gorbachev years resulted in the destruction of the Soviet Union and the Communist Party.
If Mr. Castro has a model in mind, it is probably China, which he visited in December. During his 10 days there, he seemed impressed by the Communist Party's policy of combining a state-directed economic opening with unrelenting political repression.
"It is really admirable what they are doing," Mr. Castro said at the end of his trip. Since returning to Havana, he has praised Chinese leaders for maintaining political control, arguing that their approach is the only way to avoid the breakdown of a one-party system while assuring economic growth.
Recent European and Latin American visitors had repeatedly urged Mr. Castro to let the Cuban Council go ahead and hold the meeting it had announced for this month, arguing that he had nothing to lose. Some 130 human rights groups, professional organizations and nascent political parties are members of the newly formed organization, which has no clearly defined ideology and many contenders for leadership.
"It's silly," Wayne Smith, who was head of the American Interests Section here under Presidents Carter and Reagan and is now a critic of the embargo against Cuba, said of the crackdown. "These groups don't provide any threat, and Cuba could improve its image internationally by taking it easy on them."
The shooting down of two airplanes owned by Brothers to the Rescue occurred the same day that the Cuban Council was scheduled to hold its first meeting, and allowed Mr. Castro to link the council with exile groups and to portray both as controlled by American intelligence agencies.
Leaders of Cuban Council acknowledge that they had been contacted by Brothers to the Rescue and other Miami exile organizations, and that almost $4,000 had been collected on their behalf. But council leaders stressed that they were merely trying to exercise rights guaranteed them by the Cuban Constitution and that they are a nonviolent and democratic force independent of the United States.
Throughout his long stay in power, Mr. Castro has taken actions that transformed his domestic woes into confrontations with the United States.
Faced with discontent about economic and political conditions that exploded into a street protest in 1994, he manufactured the crisis that eventually forced the United States to end its 30-year policy of automatically treating all Cubans leaving the island as political refugees.
Cuban officials obviously knew that an attack on American-based civilian aircraft would bring about yet another crisis with the United States. Adm. Eugene Carroll of the Washington-based Center for Defense Information recalls a meeting with the Cuban Armed Forces high command earlier this month in which he was asked what would happen if Cuban MIG's shot down one of the exiles' aircraft.
"My answer was that it would be a political disaster, the people in the United States who claim we are not being tough enough on Cuba would seize on it as evidence we have to get tougher," Admiral Carroll, who was leading a delegation of retired American diplomats and soldiers, said.
But the Cuban officers reacted as if they were under siege by the United States, Admiral Carroll said, arguing that "moving the headquarters of the Southern Command from Panama to Miami indicates a greater focus on Cuba," and increased the likelihood "we will foment internal disorder, and use that as an excuse to invade."
Overall, Admiral Carroll said, the Cuban high command seemed to be "paranoid and highly suspicious."

HEADLINE: U.S. Delays New Financing of Companies' Trade With China

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Export-Import Bank has agreed to defer any new financing for American companies doing business in China for at least a month at the request of the Clinton Administration, which is weighing how to respond to evidence that China has shipped nuclear weapons-related technology to Pakistan.
Harry Phillips, a spokesman for the agency, said today that it had received the request from Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Tuesday and would honor it. 
 The bank, the export credit arm of the Government, has $10 billion in requests for loan guarantees and export credits awaiting approval for American corporations seeking to do business in China. Mr. Phillips said he could not put a dollar value on the projects that might be delayed.
The bank's action stops short of long-term economic sanctions and gives the Administration a month to seek assurances from China on limiting future shipments of nuclear technology.
"We have gone to the Chinese Government and suggested that the best way to clarify our concerns is for them to be forthcoming in addressing some of our specific questions," the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said today. "And that dialogue now with China will continue."
Another United States official said the Administration was "trying to get China to agree specifically not to make these sales and to abide by the terms of the nonproliferation treaty, which they have signed." The treaty seeks to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
The official said the bank's action "sends a message to China, puts a little pressure on them to come to terms."
The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that last year, China sold Pakistan 5,000 ring magnets to use in equipment that enriches uranium, a step vital to producing nuclear warheads.
The Nonproliferation Act of 1994 requires the President to suspend Export-Import Bank financing for trade with countries that sell nuclear weapons information and technology.
The ring magnets can be used to produce fuel for nuclear power plants as well as for weapons, and American officials say China has insisted that its shipments were for peaceful use.
The issue has posed a quandary for the Clinton Administration. The President has made nuclear nonproliferation a cornerstone of his foreign policy. At the same time, the Administration is loath to see its prickly relationship with China deteriorate further or to punish American businesses eager to get a foothold in China's fast-growing market.
Tensions have also been aggravated by China's belligerent military and political maneuvers aimed at influencing the presidential election next month in Taiwan.
And the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, has been considering tariffs against imports of Chinese goods unless Beijing cracks down on the piracy of intellectual property like computer software, video recordings and compact disks.
The Administration has yet to make an official finding that China is in violation of the nuclear treaty. Administration officials said that over the next month, they will be seeking more information from China to support its case.
At the same time, the Administration will push for commitments from China to forswear future technology transfers related to nuclear arms.
With such a promise in hand, the President would be on stronger ground if he chose to impose sanctions against China for the shipments but then waive them on grounds of national interest.
"It would be an easier decision politically if one could say one got something on the nonproliferation side," said Stanley O. Roth, who was in charge of Asia policy at the National Security Council until he left the Government last month.
It is not clear to what extent the one-month suspension of credits will affect American businesses. Mr. Phillips said the bank generally took 20 to 25 applications for loans or credits related to China each month.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Tolls to Rise 17% For Bridges and Tunnels

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
The price of driving from one borough to another is to rise on March 24, with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board vote yesterday to raise the tolls on its major bridges and tunnels to $3.50 each way, from $3.00.
At the same meeting, the board also approved a five-year contract that will pay Lawrence G. Reuter, who will be the new Transit Authority president, $165,000 a year, a salary equal to the Mayor's and the highest ever paid an M.T.A. official. 
 Increases in the bridge and tunnel tolls have been expected since August, when E. Virgil Conway, the M.T.A. chairman, proposed a long-range financial plan that included higher tolls and fare increases for the subway, bus and commuter rail networks, in part to make up for declining city, state and Federal subsidies. The subway and bus fare rose 20 percent, to $1.50, and commuter rail fares rose 9 percent on Nov. 12; the toll increase is 17 percent.
The bridges and tunnels are the only part of the transit system that turns a profit -- $568 million last year -- and that money is used to support other arms of the M.T.A. Under a formula set by state law, 52 percent of the surplus goes to the Transit Authority, and 48 percent to Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road.
The board voted 8 to 4 for the increase in bridge and tunnel tolls, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's four appointees dissenting in protest of the division of the toll surplus. Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson said that two-thirds of the people who pay the bridge and tunnel tolls are city residents, so two-thirds of the profit should go to the city transit system. That would mean about $100 million more for the Transit Authority.
"New York City residents are subsidizing commuter railroads outside the City of New York," he said, though he acknowledged that the formula was unlikely to change because "the suburban legislators like it just the way it is."
Mr. Conway, who was appointed last year by Gov. George E. Pataki, a former state legislator from Metro-North territory, has said he will not lobby for a change in the law.
While tolls in general will rise, the rates paid by Staten Island residents who use the Verrazano-Narrows bridge will fall, a change endorsed even by the Giuliani representatives on the board. For islanders who use the E-Z Pass, the windshield sticker that pays the toll electronically without a car's having to stop, the discount rate on the bridge will fall from $4 to $3.20 round-trip. On the Verrazano, unlike the other M.T.A. crossings, a toll is collected only westbound, at the round-trip rate.
M.T.A. officials said that the sale of discount tokens for the crossings would continue, but, citing a need to deter hoarding, they refused to say whether new tokens would be issued.
Critics of the M.T.A., whose board is made up mostly of appointees of the Republican Governor and Mayor, contend that the discount for Staten Islanders is nothing but favoritism for the most heavily Republican of the city's five boroughs.
"It is an amazing political sleight-of-hand to have in the same financial package a fare increase and toll increases for everyone else, but giving Staten Islanders a discount," said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' group.
Transportation planners and environmentalists also contend that the Staten Islanders' discount creates congestion. "The people who use E-Z Pass are the regular commuters, who tend to travel in the peak hours," said Jeffrey Zupan, a consultant to the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that advises government on development. "This is encouraging them to do that, when what you're supposed to do is encourage people to travel off-peak."
The $3.50 toll each way will apply to the Verrazano, Bronx-Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Triborough bridges, and the Queens-Midtown and Brooklyn-Battery tunnels. The toll will rise to $1.75 each way from $1.50 on the Henry Hudson, Marine Parkway and Cross Bay bridges.
Mr. Reuter, 45, who heads the Washington transit system and is to take over at the Transit Authority on March 11, is to be paid $165,000 a year to run the nation's largest transit system, plus a housing allowance of $3,500 a month.
Alan F. Kiepper, who is retiring as president, gets $149,500 a year and a $3,000-a-month housing allowance.
When adjusted for inflation, the salary has declined somewhat in recent years. Mr. Kiepper's pay did not change in his more than five years in the job, and his predecessor, David L. Gunn, was paid $140,000 a year from 1984 to 1990.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Slow Demand At Auction Erases Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were mixed yesterday despite data that pointed to continued moderate inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 93 26/32, for a yield of 6.47 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. The price of the two-year note declined 5/32, to 99 18/32, pushing its yield up 10 basis points, to 5.36 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Treasury securities with intermediate and long-term maturities gave back their earlier gains yesterday after the results of the Treasury's auction of new five-year notes were released, an indication that demand was lukewarm, market analysts said. The Government sold $12 billion of new five-year notes at a yield of 5.680 percent, up from 5.360 percent last month and the highest since 5.810 percent on Oct. 25, 1995. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Earlier, the Treasury also sold $6 billion in 13-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.06 percent. Cash management bills are sold to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the scheduled auctions.
Today, the Treasury plans to sell $18.75 billion of new one-year bills, which at the close of the New York market had a rate of 4.93 percent.
Yesterday's economic reports suggested to some market participants that with inflation in check, the Federal Reserve would continue to ease short-term rates to help stimulate the economy.
In the eyes of some market participants, the Fed's flexibility was only slightly damaged by a report showing a stronger-than-expected rise in consumer prices. The Labor Department said consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, or three-tenths of 1 percent excluding the index's food and energy components. But many investors and economists discounted the increase because of an unexplainable rise in apparel prices, a seasonal spike in the cost of resort lodging and some statistical peculiarities.
"The numbers were consistent with a good inflation trend, and while they may not be as good as the 2.5 percent in 1995, under 3 percent is still pretty good," said Joseph LaVorgna, an economist with Lehman Brothers.
The Commerce Department's December inventories report posted the first decline since March 1994. Inventories fell a surprising half of 1 percent and sales during that period rose 1 percent.
In another report, the National Association of Realtors said home resales dropped 4.1 percent in January, more than economists expected.
With more data still due this week, like the Chicago Purchasing Managers and National Purchasing Management reports, weekly jobless claims and auto sales, few investors were willing to commit themselves yesterday without more proof, so the buying subsided late in the afternoon.
Still, a number of market participants are counting on another cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Paul A. McCulley, chief economist at UBS Securities, said the market two weeks ago priced in a Federal funds rate, or an overnight bank lending rate, of 4.50 percent, with expectations for cuts of a further 75 basis points by September. Such a cut was considered to be a "done deal, but last week Fed chairman Alan Greenspan said it wasn't," Mr. McCulley said, adding, "So now the market has spent the last week readjusting to the actual Fed fund rate of 5.25 percent."

HEADLINE: A Cultural Reluctance To Spare the Rod;
Newcomers Say Americans Spoil Children

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
The immigrant mothers sat along the edges of Brooklyn playgrounds and talked about two methods of discipline: the American way, and the way they brought with them from their homelands.
American parents, they say, give a young child a timeout or ground an older one, then may even feel guilty about it. The immigrant parents believe sterner is better, they say. They would slap a fresh mouth, spank a disrespectful child or beat one who dared to lie or skip school. 
 But that approach requires them to walk a fine line. If they administered the kind of lickings they endured while growing up in the islands, they say, they might lose their own children to foster care, or even face arrest.
"The first thing a child learns here, 'If you spank me, I'll call 911,' " said Emma Henderson, a mother of three who grew up in Dominica. "There's something wrong about it."
At a time city planners estimate that more than half of New York City's population is made up of immigrants and their children, one of the central cultural clashes is about where spanking ends and child abuse begins. Many immigrants, from cabdrivers to baby sitters to schoolteachers, say Americans spoil their children by sparing the rod. The police and child protection workers are too quick to cry abuse, they say.
The child protection system, with many social workers who are themselves immigrants, has not had an easy time resolving some cultural differences. Critics say that too often, caseworkers judge excessive punishment as acceptable, and have called for better training for agency workers.
These issues have come to the fore in two recent child welfare cases, with the arrest of a Nigerian immigrant charged with assaulting his son, who was found with a broken wrist, and of a Cambodian immigrant couple that the authorities said beat their disobedient daughter with a plastic curtain rod.
The Nigerian father, Shakiru Adebayo, told the police he was following the disciplinary ways of his country. The city caseworker who investigated an earlier abuse report on the family had decided the beatings of the boy were signs not of abuse, but of the father's cultural beliefs, school officials said.
But Olikoye Ransome-Kuti, a pediatrician who was Minister of Health in Nigeria from 1985 to 1993, said last week that Mr. Adebayo, if guilty of the charges, had crossed the line into brutality even in the context of his own culture. Breaking a child's wrist is "clearly beyond the pale," said Dr. Ransome-Kuti, now a consultant to the World Bank in Washington.
In New York City, city officials concede, the city has done a poor job in recent years of training the new workers to make complex judgment calls about when a child is being abused.
In a confidential November 1995 memo, Gene D. Skarin, associate general counsel of the city's Human Resources Administration, voiced alarm about caseworkers who have lived in the United States only a few years and see "excessive corporal punishment being an acceptable form of discipline."
Immigrants who think that hitting is the best way to teach children to be respectful and studious are running into a contrary view, held by many doctors, psychiatrists and social workers, that physical discipline can deaden a child's spirit and lead to violence later in life.
That view, along with a growing awareness of child abuse, has contributed to an evolving definition in the United States of what constitutes excessive corporal punishment, which is against the law. In many parts of the country, and in New York in previous decades, for example, principals routinely paddled the mischievous. But for more than 30 years, corporal punishment has been forbidden in New York City schools.
Immigration experts say the issue is a highly charged one for many people locating in the New York metropolitan area from all over the globe: Nigerians, West Indians, Dominicans, Mexicans, Eastern Europeans and Russians, among others.
Often, the parents have come to America for the sake of their children, only to feel they are losing them to the rebellious ways of American youth. Separated from the extended family members and neighbors who had helped keep children in line back home, and separated from their children by the long hours they put in at work, panicky immigrant parents may rely more on harsh discipline, experts say.
Mary C. Waters, a Harvard University sociologist who interviewed West Indian immigrants and their children in New York City from 1991 to 1993, said corporal punishment was the central issue for them.
"When I asked what's different about the United States," she said, "they said: 'The state comes between you and your children. Americans don't discipline their children well, and when you do it the right way, there's the danger your kids can call social services on you.'
"They were at a loss as to how to discipline your child if you couldn't hit them. It cut across class lines."
Una Clarke, a Jamaican-born City Council member from Queens, said that immigrants must learn new ways to discipline their children as part of their adaptation to American culture. When she worked for the city supervising day care centers, Ms. Clarke said, she tried to teach parents, for example, that they can tell children they will not get a new pair of sneakers until they behave.
"Many families saw that as bribery," she said. "You have to tell them it's a reward for appropriate behavior. Clearly, there is a clash of values. But the law of this country has to be one law."
The conflict between West Indian parents and children is intensified by the particular pattern of their migration, in which the mother typically arrives first, with her children following years later, often as teen-agers. Parents then discipline children who are resentful at having been left behind, and who in some cases may not know their parents well.
"The kids all knew they could call D.S.S. on their parents," Professor Waters said. "When new kids arrived from the West Indies, that was one of the first things they'd tell each other. They saw it as a lever to use against their parents. They could threaten this and maybe reduce the beating they were going to get."
George Mathelier, a Haitian immigrant, said he sees the power struggle between immigrant parents and children taking place at Prospect Heights High School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where he is a social worker. The Caribbean children who were used to beatings in their schools in the islands "quickly realize the system here is lax and loose and they can get away with murder."
He described the case of a 14-year-old Haitian who had been neglecting his homework and taking money from his parents. His father, a cabdriver, gave him a beating and the son called 911. The father was arrested and taken away in handcuffs. The case was resolved with a court recommendation of family counseling. The father pretended he was no longer angry, Mr. Mathelier said.
Next summer, the family went to Haiti on vacation. At the airport there, the father pulled out a leather strap and whipped his son on the spot. Two days later, the family flew back to New York, leaving the teen-ager in Haiti with relatives.
The clash of cultures is especially acute for the thousands of immigrant women who work as baby sitters, often 50 or more hours a week caring for the children of upper-middle-class professionals. Daily they come face to face with two opposing attitudes toward discipline.
Barbara Solomon, who was a schoolteacher in Tobago, took a job as a baby sitter when she first immigrated two years ago. One day, the 4-year-old girl in her care came in from school and dropped her coat and lunch bag on the floor.
"I told her to take it up," Ms. Solomon said. "She started screaming and throwing a tantrum. I thought, 'If she was my 4-year-old, I would have slapped her.' Her brother picked up for her. She told me her mom did not allow her to put her things away. I believe in children learning to pick up after themselves."
Ms. Solomon, who now works 12-hour shifts seven nights a week caring for an elderly person and spends another 20 hours a week in college studying tourism, said her four children have not challenged her right to discipline them. She said she tells them that if she cannot punish them here she will take them home to do it, an effective threat since they love living in the United States.
"Beating or flogging a child was the parents' way of getting them to conform," she said. "It's because we love them that we use it."
Like many other West Indian parents, Ms. Solomon said she understood the difference between discipline and abuse. She said she was careful not to bruise her children or hit them so hard their skin swells. She said she always explained the reason for the spanking.
"If I cannot beat them and they get out there, the police will shoot them when they do wrong," she said. "I love my children more than the system loves them."
The immigrant mothers in Brooklyn talked of their own mothers' pelting them with whatever came to hand, a bar of soap, a cup, a pot spoon; or whipping them with a broomstick, a shoe or a switch.
Ingrid Neverson, a 24-year-old from St. Vincent, who works a a baby sitter, vividly remembered the time she told her grandmother she was going to the library to study, but instead went to the beach. Her uncle spotted her and called the grandmother.
When Ms. Neverson got home, her grandmother found her wet bathing suit, took the 15-year-old Ms. Neverson to the bedroom and gave her a beating that left welts all over her back. "It was long," she said. "It was painful."
At the time, Ms. Neverson tried to move in with her father or her grandfather, but both backed up her grandmother. Now, she said, she thinks that her grandmother did the right thing.
As the 2-year-old boy she looks after tugged affectionately on her hand at a playground in Prospect Park, Ms. Neverson seemed shocked when asked if she had ever slapped him. She said the boy is well disciplined and that she would never hit him. When asked what she would do when she has children of her own, she replied:
"I would spank my kids. Those are my kids. I would discipline them how I see fit."

HEADLINE: Computer-Guided Selling Sends Dow Sharply Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The broad stock market ended mixed yesterday, but late computer-guided selling programs sent the Dow Jones industrial average sharply lower, erasing early gains.
The Dow lost 43 points, closing at 5,506.21, after giving up a morning gain of more than 30 points. 
 But the broad market did not perform nearly so poorly. Advancing issues barely led decliners on the New York Stock Exchange, rising to 1,234 against declines of 1,123. Big Board volume was heavy yesterday at 447.8 million shares at the close..
The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.38, to 1,107.55, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index added 2.80, to 566.66.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 2.49, to 644.75, and the New York Stock Echange's composite index fell 0.97, to 344.62.
Blue-chip stocks tracked bonds. The long Treasury bond rose about a half-point in the morning, despite robust economic reports, but dipped in the afternoon on a weak Treasury auction of five-year notes. The 30-year Treasury bond was up 1/32 point near the close, yielding 6.47 percent.
Stocks "held up as long as they could" in the face of contracting bond prices, but finally dropped into negative territory late in the session, said Leon Brand, a global technical analyst at NatWest Securities.
The Labor Department said consumer prices shot up four-tenths of 1 percent in January. Economists had expected a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department said business inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent in December, while sales rose 1 percent. That suggested to investors that manufacturers might increase production to replenish inventories, which could produce a potentially inflationary increase in economic activity.
Sales of existing homes fell 4.1 percent in January, which the National Association of Realtors attributed to winter blizzards and consumer unease.
Bob Dickey, managing director and technical analyst at Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis, said the market was reacting to two major crosscurrents.
In one corner are "folks who are seeing risk of higher rates and potentially a slowdown in the economy," Dickey said. "Those are the people taking profits right now.
At odds with them are money managers who continue to receive heavy cash inflows from investors. The money managers have to put that money to work for their customers by buying stocks, and the buying has kept stock prices up, Mr. Dickey said.
On Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute, a mutual-fund trade organization, said investors poured a record $29 billion into stock mutual funds in January, eclipsing earlier estimates and almost tripling the previous January record, set in 1994, of $10.5 billion.
AT&T finished unchanged at 64 after strong morning gains. The company said Tuesday that it would offer free Internet access on a limited basis.
But AT&T's announcement pushed down the stocks of companies that charge for Internet access. America Online fell 1 3/4, to 47 3/8; Netcom fell 2 3/8, to 20 3/8, and Uunet Technologies Inc. skidded 3 3/8, to 28 5/8.
Bear, Stearns & Company downgraded Netcom and Uunet to neutral from attractive, citing competition from AT&T.
Banking and other financially sensitive stocks rose in the morning as interest rates fell, and for the most part hung on to their gains into the close. Citicorp finished up 5/8 at 78 1/4.
The Dow industrials were led lower by a wide selection of both economically sensitive and recession-resistant names.
Eastman Kodak fell 3/4, to 71 1/2; Caterpillar fell 1 5/8, to 67 3/4; General Electric lost 1 5/8, to 76 1/8; Chevron slipped 1 1/4, to 54 1/2;, Du Pont dropped 1 3/8, to 77 3/4, and I.B.M. skidded 1 3/8, to 127 3/8.
Chrysler, another Dow component, rose 1 1/2, to 56 3/4, after Furman Selz upgraded the stock to buy from hold, pushing other auto stocks up with it. Ford Motor rose 1/4, to 31 1/2, and General Motors climbed 1/8, to 51 5/8.
