HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
Divided Verdicts From the Early Primaries Are Raising the Stakes for the Next Batch

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Just days after his candidacy was written off by his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, Steve Forbes found himself back at the center of attention today after his relentless championing of a flat-tax proposal finally paid off with a victory on Tuesday in the Arizona primary.
Mr. Forbes defeated Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, whose campaign pollster only a few days earlier had been predicting victory in Arizona. But Mr. Dole easily won in both North Dakota and South Dakota, marking the Senate majority leader's first statewide primary victories since winning the Iowa caucuses earlier this month. 
 Patrick J. Buchanan, who had been enjoying the status of surprise front-runner since his victory in New Hampshire, finished third in Arizona and North Dakota, and second in South Dakota.
The divided verdicts raised the stakes in the already hotly contested South Carolina primary on Saturday, which stands as a gateway to eight contests three days later, including a set of primaries in New England.
The turn to the South, where the trailing candidate, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, is counting on a resuscitation of his own fortunes, also brought a marked change in the candidates' dialogue. Today there was a far greater emphasis on social and trade issues that did not register with voters in Arizona.
Although Senator Dole won in the Dakotas, the most significant contest was here in Arizona, with the largest total, thus far, of 39 delegates.
Polling of voters as they left the ballot boxes showed that Mr. Buchanan hung onto the core of disaffected Republicans and staunch conservatives who vaulted him to victory in New Hampshire and jolted the Dole campaign.
But Mr. Forbes was rewarded by voters who put taxes at the top of their agenda and responded well to his calls for a flat tax to replace the current income tax system, a proposal that had failed to catch on in the earlier nominating contests.
After his victory in the Delaware primary on Saturday, Mr. Forbes has sprung back to the top tier of contenders -- and he has the most delegates to his party's national convention. Of the 996 delegates needed for nomination, Mr. Forbes is leading with 57 delegates, followed by Mr. Buchanan, 31; Mr. Dole, 27, and Mr. Alexander, 5.
But in keeping with the way this campaign has produced an ever-shifting lineup of top contenders, that only served to make Mr. Forbes, the publishing magnate, the target of fresh criticism from Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Dole. Both candidates had essentially ignored Mr. Forbes after his fourth-place finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire.
Mr. Buchanan, who said he miscalculated by not taking on Mr. Forbes in Arizona, called him a social liberal whose views would not play well in the South.
"His position on the social issues, once exposed, is basically Clintonism," the conservative commentator said of Mr. Forbes. "And of course we're going to point this out. We're going to have to clearly differentiate our positions from Forbes better than we did in Arizona."
Mr. Dole attributed his loss in Arizona's first primary to the fact that Mr. Forbes dipped into his personal fortune to saturate the state with millions of dollars of television commercials.
"Forbes spent $4 million -- that's what happened," the Senator said rather testily late Tuesday night. "We spent $860,000. We can't match that kind of spending."
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, blamed the campaign's since-dismissed pollster for assuring him that Mr. Dole would win easily in Arizona. He conceded that the Senator probably should have campaigned longer in the state.
Citing Mr. Dole's obligations as Senate majority leader, Mr. Reed added, "We have been playing catch-up ball for the last two or three weeks in some of those states."
For his part, Mr. Forbes took the attacks in stride, asserting that his victory here spoke to the power of his message.
"I think it's wide open," he said. While he played down South Carolina, where he has done little campaigning, Mr. Forbes said he was looking to a face-off in New York, where only he and Mr. Dole will be on all the ballots.
The balloting burst Mr. Buchanan's hot streak, despite his aggressive campaigning in Arizona.
But Tuesday's voting was even more troubling for Mr. Alexander, who had tried to present his third-place finishes in New Hampshire and Iowa as evidence that he was the obvious alternative to Mr. Dole. By the reckoning of his own advisers, Mr. Alexander sorely needs to do well in South Carolina.
The former Tennessee Governor faces a practical problem: If he does not win at least 10 percent of the vote in South Carolina, he will lose his eligibility for Federal matching subsidies. Federal Election Commission rules require a candidate to capture at least 10 percent of the vote in two consecutive primaries to get the money. Mr. Alexander failed to meet that threshold on Tuesday.
The three major television networks, CNN and The Associated Press, which surveyed voters as they left the polls in Arizona, found that Mr. Forbes was bolstered here by his signature issue, the flat tax, which was more popular than it had been in New Hampshire.
While New Hampshire voters said their biggest concern was the economy and jobs, voters in Arizona placed taxes as the most important.
Among the 27 percent of the voters surveyed who cited taxes as the overriding issue, nearly 7 out of 10 voted for Mr. Forbes. Six out of 10 said they preferred the flat tax to a graduated one, and 42 percent of those votes went to Mr. Forbes.
Mr. Forbes also performed well with the independent voters that Mr. Buchanan has courted. Fourteen percent of the primary voters described themselves as independents, and 41 percent of them backed Mr. Forbes. And he took half the votes of people who said they backed Ross Perot's independent bid for the Presidency in 1992, compared with 29 percent for Mr. Buchanan and 15 percent for Mr. Dole.
But the danger for Mr. Forbes is that he is still widely viewed as a single-issue candidate, and the tax issue, while a winner in a state like Arizona, might not play as well in the South.
The poll had some good news for Mr. Dole: After voters in Iowa and New Hampshire said he was a weak representative of conservative views, voters here said otherwise. Nineteen percent said a candidate's ability to represent conservative thinking mattered most to them; of those, 32 percent backed Mr. Dole and 35 percent favored Mr. Buchanan.
But as long as Mr. Forbes and Mr. Alexander stay in the race, Mr. Dole will lose votes to them and have a hard time staving off Mr. Buchanan. In Arizona, people who voted for Mr. Alexander and Mr. Forbes said their second choice would have been Mr. Dole. Mr. Buchanan's supporters, however, said their second choice would have been Mr. Forbes.
As was the case in Iowa and New Hampshire, Mr. Dole, who is 72, is still hampered by his age; a third of the voters here said his age would hinder his ability to be an effective President.
While Mr. Buchanan had a poor showing on Tuesday, the survey of voters shows that he stood out when voters considered personal qualities rather than issues.
Twenty-one percent of the voters here said their vote was largely determined by a candidate's ability to stand up for his beliefs. Mr. Buchanan overwhelmed his rivals on this score, as he did in New Hampshire. Seventy percent of the voters here who acknowledged they wanted a candidate with backbone supported Mr. Buchanan, while Mr. Forbes and Mr. Dole won 12 percent each.

HEADLINE: In a First, 2000 Census Is to Use Sampling

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
To cut costs and improve accuracy, the Census Bureau said today that it would actually count only 90 percent of the United States population in 2000 and rely on statistical sampling methods to determine the number remaining.
The plans, announced at the Commerce Department, mean that for the first time the official tally of the American population, done every 10 years and used to apportion seats in the House of Representatives, will be based in part on a scientifically determined estimate rather than the actual head count conducted through a mass direct-mail campaign. 
 Census Bureau officials say the revised method is needed to keep costs down and to avoid a repeat of the 1990 census, which missed record numbers of people that had been traditionally hard to count, mainly members of ethnic and racial minorities.
"What we intend to do to meet our twin goals of reducing costs and increasing accuracy is to make a much greater use of widely accepted scientific statistical methods, and sampling is first and foremost among them," said Martha Farnsworth Riche, the Census Bureau Director.
Scientific sampling, commonly associated with public opinion polls, involves questioning a selected group of people and using the information derived from them to count or describe a much larger group. The Census Bureau has used sampling for years to determine national characteristics like the poverty and unemployment rates. But it has never used this method to determine the official population.
In 1990, the Government refused to adjust the census results to correct an acknowledged undercount of some four million people, mostly black and Hispanic residents of large cities. That refusal prompted a lawsuit by a coalition of big cities, led by New York. The case is pending before the Supreme Court.
Critics of the bureau's use of sampling argue that is is unconstitutional because the Constitution calls for an "actual enumeration." But decisions in lower Federal courts have approved the use of sampling as long as it supplements, and does not supplant, an actual count.
Census Bureau officials say sampling is needed because of the increasing number of people who fail to return their mail-in census forms. In 1990 only 63 percent of American households sent the form back, compared with 85 percent that did so in 1970, the first year the census was conducted by mail.
The Census Bureau has to send temporary enumerators to households that do not return the forms, sharply increasing the cost.
Officials say that in the 2000 census, mail-in forms and enumerators will be used until 90 percent of the households in a county have been counted. Then a statistical sample of 10 percent of the remaining households will be selected, and enumerators will be dispatched, repeatedly if necessary, to count them. The results will be used to estimate the total number of those who were originally missed.
"Better to hound one in 10 than 10 in 10," said Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, who oversees the Census Bureau.
The bureau also plans to simply its forms, reducing the number of questions to about eight on the short form, down from 17 in 1990, and 55 on the long form, down from 59. The long form is sent to about one in every six households, and contains questions that provide a wealth of data for demographers, social scientists, marketers and governments.
In addition to mailing the forms, the bureau for the first time will allow people to pick them up at government buildings like libraries and police stations, as well as community centers and convenience stores. The bureau will set up a toll-free telephone number to allow people to call in their responses, and is also trying to determine if there is a way people can respond via the Internet and still keep the responses confidential.
Officials also plan to use new technology, including digital maps of every structure on every block in the country that will insure that the bureau does not overlook buildings.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AGREES TO TOUGH NEW SET OF CURBS ON CUBA

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Driven largely by the downing of two civilian American planes by the Cuban military, Congressional negotiators and the White House agreed today on a package of sanctions intended to punish Fidel Castro by curbing foreign investment in Cuba.
The measure, which President Clinton had opposed until this week, would give the weight of law to the nearly 40-year-old embargo against Cuba that has been the policy of every American President since Mr. Castro came to power. That would prevent any President from acting on his own, as Mr. Clinton and others have in the past, to loosen or tighten sanctions as relations with Cuba change. 
 But the package, the most tangible reaction yet to the downing of the planes last Saturday, also includes more potent provisions that supporters said would deter foreign investment in Cuba and thus hasten the downfall of an ailing regime.
One provision would deny visas to anyone -- corporate officer, principal, controlling shareholder -- with a stake in a property confiscated in the 1959 Cuban revolution from someone who is now a United States citizen. A senior Administration official saidbillions of dollars' worth of property now controlled by foreign companies in Cuba could be affected.
"I don't expect our allies will be pleased with this legislation, but we believe it advances an important part of our foreign policy," the official said.
Another provision would allow American citizens whose property was confiscated by the Castro Government to file suit in the United States against any foreign company using that property. But in a concession to win the support of the Administration, it would give the President the right to waive that rule every six months to keep the courts from being choked with lawsuits.
No other nation observes the United States embargo on Cuba. Canadian, Mexican and French companies, among others, have sizable investments there. Canada, for example, imports about $225 million of Cuban goods a year and sends Cuba about $160 million worth of Canadian goods. Canada is expected to challenge the policy under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 Only last summer, Secretary of State Warren Christopher recommended that Mr. Clinton veto this bill. But Cuba's downing of the planes, which had taken off from Florida, put enormous political pressure on the President to act decisively. Mr. Clinton only narrowly lost Florida to George Bush in 1992, and the state is considered a key battleground in this election year.
On Monday, President Clinton imposed limited sanctions against the Cuban Government, closing off charter air routes, restricting the movements of Cuban diplomats in the United States and expanding the broadcasting range of Radio Marti, the Government-supported anti-Castro radio station.
But Mr. Clinton's actions were roundly criticized as weak and ineffective by some Cuban-American leaders, by Congressional Republicans and by nearly all of the Republican Presidential contenders. And when Congress reconvened on Tuesday after a nearly monthlong recess, supporters of the stronger bill moved immediately to revive it.
Most of the corporate giants in the United States, as well as the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Association of Exporters and Importers, oppose the measure.
"What we hear from the C.E.O.'s is they feel the legislation will make it impossible for U.S. companies to develop a position within the Cuban market, while providing more opportunities for companies in other countries," said John S. Kavulick, president of the United States-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, which represents more than 100 companies.
Other officials said the maker of Bacardi rum, which had vast holdings in Cuba before the revolution, made a major lobbying effort for the measure.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and general chairman of the Democratic Party, said, "The heart of this bill is special interest legislation par excellence."
But backers of the legislation touted it as the tool that would drive President Castro from office after 36 years in power. "He is on the ropes," said Representative Dan Burton, a Republican from Indiana and a co-sponsor of the bill. "I think this is the last nail in his coffin."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the International Relations Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere, said the measure "makes continued foreign investment by multinational corporations in Cuba very unlikely."
"You can either come to the United States and do business, or you can choose to do business with Fidel Castro and his $300-per-capita national income," he said.
A jubilant Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the other co-sponsor of the bill, said, "I have one message for Mr. Castro today: adios, Fidel."
The sponsors said a conference bill would be brought to the floors of the Senate and the House in the next few days and sent to the White House by early next week.
President Clinton has indicated he will sign the legislation, which is formally known as the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act but is more commonly referred to as the Helms-Burton Act.
Opponents argue that in their haste to punish Mr. Castro, supporters of the bill are turning Washington's policy on Cuba in the wrong direction.
"We seem to have lost sight of the national interest and how best to promote it," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the senior Democrat on the House International Relations Committee. "We are voting today on a conference report that represents far more than a message. If enacted, it will cast in concrete policy mistakes that will not be easily undone."
Mr. Hamilton said that if the legislation were approved, it would isolate the Cuban people and "increase the risk of violent upheaval, and increase the risk of a massive flow of refugees to U.S. shores."
The legislation puts the Clinton Administration in a political vise. On one side are Washington's allies, especially Canada, which has long objected to the unilateral trade embargo against Cuba and the limits it places on their trade. The bill urges the President to seek an international embargo against Cuba through the United Nations Security Council.
But Mr. Clinton is facing more pressure in an election year from opponents who threaten to turn his Cuban policy into a major political issue.
"The President, in light of the incident Saturday, believes tightening the embargo on Cuba is necessary now, both to deal with this incident and promote our overall goal of Democratic change in Cuba," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman.
Differing versions of the legislation passed the Republican-controlled House and Senate last fall, but were stalled after the Administration objected to the lawsuit provision in the House bill.
But the legislation was moved to the political front burner after Cuban MIG fighters shot down the two civilian planes on Saturday. The Clinton Administration maintains the planes were shot down in international airspace; Cuba says they were within its territorial limits.
Four people were aboard the two planes, all of them Cuban-Americans working with Brothers to the Rescue, a Miami-based group of Cuban exiles opposed to the Castro Government who have harassed Cuba before. Officials say the four were presumably killed.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
South Carolina Is a Crossroads For the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: CLINTON, S.C.

 BODY:
With red lipstick from farewell kisses still smeared across both cheeks, Todd E. Alexander worked his last shift at Clinton Mills Industries' Lydia plant, a hulking old textile mill that plans to shut its doors in April. During a midday break, the 23-year-old maintenance technician explained how his involuntary search for a job had intersected with his search for a Presidential candidate in the state's Republican primary on Saturday.
"I'm looking at job security and the economy," Mr. Alexander said a few days ago. "It would sure help a lot if a President could help out the companies over here in America and make it so our products are bought." Although he said he had not ruled out Senator Bob Dole, Mr. Alexander said, Patrick J. Buchanan's protectionist message sounds pretty good right now. 
 Twenty-six miles down State Route 72 in Greenwood, there is a different South Carolina. One of the largest new employers there is the Japanese film giant, Fuji, which recently announced plans to add about 200 people to its work force of 1,000 in a sprawling complex on the outskirts of town. Since opening in Greenwood in 1989, Fuji has been an ideal corporate citizen, town leaders say, and its $33 million annual payroll trickles through the local economy each day.
That is the main reason that Alvin Rankin, a co-owner of McCaslan's, a bookstore on Greenwood's Main Street that sells office supplies to Fuji, plans to vote for Mr. Dole. "The main thing is that he's not a protectionist," Mr. Rankin said, citing the Fuji plant here and its plans for expansion. "Buchanan's is just a closed-door policy."
On the verge of a crucial Presidential primary, these are the two voices of South Carolina and, by extension, of the modern South itself.
While one voice cries out for Government protection for the mature industries that have employed generations of low-skilled Southerners, the other argues that the region's economic future lies with modern development, foreign investment and trade.
The debate between those views, both in South Carolina and in the six Southern states that vote on the next two Tuesdays, seems very likely to play a significant role in determining the Republican nominee for President. And in the process, it may reveal a great deal about the awkward coexistence of the new South and the old.
After victories on Tuesday by Steve Forbes in Arizona and Mr. Dole in the Dakotas, Republicans are still waiting for a state to winnow the field. As the gateway to a two-week spree of Southern primaries, South Carolina could do that.
Mr. Dole begins with the backing of much of the state's Republican establishment, including Senator Strom Thurmond, Gov. David Beasley and former Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. But Mr. Buchanan expects heavy support from Christian conservatives, who played a large role in Mr. Beasley's 1994 election.
And former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, while something of a late starter in South Carolina, is challenging Mr. Buchanan directly on trade in the hope of siphoning votes from Mr. Dole.
While the textile and apparel trades remain the largest employers in South Carolina, those industries have lost nearly 60,000 jobs in the last two decades. Battered by imports and automation, textile mills and garment factories have closed virtually every month, breeding the kind of economic anxiety that helps pollinate a protectionist message.
But like many Southern states, South Carolina has also staked its future on foreign investment. Last year, the state shattered records by announcing the creation of 6,307 jobs through $1.8 billion in new foreign investment, accounting for 26 percent of all new jobs and 34 percent of all new investment, the State Department of Commerce reported.
Unemployment hovered at 5.1 percent last year, half a percentage point below the national average. And while wages have just managed to keep pace with inflation over the last decade, foreign manufacturers like BMW in Greer, Michelin in Greenville and Fuji in Greenwood have reputations for paying good wages. Average pay for factory workers at those plants is $28,000 to $31,000, compared with a statewide average of $22,500 in 1994.
Doug Woodward, an economist at the University of South Carolina, said that Mr. Buchanan's social conservatism may win him support in places like Greenwood, but only until voters consider his views on trade.
"It's going to sound odd," he said, "when Buchanan says, 'Foreigners are the problem.' They're going to say, 'Wait, I work for them.' "
South Carolina, Mr. Woodward said, "is a state that really has seen both the benefits and costs of trade liberalization."
"Trade is the future of this state," he said. "This is a state that wants to be known as open to the world and as a state that can contribute and compete in the global economy. And we're doing O.K. There are pockets of poverty. There are problems in our rural communities where they've seen plant closures. But on balance, it has led to an increased standard of living and higher per-capita income."
Mr. Dole's strategists maintain that Mr. Buchanan's protectionism will not sell here.
"He is thinking of a South that he saw when he campaigned with Richard Nixon in the 1960's when there used to be a lot of sweatshops with a lot of manual labor," said J. Warren Tompkins, a former top aide to Mr. Campbell who is Mr. Dole's senior Southern consultant. "The South is changing and our economies are diversified and we have brought ourselves to the level where we are able to compete globally."
But Mr. Buchanan, who has called for tariffs of up to 20 percent on Asian imports, has not altered his message. He laces his speeches with references to textile mill closings, including the Lydia plant here in Clinton, and rails against "corporate butchers who no longer feel a deep sense of loyalty to their employees."
And although South Carolina's textile and apparel industries split over the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Buchanan has successfully used his opposition to the treaty to raise money in South Carolina. One of his most prolific fund-raisers, and one of six members of his campaign advisory committee, is the textile magnate Roger Milliken, the chairman of Milliken & Company in Spartanburg. Mr. Milliken and his employees contributed at least $14,250 to the Buchanan campaign in the first nine months of 1995, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a group in Washington that monitors campaign financing.
Foreign competition is only part of the reason that Clinton Mills Industries is closing its Lydia plant, where cloth has been loomed since 1902. "Imports have affected that plant significantly," said A. Michael Hopp, a company vice president. "But it's also that apparel and home furnishing sales are very weak. And that plant was our oldest plant and had the oldest technology."
The company hopes to relocate about half of the mill's 400 employees to its three other plants in the area. But many of the workers who got pink slips here perceive that the real enemies are overseas and below the border.
Kenny E. Brock, a 42-year-old electrician who came to work at the Lydia plant two years ago in search of job security, said he was likely to vote for Mr. Buchanan because "he wants to limit the imports and the foreign cloth and stuff like that so we'll have some work instead of Korea and Mexico getting all of it."
David E. Satterfield, a 34-year-old air-conditioning technician who has worked at the plant for 12 years, said he would choose between Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Dole. "I'm going to vote for the man who will get me a job," he said.
But down in Greenwood, when Bill W. Wilson, the owner of Thayer's Fine Gifts and Home Furnishings, looks around his store, he sees imported Waterford crystal and Lenox china and recalls how Fuji managers love to buy those things stuff as gifts to take home to Japan.
"We buy from all over the world," said Mr. Wilson, who said he will choose between Mr. Dole and Mr. Alexander. "I can't imagine this country stopping and saying we're going to keep our nice little sewing jobs and we're not going to compete. I think Pat Buchanan's dangerous in that sense."

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Grows, But Gap With Japan Slims

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit worsened slightly in December, making the 1995 total the biggest in seven years, the Commerce Department said today. The figures immediately added fuel to the debate on trade that has played a key role in the Presidential campaign so far.
The figures showed an improved performance vis-a-vis Japan, the first annual decline in America's deficit with that nation in four years. But exports to Mexico slumped sharply in the wake of Mexico's economic crisis, and the deficit with China, an increasingly politically sensitive area, continued to grow. 
 The Clinton Administration, clearly concerned that its free trade policies could leave it open to Republican charges of sacrificing American workers to the desires of big business, argued that the overall trade performance showed marked improvement, especially during the second half of the year, and that surging exports were a major source of job creation.
The export growth and the prospect of a much narrower deficit in 1996 "confirm that our pro-growth, pro-employment, pro-trade policy is working," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Administration's National Economic Council.
But Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential contender who has made protecting American jobs from foreign competition a centerpiece of his campaign, seized on the numbers as support for his case that free trade hurts workers more than it helps.
"You know what that represents," Mr. Buchanan told a campaign rally in South Carolina. "We just lost 2.2 million jobs last year."
Administration officials responded that there was no basis for Mr. Buchanan's contention, and that half a million of the 1.5 million jobs created last year were at least partly attributable to the growth in exports.
The Commerce Department said the deficit in trade of goods and services rose to $6.8 billion in December, from a revised $6.7 billion for November. The increase was lower than most economists had expected.
For all of 1995, exports were $783.7 billion and imports were $894.7 billion, resulting in a deficit of $111 billion, up $4.8 billion, or 4.5 percent, from 1994's deficit of $106.2 billion.
Exports grew 11.8 percent for the year, while imports grew 10.8 percent.
"What we're beginning to see, particularly in the November-December numbers, is a significant deceleration in import activity and a signficant acceleration in exports," said Veronika White, an economist at the First Union Corporation, a banking company in Philadelphia.
"If we look at the nominal trade balance numbers, 1995 was the first year since since 1991 where export growth outstripped import growth," she said. "If this continues, the trade deficit is going to shrink in 1996, and this will have a positive effect on economic growth."
Officials said exports for the year were hurt by economic weakness among key trading partners, including Japan and Western Europe, but especially Mexico. The United States ran a deficit with Mexico for the year of $15.4 billion after posting a trade surplus in 1994 of nearly $1.4 billion. Without the negative swing in Mexican trade, the overall deficit would have narrowed, economists said.
Administration officials and economists said that with Mexico's economy apparently starting to mend, American exports to Mexico should improve this year.
The deficit with Japan, long among the most sensitive trade issues, declined 9.7 percent, to $59.3 billion last year from $65.7 billion in 1994. Merchandise exports to Japan were up 20 percent, while auto imports from Japan declined 10.5 percent.
The deficit with China grew 14.6 percent, to $33.8 billion, from $29.5 billion in 1994. That came against a backdrop of increased tensions between the United States and China over human rights, nuclear technology and other issues.
Underscoring the sensitivity of the trade relationship with China, the White House has suspended for 30 days any financing of deals by American companies in China through the Export-Import Bank while the Administration considers whether to impose sanctions on Beijing because of its sale of nuclear technology to Pakistan.
With Mr. Buchanan's calls for protectionism having struck a chord with some voters and with the Republicans generally moving to distance themselves from their historical support for free trade, the Administration's leading economic policy makers were eager today to fight back on an issue that they had hoped would be an easy plus for them.
"We've got a significant education job to do with the American people," said Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary. "There's a lack of understanding of how dependent our economy is on exports and healthy trade. That's why we've taken such aggressive action to open markets around the world."
But the officials said there were signs that their message was getting through, including recent exit polls in Republican primaries showing that for the first time more than half of those responding believed free trade was good for the economy.
They said that far from costing jobs, free trade agreements had insulated the American economy from fallout from problems in other nations. The North American Free Trade Agreement, for example, had taken some of the sting out of Mexico's economic collapse by helping American companies increase their share of Mexican imports to 75 percent from less than 70 percent over the last several years.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: BEHIND THE SCENES;
Former Carolina Governor Promises His State for Dole

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: GREER, S.C., Feb. 28

 BODY:
"I'm back in the cross hairs," said Carroll A. Campbell Jr., the natty, self-assured former Governor of South Carolina, sipping coffee in an effort to shake the effects of only three hours' sleep.
"We have to deliver for Dole the way we did for George Bush in 1988 and Ronald Reagan in 1980," he said. "I know it. Everyone knows it. He needs this state to get back on top. It's harder this time, with Steve Forbes already spending enormous amounts on television -- 21 spots a day on one station in Columbia, they tell me. Every vote he gets comes right off Dole's total. 
 "But I promise you: Bob Dole is going to win South Carolina."
Mr. Campbell left office a year ago with a 72 percent approval rating, and he is often called the most popular governor in the state's modern history. Now the president of the American Council of Life Insurance in Washington, a lobbying group with a $35 million annual budget, he has plunged into the campaign in South Carolina on behalf of a man whom he did much to defeat eight years ago.
Between Steve Forbes's money and Patrick J. Buchanan's populism, he has his hands full, and then some, with the pivotal primary here set for Saturday. Senator Dole leads in the latest independent polls, but some here say he is slipping.
The stakes are high for Mr. Dole, who has won only contests in Midwestern farm states: Iowa, North Dakota and South Dakota. As a Kansan, he had an obvious advantage there. Elsewhere, he has lost -- in New Hampshire, Delaware and most recently Arizona. South Carolina could be a brick wall or a springboard for him, with primaries on Tuesday in Georgia, New England and other states.
"If Bob Dole can't win decisively in South Carolina, national Republicans are going to wonder if he can win anywhere," said Earl Black, who was once a professor at the University of South Carolina, and now teaches Southern politics at Rice University in Houston.
For Mr. Campbell, the stakes are high, too. Mr. Dole, a plain-spoken plainsman, is not a natural fit in the more baroque political world of the South. Mr. Campbell is his most important guide here, with the possible exception of Mr. Dole's wife, Elizabeth, who comes from Salisbury, up Interstate 85 in North Carolina.
Mr. Campbell is proud of his ability to assure victory here to the candidate of his choice. He is flattered, he admits, by talk of him as a possible Dole running-mate: "If he goes South, we may be on the short list."
And he resents attacks on his accomplishments, which is what he sees in Mr. Buchanan's economic nationalism. Free trade is the 56-year-old former Governor's gospel. He traveled the world as Governor, seeking investors and personally negotiating deals that brought the BMW car plant to the outskirts of Greenville, where Mr. Dole spoke this afternoon, and the Fuji Photo plant to Greenwood.
"We have 110,000 new jobs in South Carolina in foreign-owned factories," he said in a speech this morning at the Liberty Life Insurance Company in Greenville, the Piedmont city where he grew up. "More than $27 billion in new investment, lots from abroad. Jobs that pay an average of 5 to 15 percent more than the old average in this state. Three ports thriving now, supporting 78,000 more jobs. Sure some people are hurting -- the textile workers especially, but not, most of them, because of Gatt or Nafta. Why are they out of work? Simple: computers, robots, our electronic age, that's what's cutting employment."
Then he lit into Mr. Buchanan, who has been citing the loss of textile jobs as proof of the evils of free trade and foreign competition. "Buchanan says, 'Let's build a wall around South Carolina and man the bunkers in this state,' " Mr. Campbell said. "That's the most backward thing we could do. For the first time in history, South Carolina has a diversified economy. We're prospering. Now he wants to take us back to the dark ages, just when we're seeing the light."
Mr. Dole, he conceded, does not make the case nearly as vigorously.
"I'm trying to get him to do it," the former Governor said. "He's starting to. I've been through this a bunch of times. I know the potholes; I can help him. But you know, in the end the candidate wins it or loses it."
But this afternoon, inside the BMW plant in Greer, Mr. Dole mumbled a few phrases about free trade, then stepped aside and let Mr. Campbell, Gov. David Beasley and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, his erstwhile rival, speak for him. Standing beneath a bright red Z-3 roadster, mounted vertically, Mr. Gramm said that "those who would throw in the towel on America," meaning Mr. Buchanan, "should come to South Carolina and see how things are done."
Mr. Dole looked like a spectator at his own wedding.
Mr. Campbell is not quite as well placed as he was eight years ago. He and his partner in what came to be known here as "attack-dog politics," Lee Atwater, started organizing the state and region for Mr. Bush with the help of Mr. Atwater's renowned Rolodex in 1985. South Carolina provided not only the "firebreak," as the Bush campaign called it, that cut short a string of disappointing performances, but also the key to Mr. Bush's ensuing Super Tuesday sweep, in which he won 16 primaries, 577 delegates and the nomination.
Mr. Atwater died of cancer in 1991. Mr. Campbell's successor, Governor Beasley, is not quite in his league as an organizer or strategist, and the Dole organization is neither as deep nor as extensive as the Bush network. Mr. Campbell and Mr. Beasley have made television commercials for Mr. Dole (though some South Carolina politicians say the current Governor is not as enthusiastic about the Senator as the former Governor is). They tout Mr. Dole's experience and his common sense, and picture him as a unifier of the the Republican Party and the nation.
But Neil Smith, a longtime Republican organizer in Pickens County, west of Greenville, told Mr. Campbell today that no one from the Dole organization had bothered to call him this year to work in the campaign." "If Carroll were really running things," he said, "it wouldn't be like that. But now you've got the Christian coalition and other religious conservatives in power in a lot of places. They aren't organizers, and the ones that are are for Buchanan, most of them."
Sounding almost worried, Mr. Campbell commented: "It's time for Senators and Governors and other officeholders to start calling up Lamar Alexander and Richard Lugar and all these other candidates that don't have much of anything going for them and tell them they need to get out of the race, stop splitting the mainstream vote six ways, unite behind Dole and beat Pat Buchanan."

HEADLINE: House Vote Keeps Peanut and Sugar Price Supports

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The House narrowly rejected efforts tonight to eliminate Government price supports for peanuts and sugar, which critics contend cost American consumers billions a year.
In a vote reflecting regional farming interests more than partisan politics, the House by a vote of 217 to 208 defeated an amendment to phase out sugar price supports over five years. Earlier, lawmakers rejected an amendment to eliminate the peanut program by a 212-to-209 vote. 
 But the House drew the line at generous provisions for dairy farmers and adopted an amendment, by a vote of 258 to 164, to partly dismantle price supports for milk. The amendment offered by Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, phases out over five years a policy of keeping milk prices high by purchasing surplus cheese, butter and nonfat dry milk.
Mr. Solomon's measure preserves a regional system of price supports for milk and offers a dairy program that the Senate and the Clinton Administration find more acceptable than the provisions it replaces.
The votes on the amendments to the farm bill tested the free-market principles Republicans have espoused and, in the case of sugar and peanuts, found them to be secondary to the concerns of farm constituents.
The House plans to vote on Thursday on the entire farm bill, which represents the most sweeping agricultural legislation in 60 years and would end Depression-era programs that pay farmers not to plant certain crops.
The bill would replace subsidies on many crops, including corn and wheat, with fixed payments that would gradually decline over the next seven years.
The Senate approved similar legislation earlier this month, by a vote of 64 to 32. The Senate bill contains conservation measures that the House does not. But efforts to cut back on the sugar and peanut subsidies were blocked there.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has said he will recommend that President Clinton veto the overall bill, if the House version prevails. The Administration has not taken a position on the sugar or peanut amendments.
Congressional supporters of the subsidies warn that eliminating Government aid would cost thousands of American jobs to cheaper imports, and have threatened to withhold support of the overall bill.
But an unusual alliance of free-market economists, consumer groups and food companies that buy raw commodities formed to attack price supports that they say cost Americans $3 billion a year.
Under the sugar program, for example, the Government sets price supports that maintain domestic sugar prices that are twice those on the world market and, according to the General Accounting Office, cost consumers $1.4 billion a year. Strict quotas on cheaper foreign sugar maintain the support price levels, which critics say benefit a small number of wealthy plantation owners and encourage overproduction in environmentally sensitive areas like the Florida Everglades.
The the sugar program enjoyed the support of an alliance of its own, including sugar cane and sugar beet growers as well as corn farmers, who produce corn sweeteners used in soft drinks. Proponents argued that eliminating the program would not prompt manufacturers to pass along the savings to consumers.
Both sides of the sugar debate asserted that jobs were at stake.
The United States Cane Sugar Refiners Association says 11 of 22 American sugar refineries have gone out of business since 1981. A Domino sugar refinery in Brooklyn that employs 800 people may have to go out of business unless sugar price supports decline, industry officials said today.
But Ohio and Michigan lawmakers, for example, warned that 12,000 sugar beet farmers could go out of business without the Government's safety net.
Moments after the vote on sugar, dozens of lobbyists sitting in the House gallery cheered, hugged each other and gave the thumbs-up signal to lawmakers on the House floor.
Under the peanut program, the Agriculture Department sets a national quota for the amount of peanuts that can be grown domestically and still receive full price support. The farm bill would reduce this support level to $610 a ton from $678 a ton. But opponents, including conservative research organizations and consumer groups, supported the amendment to drop the support price to $310 a ton by 2001, and end the program entirely the next year.
House Republican leaders tried earlier this month to force the overall farm bill to the floor for a vote without considering any amendments. But moderate Republicans and Democrats protested.
The centerpiece of the overall bill rests on provisions that would remove farmers from a decades-old system of complex subsidies and limits that paid them for certain crops whenever market prices dropped too low, and replace that system with payments aimed at easing farmers' transition to a market-based approach.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Judge in U.S. Overturns Judgment Against Swiss

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A staggering $125 billion default judgment against two Swiss governmental agencies was overturned yesterday, temporarily allaying fears of a financial crisis in Switzerland.
Judge David Trager issued the ruling in United States Federal Court in Brooklyn, then heard a motion by Swiss officials to dismiss the entire case. He set no date for a ruling. 
 The case dates to the 1961 death of Grant S. Higgins, a Seattle real estate salesman, who according to his family left an estate worth $600 million in gold and silver mining contracts at the Inter Change Bank of Chiasso, Switzerland. The bank collapsed om 1967.
State Supreme Court Justice Gerald S. Held ruled in the estate's favor in 1994, largely because the defendants did not show up for the hearing.

HEADLINE: Big Business Can't Run From Workers' Plight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire (column, Feb. 26) smells a pinko-populist plot to which he assigns the label "New Socialism," with Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential contender, playing Marx and with me as fellow traveler. 
 I've been called worse by better name-callers, but to be anointed a New Socialist by the midwife of the New Nixon makes me tremble for the future of neologism.
Labels aside, Mr. Safire still gets my thinking all wrong.
Wage disparities have been growing and real median wages sliding since the late 1970's, and lots of Americans aren't happy about it. The Clinton Administration has restored job growth and has shrunk the deficit, and median wages have stopped dropping.
But the long-term challenge of restoring wage growth is still before us. That's why we're fighting for more investments in education and job training, a higher minimum wage, the earned-income tax credit for working families, and better pension and health-care security.
Of course, government can't do it all -- especially a Federal Government trying to shrink the deficit while carrying a $4 trillion debt. That's where the private sector comes in.
If corporate America doesn't step up to the plate, it will have to contend with far worse than a proposed tax incentive for upgrading employee skills, sharing the profits or helping the laid-off find new jobs.
Try protectionism and nativism for starters. Mr. Buchanan may fade, but not the anger that fuels him. Unless present trends are reversed -- in the words of an earlier plutocrat-turned-populist -- you ain't seen nothing yet.
 
ROBERT B. REICH
Secretary of Labor
Washington, Feb. 27, 1996

HEADLINE: Big Business Can't Run From Workers' Plight;
For a New Capitalism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What William Safire (column, Feb. 26) and other advocates of free enterprise forget is that corporations are themselves the products of one of history's most far-reaching experiments in socioeconomic engineering. 
 Genuine laissez-faire capitalism would require the state to get out of the business of chartering corporations and of limiting the liability of investors to the value of their shares and granting corporations First Amendment rights identical to those of flesh-and-blood citizens.
We have not only accepted the legitimacy of these artificial persons called corporations, but have also allowed our representatives to grant them political and economic rights far exceeding any corresponding responsibilities.
Nevertheless, it would be reasonable for us to require, in exchange for limits on the liability of investors and other corporate privileges, not only environmental and other provisions mandating greater social responsibility but also limits on corporate profits, combined with limits on executive compensation.
Such limits could be set low so as to promote greater economic equality, or they could be set high so as to affect only a small number of corporations that either are extremely profitable or pay their employees or officials high salaries. Neither option would endanger corporate competitiveness, since corporations would be affected only after achieving profitability in the marketplace.
Mr. Safire talks about the "stultifying excesses of income redistribution." Thanks to the efforts of President Reagan and a compliant Democratic Congress, such excesses have indeed occurred during the past 15 years. But the redistribution has been in the direction that Mr. Safire favors. The rich have become richer while the poor have become poorer, and the middle class has barely kept pace.
 
RALPH SUTER
Chicago, Feb. 27, 1996

HEADLINE: Woes of Modern Russia Mirrored In the Decline of Its Coal Mines

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: SHAKHTY, Russia

 BODY:
Faced with the slow, agonizing decline of one of its vital industries, Russia has begun an ambitious attempt to rescue its failing coal mines.
In the dank, serpentine tunnels of the Yuzhnaya mine here in southern Russia, where miners toil amid rickety scaffolding, it is clear that the industry is crumbling. 
 Decades of mismanagement and unfulfilled reforms have created a kind of permanent crisis for Russia's 800,000 beleaguered, but still politically potent, coal workers.
And the stakes go far beyond coal.
With the financially stretched Government doling out billions of dollars in subsidies, the restructuring of the coal industry is central to Russia's efforts to contain spending and inflation. It could involve closing half of Russia's 261 mines, laying off tens of thousands of workers and cutting back on subsidies and encouraging competition.
The overhaul also provides an important test of President Boris N. Yeltsin's election-year promises of continued economic reforms in the face of stiff resistance from managers determined to maintain their control of Russia's smokestack industries.
The restructuring is being carried out under the watchful eyes of the World Bank, which has promised a $500 million loan on the condition that the reforms proceed and that an adequate social safety net be set up for the laid-off miners.
The loan, unlike the new $10.2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, would be specifically earmarked for creating a smaller but more viable coal industry.
"The most difficult thing is to change the mentality," said Yuri N. Dashko, a Russian mining expert who has been been working closely with the World Bank. "Money alone won't solve the problem."
The results of the old mentality are very much in evidence at the Yuzhnaya, or Southern, mine in this hardscrabble mining area 600 miles south of Moscow.
Wearing padded uniforms and carrying small oxygen tanks that hold an hour and a half's supply of air -- a precaution against cave-ins -- miners crowd into a shaky elevator for the long descent.
After a jarring train ride through several miles of tunnels, another steep descent in a second train and a final march through pools of dank water and clouds of acrid dust, the miners begin their six-hour shift, scraping coal out of deep, narrow crawl spaces.
They do it for the same reasons that their fathers did. It is practically the only job in town. "If you don't know a trade or steal, what else is there to do?" Vyacheslav Samoilov, a 35-year-old miner, said.
The problems have been long in the making. While other countries have also been forced to shrink their coal industries, Russia's distress is heightened by decades of Soviet rule.
Under Communism, the emphasis was on achieving maximum production, not on efficiency. The Government pampered the mines with large subsidies, and let them transport their coal on the railroads for nominal charges.
But Russia's industrial decline has lowered the demand for energy. The coal industry is losing business to natural gas. Rail costs have soared. More than half of Russia's mines may be inefficient, Russian experts say.
 
The Problem
A Soviet Legacy In the New Russia
The Soviet style of management lingers on. Many of the critical decisions -- which mines to close, which customers to sell to and how much to charge -- are not made by local officials. "We practically do not make any decisions," Gennady Semashko, the union leader at Yuzhnaya, said as he waited for the elevator to take him to surface.
Instead, the decisions are made in Moscow by managers at the Russian Coal Company, the state-owned concern that controls virtually every facet of the industry, including the distribution of subsidies.
For their toil, miners here may receive $200 a month or even more, depending on their years of service and the difficulty of their job. That is more than double the wage for local schoolteachers. In addition, the Government provides the miners with housing, schools and clinics.
Salaries of miners in Arctic and other northern regions can be several times the rate here, but many coal workers earn as little as $60 a month, and wages have been delayed for months at a time.
Furthermore, the work in the mines is dirty and increasingly hazardous, as tight budgets have forced miners to use old equipment and hampered repairs.
In early February, the problems came to a boil as miners across Russia launched a two-day strike. The walkout, four months before the presidential election, prompted a panicky Government to promise the payment of $200 million in back salaries and increase subsidies to the industry to $2.2 billion for 1996.
But the payoff to settle the strike was more of a temporary salve than a solution.
Reformers say the strike reflects the Russian Coal Company's reluctance to make tough decisions and helps keep up subsidies, which consumed a hefty 1 percent of Russia's gross domestic product in 1994. That made coal second only to agriculture as a burden on the Russian economy.
Too much of the subsidies, reformers say, goes for inefficient mines and too little is set aside for creating new jobs. They also complain that the state company diverts funds to questionable investments and financial companies that receive no outside scrutiny.
By treating wages as a lesser priority, they say, the company has created pressure for more spending by the Yeltsin Government, which recalls it was the miners who helped bring down Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President.
The Government's efforts to end the strike also involved financial gimmickry.
To appease the miners, the Government included the World Bank funds in the promised subsidies for 1996, even though the bank is still evaluating the coal restructuring plan and has yet to approve the loan.
"We have already begun to divide the skin of a bear that has not been killed yet," said Igor S. Kozhukhovsky, the Economic Ministry's coal expert, and a staunch advocate of reform.
Even so, miners are beginning to complain that the promised wage payments are again being delayed, raising the specter of more labor unrest.
Boris G. Fyodorov, Mr. Yeltsin's former Finance Minister, said: "These guys are so afraid of the miners, the moment somebody announces a strike they promise to pay. Of course, they do not pay on time. Then in the next six months a new wave starts."
Mr. Fyodorov said the Government needed to aggressively carry out a 10-year plan to shrink and overhaul the industry.
"It has to be a very clearly defined plan, which is properly budgeted each year and then implemented with an iron fist," he said. "Probably, we should invite Margaret Thatcher to help us with this."
 
The Reform
Yeltsin Sidesteps Key Questions
With the World Bank loan hanging in the balance and the coal industry on the brink of insolvency, Mr. Yeltsin has declared his support for a sweeping overhaul.
But he also sidestepped hotly contested questions. Who will control the billions of dollars in subsidies, as they are being reduced? And who will ultimately own the industry's mines and other assets? Stock is to be issued in the state-owned Russian Coal Company, but the Government will own 100 percent of the shares for at least three years.
Mr. Yeltsin's vagueness has fed the power struggle in Moscow between reformers in the Economic Ministry, which wants to break up the monopoly the Russian Coal Company enjoys, and the bosses of the company, who want to preserve their control.
Sketching out his vision of a smaller, more profitable coal industry, Mr. Kozhukhovsky said subsidies should be phased out over at least 10 years.
As many as 150 of Russia's mines would be closed. The work force would be slashed to less than half its current 800,000.
Several steps would be taken to sharply limit the influence of the Russian Coal Company and encourage new competition, Mr. Kozhukhovsky added.
For example, instead of allowing the company to control the subsidies, that responsibility would be given to a committee of Government, trade union and company officials -- an approach strongly supported by the World Bank.
Significantly, the Russian Government promised to take this step during its recent negotiations with the International Monetary Fund. But it is not a binding commitment.
Three dozen new regional coal companies would also be given control of the mines, which are now effectively controlled by the Russian Coal Company.
The responsibility for maintaining schools, hospitals and other social services in mining communities -- a task of the coal industry now as in Soviet days -- would be transferred to local authorities.
While market reforms are expected to result in a decrease in coal production in the next few years, Mr. Kozhukhovsky forecasts that output, which was about 262 million tons in 1995, according to Russian figures, would actually increase to 280 million to 300 million tons a year at the end of the 10-year period, thanks to new technology and free-market efficiencies.
"Competition in every market segment is the best guarantor of energy security," he said.
 
The Opposition
Old-Time Coal Czars Reluctant to Let Go
But Yuri N. Malyshev, the director of the Russian Coal Company, is reluctant to give up his company's place at the top of the coal pyramid.
In an interview in his Moscow office, which is dominated by a huge map of Russia's coal empire, he said his company was the main repository of expertise on coal and mocked the idea, backed by the World Bank, of sharing responsibility for the distribution of subsidies.
"Somebody wants another experiment in Russia," Mr. Malyshev said. "When seven nurses take care of a child he may end up without his eyes."
He added that the World Bank was putting too much emphasis on shrinking the industry and financing social programs for the miners.
"We cannot fully agree with the bank in terms of allocating all the financing to closing mines down and to social protection," he said. "It sounds good, but if we do not invest money into prospective mines and quarries we will end up with all those promising projects being closed down."
Ultimately, the question will be decided by Vladimir V. Kadannikov, a former automobile industrialist who replaced a free-market advocate, Anatoly B. Chubais, as Mr. Yeltsin's top economic official, and perhaps by the President himself.
Mr. Kadannikov has already talked of limiting the Russian Coal Company's role in distributing subsidies. "The right steps are being taken toward reform," said Mary Louise Vitelli, a World Bank adviser on the loan. But details of the restructuring still need to be worked out.
In the meantime, the miners at the Yuzhnaya mine toil away, hoping only that their paychecks will someday arrive on schedule.
"I came here hoping to work and support my family," Vyacheslav Klemonov, a 46-year-old miner, said at his work station 1,300 feet underground, his face smeared with coal dust.
"But the old ways do not exist anymore," he said. "No one is offering to retrain me. There is no other job available. I have nowhere else to go."
 "After a jarring train ride through several miles of tunnels, another steep descent in a second train and a final march through pools of dank water and clouds of dust, the miners begin their six-hour shift, scraping coal out of deep, but narrow, crawl spaces.
"They do it for the same reasons that their fathers did. It is practically the only job in town.
" 'If you don't know a trade or steal, what else is there to do?' Vyacheslav Samoilov, a 35-year-old miner, said.
"The problems have been long in the making."
